name: Πρόεδρος. -
text: The next item on the agenda concerns the debate on the question with a request for an oral reply to the Commission, on child malnutrition in developing countries, by Linda McAvan, on behalf of the Committee on Development (O-000083/2014 - 2014/2853(RSP) - B6-0041/2014).

name: Linda McAvan
text: author. - Mr President, the Millennium Development Goals set clear objectives that include the eradication of extreme poverty and hunger and the drastic reduction of child mortality. Looking at progress in this area, we have made progress, but despite that, the number of children dying or suffering from undernutrition remains unacceptably high. This oral question and resolution seeks to ensure this issue is given the priority it deserves by the Commission in our collective action towards the post-2015 global development framework. Undernutrition represents an enormous development challenge. The World Health Organisation says that undernutrition is the biggest contributor to child mortality, causing 35% of the disease burden in children under five. It can create a vicious cycle of poverty, can reduce productivity and impede social and economic development. That is why the fight against child undernutrition and the provision of universal access to adequate nutritious food should remain as one of the major goals in the post-2015 agenda. We voted on Tuesday on that issue, and it is something we do feel is very important. In the draft document by the Own Working Group of the United Nations, goal 2 of the draft SDGs has a target to end all forms of malnutrition by 2030 and by 2025 achieve the internationally-agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under five. The World Health Organisation Assembly endorses the global target for a 40% reduction of the global number of children under five who are stunted by 2025. That means reducing the number of stunted children by more than 70 million – 70 million, colleagues – by 2025. In the Stier report on Tuesday, our Parliament voted with a huge majority to support this objective and goes further, calling for the zero hunger goal to end the scandal of hunger by 2025. It calls for promoting sustainable agriculture and recognising the specific needs of women farmers related to food security. These are vital efforts in our fight against child malnutrition. So what we are asking the Commission for this morning, and why we have asked for this debate, is because we now need a concrete action plan from the Commission on how we, as the European Union, can contribute to the child undernutrition targets, and how we can work with our international partners to achieve this. I understand that the Commission services have been working on an action plan on nutrition, and I wonder, Commissioner, could you update us on this and tell us what is happening and when we can expect something concrete? And how can the Commission ensure coordination, both in its different policies and with our international partners, in speeding up progress towards the WHO targets? Reduced and ending child undernutrition is possible but, like our other development policies, it requires resources, coordination and political will. This week we have had a debate marking the 25th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Tackling undernutrition in the next 15 to 20 years would be a key contribution to make sure that every child could have the basic right that gives them the opportunity for a decent life.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, I am here with you today on behalf of Commissioner Mimica. I would like to thank Ms McAvan for this pertinent question. It reminds us all that undernutrition is not only a real human tragedy but also an economic issue which can be in the way of sustainable development. Let me underline that the Commission is fully engaged to improve the current situation, since in the last few years the European Union has indeed emerged as a key actor in the area of nutrition and has put nutrition at the heart of its development policy. The 2013 Commission Communication ‘Enhancing Maternal and Child Nutrition in External Assistance: an EU Policy Framework’ set a strategy on nutrition with two objectives: reducing wasting as well as stunting of children under the age of five. The Commission has also developed two action plans: one which addresses undernutrition in emergencies and mainly targets wasting. The second one sets out how the Commission will implement the EUR 3.5 billion it has pledged to reduce the number of stunted children under the age of five by seven million. Although these action plans do not foresee any mid-term evaluation, accountability to track financial resources and monitor the impact of nutrition intervention represents an important horizontal pillar of our nutrition action plan. We are fully aware that nutrition-specific intervention which addresses the immediate causes of undernutrition will not be sufficient. There is a need to address the basic and immediate causes of undernutrition. Therefore nutrition has to be mainstreamed in other relevant sectors like agriculture, education and water, and nutrition-sensitive intervention implemented. This is one of the reasons why the Commission has earmarked EUR 3.1 billion for nutrition-sensitive intervention, mainly through agriculture. Unfortunately there is not enough evidence on the effectiveness of nutrition-sensitive intervention. To address this challenge the Commission will promote applied research to identify the cost-effectiveness and monitor the impact of nutrition-sensitive actions. Based on the results of these efforts, the Commission may decide, during the mid-term review in 2017, to redirect some funds to possibly better-performing actions in order to attain the set objectives by 2025. In front of the challenges ahead, the Commission cannot work alone. The Commission intends to continue raising awareness of undernutrition issues in international forums like the Scaling Up Nutrition (SUN) movement, which has now been joined by 54 countries in the Committee on World Food Security. Second, the Commission will also strengthen its strategic partnership with FAO and WHO for nutrition and use events like the International Conference on Nutrition to keep the political momentum on nutrition. Third, at country level, the Commission has applied the principle of aid effectiveness through the joint programming within the 2014-2020 programming exercise. Last but not least, the Commission will continue its collaboration with NGOs through regular information- and experience-sharing lessons. In conclusion, I am fully aware that tackling undernutrition effectively will require combined efforts at all levels. I welcome Parliament’s interest in this matter and I thank you for your continued support.

name: Anna Záborská
text: for the PPE Group. – First of all, I would like to thank the Chair of the Committee on Development Policy, Linda McAvan, for taking on the role of rapporteur on a document that was actually approved by the committee at the last parliamentary term. I also thank my colleagues in charge of this theme in the various political groups for their cooperation in tabling amendments. It has already been mentioned that this week we voted on a document that will be with the Millennium Goals after 2015. Lack of nutrition is a truly complex problem that lies as a responsibility throughout society. It lies as a responsibility because the lack of nutrition does not respect fundamental human rights, and that is the right to a dignified life for the little ones, those children who live in hunger. When we take that a few children die every minute, not because there is war in their countries and not because they are sick, but because they are hungry. And it's not just those children who are dying, it's the other children, thousands and thousands of children who are bearing the consequences of this lack of nutrition for life. We are talking about figures here – I think we know these figures almost by heart, but cooperation is important, cooperation is important, both with the Institutions of the European Union and with other nutrition organisations, especially with the FAO. There needs to be a meeting this week, and I think that cooperation should be closer. And just one more sentence: I believe that what the Commissioner said in the hearing, that we will look more at poverty, we will look more at hunger than on climate change.

name: Patrizia Toia
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I welcome you and tell you that our first meeting in this House is taking place on a particularly significant issue, because there are such dramatic realities that we end up almost addicted, as if they were inevitable. But then, looking at them a little more closely, we see that they are by no means inevitable or inexorable, that they are tragic realities but perfectly solvable. We know how this should be done, we know what instruments should be put in place, we know the causes of these phenomena and we see the effects. And so I think that the very fact – as my colleague also said – that they are not inevitable really should make us take on a great responsibility and understand that if it is possible to do so, we must do so.  The question is whether we are capable, whether we want to put the instruments in place and, above all, do so to an appropriate extent. Today, this phenomenon of malnutrition, child malnutrition, takes on even more devious, more hidden forms: it is the so-called hidden hunger, which is less obvious, less impacting even as images that reach our eyes, to knowledge through NGOs and international cooperation operators, but which are equally negative and prejudicial to the development of boys and girls. And so this phenomenon of hidden hunger is also one of those that we want to tackle.  We are mobilizing in these days with renewed vigour precisely to coincide with the 25th anniversary of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. And I would really like to thank our chairman Linda McAvan and all my shadow colleagues because we want to tell her that our commitment as a Parliament is there, not only of the DEVE Committee, but of parliament as a whole. We call on the Commission to take this step forward just as effectively, with equal conviction. I really do think that we should not have – and I say this to myself first of all – the right to commemorate and celebrate if we do not accompany this right with a serious commitment, a measurable commitment - you spoke of numbers, figures and dates, and we appreciated that - and a commitment that also looks at effectiveness in its use.  We know that resources for international development, like other resources within the Union, are not always used effectively, but we cannot afford to lose anything here. So even this dimension of effectiveness control, of understanding what happens to our plans becomes absolutely essential. So I believe that we must make these commitments with renewed vigour. You spoke about these plans, you also talked about the need to make an evaluation of effectiveness in order to see how to reprogramme the interventions. Well, I would ask you to have a very cooperative and very engaging relationship with Parliament throughout this process, because you will find, as you have seen, great competences and passion in the committee and therefore a great desire to cooperate in the development of the most effective measures.  Many things have been done – linda mcavan mentioned some of the results, you mentioned them – and I think that Europe should be proud to have contributed to these results. However, the phenomenon is returning to certain geographical areas and places where it was not there as a result of the economic crisis, as a result of speculation on food prices, essential food products. We therefore also ask you to involve your colleagues in a vision of a policy that is a little more horizontal and across the agenda in order to trace the causes of some of these phenomena that can perhaps be tackled in other areas, with a different agricultural policy, for example, with a different trade policy, with a financial policy. This phenomenon of commodities speculation on food is something – I believe – intolerable to the common opinion of this Parliament. Finally, one final point: we have all seen, reading and documenting, not only for this occasion but for our work, how the role of women is fundamental. There are data that make you shudder: 80% of women contribute to food in developing countries and 60% of malnourished people; they contribute to producing and being the real farmers, the farmers, and they have 2% of the ownership. That is what we are also doing about women, who are an element of development in many countries, not just in the West that we know.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Just before yesterday in this chamber, Pope Francis said: "It is ediving that millions of people around the world are starving, while tons of food are thrown out of our tables every day." According to a study by the United Nations, 1.3 million tonnes of food is destroyed each year.  Dear! No Action by the Commission, no subsidies spent on combating malnutrition will work unless we make a comprehensive change in the regulations and practices of food producers beforehand. Why are we debating this vague document if we can continue to speculate on the prices of goods in accordance with EU law by throwing away tonnes of food products in order to prevent their prices from falling? And those who share their surplus food, punish taxes.  In this context, the Commission's proposals to address hunger among children by promoting gender equality and empowering women in all areas of nutrition seem like a grim joke. We must have the courage to tell ourselves a brutal truth here in this Chamber today. It is EU legislation that largely allows unethical practices of food producers. If we want to counter the greatest disgrace of today – the scourge of hunger among children – we must take really decisive action and start it by changing the regulations that have so far undermined many of our efforts to improve the existence of the most vulnerable among us. Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Please provide specific actions planned by you to change the regulations that would solve this problem.

name: Louis Michel
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, the world is experiencing a silent crisis that is devastating entire communities in the developing world. The european Parliament's examination of this issue therefore obliges us to focus on a humanitarian, political, economic and developmental scourge that requires a coordinated and coherent response. This is, of course, an ethical imperative that also generates collateral economic effects. We all know- this has been said and repeated here - that more than 165 million children under the age of five are malnourished and that the first thousand days of life are of paramount importance for the development of the child.  We are all aware of the recurrent nutritional crises in the Sahel and sub-Saharan Africa. What interests me is how we are going to address the causes of this evil? We cannot separate this issue from that of food self-sufficiency. I would like to take a look at your performance at the time of your hearing, so I think you are certainly aware of these issues, and in your plan and in your approach, the need for cross-cutting policies that are not only about undernutrition but also about food self-sufficiency is taken into account.  I have not yet heard of the subject of land grabbing; I see that in Africa there is a real tendency in the economic world to take over land, a tendency with obviously dramatic consequences.  We talked about water, there is also education and technical transfer, perhaps from us, that will improve the productivity and yield of those lands.  I agree with the speaker that it is quite scandalous to allow financial speculation on food. As for the issue of women, I obviously agree because I am a privileged witness to the major role of women, particularly in Africa and in the economic world. Commissioner, we trust you and we expect you to come back to us with a fairly broad plan that encompasses the whole issue.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, hunger kills people, and millions of children suffer from malnutrition in the south. But also in southern Europe children suffer from malnutrition. In my country, galicia, there are more than 20% of children below the poverty level. In the Spanish state today, 60% more people are at risk of poverty and social exclusion than in 2007.  The cause of this situation lies in the policies of the European Union, which make it possible for multinationals to steal the wealth of peoples, which prevent them from developing their agriculture, which occupy their lands, which impose ruinous free trade agreements on peoples.  Without questioning these policies there will be no solution to hunger and malnutrition in the south, without putting an end to the troika's policies, hunger and malnutrition will continue to advance in the north. Mr Commissioner, the neoliberal policies of the European Union must radically change, with urgent measures such as ending multinational summing-uppolicies, ending free trade agreements, acting, adapting, changing agricultural and food policies within the framework of food sovereignty.  Anything other than moving forward with such measures will be empty words, and next year we will continue here to count numbers of malnourished people, numbers of people starving.

name: Maria Heubuch
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the We are voting today on an important report. It is shameful that millions of children are still suffering from hunger and that every few minutes a child dies of hunger. I am also very pleased – and I would like to thank Mrs McAvan very much – that in this report we are not only talking about malnutrition, but also about malnutrition, because it is not enough for children to get enough calories. For healthy growth and age-appropriate development, they need a balanced diet with vitamins, with trace elements, to name but a few. However, we will not achieve this if we continue to promote the usual monocultures. They displace diversified cultivation systems with different cereals and vegetables and thus also the production of the required micronutrients. I call on the EU here to follow the recommendations of the EU Special Rapporteur on the right to food, who explicitly mentions greener agriculture as a way for these countries to feed themselves, and who also points to the role of agriculture in climate change and the fight against poverty. It is therefore important to promote and support small farmers, because they have the potential to spread diverse climate-friendly farming systems, they have the potential to produce fair food that meets local dietary habits, they have the potential to build an economy. Because with the original production are also the processing, transport and trade in the region. This is where the potential for the labour force lies, and thus the first step out of poverty. But without land, no food can be grown. This means that traditional land rights must be protected, that access to land must be guaranteed for the local population, especially women. This must not be the winner who puts more money on the table. The local population must be the victors here, and we must not encourage further land grabbing under any circumstances. Investment in agriculture is absolutely necessary. They are necessary if we are to fight hunger and poverty in developing countries. But not every kind of investment in agriculture is helpful here. If private investors end up more or less expelling the local population from their own resources and depriving them of it in order to carry out this indispensable food production themselves, in order to produce large margins for the world market, for international markets, then no child will be fed up. Trade agreements must also take this into account in the future, and they must also do justice to this. Otherwise, these countries are becoming increasingly dependent on international commodity markets and on fluctuations in prices on these markets. They become dependent on food speculation, and stock market developments thus become decisive for whether a child can go to bed hungry or full at the end of the day. This is highly immoral, and we must fight against it. Poverty and hunger can be prevented by providing sufficient support to local farmers. That is the only way for these countries to achieve food sovereignty. We need further greening of cultivation systems in order to adapt them to climate change, because it is precisely these countries that will be the first to be affected by climate change. Both are fundamental elements in the fight against poverty and hunger.

name: Amjad Bashir
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. –  Mr President, I remember 30 years ago, back in 1985, Bob Geldof and others organised Live Aid to raise relief funds for the ongoing Ethiopian famine. We now risk a new famine in Ethiopia because of water control of the Nile. Unlike democratic Ethiopia, the Egyptian military ruler in the neighbouring country is causing problems by trying to enforce an old colonial right over the Nile. I think this is not sustainable; I think that Ethiopia, which contributes over 80% of the waters of the Nile, should have access to the Nile, not just for generating electricity but also for agriculture, and for feeding and providing water for its citizens. I think that we should look at the water rights of all the countries of that region.

name: Georg Mayer (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his More than 165 million children under the age of five are malnourished. 2.6 million children die of malnutrition every year in our world, which is deeply sad and, at the same time, deeply shameful for us. Malnutrition leads to conflict, poverty and social insecurity. The United Nations Millennium Goals have already achieved a great deal. In 1990, malnutrition was still 18.7%, and we are currently at 11.2%. Much has been achieved, but the number of malnourished children remains at an unacceptably high level for us. The main reason for hunger is poverty. Experts also attach great importance to the education of women, especially in terms of malnutrition, which leads to increased infant mortality. Combating poverty in the regions affected by hunger means better and more efficient use of development cooperation funds and the optimising of European funds at national and EU level.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, despite the achievements of the Millennium Goals, the fact is that we still have nearly a billion people starving in the world. Of these, 225 million are children under the age of 5 who are chronically malnourished. Technological advances have allowed there to be food for all, among other things, but despite this, children continue to starve to death and remain malnourished.  It is a scandal, as Pope Francis called it, whose messages I hope we have not only listened to and quickly forgotten, but with our long applause in this House we have accepted and supported. So there's food for everyone, but there's no justice for everyone. That is why this week we adopted a Resolution on a new global framework for development and we demanded that the European Union and the international community focus on the causes of poverty and hunger. And clearly, this resolution by Colleague McAvan mentions what those causes are, and there are more of them.  But in short, if we are going to resonate by following the Pope's messages, then we must conclude that the main causes of poverty and hunger are in fact selfish human behaviors and policies that have only material interests in their center, namely the strongest ones, and ignore the dignity of human life for all its duration. Yes, as a Christian Democrat, I will point out that the issue of child malnutrition shows that the dignity of human life must be protected from the start. Here, as stated in paragraph 3 of this Resolution to meet nutritional needs, the first 1,000 days of a child's life, including the gestation period, are paramount.  However, it is not enough to say that we want to protect life from the beginning, it is also necessary through an effective coherent development policy to allow that child when it is born to have a quality diet, access to health, education and we all have to work on it together a lot more. In this regard, I welcome the Commission's intention to invest EUR 3.5 billion, as well as the intention of the Commissioner, who said he wanted strict monitoring to implement and assess the effectiveness of these programmes. And I also expect that the Council will support in December the objective of this Parliament to eradicate hunger al more fully, the so-called Zero Hunger Goal.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is precisely in this House, as my fellow Members have said, that Pope Francis has reminded us that Europe has a special responsibility in the fight against poverty and hunger in the world.  The right to food will only be guaranteed if we concern ourselves with its real subject, with the person suffering the effects of hunger and malnutrition, and this means at political and legislative level ensuring as much coherence as possible between the Internal and External Policies of the European Union, between the commitment to poverty reduction and the implementation of European choices in policies such as agriculture. , the environment, fisheries and energy. Commissioner, it is with this global approach that Europe will really be able to mark a turning point in policies to combat poverty and child malnutrition, and this resolution reiterates that Europe will no longer be able to tolerate the fact that in some poor countries, even with our complicity, there are full reservoirs and empty bellies due to the perverse effects of rising global food prices and land use.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, child malnutrition is a scourge. It kills and causes irreversible damage to children. This scourge will be combated, of course, by acting on its merits and in the long term with a good development policy. Everyone has talked about water, school, agriculture, food self-sufficiency and land management, that is obvious. But if we want immediate results, if we want to save children today, we must change the paradigm and allow development policy to take ownership of the results of humanitarianism.  We know how to reduce child mortality. This has been done in the Sahel as part of humanitarian actions thanks, moreover, to the support of ECHO: one million children treated since 2006 with 50 dollars a year. Ready-to-use therapeutic foods are given to a child in the form of sachets and saved! The World Bank, as you know, has largely validated this approach.  I say to you, we must all reflect and ensure that the eleventh EDF takes this approach into account, learns from humanitarian practice, organizes it on a large scale so that the children who are suffering today in the world of malnutrition are saved tomorrow.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL). -
text: Worldwide, enough food is produced to feed everyone. And yet tonight, one billion people are going to sleep, including 250 million children. The Party for Animals considers this unacceptable. However, the main causes of hunger and malnutrition remain underexposed. These are our own agricultural policy and our own consumption patterns. We can feed 10 billion people with the current area of arable land, on the condition that we stop spending most of our cereals and crops on animal feed, on biofuel. 70% of the arable area is used to feed animals instead of humans. In order to achieve this, Brussels' agricultural policy must be radically reformed and we must stop providing our own farmers with EUR 363 billion in agricultural subsidies, stop dumping agricultural surpluses in developing countries. However, the best measure is simple and inexpensive: our consumption pattern. We need to eat less meat! Every five seconds, a child dies of hunger. During my speaking time here of one and a half minutes, that was 18 children! This is unacceptable and we must and can do something about it.  That is why we support the measures proposed by the rapporteur; we also believe that agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, it is very good that the Commission is paying attention to inadequate nutrition of children, which is not only malnutrition, but also a lack of micronutrients. Indeed, we know that even a child under the age of five will be prevented from developing mentally if he or she does not receive enough important micro-nutrients with food. Unicef, for example, has taken this issue very seriously and has taken action in it. Indeed, as the Commissioner says, the EU can also act through UN organisations to promote this issue. It is very much a question of moving towards more one-sided farming as well. That is why the Greens have tabled an amendment stressing the importance of an agroecological approach. It has also been the message of the UN Special Rapporteur. Indeed, it provides opportunities for more diversified farming, which in turn means that it is mothers who are farmers in Africa who can provide more diverse nutrition for children, which is absolutely essential for their development. I would also like to draw attention to something that Mr Michel also addressed, namely land grabs. We should be able to examine how the European Union's free trade agreements with developing countries actually contribute to large companies gaining control of large areas of farming from the governments of developing countries, which in turn reduce the opportunities for small farmers. We would like to see an inquiry into this. The World Agricultural Organisation (FAO) has drawn up a good code of conduct on this issue, voluntary guidelines, and I hope that they will gradually become binding, so that the needs of poor people, that is to say the majority of the world, are actually taken into account and not sacrificed to big business.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, UNICEF, who, the World Bank and the UN recently indicated that infant mortality rates between zero and five years have fallen by 49% in the last twenty years. In this period, therefore, as many as 100 million children have been saved, although, given the data in hand, 6.3 million children under 5 died in 2013.  Malnutrition remains unfortunately the world's first disease and around 80% of malnourished children live in sub-Saharan Africa or South Asia. Although we would like to stress the good work that has been done in the Committee on Development by the rapporteur of the report, we will necessarily have to do better and aim with conviction for better results.  In this respect, I call on my fellow Members of this House to accept our amendment to ensure sustainable water and electricity as a sine qua non for allowing the peoples of underdeveloped countries to live independently. Every day, ladies and gentlemen, 17 000 children die. We must not waste time on sterile discussions, because in the minute that has elapsed while I was doing this, another 12 children have already died.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the nutritional situation of children under the age of five is one of the indicators of family well-being and one of the determinants of children's survival. Child malnutrition is one of the major causes of infant and child mortality. It can adversely affect the child's mental development and, consequently, health and productivity in later life. It is also one of the criteria that the World Health Organisation recommends for assessing equality in health. Unfortunately for Europe, new areas of malnutrition that are suffering from the effects of austerity policies in response to the economic crisis must also be in place. As we speak, in Greece, children pass out in schools during class due to malnutrition. Thousands of Greek families, with zero income due to unemployment, do not have to give their children the necessary. Kids go fasting to schools. Teachers and teachers, out of their meager salary due to memorial cuts, give money to canteens to offer discreet lunches to children who know they cannot afford to buy. But these, out of pride or even shame, refuse to accept it.  Instead of giving the quality of life that our children deserve, with the wrong policies and the wrong economic measures we are bringing countries of Europe into the living conditions of sub-Saharan Africa.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The world has a food problem that particularly affects children. While great progress has been made towards achieving one of the Millennium Development Goals, halving the rate of malnourished people in developing countries. The problem, however, has not disappeared, it is ubiquitous and complicated. I therefore support the content of the motion for a resolution. Poverty is the main cause of malnutrition among children in all regions of the world. The most difficult situation is in South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. Unicef data shows that around 100 million children worldwide suffer from malnutrition, and more than 50 million children under the age of five are suffering from hunger. By contrast, as many as 160 million children worldwide suffer from growth shortages.  Malnutrition inhibits the physical development of the child, weakens his intellect, the ability to concentrate and learn, and consequently deprives him of the chance to be independent in the future, to find a good job and to break the circle of poverty in which he grows up. That is why, in the report on the post-2015 global development framework, which was voted on yesterday by a large majority, Davor Stier mentioned combating poverty and, as a result, hunger, malnutrition among children as the most important objective.  As a member of the DEVE Committee, I would like to stress the particular need to help developing countries to support their real development, which will enable self-sufficiency in the future. We cannot refuse emergency assistance, especially in extreme cases where not only children suffer from hunger, but their entire families. Malnutrition is especially dangerous for pregnant women, as it can cause significant harm or hinder the development of the fetus.  Well-nourished children are hopeful for future generations, healthier and learn better. Thanks to this, in the future they have the opportunity to provide themselves and others with decent living conditions. Meanwhile, today one child dies every 5/6 seconds in the world, as we already know. Together, we can change that.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D). -
text: Sur President, Sur Kummissarju, fid-diskors tiegħu f'din il-Kamra, il-Qdusija Tiegħu l-Papa qal hedge 'Mhux a大大ettabbli li miljuni ta' nies imutu bil-ġu waħt li aħna narmu tant ikel minn fuq l-imwejjed tagħna!'. Żewġ biljuni nies fid-dinja jbatu minn ġuħ moħbi; miljuni ta' tfal ibatu minn ġuħ estrem li jwassal għall-mewt. L-edukazjoni tagħti potenzjal ta' xogħol u tkabbir ekonomiku importanti biex jirribatti l-ġuħ u l-faqar, biex ikun hemm żvilupp sostenibbli u titjib fil-qagħda so大jali. It-tagħlim fuq l-ikel u n-nutrizzjoni għandu jkun parti integrali mill-edukazzjoni formali, biex b'hekk inkabbru ġenerazzjoni b'saħħitha li kapaħi tgħix b'modnji dituż. Investiment f'dan is-sens hu investiment fil-futur; investiment f'nies li kapa大i jsibu xogħol biex jgħixu huma u jgħajxu l-familji tagħhom. U għalhekk nixtieq nistaqsi flower-gumsjoni: xi pjani hemm biex ngħinu flower-pajjizi li għadhom qed jiżviluppaw, biex nedukaw lin-nisa u t-tfal biex b'hekkħ jaarbu min-nassa qerrieda tal-ġuħ u tal-faqar?

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE). -
text: Mr. President. Thank you very much, Mrs McAvan, for your excellent document. Talking about child malnutrition is no longer a deprivation of developing countries. Children's poverty figures in large countries, in European countries like mine, Spain, cause shame and scandal. We are talking about three and a half million children who are not guaranteed sufficient daily nutritional input for their timely development, the physical and intellectual development that is essential to becoming first-class citizens, as we all pursue. How are we going to be able to work, tackle and end hunger in developing countries if we are able to allow this to happen in the countries of the European Union in 2015? Commissioner, you mentioned agriculture, water and education for developing countries. Let me offer you to accompany these issues with decent employment and nutritional and educational security, with universal child benefit in the countries of the European Union. Society must think about the future of children, but it is our obligation to act on their present. They have recognized rights, but they don't have the ability to enforce them, so it's up to adults to defend them.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE). -
text: Mr President, yes, we proclaim and claim the right to food as a moral commitment. More than 165 million children under the age of five are malnourished and approximately 52 million are acutely malnourished. We are faced with an urgent challenge and an urgent need that we must face quickly. The initiative we are debating today is absolutely timely, very timely, and all the more so since on Tuesday, within this House, we voted with a very large majority — 541 votes — on the Union and the global framework for post-2015 development. Parliament's position, ladies and gentlemen, is unequivocally clear. We literally consider food to be a basic human right, in order to set a clear goal of "zero hunger" and end the hunger scandal by 2025. We stress here that efforts to eradicate hunger, malnutrition and the phenomenon of hidden hunger should focus especially on children and nursing women. I am very pleased to note that in the United Nations proposal for the new Post-2015 Development Agenda, one of the goals is to end all forms of malnutrition by 2030 by focusing on children. But we need to further open the scope to achieve our goal and eradicate child malnutrition. Efforts must be made to help improve developing countries in other fields, such as the provision of safe water and sanitation, hygiene, sustainable agriculture, fisheries, natural resource management, a healthy environment, measures to support women to ensure a healthy life for themselves and for all members of their household. In addition, family farming and its coherence with global land governance and tenure frameworks should be promoted.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as a member of this Parliament's Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, let me stress that in the injustice of child malnutrition, there is an internal injustice, namely the discrimination of little girls in relation to little boys. Thus, before the age of five, girls are three times more likely than boys to be severely malnourished. Deprived of good food conditions and therefore even more vulnerable to growth problems, girls are more likely to die when they are still very young. It is therefore necessary to identify cultural and religious barriers in discriminatory practices and attitudes detrimental to girls, and of course to try to remedy them.  Moreover, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, if women farmers had access to the same means of production as farmers, they could increase yields worldwide by 20-30% and increase agricultural production for food purposes. In other words, these advances would prevent 100 million people, or even 150 million, from suffering from hunger. Therefore, addressing inequalities between men and women and between girls and boys from an early age, ending the unfavourable treatment of girls, and improving the prospects of women farmers are concrete ways to combat child malnutrition in developing countries. It seems to me that this is a priority.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE). -
text: Almost one billion people in the world suffer from hunger and 2.6 million children in developing countries die of malnutrition every year. In Mali, an estimated 500,000 children in the country will suffer acute malnutrition by the end of 2014. The causes of child malnutrition are diverse, and the overwhelming majority of them are the human factor. That means they can be avoided. It is often conflict and political instability that are the main causes of child malnutrition. We therefore need more methods, statistics and monitoring of the consequences of different types of conflicts on children and their nutrition. The governments of developing countries must create an environment for better baby food and care. That is why national plans and strategies need to be better coordinated. On our part, the Commission and the Member States should mobilise long-term financial resources and investments in the field of nutrition and cooperate effectively with international organisations. Financial assistance, investment and financial resources are extremely important in combating the threat of acute malnutrition in developing countries. However, in many cases – mali or Syria can be cited as examples – stopping the conflict, preventing violence and creating political stability through diplomatic and political negotiations is certainly just as important as foreign financial assistance.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, child malnutrition and hunger in the world must be the real priority for the European Union and the Commission must develop serious policies against food waste. For too many children, childhood is not a joyful phase: more than 225 million people under 5 suffer from malnutrition or growth delays as a result. In developing countries, it causes death for 2.6 million children every year and is by far the leading cause of infant mortality.  The European Union is therefore called upon to step up its efforts on this issue significantly. The complexity of the approaches would require a superior control room with the involvement of several strategic sectors (health, education, agriculture and water resources) through integrated actions with which to combat and definitively eradicate the drama. For this task to which the European Union is called upon, it must press, involving the United Nations, the G8, the G20 and emerging countries, the governments of countries at risk of nutritional emergency to promote reforms that less selfishly put the large agri-food production chains and, more effectively, small farmers in a position to produce sufficient food for themselves and their families in a sustainable way.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, Gabriela Mistral, a Chilean Nobel Laureate, wrote 70 years ago: "We are guilty of many mistakes, but our greatest crime is abandoning children and neglecting the source of life. There are many things we can wait for, but the child cannot wait." Right now is the time when his bones form, his blood creates, and his feelings develop. We can't answer him tomorrow, his time, or his name is today. What we've done since that time, we can ask ourselves. We're all responsible. Europe is responsible. Sir, thank you very much for your dedication and I believe you are committed to this task and this job. I especially thank you for intending to coordinate this work, for intending, I believe, to coordinate the internal and foreign policy of the European Union and that is the only way to be balanced. I also welcome that you plan to have an efficiency assessment and I am confident that you will work well with this Parliament. I want to thank Ms. McAvan for keeping this topic important and alive, and especially coming in the week after we adopted the global framework for development after 2015 on Tuesday and I believe this needs to be coherent, coherent and we will act well. Nor should we ignore this week's visit by Pope Francis, who has said in this Parliament and cannot remain cool on these words: "We cannot stand still, not only in Europe but also in the world, while so many quantities of food are wasted." So it's up to us to act, we have to see what we can do. In any case, the Millennium Goals have partially fulfilled their role. I believe there's a lot of work for us and we really can't just stay for words. We must all act together.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D). -
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to begin by recognising the role of the European Union in aiding the development and combating child malnutrition. However, food and financial crises since 2008 have again increased and jeopardized the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals. Therefore, although the EUR 3.5 billion announced by the Commission to combat this situation is positive, more effort is needed. To do this, we need to review the actions we have undertaken and frame them within a plan that captures the main axes that Unicef itself has marked as a roadmap. In this multisectoral plan I would dare to highlight three major objectives: the first objective, a programme of the first thousand days of the child, considered critical to its subsequent development; the second, the promotion of small-scale agriculture; and, thirdly and in a no less important way, to stimulate and encourage women's participation in resource sharing, because it is clear and recognized that, when women distribute and control resources within the family, malnutrition within the family is much less. Therefore, we will empower women, give them ownership of land and educate women and girls.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE). -
text: Mr President, with 3.1 million child deaths each year in developing countries, malnutrition is the highest mortality factor in children under five years of age. The fight against child malnutrition is and remains one of the main Millennium Development Goals for 2015. When we talk about child malnutrition, we always link it to food insecurity and poverty, but also to unhealthy domestic environments and inadequate access to health services. Currently 805 million people worldwide do not have enough food to lead a healthy life, most in Sub-Saharan Africa and also in Asia. One in nine people in the world is in this situation. There are also 66 million school-age children in the world who go to school going hungry. The first thousand days of a child's life are essential, as has been said here, so that he can have full growth and his dignity can be respected. It is the period that is therefore considered most critical in order to prevent malnutrition and its consequences in adulthood. It is true that the European Union has made an important effort on all issues of development cooperation, but we must do even more to alleviate this problem, with innovative funding, but also with long-term funding. The aim is that we can talk about food availability, accessibility of these foods and also that these foods can be adapted to the needs of the children themselves. We need to invest more in health, in education, but also in equal opportunities. A large part of women and children working in agriculture, if they had the same rights and if they had the same opportunities and access to services as men, would not be in this situation. I would therefore like to encourage the Commission and the Commissioner to work in this area. Above all, political will is needed to invest in these areas.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I would like, more than to talk about malnutrition in developing countries, to speak literally of hunger. I would therefore like to bring to this debate the expression hunger of children within the European Union. Particularly in troika-intervened countries, there is an urgent need to talk about hunger created by unemployment, bankruptcy and an absent state.  In my country, Portugal, it is the schools that guarantee a hot meal to children. It is these same schools that open doors on Saturdays and Sundays to ensure that children will not be without food. And you know why? Because in a country of unemployment, where migration is forced, parents cannot feed and support their children. In 2011 – we are talking in the midst of the crisis – about 29% of Portuguese children were at risk of poverty. With the misery imposed by austerity, it is estimated that 35,000 children are hungry in my country. There is famine in Europe, there is famine in Greece, Spain, Portugal, Ireland.  What does the Commission intend to do about poverty and hunger within the European Union?

name: Brian Hayes (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I want to welcome this resolution – this report – and to congratulate Mrs McAvan for this work. I think it is important to recognise that we have seen significant progress in the area of malnutrition in the course of the last number of years and, as we go into next year – 2015 – not just in terms of the Millennium Goals but also in terms of the focus in the European Union for the European Year of Development, we need to prioritise this issue to make sure that there is a strong focus within the Commission, within Parliament, on making sure we make progress. As other colleagues have said, every single day, 22 000 children die of malnutrition, and 90% of those deaths are within Asia and Africa. Every single death is preventable, and I think we need to ensure that the political will is in place to resolve this issue once and for all. Colleagues have spoken about the need to support farmers in the developing world, to make sure that they have the right equipment, the right technology, to make sure they have support. We have also spoken about the need to improve diet, to make sure that there is a sustainable food supply. We have also spoken about the need to ensure that discrimination, especially discrimination against women, is tackled within the developing world, and the position of women in terms of education at home and in the workplace also needs to be tackled. We also have to encourage greater use of breastfeeding to avoid contaminated water; and I think, crucially, a plan needs to be built around a child’s first 1 000 days, which other people have spoken about. The first two years are crucial in terms of getting on top of the problem of malnutrition. I think tackling food price volatility and food price security is another issue that we need to address. Even though progress has been made, much more can be done, and if we resolve to do this together, working with other partners throughout the world, I believe that we can address this even further.

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, the title of the matter, the malnutrition of children, is an apocalyptic confession. So we all admit that there are children who are malnourished. Everything that has been heard, all the findings are correct. But the findings are not enough. We need to get to the cause. Why is the phenomenon of malnutrition created, especially in children?  Cause is the system that has a God of money. Let's not turn a blind turn. The system is the capitalist regime, it is the global authoritarian regime, it is the G8-20, it is the regime of wars against peoples, nations, citizens, it is the regime of arms manufacturing and the arms trade. I was surprised that the Pontiff yesterday did not launch a campaign against the abolition of weapons. The working population, scientists say, if the above regime did not exist, would only have to work one minute a day to meet all needs and put an end to this situation.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the European Every day, 25,000 children fall victim to famine on Earth, with more than 800 million people starving or malnourished. A few days ago, the World Nutrition Conference II took place in Rome, during which an action plan was adopted to promote healthy eating and combat malnutrition.  In its report, the UN Working Group on the Creation of the SDGs states, as we heard here this morning, that by 2025 the number of starving and malnourished children under the age of five should be reduced by 40%. This is a task for all of us and represents concrete proposals from the European Commission. I would like to draw attention to the fact that there are many good civic initiatives here in the Union for food programmes, to combat malnutrition and hunger, and we should pay attention to them. I am thinking here of the Hungarian initiative "All children should live well". I believe that if these initiatives could be made known at international level, good practice could be applied, it could help both inside and outside the EU. Thank you!

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D). -
text: Thank you very much for the opportunity, Mr. President. There were a lot of numbers in our discussion today, although I can only really support one number, zero in particular. There's no such things as 40 or 20 or 30, and I don't know what percentage had to be reduced. There can be one objective: zero number of starving children. And I also ask Commissioner, if the first 1 000 days of children are so important to all of us, then this Commission should also have in its first 1 000 days its task to solve the problem of not having a starving child in Europe.  Only in my country, Hungary, almost every second of the children born today faces the prospect of starvation as a child. This is intolerable in rich Europe! I suggest we start advising others when we've cleaned up our own house. Thank you very much!

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE). -
text: I would like to draw attention to this extremely important debate on some specific problem of children in refugee camps. We have more and more refugee camps, there are increasingly different reasons for them, and most often our incompetence, the inability of the international community to solve problems in a timely manner. And the situation of children in refugee camps is deteriorating day by day, and resources are getting less and less. I would like to point to the fact that the European Union not only shows what we are always showing, the broad-heartedness when it comes to supporting people in need, but also to contribute to the international coordination of aid and to determining what kind of situation we actually have today after all the catastrophes that are happening around the world, and that the most vulnerable children are helped while there is still time for them not to be traumatised.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr President, child malnutrition is spreading rapidly as global poverty increases. Malnutrition, due to Mercely austerity, is now also affecting the children of the European South. In Greece, the troika and memoranda have created a huge humanitarian crisis. 40% of the population calls below the poverty line and the unemployed have reached 1.5 million. According to UNICEF, more than 439,000 children live below the poverty line. Child poverty reached 40.5% in 2012 and the situation is tragic, especially in large families. Incidents of fainting of children in Greek schools due to hunger are frequent. The only solution, Commissioner, is to abolish the memorandums and reverse the policy of austerity.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE). -
text: I would like to point out what is the basis for child malnutrition in developing countries. A lot of causes were mentioned here. One of the indisputable attacks on children, of course, is war crimes, criminal groups. Even in Europe, we find areas of malnutrition today. I must mention the east of Ukraine, where children suffer in a way unprecedented in civilised Europe.  I am therefore proud of what the European Union has done for its almost seven decades of existence. Peace between its member countries, cooperation.  Of course, I support the measures proposed by the rapporteur, but I wanted to point out that if there was real peace and cooperation between the peoples of the world, the problem would be disproportionately smaller.  Our Union should also act as an example, as the Holy Father and yesterday's Sakharov Prize winner, Mr Mukwege, pointed out.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, child hunger and malnutrition have a structural dimension and very concrete causes, such as the favouring of the exporting agro-industrial model and the consequent qualitative impoverishment of the global agricultural sector. Years and years of insufficient investment in agriculture, promotion of agricultural abandonment, settlement of family farming and small and medium-sized farms, a sector that provides the livelihood of 70 % of the poor populations of the planet. Market fundamentalism, privatisation and liberalisation policies, free trade have had and have the consequence of land abandonment, the concentration of its property, the dominance of production by a few and the food dependency of many.  Hunger and malnutrition are a living accusatory libel that weighs on an unjust, exploitative, oppressive system – for this very historically condemned. It is regrettable, but enlightening, that it addresses the question that launches this debate, that children's malnutrition be addressed as a profitable investment for donors. The fight against malnutrition is, yes, an ethical duty, indeclinable, and first of all a matter of justice.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D). -
text: Mr President, this resolution is important, and even a small step forward in eradicating malnutrition is indeed important.  I would like to ask you a little bit like Mr Glezos, why is this happening? And there has been a lot of analysis of it here, but I would like to add one reason myself that one worrying problem in Africa, for example, is the so-called land grabbing phenomenon, that is, rich Arab countries and multinationals buying agricultural land because they know that the earth is not growing, but that more and more land is needed, and when they acquire these lands, they also determine what is produced, how it is produced. , and in this way small farms are suffering and this will partly lead to the agricultural sector being driven down in Africa. Isn't this colonialism, actually neo-colonialism at the worst end? I believe that the Commission, in its policy on Africa, must take this land grabbing very seriously.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, thank you very much for this in-depth debate and for the very interesting viewpoints, for example on the role of women, the role of local farmers and, of course, the problem of land governance. There were very crucial issues in this debate. I think the acceleration of initiatives and the commitment to nutrition confirms that the Commission was right to focus on nutrition in its development agenda. EU Member States have shown a strong interest in the Commission’s nutrition action plan, and the Italian Presidency is preparing Council conclusions. This will increase commitment and improve coordination with Member States and reaffirm the EU’s leadership in this area. Last week the International Conference on Nutrition showed the intention of more than 170 representatives of states to eradicate malnutrition and led to the adoption of the Rome Declaration on Nutrition. In this context I highly welcome, of course, the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on nutrition and the initiative of Ms McAvan as chairwoman of the Committee on Development (DEVE). I sincerely hope that with our joint efforts we will be able to relegate under-nutrition to history, once and for all, and pave the way to sustainable development. Thank you once again for this in-depth debate on this very crucial issue.

name: Πρόεδρος. -
text: I have received, in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure, a motion for a resolution. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 27 November 2014 at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: It seems that in modern times it does not even seem necessary to remind everyone that everyone must have the right to food and proper nutrition, in some countries of the world it is still necessary not only to recall this, but also to implement it. And the right to food and nutrition can only be guaranteed through poverty reduction, through ensuring adequate income for families, and eradicating huge social inequalities. Unfortunately, children in developing countries suffer the most from hunger and non-food. As I said, children's malnutrhean is linked to food insecurity and family poverty, exclusion, inadequate care and food provision, inadequate healthcare. In developing countries, the inefficiency of children is caused not only by food shortages and insufficient infrastructure, but also by problems with food distribution, incomplete access to food and insufficient purchasing power, especially in view of the high food prices, which are further inflated by speculation. It is painful that today's reality is that in some countries we are talking about how to reduce food waste, while in others we are counting the children who die of hunger. I would like to call on the Commission to take concrete measures on food support and food assistance for children, pregnant women and mothers feeding children in developing countries.

name: Wałęsa Jarosław (PPE)
text: in writing. – Child malnutrition and undernutrition continue to be of great concern. Therefore, I will continue to support the measures taken by this House and this Union in the efforts to eliminate child malnutrition. It is evident that there is not a one-solution-fits-all scenario in which to implement, thus we must remain open and diligent in our approach.  One important factor that can make a tremendous amount of difference is nutrition for the unborn child while the mother is providing for them both. The crucial point for child nutrition is the first 1 000 days which is when the nutritional needs of the child may vary but good nutrition during this time is vital. In addition child nutrition can be linked to the education, or lack thereof, of the mother and also needs to be addressed in future policy.  While the Commission has in fact earmarked EUR 3.5 billion between 2014 and 2020 to improving nutrition in some of the world’s poorest countries, I would encourage the Commission to scale up its commitments as regards nutrition-specific interventions in order to meet its objective of reducing by 7 million the number of stunted children under the age of five by 2025.

name: Πρόεδρος. -
text: The next item on the agenda concerns the debate on blasphemy laws in Pakistan (2014/2696(RSP))

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. - Mr President, Pakistan’s blasphemy law prescribes life imprisonment or even a death sentence for any individual who expresses disparaging remarks about Islam. Such laws have been invoked in order to target minorities and disproportionately, in particular, have been targeting Shia Muslims, Ahmadi Muslims, Christians and Hindus. Sadly, the vast majority of cases are fabricated. Death and prison sentences are administered by the lower first instance courts, and whilst Pakistan has, to its credit, never actually carried out an execution for blasphemy, significant numbers of those accused and their families are forced to endure threats of – if not actual – mob violence and possibly even public lynchings. Whilst Pakistan has taken steps in recent years to ensure that renewed respect for fundamental human rights remains a top priority on its political agenda, we must continue to urge the authorities to go further, to adhere to the Constitution of Pakistan and modern international standards by fully guaranteeing the human rights of all people and citizens in Pakistan, particularly the most vulnerable citizens, minority groups, women and children. Therefore my group, the ECR, urges Pakistan to repeal these laws, which incite profound intimidation and fear.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in his speech to the Constituent Assembly of Pakistan on 11 August 1947, Ali Jinnah, the founding father of the nation, enshrined the principle of equality between citizens. Jinnah argued that Pakistanis were free, free to go to their temples, free to go to their mosques and any other place of worship in the state of Pakistan. The Pakistanis could belong to any religion or caste or creed, because that had nothing to do with state affairs.  Shahzad Masih and his pregnant wife Shama and Aisha Bibi are just the latest of the many victims to have pakistan's blasphemy law. This law is the most important instrument of oppression of religious minorities and denies the same values on which Pakistan was founded. Each episode of alleged blasphemy forms a chain of injustice, in which violence increases exponentially with each passage.  The European Union must do everything in its power to ensure that the Pakistani Government guarantees its citizens full respect for the human rights enshrined in the International Convention to which it is a party, including through the threat of suspension of the generalised system of preferences.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank For Europe, Pakistan is an important partner. It is therefore of particular interest that human rights should also be given full consideration here. Unfortunately, there are always worrying violations of human rights. In particular, we are concerned about the enforcement of the blasphemy law. People are sentenced to long prison sentences and in many cases to death for allegedly insulting the Prophet Mohammed. These blasphemy laws must be rejected, as must the associated death penalty. It must not be the case that the human right to freedom of religion in Pakistan is systematically violated and that these so-called laws play a major role in this. Above all, Pakistan must be reminded that it must stop the ever-increasing self-justice in this context. We do not need a mob law, we need the rule of law in Pakistan.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Mr President, cultural relativism is increasingly rampant in this Parliament, I regret that. Christians are indeed discriminated against in Pakistan, but they are not the only ones, Hindus, Ahmadis, Sufis, Shiites or even Sunnis, as long as they advocate religious tolerance, are also.  Pakistani laws criminalize blasphemy and apostasy. They restrict freedom of expression and are used for persecution, ill-treatment and intimidation. They are misused and must therefore be abolished and not just reviewed as requested by the resolution. Violence must stop and those who orchestrate it must be brought to justice and condemned. The death penalty must be abolished, and a real separation between politics and religion must be implemented.  Religious violence is unbearable, especially when it is used for political purposes, and it is not by dealing with fundamentalists who demand the application of Sharia law that civil peace will be brought back to Pakistan.  For us, this resolution is not up to the challenge, which is why we will not vote for it.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: author. – Mr President, not one year has passed since this House adopted a resolution on this topic, and we are once again faced with various horrific incidents resulting from these laws. This is a tragedy. How can Pakistanis have faith in the rule of law when claims that are near impossible to prove can mean life imprisonment or the death penalty? How can those acquitted on blasphemy charges return to an environment that breeds hostility? How can religious minorities feel safe in their homes, having seen a couple beaten and burnt alive? Even lawyers who are courageous enough to defend those charged are at risk of mob violence and murder. This is the situation we are dealing with repeatedly, and we have seen no improvement. It is time for Pakistan to embrace the human rights obligations and the constitutional duty it owes its citizens to protect them, whether they are Christian, Muslim, Hindu or atheist.

name: Jeroen Lenaers
text: author. - Mr President, I appreciate very much the fact that we have this opportunity to discuss this, with the resolution, after the debate we had in the last plenary about Asia Bibi, because we also, like our colleagues, are deeply concerned about the controversial blasphemy laws in Pakistan, blasphemy laws that are used to make freedom of expression, freedom of religion for all faiths, increasingly difficult. Several wild accusations have already led to death sentences. One of the most famous, which we discussed last month, was that of Asia Bibi, a Christian woman who was sentenced to death. We need to call strongly on the authorities of Pakistan to repeal these laws, to have a thorough review and to repeal these laws. To achieve that, a strong signal from the European Union is also necessary. I call on the Commission and the EEAS to use all the tools at their disposal to put pressure on the Pakistani authorities to actually introduce some change.

name: Pavel Svoboda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Our resolutions for the protection of religious freedom sometimes have concrete positive results. In July, we passed a resolution on Sudanese Christian Meriam Ibrahim sentenced to death. This woman was acquitted a week after our resolution was adopted. Today, we stand up for Asia Bibi, a Pakistani, also sentenced to death, and other victims of Pakistan's blasphemy law.  I call on the leaders of the European Union to ask the President of Pakistan to grant clemency to Asia Bibi, because this is the fastest legal way to free her. If Asia Bibi and other victims are not freed, I call on the Representatives of the European Union to revise the development aid and trade preferences that the European Union provides to Pakistan. This is because respect for fundamental rights is one of the conditions under which the European Union provides development aid and trade preferences. In the Sudanese case, this threat has impressed.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Amjad Bashir (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – My question is: are we in this House discussing Christian rights as opposed to Muslim rights? Let us not make this debate Christianity versus Islam. Let us defend all people that are targeted under these blasphemy laws. You, sir, and others have mentioned a lot of Christian people that have been persecuted throughout the world. We are here to defend all people of all faiths, not just Christians.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Statistics show that Muslims are the most affected by the blasphemy law, and we are fighting for them here in this house.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Pakistan is an important partner for Europe, as Mr Weidenholzer said, and that is why we must be frank with our partners and friends. And now we are going to tell Pakistan directly that repeal these blasphemy laws, they have clearly led to oppression, discrimination and public humiliation. And they affect Christians, many other religious minorities, certainly Muslims too.  The Pakistani authorities have failed in this work, even though the international community, the UN, the European Parliament and other international actors have on many times pointed this out and called for a correction. Pakistan must now address these fundamentals. What creates such an injustice, and we are really asking the European Union to discuss these problems caused by blasphemy laws with the Pakistani authorities.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, our formation defends secularism, that is, the separation of religion and the State. In this way, we protect all religions. I repeat: we protect all religions. That is why we can only speak out against these anti-blasphemy laws, because they violate international conventions on human rights. That is why we request, we urge the Government of Pakistan to abolish them to comply with all international law. And they have signed the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the Convention against Torture and even a moratorium on the death penalty. But we still cannot forget that the growth of religious extremists has much to do with the interference of the West: the use of these extremist groups, the destabilization of Balochistan or the use, by our beloved Nobel Peace Prize laureate, of extrajudicial killing through unmanned aerial vehicles.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I speak in my role as Chair of Parliament’s Delegation for Relations with the Countries of South Asia, which includes Pakistan. I want once again to reassure Members that these issues are raised by the delegation with the highest authorities when we travel there. I think there are many people in Pakistan who recognise that there is a need for change, not just for minorities but for all Pakistanis, whatever their belief. People should not be facing arbitrary accusation; they should not be in a situation where evidence is presented against them which they cannot hear and which they cannot test. But we also have to realise that to argue for change is really literally putting your life on the line, and I do wonder sometimes how brave many of us would be in those situations. Part of what we are trying to do in Pakistan is to change the situation on the ground, to make change possible, so that is why we need to support universal education which does not undermine Islam but undermines the power of those who would use it for their own purposes. (The speaker agreed to take one blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Lambert, you are, of course, Chair of the relevant delegation, and there have been calls for a review of aid and trade preferences. Would it not be right for us to maintain the reviews that we are carrying out under the scorecard mechanism and, in particular, to keep an eye on who would be most affected by any actions we would wish to take? It is, of course, also very indicative that the Pakistani authorities are now beginning to take a certain view on such things, with over 40 arrests having been carried out in the most recent episode. Would you regard that as a positive development? Would you also agree with me that, in fact, Pakistan requires our assistance to deal with this issue, rather than simply receiving resolution after resolution?

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the question. I do believe that we should, obviously, be sticking to the European Union’s rules about the way we review aid and trade policy. It is something that I have certainly asked for, as a consistency of approach in the way in which we do that. I think the scorecard mechanism is really important. The arrests are welcome as part of a signal from government to people that they should stop the manipulation of these laws. I think we need to be working with the Pakistanis to enable change, which is not to say we should step back from the rules we have in place on human rights. (The speaker agreed to take one blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Mrs Lambert, I too would like to support the point made by my colleague here, Sajjad Karim, on the scorecard and on the arrests and the investigations. But I would like to ask you as an expert to take up the point made by Mr Bashir earlier, where he tried to make this out to be something about protecting Christians versus Muslims. In my reading of the statistics, there is a disproportionate – vastly disproportionate – targeting of minorities, including Muslim minorities – the Ahmadi Muslims in particular, the Shia Muslim communities, as well as Christians and Hindus – and statistics would suggest that it is nothing to do with Christianity versus Islam, it is about targeting minorities. Would you agree with that statement?

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – I would not call myself an expert in this, but in terms of the targeting that we are seeing, yes, I think quite a degree of it is against a range of Muslims and, indeed, a range of minorities. Some of it, I think you can see, is politically manipulated and some of it is much more to settle local scores, but I do think that when we are talking about the issue, we have to be very careful that we are not presenting this in a way which can be interpreted as an anti-Islam agenda, because that plays into the hands of those who actually do not want to see any reform.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, cross compliance is as important a concept as it is abused. Indeed, Pakistan, our important partner, is a good example of how coherence is often a rare commodity in the EU's external relations. Since 1 January 2014, it has been granted the SGP+ regime, preferential access to the single market given to developing countries committed to ratifying 27 conventions on human, labour, environmental and good governance.  I wonder how this obligation and how the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights of 1966 is compatible with the so-called blasphemy laws, which in some cases provide for the death penalty or prison for life and in others the impossibility of being able to preach or propagate one's faith, whatever it may be. That the granting of status is due to a sudden crisis of blindness on the part of the Commission? These are frequent crises, when there are commercial interests at stake that must take the lead over rights. Incredible choices that make us uncredible and that do not help our Pakistani friends. Not to be indignant about this, for me, is true blasphemy.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Amjad Bashir (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Does my colleague Mr Castaldo accept that a lot of the crimes that are being committed, especially in the Third World and in Pakistan, are due to poverty? Is it right that we penalise a nation, and therefore further impoverish people that many a time try and abscond or try and take land, dispossess neighbours, etc? I think it is wrong to penalise a nation on that basis and then cause it to become poorer.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: answer to a "blue card" question.
