Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, as you well know, I am one of those who always denounces it, but I also wonder: what does this have to do with freedom of religion and freedom of thought?  I sincerely believe that the European Union can develop an important and healthy trade and political relationship with Pakistan. It is precisely for this reason that as friends we must remind our friends that, just as we must make greater efforts to allow development in countries that are currently even further behind our own, they too must try to give greater freedom of expression and religion. The right approach is the 'plus for more' approach and we must pursue it consistently.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the issue of Pakistan seems clear to me: Europe is helping Pakistan and Pakistan is destroying our small and medium-sized enterprises at European and Italian level. They burned two Christians and here they pretend to be practically nothing, but as soon as Putin says something you are against Russia and against Putin. You're cowards, you have to wake up. I make a proposal, the solution to improve Europe and make Pakistan happier: take Katainen and Juncker, take them to Pakistan, let them stay there, and let Europe resume. Because it's a fondue socket! Like Juncker, who says he moves 315 billion when he's 21, it's a fondue outlet! It is like saying that Europe can wake up and, as we say in Italy, blessed little girl! Other than waking up here, nothing works. Nothing works here and you don't wake up, other than Pakistan.

name: Preşedintele. -
text: I refrain from any comment.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul Pakistan is one of the world's most dangerous countries for Christians. For decades, the country's blasphemy laws have had devastating consequences for various religious minorities. An accusation of blasphemy is enough to be convicted, for life to end. What happened in eastern Pakistan on 7 November is a grim example of just that. A baseless indictment of the Christian couple Shama Bibi and Shahzad Masih led to them being beaten by a giant mob before being burned to death.  In view of the consideration of this resolution, representatives of Pakistan have assured me and other Members that Pakistan respects the rights of all citizens. There are many of us who doubt that assurance. That is why the serious call to Pakistan's responsibility is to abolish the blasphemy laws. Respect religious freedom. The abominable thing that happened on 7 November must not be repeated.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D). -
text: Mr President, when I joined a delegation from this Parliament to Pakistan in 2013, nawaz Sharif's government undertook to implement a moratorium on the use of the death penalty and to improve human rights. This was a key condition for this Parliament to consider granting GSP Plus status to Pakistan. But we are regressing and, as we see, covered by the reactionary blasphemy law that serves to spread fear and religious and ethnic intolerance and nullifies any legislative progress that has been made in the meantime.  The blasphemy law impedes religious freedom, oppresses minorities, Christians and Muslims, Shiites and Sunnis, and oppresses citizens. It retains Pakistan at the bottom of the civilizational scale. Worse, propagated as an anti-terrorism tool, it plays the game of terrorists, crushes civil society, which wants to live in a free and democratic Pakistan.  We have to demand it, we have to send a clear message to Nawaz Sharif and we have to support all those who in Pakistan are scoffing for freedom and democracy and human rights. (The speaker agrees to answer a question asked under the Blue Card procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – The question I want to ask is: would she agree with me that some in this House have asked for suspension of the GSP+ agreement? Whilst we all agree on the need for a change, if we want to see change and help the victims, do we need to work with Pakistan or to threaten Pakistan?

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – In my opinion, what is necessary is the abolishment of the blasphemy laws, because these blasphemy laws clearly contradict basic human rights, which were a condition for GSP+, so that message must be sent to Pakistan. I do not think that withdrawing from GSP+ would be positive at this point, but that must definitely be on the horizon if Pakistan does not take the necessary measures and continues to obey, for instance, reactionary forces from Saudi Arabia and to put forward these laws that basically violate the human rights of Christians, as well as Muslims, in Pakistan.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR). -
text: Ladies and gentlemen, try to imagine that your sister is doomed in Pakistan and you cannot help her. Or is there a closed citizen of our country, what are we going to do? Asia Bibi, for example, is a victim of religious hostility, and we Europeans, as guardians of human rights, are obliged to help it. She's a Christian woman who wanted to quer the thirst for Muslims, they gave her up under bohorha law and went to jail. She's often beaten, hungry and thirsty in solitary confined. Our society is based on helping those who need it. To save a mother-of-five who is punished for helping a neighbor just because she is a Christian deserves extreme efforts to save her. The people of Eastern Europe know this, we have experienced persecution because of the faith of the Communist regime, and Christians have suffered. 25 years on from the regime, I must say that freedom of religion is a luxury in many countries. Several countries, such as Pakistan, Iraq or Syria, do not allow the free faith in God to be freely expressed, that is not right. Spreading fear through religion is not worthy of these times. Mercy is not paid for by death. In a civilised world, aid is rewarded. Irrational blasphemy laws create an opportunity to persecute, persecute, criminalise people of other faiths.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, no religion can justify barbarism and savagery. No religion can justify a raging mob attacking a Christian couple to death and singing their bodies in the ovens of the factory where they worked. No religion can justify shooting a governor in Punjab province and a Christian minority minister just because they criticized the blasphemy law and were in favor of the rights of religious minorities. No law can justify them staying in prison, with the possibility of being sentenced to death, more than a thousand people whose most known and emblematic case is that of Asia Bibi. No religion can justify killing a lawyer, Rashid Rehman, in the full exercise of his term of office, for defending a constituent accused of blasphemy in court.  No more barbarism! Pakistan must be brought into the community of civilized nations.

name: Amjad Bashir (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, I strongly condemn the brutal killings of Shama Bibi and Shahzad Masih, Pakistani Christians, by a violent mob and other abuses committed in the name of blasphemy. These barbaric acts cannot be acceptable to this Parliament, the international community and the Pakistani nation. I know the Pakistani nation is in a state of deep shock and outrage. It is important to understand that these laws have existed in Pakistan since colonial times and that the majority of cases registered under this law have been against Muslims. I have been assured by the Pakistani authorities that they are taking adequate steps to prevent possible misuse and abuse of the laws. It is also important to remember that no one has so far been punished under these laws. Cases instituted under the law have normally failed to withstand judicial scrutiny at the various levels. It has been made compulsory that no police officer below the rank of superintendent of police can investigate the charges.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in November 2010, Asia Bibi, a Pakistani Christian, was sentenced to death by the authorities in her country on the grounds that she had insulted Muhammad. Since then, all attempts to appeal this decision have been rejected. She is currently awaiting the decision of pakistan's Supreme Court on death row, her last resort to save her life. Colleagues, I would like to point out that, according to The Black Book of the Status of Christians in the World, between 120 and 200 million Christians are persecuted every year. In other words, millions of people risk their lives every day simply because they believe in Christ. Nevertheless, once again, the arrogant ideology of human rights underpins this resolution, and that is why I will refrain from supporting it. I will not support further interference by the European Union, which has only one purpose: to bring down the sovereignty of States in order to achieve the geopolitical ambitions of a global power and the oligarchies that serve it. May our Western governments begin to oppose the Islamization of Europe and the extension of Islamic fundamentalism in our own societies before giving lessons to the whole world! Asia Bibi will not be saved by Western right-of-hommism, she will be saved by a Europe that will assume its Christian civilization and which, by the fact of its power, will offer natural protection to Christians in their own country.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE). -
text: Mr President, as is the case with other minority communities in the country, such as Christians, the Baloch people have been targeted through the blasphemy laws in Pakistan.  Mentally ill people have also been victims of these laws, which demonstrates how the Pakistani State fails to protect and mistreats the vulnerable groups in its society. The blasphemy laws are in violation of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which Pakistan needs to adhere to if it wants to benefit from the GSP with the EU. We should not overlook the fact that many secular parties in Pakistan have been advocating amending or abolishing the blasphemy laws. This is something for the European External Action Service to pay attention to when dealing with Pakistan.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Pakistan is the only Muslim country that has a blasphemy law. Since 1990, when this rule was introduced, there have been about 60 executions. Sharia violence affects not only Christians but also other minorities. We in this House have protested against the decision of the High Court in Lahore to upheate Aisha Bibi's blasphemy death sentence, just as we have expressed our horror at the murder of two young men, Christian spouses, parents of four children, burned alive in Pakistan by an angry mob because they were unjustly accused of blasphemy.  But indignation is not enough. Europe must urge Pakistan to take the necessary steps to repeal the odious blasphemy law. The European Union has a duty to urge the Government of Islamabad to consider a moratorium on executions. Formal convictions are no longer enough. Europe must use all the means of pressure it has at its disposal on the Pakistani Government to help religious communities. Europe can and must take action to ensure that Pakistan fulfils its obligations to freedom of expression and freedom of religion and belief.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR). -
text: The European Parliament is right to call attention today to the blasphemy legislation, which must be repealed. Rightly so, because Asia Bibi has been innocent on death row for many years. She needs to be free! And that can be done by a presidential decree or by a quick hearing before the Supreme Court in Lahore.  We are right to deal with this case now, because there are hundreds of Asia Bibis. The blasphemy laws are a blanket of fear across Pakistani society and are abused by extremists there. The blasphemy laws must go. We are right to be discussing this today because the laws are contrary to the human rights treaties that Pakistan has signed and are contrary to the GSP+ relationship it has with the European Union. Mrs Malmström, the European Commission, must therefore quickly examine whether the obligations that have been fulfilled under the GSP+ are justified. No trade benefits if there is religious persecution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE). -
text: Mr President, a lot has been said and I agree with all of what my colleagues have said. With this resolution, we both want to send a clear message of support to Asia Bibi and urge the Pakistani authorities to save this woman, including by repealing blasphemy laws.  This resolution repeats all the persecutions suffered by people who do nothing but believe in God. Our Parliament and the European Union have a very clear responsibility to defend religious freedom, regardless of religion; this is addressed to Mr Chauprade, but I agree with him on one point: our responsibility is also to defend Christians since our history and our deep identity are deeply rooted in Christianity.  If we do not defend the more than 150 million persecuted Christians in the world, who will do it for us?

name: Marek Jurek (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Many of our colleagues have already spoken about the Case of Asia Bibi – Mr Škripek, mr van Dalen, Mr Svoboda, Mr Chauprade, Mr Caputo. I want to propose and demand more pragmatic action, because Asia Bibi can no longer endure the psychological torture of being held on death row for many years. The authorities of the Subcarpathian region in Poland proposed to the Pakistani authorities to accept Asia Bibi for treatment. The mayor of Paris proposes the same. These concrete social proposals must be supported by european Union diplomacy. This is a concrete call on Minister Mogherini to support the initiatives taken by specific local authorities in our countries. This woman has to get out of prison. And of course we must repeat one thing to our partners in the Islamic world: no Muslim in Europe is persecuted in this way because of their religion. So we should demand these principles, those laws that we apply ourselves.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, I ask that the death penalty conviction of Asia Bibi, a Christian woman and mother of five, who was arrested in 2009 on a false blasphemy charge be overturned and ask that she be released. I ask that the perpetrators of the murder of Christian couple Shama Bibi and Shahzad Masih beaten by a group of Muslims be revealed, accusing them of burning the pages of the Koran and burning them alive in the brickyworks where they worked.  I ask that the blasphemy law in Pakistan be abolished, because its application violates human rights and the right to freedom of expression of religion. The fact is that Pakistan plays an important role in promoting stability in Southeast Asia, so I call on the Pakistani authorities to set an example in strengthening laws and human rights, not in violating them.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I stand here actually feeling very proud of the fact that we are having the type of debate that we are, in this Chamber. Once again, his Holiness the Pope took the floor just the day before yesterday and made it clear that when Europe does not hold firmly to its values, we are set adrift, and that I see being demonstrated here today. So many of our colleagues may be unaware, but actually this House and the European Union have already been instrumental in securing the release of a European citizen from death row in Pakistan. It is something that we achieved some years ago. There is no reason why our dialogue should not allow us to pursue that sort of constructive dialogue again. To the Commission, I can simply repeat: we have, of course, a variety of calls in terms of the trade relationship that we have with Pakistan. After a considerable and very vigorous exercise, we granted the GSP+ to Pakistan. We have the scorecard mechanism. Let us please apply that as vigorously as we possibly can. This is a time for every colleague in this House to come together and work with Pakistan in order to achieve the ultimate end of saving that life.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, there is no religion that can justify such actions. We use the instruments at our disposal here today, this Resolution is also an instrument and it is commendable that we have a Resolution.  However, the fact is that 150 million Christians worldwide are persecuted.  The fact is that the blasphemy law in Pakistan is very oppressive and intolerant and we really cannot coldly observe that after the killing in the oven of two citizens of Pakistan, Asia Bibi is sentenced to death. Just because she was a Christian and only because she used the right to water for her children. So human rights are at risk on a multi-grounds basis. I have one suggestion, so we're sending a message today if possible. However, I am not sure that this message will have a positive effect.  I have a proposal to Mr. Stylianides, since development aid is going from the Union and toward Pakistan, to look at how this development aid is being sent to Pakistan, and that may be one constructive proposal.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE). -
text: Mr President, it is in the name of the founding universal values that respect for the fundamental rights of individuals, freedom of opinion, freedom of thought, freedom of conscience, freedom of religion and religious tolerance are that we urge the Pakistani authorities to repeal blasphemy laws.  I recall that it is the Pakistani constitution itself that is supposed to guarantee the rights of minorities and religious freedom, the rights of all minorities and, above all, all religious minorities. We, therefore, really must demand that our Pakistani partner respect its own commitments, that it respects human rights.  But why hide behind our little finger? We know that it is Christians who today, in too many countries around the world, are among the most persecuted religious minorities. The case of Asia Bibi, this young woman, whom we must manage to get off death row, particularly stirs opinion. We have to do everything we can to free Asia Bibi.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, on behalf of the High Representative/Vice-President, Federica Mogherini, we welcome the adoption of your resolution on the blasphemy laws in Pakistan. As recalled in the European Union guidelines on freedom of religion or belief and the European Union guidelines on freedom of expression, laws that criminalise blasphemy can have serious inhibiting effects on the exercise of these human rights. As a general principle, the European Union recommends the decriminalisation of blasphemy offences. In Pakistan the blasphemy laws are frequently used to settle personal conflicts or to stoke up secretarian and interfaith tensions. The application of blasphemy laws is an issue of considerable concern for the European Union, not least because they carry the death penalty. In our human rights dialogue with Pakistan in June we discussed the blasphemy laws. We reminded the Government of Pakistan of its obligation to enforce the provision of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights concerning freedom of religion or belief. During his official visit to Pakistan in October 2014, the EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Mr Stavros Lambrinidis, specifically raised the misuse of blasphemy laws with several ministers as well as with religious leaders. He also expressed deep concern at the decision of the High Court to uphold the conviction of Mrs Asia Bibi, despite blasphemy legislation being a sensitive issue within Pakistani society. The EU message is that leaders, whether political or religious, must find the courage to address this. Threats and violence against judges, lawyers and human rights defenders involved with these cases are common. Some of them have even been killed. It must be clear that any form of immunity for such crimes would undermine the justice system and the rule of law. The European Union will continue to use any appropriate opportunity to raise this issue with our Pakistani counterparts. In this regard, the GSP+ trade preferences are a major milestone in our relations with Pakistan. GSP+ offers a clear framework for assessing and promoting progress in implementing the 27 co-international conventions on human rights, labour rights, environment and good governance – a process we are following closely. The European Union, and notably our delegation in Islamabad, will continue to follow the case of Asia Bibi closely and to advocate for the verdict to be overturned and for Mrs Bibi to be released. The European Union will use any opportunity to raise this case, and the wider issues of the death penalty and the blasphemy law, with our Pakistani counterparts. I have taken note of and welcome your strong interest in this issue. Let me assure you that the European Union remains fully committed to engage with Pakistan – with the government, human rights defenders and other stakeholders – to promote and defend human rights. The forthcoming visit to Europe by the Chair of the Pakistani Senate early next year may be a useful opportunity to discuss our concerns.

name: Președintele. -
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. I would like to speak today to remind all of us of the importance of continuing to fight tirelessly in defence of human rights in all those places where they are constantly under threat. I am referring now, in particular, to the current situation in Pakistan. We all know the story of Asia Bibi, the Christian mother of 5 children sentenced to death only because she drank water from a well intended for Muslims. This is all the more shocking when we consider that the High Court of Justice in Pakistan has ratified the death sentence, which will have to be carried out shortly. So the rule of law does not exist in Pakistan at all and Christians continue to be persecuted with impunity. It is important for the Pakistani authorities to realise that if they continue to violate human rights so barbarically, dialogue with the European Union will become impossible, given that a sine qua non for dialogue is precisely about good governance and respect for human rights. And the case of Asia Bibi is not the only one in recent history, since only two weeks ago, on November 7, a Christian couple was beaten to death, accused of burning pages of the Koran.

name: James Nicholson (ECR)
text: , in writing.– Under blasphemy laws in Pakistan, defiling the Koran or insulting the Prophet Muhammed can result in life imprisonment or the death penalty. Under these provisions, which are part of the Pakistani Penal Code, dozens of people are persecuted every year, although the vast majority of cases are actually fabricated and part of land or workplace disputes. While no one has been executed by the state for blasphemy, those accused of breaking these laws often spend years in prison and along with their family are at all times in danger of mob violence. Even advocates for reform in Pakistan run the risk of being targeted by extremists. It is abundantly clear that the blasphemy laws have been used to instil fear into religious minority communities, and in particular Christians. While minority rights are guaranteed by Pakistan’s constitution, the government must actively address religious hostility within society. Pakistan has a duty to respect, and provide adequate protection to, people of all faiths. Freedom of thought, conscience and religion are fundamental human rights. These rights belong to all Pakistanis, irrespective of their faith.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: We are in the process of calling on Pakistan to revise its blasphemy laws today. In the run-up to the event, we were told by the Pakistani side, among other things, that these laws were intended to protect any religion and that principles of the rule of law would be upheld anyway. The fact is, however, that between 1986 and 2007, 647 people were indicted on the basis of these laws and half of the defendants were not Muslims. However, 95% of Pakistan's inhabitants profess the Muslim faith! In fact, despite all the claims made by the Pakistani Government, the laws are primarily non-Muslims. Furthermore, cases such as that of Muhammad Asghar show that people are sentenced to death under these laws, who would be found to be incapacitated under Western jurisdiction. A call to revise these laws may be a first step in public. However, we must consider further steps today to put this call into action if Pakistan sticks to its rigorous line of application of this injustice.

name: Preşedintele. -
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the case of Šešelj, accused of war crimes (2014/2970(RSP)).

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the ultranationalist Serbian leader, Vojislav Šešelj, on trial at the International Criminal Court for war crimes and released temporarily for health reasons, returned to Belgrade and there were family members and many supporters who chanted Chechen chants and chanted anti-government slogans at the airport.  Shešelj is accused of crimes committed against Muslims and Croats during the war in the former Yugoslavia. Serbian politicians and media, commenting on Shešelj's return home, made no mention of war and crime. The crucial issue dealt with in the Serbian media was the function and actual legitimacy of the Tribunal in The Hague: whether this is a court that operates in a fair manner, whether it has violated Shešelj's rights and whether The Hague only processes the Serbs. In the crowd Šešelj moved very well and without anyone's help, indeed he entertained the crowd by giving speeches as a political leader.  The European Union cannot stand by and watch the myth of those who have supposedly committed horrendous crimes against humanity be worshipped. In cases such as these, a faster and more certain course of justice would be desirable, because there is a risk of unacceptable delegitimization.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: Developer. - Mr. President, I fully support this resolution and its critical approach, not only towards Seselj, but also those who daily enable him to continue spreading hatred through historical revisionism and propagation of Greater Serbian expansionism.  None of his circus, however, would have come to the fore if Serbian authorities had immediately fenced off and condemned Seselj's sickening statements and behaviour. It is clear to me that they were once colleagues and closest associates, but as today's leaders of Serbia, it should be in their interest to close the war and open a new, European chapter.  I would also add in the end that I am surprised and disappointed by the incredible inefficiency and bias of The Hague tribunal, which has not fulfilled its historical task but only brought additional unrest into the territory of the states of the former state.

name: Davor Škrlec
text: Developer. - Mr. President, the day before yesterday the Holy Father, right from this Parliament, sent a message of hope to the peoples of the Balkans with the desire to establish lasting peace in a region that is a witness and a victim of war conflicts.  Vojislav Seselj's hate speech reopens the wounds of war conflicts and insults the collective memory of Croatian citizens. Aware of the risks, the International Court of Justice in The Hague irresponsibly opened up space for the potential destabilisation of the region, further eroding the credibility and trust of citizens shown to the international institution.  I expect Serbia's institutions to demonstrate the responsible behaviour of a country that is a candidate for MEMBERSHIP in the European Union and respect for the fundamental principles of the European Union. Protecting minority rights and human rights in general and respecting diversity and promoting good relations in the region are necessary preconditions for cooperation. I strongly support political parties and civil society organisations in Serbia whose activities focus on lasting peace in the region and constructive co-operation. I believe serbia will meet the expectations expressed in this European Parliament resolution on its way to the European Union.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank The past lies like a dark shadow over ex-Yugoslavia. It cannot be escaped, and therefore the crimes must not be trivialised or swept under the table. They must be worked out, guilt and responsibility cleared up. There are due process of legal proceedings for this. Truth-finding takes time, often unbearably, as in the case of Vojislav Eelj. The court has now temporarily released the accused on humanitarian grounds, as is customary in constitutional states. This fact does not entitle anyone to draw any conclusions about a future judgment. It could be seen as simple if the shadow of the past did not lie over the region. It can only be escaped if the institutions of the rule of law are respected and cooperated with them without reservation. The current Serbian Government has committed itself to this, and we should therefore not make this case the subject of a non-functioning past.

name: Jozo Radoš
text: Developer. - Mr. Vice President, colleagues, it is important in this Resolution to state the inadmissibility of the Decision of the Hague Tribunal on the release of Seselj and also to condemn his attacks on the sovereign states of the Republic of Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina and the glorification of war crimes.  But Seselj is sick, some say crazy, a war criminal that we will not change, and the Hague tribunal is nearing the end of its work and is not a court of the European Union, but is a court of the United Nations. Serbia is the most important topic of this Resolution, as it is a country on which the fate of other Western Balkan countries depends largely and can be influenced by both good and bad.  That is why it is important to call on the Serbian political leadership to condemn Seselj's hate speech and his attacks on neighbouring states, and of course it is even more important that they actually do. And what ALDE specifically insisted on, to empower and apply laws that prohibit hate speech and incite violence.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Mr President, there is no need to list the crimes against vojislav Eelj. Slobodan Milosevic considered it to be the personification of primitive violence, that is to say! The historical leader of the Serbian far right sees himself as the heir to the Chetniks, militias that collaborated with the Nazis during World War II. He appeared before the Hague Tribunal, was sentenced to only 15 months in prison for scraps and has not yet been tried on the essentials. Released for health reasons, barely returned to his country, he resumed his hate speech. His trial has dragged on too long, his victims are entitled to justice. This executioner, sick or not, must be condemned, it is the best way to prevent him from harming the reconciliation that Serbia so desperately needs.  But this resolution, requested by the EPP, risks serving it in the end. Already, he is using it to advertise himself. Without disagreement on the substance, I therefore fear that this resolution is ineffective or even counterproductive. I therefore ask, once again, for a better choice of our emergencies so that they actually serve the defence of human rights around the world.

name: Andrej Plenković
text: Developer. - Mr. Vice President, the resolution strongly condemns the wartime warmongering rhetoric of indicted war criminal Seselj after his return to Belgrade. We call on The Hague to review the conditions for his stay at large in the new circumstances and regain its own credibility. We condemn Seselj's insulting of victims in Croatia, especially on the day of remembrance of the victims of the heroic city, Vukovar. His remarks opened up the psychological wounds of the victims' wars in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also created new fears for minorities in Vojvodina. We also oppose the advocacy of the Great Serbia project with territorial claims on neighbouring countries.  The resolution is a clear message to authorities in Serbia who have not responded adequately to Seselj's hate speech in political or legal terms. We ask Serbian institutions to investigate whether Seselj has already violated Serbian laws and to protect minority rights. Responsible democracy means accepting European values. Therefore, Serbia, which wants to join the European Union, is invited to clearly condemn Seselj's actions.  What is the problem for President Nikolic, Prime Minister Vucic, Minister Dacic? Is ignorance a political tactic or is silence a fear of Seselj? Your silence leaves doubts about the current authorities' position in Serbia on prosecuting those responsible for war crimes. In the interest of Serbia's European future, react.

name: Eduard Kukan
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I fully understand the evil of wartime rhetoric and hate speeches against neighbouring countries and minorities, especially in the Western Balkans. Therefore, I will always fight for policies of peace and reconciliation. Šešelj’s public appearances go precisely against these principles. Our response, however, should not create more tensions, and especially not by giving this accused war criminal more attention than he deserves. I think it is unfortunate that Šešelj’s radical statements have been given such unnecessary publicity and attention by the media and some politicians. I only hope that they are not going to be used as an instrument for further political tension in the region. I am also convinced that this resolution is not a good place to give instructions to the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY). It is an independent international body created by the United Nations and has a clear mandate. For these reasons, I hesitate to support this resolution.

name: Tonino Picula
text: on behalf of the S&D. Club – Mr. President, there is an emergency situation, we have an extraordinary resolution. This is an indicator that some regular condition may be changing for the worse.  Unfortunately, stability and peace are not yet a regular situation in the Western Balkans. That is why the case of war crimes indictee Vojislav Seselj has a dimension of urgency with regard to space and time. The Western Balkans will long feel the effects of aggression, death, destruction committed on behalf of a project in which Seselj was an active participant. He wasn't convicted of it, he didn't regret it, indeed. His, I hope, provisional release also unleashed the fears of victims who again have to experience trauma because he performs as if time stopped in the early 1990s.  I also see the resolution as an incentive for Serbian authorities to check whether Seselj is violating domestic laws with hate speech and supporting democratic forces in Serbia to resist ideas that have cost Serbian neighbours and Serbia itself so much recently, and the European Parliament, which awarded Dr. Mukwege yesterday, should react persistently to inciting hatred on its continent as well.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Dear Mr President, honourable Members, I fully share the opinion of the petitioner of this draft resolution. Shevel's name has become a symbol of war crimes, it has become a symbol of ruin, a civil war waged on the territory of the former Yugoslavia for more than fifteen years, which has claimed hundreds of thousands of lives, destroyed fates, destroyed homes, destroyed infrastructure, destroyed relations in the Balkans.  This great state, this chauvinistic politics of Shessel, has led to millions of people leaving their homelands and not yet coming home to them. And this policy still continues as an echo of his actions in Tsaribrod, in Basilegrad, in Surdstreet, etc. The place of war criminals is in prison, not on the loose.

name: Ivo Vajgl
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, – Šešelj is a metaphor for crime on the premises of the former Yugoslavia. A metaphor for the worst things that have happened, and he's forever imprinted his image under the fears of Vukovar. Shešelj is a man about whom history will write in the same letters as the greatest criminals of fascism, Nazism and other isms. Sheshelj should not have given the public tribune that in this day and age, in different circumstances, he proclaims his old, discarded ideas. I don't want to criticise the Hague court, but because of its decisions, it certainly wasn't the most brilliant, it was misguided. As far as the authorities of Serbia are concerned, they have been belgradeed since the arrival of Šešelj, they have no merit for the arrival of Šešelj. However, I call on them, and this resolution calls for them to step on its toes with the means of the rule of law.

name: Igor Šoltes
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – Why did I sign the resolution on Šešelj? Of course, not because I would like to judge his responsibility for war crimes, only the Hague Court can judge this, and I hope that he will do so as soon as possible, because if we did, we would not be talking about these matters today. Secondly, I did not sign the resolution because I would like to share the lessons of Serbia and its leadership. It has already responded to Serbia with changes that have made Serbia a completely different country and society in the eight years since his departure to The Hague than Sheshelj and his supporters imagined. However, the fact that the judgment has not yet been handed down does not give The Shesha's right to spread the lies that are blaming the victims of the crimes that have occurred and spreading the hatred that can lead to new violence, the new tensions. Such a speech must also be condemned here in the European Parliament, in which our colleagues from Serbia will one day sit. And my support is mainly for those who are fighting in Serbia to keep their society open, tolerant, modern and democratic, so we cannot be silent either here, not even in Serbia.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI). -
text: Mr President, in a short time we will be called to decide on the fate of Dr Šešelj, a man who remained in prison for twelve years as a political prisoner, not for what he did but for what he said, that is to say for his ideas. Have you ever thought, ladies and gentlemen, of the possibility of convicting the president of the party with which you have been elected, without having committed any offence? You will say 'no, because this is not a democracy'. We Greek nationalists, however, will unfortunately say yes. Yes, because for fourteen months now the leader, six Members and a number of members of our party have been unjustly and illegally in prison, not because they have committed something bad, not because they have said something bad, but simply because their political opponents cannot deal with their own arguments with political arguments. "Judicial arbitrariness under a government political mandate" you will tell me and I will agree with you. Unfortunately, democratic states, when they impose political purposes, violate human rights in the same way, perhaps even worse, than totalitarian states, which we rightly condemn.

name: David McAllister (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the main message of our resolution is to strongly condemn the appalling hate speeches and wartime rhetoric of Mr Šešelj. This kind of incitement to hatred and the encouragement of territorial claims have no place at all in the Europe of the 21st century. Today we encourage all authorities in Serbia, the government and the opposition, the political parties, non-governmental organisations and all individuals to fight against hate speech. I would like to outline that the European Parliament stands by Serbia on its European path. Serbia itself has declared EU accession as its key strategic goal, and we can all acknowledge the progress this country is making towards this goal. Serbia clearly belongs to our European family and has the capacity and ability to deliver and to get closer to the European Union in the near future. We should support our partners in their efforts. This also needs to be the message of today’s debate.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR). -
text: Condemnation of Szeszel's crimes is an obvious requirement of justice, that is, above all, an appeal to the International Court in The Hague to consistently judge this crime. This is, as the motion for a resolution says, a crime based on national hatred, but for justice to be fair, it is necessary to bear in mind all the crimes, including those committed on the basis of communist ideology. Many of them have not been tried. This applies to Central Europe, this applies to Polish.  Finally, the last remark: the just condemnation, the necessary condemnation of Mr Sheszel and his crimes must not close the door for the brave Serbian people, who have the right to participate in the European Community, like all the Balkan nations. We should do both.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE). -
text: Mr. President, (the beginning of the speech is not heard) is that the Hague tribunal established to convict criminals in the former Yugoslavia has issued a decision that again potentially incites hatred in the territory of the former Yugoslavia. In this context, as inappropriate as it may be to talk about judicial decisions, we must warn the court and the public that this decision will certainly not contribute to peace and stability. The conviction of the villain Seselj is here in this house definite and completely clear and unanimous. I also want to highlight the positive fact that seselj's call for hatred and new conflicts has not been met with any serious passing in Serbia and serbian citizens have largely ignored his views.  And especially important is that today we have a situation where the Government of Serbia wants a European path, Mr. Rama's visit to Belgrade and a visit to Sarajevo is something that is indicative of good intentions at the moment by Serbia.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE). -
text: I, in turn, would like to condemn in very firm terms the recent actions of Šešelj, who has been charged before the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia of serious crimes committed on the territory of Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. We are all outraged, as we have seen, by the rhetoric used by Šešelj around the theme of "Great Serbia", by the incitement to hatred, as well as by his reception as a hero in Serbia after his provisional release on humanitarian grounds. As Parliament's rapporteur for Bosnia and Herzegovina, I have watched the reactions in this country, the sense of revolt of the victims for whom Šešelj's recent actions only reopen unhealed wounds. In addition to this emotional burden, Šešelj's actions risk compromising efforts for reconciliation in the Balkans, and public trust in The Hague Tribunal, which is an important tool to achieve this reconciliation, risks being affected. Finally, I would like to encourage the political class in Serbia to unite in rejecting statements of this kind, bellicose and incitement to hatred.

name: Preşedintele. -
text: We have the catch the eye procedure, but we have several colleagues who have signed up, but due to the fact that we still have a topic to debate and we would like to start the votes at 12.00, taking into account the timetable for departures from Strasbourg, I ask you for permission and understanding to give the floor to a single person who has not spoken and who will not speak. The others either spoke in the catch the eye procedure, or spoke in debates, or will speak in the debate. That is why I will give the floor to one person, Mr Khan, on this procedure, and then I will ask the Commissioner to speak. Mr. Khan, you have the floor for a minute. Mr Khan came out of the room before this announcement, so I ask Commissioner Stylianides to speak.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I am presenting this point on behalf of High Representative and Vice-President Federica Mogherini. I note that a number of honourable Members called for an urgency debate on the decision by the International Criminal Tribunal for former Yugoslavia regarding Šešelj. I also note the important resolution adopted by Parliament today. As you are aware, the Tribunal took this decision on health grounds. We have noted this decision by the Tribunal. We do not have further views on that decision. The Tribunal is an independent international court created by the United Nations and responsible for determining individual responsibility for war crimes in former Yugoslavia. The European Union respects the Tribunal’s decision. As far as Šešelj is concerned, his statements belong to an epoch which is long gone. We note that the case against him is still ongoing and that he will have to return to the Tribunal when so requested by the Tribunal – very important. With regard to Serbia, we welcome the country’s commitment to work towards its European future and towards regional cooperation and reconciliation. Cooperation with the Tribunal is an important element in this context.

name: Preşedintele. -
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. – The alleged war crimes have been brought before Mr Shešeljo has been released prematurely, although the charges against him include crimes against humanity, incitement to hatred or talking about possible occupations of neighbouring states. In support of this resolution, I therefore stress that any release of such and similar war crimes actors must be considered very well and that behaviour and action should be directed against both their own state and against an EU Member State or any member of the international community, strictly assessed, in accordance with the highest political, moral and legal standards. Especially in view of the status and responsibilities of the Serbian State as an EU candidate.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D)
text: Writing. – Let me say that, in my work so far, I have often pointed to the dangers of hate speech, radicalism, nationalism and the horrific consequences that these phenomena have. I will always seek to condemn those who seek to achieve their political goals through manipulation and war-related rhetoric. Especially those accused of war crimes and have shown in the past that they choose conflict behaviour rather than conciliation. However, honourable plenum, I would like to call for the caution and political wisdom required by today's decision on the resolution relating to the temporary release of Vojislav Šešel, accused of a war crime. I believe that the adoption of the resolution of oil-on-fire, which is completely unnecessary at the moment, is, more than anything, undesirable. It is clear that these are political provocations that we in the EP want to overlook, not respond to. By adopting a resolution, we give the accused exactly what he wants: attention and meaning. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that the adoption of such personalised resolutions is not in the EP's practice. Once again, I repeat that the EP should not be used as a polygon to tackle or promote internal political issues. What we need at this moment is a firm will: to overcome as soon as possible the conflict that led to the bloody Balkan wars and the sober determination of the UK to a common future within the EU.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. – Tolerance that adorns the institution of the European Parliament cannot remain mute to the wartime rhetoric of indicted war criminal Vojislav Seselj. Urgent responses are needed to hate speech and condemnation of behaviour offensive in the historical context and in the context of European integration, acceptance and sharing of European values, democratisation and Serbia's progress.  There are rare opportunities and topics on which entire states, in a democratic world where debate is expected, stand with all their political options undivided in a position. I am proud that Croatian MEMBERS of all political options in the European Parliament recognised the importance of the moment and sided with reason and dignity together. This kind of rhetoric in Serbia, which wants to go the way of European integration, must have no place.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. – I join my colleagues in deploring the recent public statements and incitement to hate of Vojislav Šešelj which represent clear attempts to destabilise South-East Europe and derail Serbia from its European path. He represents a threat to the progress in regional cooperation and reconciliation in the Balkans and we must not ignore his influence. The final order of the International Criminal Court for the Former Yugoslavia, published on 6 November, stipulates only that Šešelj should refrain from witness and victim intimidation and return promptly to The Hague when summoned. No restraints were put on Šešelj in terms of political activity. Šešelj told his supporters upon his return: ‘I won the battle against The Hague and that was my goal.’ This statement and his actions after his release represent a provocative attitude which requires a firm and adequate political reaction and legal response. I echo this resolution’s call on the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia to undertake measures to re-examine the existence of requirements for provisional release under new circumstances. I urge the Serbian authorities to respect their obligations under the framework on cooperation with the ICTY and their obligations as an EU candidate country.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. – Dear Mr. President, on behalf of those killed and displaced, those whose homes have been destroyed, those who have been abused in the camps, on behalf of all those who died from vukovar and Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Vojvodina, I ask that the war criminal Vojislav Seselj be sent back to The Hague prison. I also ask for this on behalf of all Croatian defenders, especially Croatian defender Veljko Maric, who is illegally held in prison by Serbian authorities and does not provide him with the necessary medical care.  Vojislav Seselj's release is inadmissible, especially since the verdict against him has already been written. Vojislav Seselj has made a series of public statements in which he has repeatedly called for war, instiged hatred of non-Serb people and expressed territorial claims, all of which lead to the destabilisation of Southeast Europe. He violated both conditions under which he was released from prison, and the Serbian government's response as well as that of The Hague tribunal were completely absent.  I ask The Hague tribunal to return Seselj to prison and for Serbia to start acting in accordance with European policy if it wants to be a member of the EU.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – WE MAY vote against this Resolution on issues of form and substance. The Resolution is part of Article 135 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament on statements 'on urgent cases of violation of human rights, democracy and the rule of law'. Vukovar's statements on the 23rd anniversary of Vukovar, however incendiary they may have looked like, cannot be regarded as an urgent case to which to apply Article 135. We consider that this Article of the Regulation should also not be used in the particular interest of a Member State, as might have happened in this case. In addition, the Resolution is biased and obvious the responsibility of other sides in the dispute not to mention the responsibility of Gotovina, Markaa (they have also been charged by the International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia for war crimes) or Croatian paramilitary groups in clashes in Krajina or Vukovar. The resolution also ignores condemning the ultranationalist and hateful statements that have been made in Croatia. PODEMOS condemns any ultranationalist rhetoric that seeks to influence the political agenda of the region and hinders the reconciliation of the people of the former Yugoslavia.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Iraq: the abduction of women and the ill-treatment of them (2014/2971(RSP)).

name: David Campbell Bannerman
text: author. - Mr President, as Chair of the Delegation for Relations with Iraq, I welcome the creation of the new unity government in Iraq and offer my delegation’s unwavering support in helping it to build a fairer, more inclusive society, including one which protects and promotes the rights of women. I condemn without reservation the barbaric killings, kidnappings, rapes, sexual violence and torture committed by ISIS fighters in Iraq. Such actions arguably constitute war crimes and crimes against humanity. These terror attacks against women and girls, committed by the so-called Islamic State and associated groups, are inhuman. They also include targeted attacks against members of the ethnic and religious minorities such as Kurds, Syrians, Christians, Yazidis and Turkmen. The utterly abhorrent use of forced religious conversions, forced marriage, sexual enslavement and gender-based violence by ISIS against women and girls in Iraq is evidence of this. Further steps need be taken to ensure the safety of women and girls ... (The President cut of the speaker)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years ISIS has created a model of systematic violation of every human right, functional to the realization of its perverse project. From this point of view, violence and atrocities are an instrument of propaganda and conquest. More than 5 000 women, prisoners destined for the role of slaves and concubines, have now been at the expense of two former candidates for the Iraqi Parliament in Mosul. There's no remora in front of the girls either. What is the world in which being raped at 12 is everyday normality? Our Sakharov Prize reminded us that the international community has drawn a red line for chemical, nuclear and biological weapons, but rape is cheaper, more accessible and perhaps even more destructive: it destroys the soul and body in one fell swoop. If we in the Eu ropean Union do not really sanction those who finance and support those who use it as a weapon, we too are guilty. Guilty, guilty of uttering only fine words.

name: Alyn Smith
text: author. - Mr President, in the minute available I will do my best to take stock of the dreadful situation in Iraq. It is important that we remember that the intervention in Iraq was a catastrophic failure of judgement and politics on the part of the Western community, and those in favour of intervention should hang their heads in shame. We have tipped Iraq into the abyss and women are suffering, men are suffering, children are suffering, but it is right that in this resolution we take stock of the dreadful situation of women in particular. We have a couple of ideas in the text. There is much in the text to admire: paragraph 12 in particular raises the plight of the LGBT community within Iraq. Paragraph 13 urges Iraq to implement UN Security Council resolution 1325 on women, peace and security. We do have a few ideas within this resolution about how to improve the situation of women in Iraq, but we have a historic responsibility to the women, men and children of Iraq to not walk away and to remain engaged to make their lives better.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank When you hear about northern Iraq, of the thousands of women and children being held in camps, you feel that there has never been a declaration of human rights, a Hague Convention of War or the abolition of slavery. A mad troupe of ideologically blinded extremists is overcoming everything humanity has achieved in terms of civilisational progress. The victims are unimaginable. The girls and women of the Yazidi religious community suffer the most. Thousands are detained, deprived of their personal integrity and humiliated, sexually abused, many of them are forcibly married and sold in slave markets. We cannot accept this! We must help these people. We have proposed this request for urgent procedure because we hope to help the international community to do more to put an end to this barbaric activity.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in two days we have just travelled through two of the main fields of horror that are currently disfiguring the humanity of our world.  Yesterday, Dr. Mukwege moved us all by describing the plight of women in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Today, by addressing violence against women and children in Iraq, we are opening another window on the unacceptable. Kidnappings, slavery, rape, sexual and physical abuse of women and children, not to mention - it is hardly believable - the sale of Yezidi women in the Mosul market.  In the face of such atrocities, it is the least that, in our resolution, we strongly condemn these attacks and call on the Commission and the Member States to take specific measures to remedy the tragic situation experienced by women and children in Iraq and Syria. But, above all, what is essential to me is that we call on the Iraqi government to ratify the Rome Statute so that the International Criminal Court can prosecute the crimes committed by the Islamic State.  (The President cuts off the speaker's microphone)

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: Author. - Mr President, some are suffering a real ordeal, but not only now, when we have the scarecification of the bad state called ISIS, grown after the destabilization of Iraq and Syria. I miss pointing out what happened in 2004, when coalition authority repealed the 1959 Civil Code, the status of the lay family—the most advanced in the entire Middle East—arising from the republican revolution, which granted rights to all women, regardless of their confession, and which was replaced by another that gives religious or tribal leaders the power to regulate family matters through religious laws. I miss the condemnation of all actors, not just isIS: Iraqi government, multinational forces, military and security companies; just as I miss the requirement to eliminate in law any discrimination against women or the LGBT community. And, therefore, I believe that we will only abstain from this resolution.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: author. - Mr President, Dr Mukwege concluded yesterday that women and their bodies have become battlegrounds and instruments of war, sadly not only in Africa. In Iraq, Islamic terrorists have caused in half a year a catastrophic humanitarian crisis and the displacement of hundreds of thousands of people. UN estimates show that, in October, between 5 000 to 7 000 women were held in makeshift centres and sold by Jihadists as sex slaves. We call on the European Commission to take specific action to contribute to guaranteeing women in Iraq the respect of their fundamental rights, safety and freedom from slavery. A special mechanism to assist traumatised women, notably Yazidi women, is needed to offer them medical and psychological assistance. Lastly, that is why the US and the international community’s initiative to fight the Islamic State is to be welcomed.

name: Seán Kelly
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it is hard to read this resolution without becoming disgusted and indeed nauseated to think that in the 21st century we have, as reported here, physical and sexual assault, sexual slavery, trafficking, enforced marriage, women and girls sold in open markets, women and girls bought with price tags for the buyers to choose and negotiate the sale, and then self-appointed courts which condemn women to death on spurious grounds and shoot them in the back of the head. It is time, I think, for a new order at international level. When red lines are crossed as clearly as they are here, there has to be some way of intervening to save the lives and dignity of women and young girls in particular. Also of immediate concern are the winter needs for the recently displaced, and hopefully at European level we can do something about that immediately.

name: Edouard Martin
text: On behalf of the group, Mr. President, the situation of Iraqi women in the self-proclaimed "Islamic State" is dramatic. Parliament must therefore take strong action because there is a serious violation of human rights. Women are subjected to forced marriages and rape, as has been said, enslavement and sale in Mosul markets at a fixed price. If they have clear eyes, they are more expensive, if they are less than fifteen years old, they cost even more. Today, for example, more than 6,500 Yezidi women are missing.  Originally, Daïch members targeted women from religious minorities. Now it is all women who are targeted, beyond the denominations. Women are always the first victims of war, they are a bargaining chip.  With this resolution, the European Parliament sends a strong message of condemnation. This resolution will be sent to all national parliaments, the Council, the European Commission, the relevant national ministries and the High Representative. Let me conclude with a few words about the situation in Europe... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Let us not talk about red lines, because these red lines have long been crossed many times in the context of the so-called Islamic State. But let us also speak as politicians about the significant mistakes that have been made by the Iraqi authorities, and perhaps by us, by the West, because this inaction by the authorities in Baghdad has triggered what is happening at the moment, and in much of Iraq, and in parts of Syria. Of course, we must protest, but the verbal protest cannot end. We need to take very real action as a European Union, because what is happening is images from maybe a few hundred or a thousand years ago, not from the 21st century. I think that the European Parliament should force the Council to act very decisively.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would ask you to give me one minute and ten seconds, as was the case with all my colleagues, precisely because there are no two-speed colleagues in this Chamber. Please give me no time, Mr. President.  I have been in this Parliament for five months and in that time we have adopted resolutions condemning the violence and murder of civilians, children, women, religious minorities. We have adopted resolutions condemning only the results and not the causes and policies that cause them. Today's resolution refers to Iraq. Ladies and gentlemen, we bombed it, we invaded it, we broke it up and now we are asking the chaos we have created to respect human lives and rights. We will leave with our conscience that we have done our duty. Only when we decide to say things by name! A litre of oil: how many lives? An ounce of gold: how many lives? One cubic meter of gas: how many lives? A unit on the Stock Exchange: how many lives? Only when we answer these questions honestly will women and the people of Iraq, Syria, Palestine, Afghanistan, Libya and Ukraine perhaps be worth hoping for. Ladies and gentlemen, there is a long list. And it will grow as long as we continue to feel small and behave accordingly.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Yesterday we heard from Dr Mukwege impressive accounts of the most brutal sexualised violence in Congo. He has repeatedly stressed that these systematic rapes in war are to be seen as a method of warfare. Today we are opposed to another form of warfare, but it is also based on the degradation and destruction of women and girls. As early as September, we received reports of systematic action against Yazidi families. The women and girls are separated from their families, sometimes forced to marry IS fighters, are subjected to sexual violence and traded in slave markets. This sexualized violence is part of the IS strategy, which in turn is part of a brutal campaign to wipe out all traces of non-Arabs and non-Sunni Muslims. I would particularly like to highlight that the International Criminal Court is already considering investigating foreign IS fighters whose countries of origin have ratified the Statute of the Court. But that is not enough. We therefore call on the Iraqi Government to ratify the Rome Statute without delay.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, according to a recent report by Amnesty International, since the Islamic State launched its campaign of systematic ethnic cleansing in northern Iraq, hundreds if not thousands of women and children from the Yazidi minority have been kidnapped. Islamic State militias continue to dominate part of the territory, inflicting terrible torture on the population. One way to avoid them is to convert. But sometimes, especially as far as women are concerned, that is not enough either. Sex slaves given to the best emir or abused for the use and consumption of extremist troops, many of them to escape the ferocity decide to end their lives. The fate of most women kidnapped and held captive by the Islamic State remains unknown. These horrors struggle to cross the borders of territories controlled by Islamist militiamen. These acts of sexual violence complement very serious human rights violations and can be considered both war crimes and crimes against humanity. Gentlemen, we can't just stand by and watch! Let us try and find a way to intervene in the most effective way immediately.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI). -
text: Mr President, Iraq is now at the centre of our debates, but it is above all the responsibility of many of you and your friends.  Twenty-five years ago, George Bush, in the name of oil, made the disastrous decision to engage in excessive hostilities against a secular, united country, despite its community and denominational diversity. Built on an ideology of economic and social development shared by most of the people, Iraq, a country of a multi-millennial civilization, was slipping down the path of total chaos. The consequence is that he has fallen prey to the worst totalitarian ideologies ever encountered.  Many of those who now sit with us participated in the scandalous 2003 operation carried out, this time by the heir Bush. Today, you are hiding behind a condemnation that looks, alas, like an Islamic state established in Iraq and Syria thanks to an American policy of open, implicit or derivative support and with Turkish collusion. However, you continue to want to support groups that carry Islamist ideology in Syria, Libya and elsewhere... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking We are witnessing increased attacks by the self-proclaimed Islamic State on civilians in Iraq. Mass killings, violence, especially against religious minorities, abductions and rapes have led to a humanitarian crisis in the region. The most common victims are women and girls, treated as goods, sold at local fairs or forced into marriages.  Developments in Iraq and the transnational nature of the so-called Islamic State are of great concern to the international community. Any acts of aggression and blatant violations of fundamental rights against religious minorities, especially women, by Islamist militants must be strongly condemned.  As Denis Mukwege, who received this week's Saharov Prize, said, "rape is a cheap, accessible and insanely destructive weapon designed to humiliate and dehumanize women, an extremely cruel form of human destruction." Those responsible must be punished, and in this context we call on the Iraqi authorities to join the International Criminal Court in order to enable the effective prosecution of those responsible for crimes against humanity.

name: Bas Belder (ECR). -
text: For three aspects of unspeakable female suffering, I would like to draw your attention: 1. Development of psychological tools for the countless girls and women who have been raped by ISIS fighters;  2. The dire emergency of more than two million widows, religious "solutions" such as "Mutaa ́a" (a "temporary marriage") or polygamy must really be fought with Iraqi human rights organisations; 3. Finally, very worrying is a recent Iraqi legislation which no longer applies to a minimum age for marriages, but which does set rules for girls aged only nine (!) who want to divorce. Here too, the EU is to fight fighting together with Iraqi human rights organisations.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, this resolution theoretically deals with the kidnapping and ill-treatment of women in Iraq. There is so much to say that women are victims of ill-treatment - the word is weak - not only by Daïch, even if this terrorist group which claims to be a state reaches heights in horror: rape, sexual mutilation, forced marriages, slavery and even, indeed, the sale of women at prices varying according to religion. Christian and Yezidi women are the first victims of this barbarism. The younger women, the more expensive they are. But other resolutions devote only a small part to the general situation in Iraq and, as a bonus, we welcome the intervention of the United States when it has, at the very least, some responsibility in the disorganization of that country.  Again, the way in which human rights emergencies are dealt with in this Chamber is increasingly incomprehensible and ineffective. Really read this resolution, you won't find everything you've just said. Iraqi women... (The President cuts off the speaker's microphone)

name: Giulia Moi (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 25 November, we celebrated International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, but this event is only an empty anniversary given what is happening in Iraq as a result of islamic state terrorists. Yazidi women suffer atrocious violence, abductions, ill-treatment, sexual abuse, forced marriages, conversions and summary executions on a daily basis.  I strongly condemn this violence and call on the Commission and the Member States to take concrete measures to ensure respect for the fundamental rights of these women. I also hope that the Iraqi Government will become a member of the International Criminal Court as soon as possible in order to allow the persecution of war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by the Islamic State.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, I am honoured to be here today, on behalf of High Representative/Vice-President Federica Mogherini, to address an issue of the greatest concern. We are dismayed, like all of you, by the daily reports of atrocities specifically targeting women and girls by ISIS and associated armed groups in Iraq. In particular, there are reports of kidnappings, forced marriage, slavery, sexual abuse and forced conversion which are targeting in particular the most vulnerable people belonging to ethnic and religious minorities. The EU, in a formal conclusion of the Foreign Affairs Council and the European Council, has repeatedly condemned in the strongest terms these brutal acts and calls for the perpetrators of these gross abuses to be held accountable. We therefore strongly support the work of the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, who has launched an investigation on ISIS human rights abuses in Iraq, and the gathering of strong evidence of violations of international human rights and humanitarian law. The Iraqi Government should now ensure the investigation of all human rights abuses to avoid immunity on all sides and send a strong message on the importance of respecting the rule of law. This will require reform of the criminal justice system and the steady consolidation of a culture of respect for human rights. An independent judiciary giving a sense of equality to all citizens before the law will be a crucial element in the process of national reconciliation, which is a matter of urgency. Many human rights violations currently committed in Iraq qualify as crimes against humanity. We therefore strongly recommend to the government to accede to the Rome Statute or at least accept the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court over the current situation and Article 12(3) of the Rome Statute. The EU stands ready to continue supporting the major reforms needed in the area of the rule of law and governance in Iraq. A new programme for an amount of EUR 10 million was started in early September. In addition, the EU is financing a number of assistance programmes more directly related to the protection of women and children, including an ongoing project on establishing a strategy for the protection of women and assisting victims of trafficking and sexual and gender-based violence. On the humanitarian side, the protection of vulnerable groups, including women and children, is a priority for the European Union. The needs of the 2.1 million displaced people and refugees are huge. As the number increased, the EU scaled up its relief efforts. The European Union humanitarian action will include medical and psychosocial assistance to victims of all kinds of violence, including sexual and gender-based violence. Let me conclude by underlining that the EU will continue to support the Government of Iraq in such challenging times and will increase its efforts to alleviate the suffering of innocent civilian victims of a horrific wave of violence. (Applause)

name: Preşedintele. -
text: The debate has been closed. The vote is now taking place. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. The armed group of the so-called Islamic State (Isis) has in recent months been responsible for war crimes including summary killings and mass abductions against members of ethnic and religious minorities, which have seen women as the main victims of these barbarism. They are kidnapped in their thousands by Isis militiamen to be sold or forced to marry jihadists.  These terrorist activities are totally unacceptable. An Amnesty International report openly speaks of 'ethnic cleansing of historic dimensions'. The situation in Iraq far exceeds the threshold of mere concern and requires decisive action by Europe and the entire international community. The Commission must act now: no more proclamations condemning the killings, abductions and rapes committed by the combatants. We need concrete action, we need to take appropriate measures to ensure the safety of women and girls in Iraq, as well as members of religious and ethnic minorities.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – We will vote on the draft resolution, which I, too, support. I would like to draw attention to all the well-known facts, which we do not like to talk about publicly: at the beginning of today's mass deprivation of women and children in Iraq, there is illegal military intervention by some Western states more than a decade ago, in which some European Union states have also participated in various forms. I don't want to stand up for dictators in any way. I would just like to ask whether this intervention has brought more suffering to the Iraqi people than to the overthrown regime. I don't want to moralize or compare the numbers of dead, refugees or tortured before and after the intervention. I would just like to recall the enthusiasm of some politicians, including in the Union, at the time of the intervention. The fiction and enthusiasm that accompany many of our countries' activities today, for example, in Ukraine. Activities promoting violence and taking the future of women and children in other regions of the world. It is right to condemn the so-called 'red tape'. Islamic State for brutality, religious intolerance and terrorism. But it is also worth remembering who drew the current borders in the Middle East and "forgot" about the great Kurdish nation. Who armed, trained, and encouraged various Shiite and Sunni militias in Iraq or in the fight against the government in Syria. Who keeps repeating the same mistakes.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. I unreservedly condemn the barbaric killings and sexual violence perpetrated by ISIS fighters in Iraq and used as a means of propaganda and conquest. The violation of women's rights in the country is untenable and we must denounce this mistreatment. Women and their bodies are an instrument of war, sexual violence is a weapon of devastation aimed at spreading a climate of terror. Women deprived of their integrity suffer serious physical and pissological damage. Everything must be done in our power to combat this systematic delination of human rights and international humanitarian law. We must promote a fairer and more inclusive society that protects and promotes women's rights. ISIS has extremed Sharia law and imposed a totalitarian vision of the Muslim religion by opposing progress and civilisation. We must ensure that, through the ratification of the Rome Statute by the Iraqi Government, those responsible for serious war crimes and crimes against humanity do not go unpunished and are held accountable to the International Criminal Court. Only through the reform of the justice system and the spread of a culture of respect will concrete results be achieved.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. – I will support the European Parliament resolution on Iraq because I condemn the brutal acts of the Islamic State against all persons, and in particular women and children of other religious beliefs or ethnic or national origin. The Islamic State's actions have triggered a humanitarian crisis and displaced large numbers of residents in the region. Defenceless women and children in particular are a more vulnerable group and it is completely unacceptable to abuse, re-education, indoctrinate and sell into slavery.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing.– 25 November marks the International Day against Violence against Women, and I am glad that we have been able to discuss this topic with the Commission here in the European Parliament in recent days. Although statistics on violence against women on the European continent are breathtaking, they are still less menacing than outside the Borders of the European Union. Yesterday, the Sakharov Prize laureate, gynaecologist Denis Mukwege, spoke about the brutal violence faced by women in congo. However, similar atrocities are becoming more frequent in Iraq. Sexual enslaving, forced marriages, trafficking in girls, who are often only 12 years old, and thus humiliation and deprivation of human dignity, must be condemned by the whole world.
