As it is increasingly said, the self-proclaimed Islamic State has nothing to do with Islam, and it would therefore be extremely important that the supreme leaders and authorities of the Islamic religion condemn not only the violence against women, but especially its actors. The Holy Father said here in plenary this week that forgetting God is what prolific violence. If the world is silent, if we remain silent, we will become accomplices to this brutal violence.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Ladies and gentlemen! We shall now proceed to the vote on the motion of censure tabled against the Commission. This vote shall be taken by roll-call vote. Qualified majority voting and two-thirds of the votes cast are required. - Before the vote:

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, under the Rules, people are not supposed to display banners in Parliament, and yet we have a whole array of banners over there. Can you please ask our colleagues to take them down? Otherwise we will all have the same right to display banners.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: In accordance with the Rules of Procedure, flags may not be placed on the table here either. Maybe you can pack your flag. (Applause) (The vote will be held. The President then announces the result of the vote.) 101 votes in favour 461 against 88 abstentions The motion is rejected. (The vote was suspended)

name: Der Präsident. -
text: We shall now proceed to the vote. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, I have an oral amendment of a minor nature to make, on behalf of the ALDE Group and supported by four political groups. While appreciating the work by my colleagues and also the initiative taken by Mr Pieper, I would like to draw your attention to paragraph 11, where today, as it stands, we would express to Parliament that the proposal should not be adopted by the Commission unless accompanied by a positive opinion. I do not think that we can impose on the Commission a statement which would in fact give the independent Impact Assessment Board the possibility to assess what is positive and what is negative. So my proposal would be to leave the text as it is, namely ‘reiterates the view’, and then we would continue ‘that proposals should not be adopted by the Commission unless accompanied by an opinion cleared by the Impact Assessment Board’.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt (S&D). -
text: Mr. President! Excuse me, but the devil of error has crept into our voting list. We wanted to vote in favour of this and not to reject it. We are, of course, in favour of creating the best possible conditions for disabled people.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD). -
text: I do not blame Mr Juncker for being President in a country that is a tax haven. I wish I could live in a country that is a tax haven.  I think his own taxpayers, his own citizens, should blame him for giving tax breaks to selected companies, whereas many smaller companies don't. That's what I blame our government for. In my country, it is even the Finance Minister who receives such tax benefits on his companies, does not pay taxes, while hundreds or thousands of smaller companies pay taxes.  What I blame Mr Juncker for is the hypocrisy that he provided such tax advantages in Luxembourg and is now the President of the European Commission, who blames others for granting such advantages.  When I voted to trust this Commission, the question for me was, did he win my trust from the beginning, when his Commission was created? I voted against this Commission and my confidence ... (removed the speaker's word)

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, it is important that we take a strong line on tax avoidance. It is unacceptable that large corporations are getting away with using facilities paid for by citizens without contributing their fair share in return because certain countries are exploiting loopholes in legislation. President Juncker has serious questions to answer about this and we will make sure he does. But, instead of bringing down the Commission, we should make it tackle the issue head-on. That would truly be in the interests of our citizens. I strongly doubt that it was the interests of our citizens which guided the instigators of this motion for resolution in the first place. I wonder: might they just be after a prolonged inquiry that is not necessarily the best way to tackle this issue and just keeps them in the news? That is why I voted against this motion.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE). -
text: I voted against censure. I consider this proposal by the far right to be populist. It is a proposal that will not contribute to a good view of the European Union and I am glad that it has received so little support. Mr Juncker and his team must have a chance to show in the coming period that the Commission will be able to solve the problems of the European Union and that it will also address tax issues. I personally believe that the problem of tax havens is not a legislative problem, for some it can be an ethical problem. I believe that if we want to tackle tax havens, then we should address them not by further administrative tightening of conditions, but rather by reducing taxes across Europe. We will try to take steps so that companies do not have to search for tax havens.  Low taxes are the solution so that tax havens in Europe do not arise in the future. I am not in a good place for the issue of tax policy to be taken away from the Member States.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: Thank you very much! As a criminal lawyer, I've made it clear that there's a thief who regularly steals, and then when he gets caught, he gets offended and says that stealing is actually so badly regulated in the penal code. There's the one who takes foreign things from someone else... There's no detail on what a foreign thing is, what it is to take it, and besides, people don't take enough care of their property. The person is being celebrated and is thought to be such an expert in theft that he should be appointed president of the National Crime Prevention Council. I think that something like this has happened to Mr Juncker, which is why I supported the motion to remove him or declare him unfit. For this role, I have proposed to support the motion of censure.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI). -
text: Mr President, thank you for the floor. The rejection of the motion of censure against the Commission is a disgrace to the parliamentary majority. Yes, Mr Juncker's transgression is that, during his prime ministership and finance ministership, he made Luxembourg a tax haven, thereby withdrawing billions of euros from the countries, the countries in which these companies actually operate. At the same time, the shame belongs to this majority. This is the majority that has failed to make a substantive argument in favour of Mr Juncker. In part, they talked about personally attacking the submitters, and partly the Socialists stated what a complication it would be if a new Commission had to be elected. You have lost all moral ground for both Parliament and the Commission to act as defenders of so-called European values and to impose sanctions.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, we have not seen anything good in this House today. We have seen how those who defend tax havens, such as the City of London, or those who hold anti-human rights stances presented a motion of censure. But we have seen something even sadder: the Socialists in this House, and in particular the Spanish Socialists, had the opportunity to support the motion of censure that we wanted to push against the person responsible for tax havens and against the person responsible for austerity policies that harm European citizens. Today the Spanish Socialists have shown again that they have a hard time moving from words to deeds. They were the ones who supported this Commission and they are the ones who have shown this week that they are with Juncker and with the tax havens. Bad news for democracy in our country and in Europe.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Eurosceptics and the extreme right, who have tabled the motion of censure against Jean-Claude Juncker, are in fact carrying exactly the same logics as they claim to be fighting. They are those of contempt for a general European interest in favour of national selfishness and the choices of struggle and competition between states.  Like others, Jean-Claude Juncker has indeed been the architect of an scandalous system in which tax havens are organised within the Union, which consists of diverting revenues solely for the benefit of a few shareholders or a few large groups and financial institutions. This then justifies austerity policies, the decline of social programmes in the poorest countries and the refusal of investments of general interest. But we must refuse to hold hands with nationalism on the one hand and injustice on the other. So, in fact, abstention is necessary.  This system, implemented in Luxembourg and elsewhere, which may seem legal in the eyes of some is in fact an illegitimate and inequitous system. We will only come out of it more Europe and less competition to defend the general European interest.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I voted against Mr Juncker’s appointment and I voted against his Commission. I was unusual, I think, only in being open in voting against him; you could not find anyone who was privately in favour of him. His views are out of step with Europe. It was like a shade, a spectre from the 1950s rattling its chain, still talking about the harmonisation of minimum wages and fiscal policy and all the rest of it. Nonetheless he is entitled, as anyone else, to the presumption of innocence. An investigation has just been launched and has not concluded. This motion is badly timed, badly conceived, and badly drafted. I was not able to support it because, of all the reasons that I could give for wanting to get rid of Mr Juncker, the fact that he presided over a low tax regime is not one of them, unless he has been found to have done something illegal. And this is a point that my colleagues on the left seem to have missed completely. It is not a crime to cut your taxes, and the solution to a country having lower taxes than yours is not to try and legislate, to export your costs to them – it is to cut your own taxes.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr President, as you know, I have voted against Juncker's candidacy for the post of President of the Commission because, as a representative of the old political world of Europe and for years President of the Eurogroup, he is responsible for the memoranda, for the humanitarian crisis in Greece and for the shameful debt that has been put on the backs of the Greek people. Junckergate's revelation now makes it doubly necessary to remove Mr Juncker. I therefore voted in favour of the motion of censure against the Commission put forward by Mr Zanni and the Five Star Movement in order to get rid of Juncker and his company. The fact that the motion of censure was also signed by members of the far right, with whom, as we know, we are opposite and divides us in an abyss on a political and ideological level, cannot be an alibi for not voting in favour of the motion of censure, since the major issue is the expulsion of Juncker. After all, everyone's political path is well known and recorded and therefore there are no misunderstandings. Everything else is evasive and consolidates Juncker into the Presidency of the Commission.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! Politics starts with looking at reality. If we do not like reality, we should change it through political legislation. We do not like what is happening with national tax policy at the moment, and I hope we will agree on that. We must then, of course, harmonise tax policy. I would therefore like the Commission to work very quickly and without delay on this very issue. That is why the Commission must remain operational, which is why I voted against the motion of censure. I am also curious to see how the Member States behave. I hope that we will use the momentum that has now been created in Europe – harmonisation of tax policy – so that the Member States too can finally give up their opposition and we can harmonise tax policy. I repeat: the Commission must start this quickly, it must remain operational. That is why a motion of censure is neither helpful nor effective. It is simply populist.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR). -
text: Mr. President! I too voted today in favour of the motion of censure, thus against Mr Juncker and his Commission. I would have liked to have voted for a further independent investigation into the allegations, but that is obviously not in the interests of the majority of this House, which wants to conduct an independent investigation into the allegations. That is why the only thing that has been put to the vote now is the motion of censure, yes or no. This is a purely factual question, it is non-ideological and not to judge on the right/left: do we support this Commission or do we not support this Commission? We in the Alternative for Germany have already spoken out against it very clearly on two occasions. We did not vote for Mr Juncker as President of the Commission and we did not vote for the Commission as a whole. That is why it is exclusively logical to take another decision on this issue, which is to say in favour of the motion of censure, in the same way, even in a completely non-ideological manner. As I said, this is not right or left, but simply clear expertise.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Today I voted against the Juncker Commission for all the reasons set out in the motion of censure that I signed with the spokesmen of the 5 Star Movement and 75 other Members, but also because of my own experience in this Parliament's Committee on the Environment. Here I represent as coordinator the Europe Group for Freedom and Direct Democracy and all policies relating to the environment, health and food safety are discussed there. Well, on these issues, the Commissioners-designate do not intend to abandon the use of fossil sources and fissile sources, with the support of those in Italy who want to double these oil extractions and their harmful impact on the health of citizens. They are therefore not committed to actually reducing harmful emissions from companies in a united Europe. On the other hand, the new college chaired by Juncker also wants to eliminate those few promising legislative initiatives, such as the one prohibiting the use of non-recyclable plastic bags or those that go in the direction of penalising.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI). -
text: Mr President, I naturally voted against the motion of censure against Mr Juncker, not out of personal animosity against him, but for all the reasons that justify the mistrust that one can have towards him.  I would just like to give an overview of Mr Juncker's rhetoric. During the debate on tax evasion that he encouraged in Luxembourg, I introduced him as Minister for Economy and Finance and I also recalled that in the event of a scandal for which he was perhaps not personally responsible, that of the Luxembourg secret services, he had been forced to resign.  Mr Juncker rebuffed both statements, saying: "I have never been in charge of the economy" - playing on words - "and I have never resigned, you better inform yourself before speaking". So I have inquired and I see that Mr Juncker was 20 years Minister for Labour, Employment, Treasury and Finance, but it still has to do with the economy, and that he was Prime Minister for eighteen years. As for his resignation, after the scandal, he was forced to call early elections and Xavier Bettel succeeded him. I guess he had to resign in the meantime.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. Today, 27 November 2014, my colleagues renewed their confidence in the commission as a whole and its President Jean-Claude Juncker. We in the 5-star Movement tabled the motion of censure because we do not believe that Either Juncker or the Commission in its entirety is capable of pursuing the interests of European citizens. The Lux Leaks scandal has only given more circulation to news that was already known. It is nothing new that states such as Luxembourg, Austria, Belgium and Ireland, exercising their fiscal sovereignty, have practised forms of tax competition which have favoured the large multinationals and created damage estimated at EUR 1 000 billion. These attitudes are at odds with the interests of the EU and its citizens and the spirit of European solidarity. Apart from what Juncker has said, what matters is action and these do not lay in his favour, as does his past and that of Commissioners such as Hill and Cañete. The citizens of Europe are tired of fine words and promises and are calling for radical change! For all these reasons, my colleagues in the 5-star Movement and I have wholely voted for this motion of censure.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. - We voted against the motion of censure of Europhobes and extremists, although the Socialists do not support Mr Juncker to be President of the European Commission. However, we were the first to ask you to appear in the European Parliament and to present an action plan against tax evasion and avoidance across Europe. In addition, an investigation into tax policy in Luxembourg is open. But what the Socialists are not going to do is fall into the trap of Europhobes and extremists to seize any opportunity to create chaos. We're not going to give them wings, and we're not going to align with Marine Le Pen and the extremists in their ends. We ask for explanations and they have been given. We call for reaction measures and they have been put in place. And we're asking for research and it's developing. Citizens today feel let down and deceived to learn that big businesses evade taxes while they are still being demanded of sacrifices. The Spanish Socialists will continue to work to end both.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Juncker and his Commission must be censured. Our group, GUE/NGL, proposed a motion of censure which unfortunately did not succeed, as neither the Greens nor the S&D Group agreed to sign it, implicitly supporting Juncker. We cannot sign in favour of this motion of censure that is presented to us because it has been proposed by the far right, which seeks only to take advantage of the climate that has been created in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, without making any criticism of the system that Juncker represents. That's why I abstained.

name: Louis Aliot (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the motion of censure against the European Commission. Mr Juncker, President of the Commission, is directly implicated today in the "LuxLeaks" case. While Mr Juncker led his country between 1995 and 2013, Luxembourg has become a tax haven. More than 300 multinationals have thus been able to evade the taxation of countries producing wealth through tax contracts, techniques based on the artificial location of patents, transfer prices distorted between subsidiaries, and other financial artifices.  Wealthy multinationals have been able to save in front of Mr Juncker's complacent gaze colossal sums by passing through the Grand Duchy hundreds of billions of dollars at the expense of taxpayers in other European countries, French citizens in the lead, who must pay more taxes to compensate for the leakage of tax revenues organized by Luxembourg. I therefore believe that it is imperative to act and to overthrow the Commission and Mr Juncker by voting in force to vote for the motion of censure.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. - The European Commission has been in office for only one month. In this context, the present motion of censure by the anti-European and far-right Members is to be understood as a destructive manoeuvre aimed at damaging the European institutions. However, the topicality of the tax affair in Luxembourg has once again highlighted the need for a European response to the 'tax ruling' practised by many Member States. Luxembourg legislation, which is the focus of interest, is legal, but it is not legitimate. The creation of tax justice must be a priority at European level, into which the Commission must kneel honestly and unreservedly.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. - It was important to vote in the public interest, rather than in the interests of the political establishment. Luxleaks must not be swept under the carpet.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. "I logically voted in favour of this motion of censure, of which I was a co-signer. Jean-Claude Juncker's overwhelming responsibility in the so-called "LuxLeaks" affair should have led the President of the European Commission to resign. Since he did not have that courage, we suggested to our colleagues that he be forced to do so. Indeed, Mr Juncker, president of an institution whose legitimacy we also dispute, now claims to fight against tax evasion, even though he has skilfully encouraged it for years for the benefit of Luxembourg and multinationals... and to the detriment of other Member States, starting with France.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. - I voted against the motion of censure against the European Commission which had been tabled by the Europhobes and the extreme right in the continuation of the so-called "Luxleaks" dossier. Rather than resigning, I prefer quick and concrete results in terms of employment and taxation.  The resignation of the Commission would have delayed by several months the much-needed effort we need in terms of economic recovery and employment.  It would also have delayed the commission's immediate action on tax transparency and harmonisation at European level.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted against the motion of censure because doing so in favour involves supporting groups working for non-Europe from the institution itself. With this motion, its aim is not to improve the European project, but to help put an end to it. On the other hand, our group has chosen the need for as independent an investigation as possible to clarify whether the tax benefits are legal or not and whether Juncker has any liability in relation to this matter. In the event that you have any responsibility, we will demand, as we have announced, the corresponding political consequences.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The LuxLeaks case has shown that powerful corporate tax evasion schemes, such as the so-called tax ruling practice, involve the creation of a subsidiary or holding company (a company itself a shareholder of other companies) in Luxembourg. Generally, it is a simple office with little or no staff. Then, tax arrangements are made: this ranges from the simple rebate on the VAT rate to the most complicated arrangements such as that of the "patent niche". In some cases, the company is completely exempt from tax, such as Ikea. All this to allow 340 multinationals to evade a large part of their taxes, especially in France and Europe. During this research period (2002-2010), Mr Juncker was Prime Minister of Luxembourg. Today, Mr Juncker is President of the European Commission, supported by a grand left-right-centre-green coalition, and it is not acceptable for a person responsible for setting up this system to be retained in this post. That is why I signed this motion of censure and, of course, I voted in favour.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I supported this motion of no confidence first with my signature for its presentation and then with a vote in favour. If today, as President of the new European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker preaches ethics and morality in European finance, let us not forget that when he was Prime Minister of Luxembourg he ran a system that, by facilitating banks and multinationals, took millions of euros of taxes from the coffers of the Member States. These are the facts, all the rhetoric that will be used to cover them, it will not erase them. The new European Commission no longer has any credibility.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. - I've put down my voice. Jean Claude Juncker's role in Luxleaks is not primarily about whether Luxembourg's systematised tax avoidance scheme is illegal or not. The big question is whether one of the chief executives of this type of policy should be entrusted with one of the most powerful political posts in the EU. I don't think so. The GUE/NGL initiated the first motion of censure against Juncker. It was based on a political criticism of austerity policies, forced privatisations and tax avoidance policies for big companies. Unfortunately, members of both the Green Group and S&D declined to sign, so the required 76 names were not met.  In doing so, the democratic parties also left the "walk over" to the extreme right, which took advantage of the situation and put forward its own motion of censure. The absence of political accountability, and congestion in the middle of the political landscape, gives right-wing populism fertile ground. The extreme right's motion of censure is based on completely different premises. They do not require a change of political direction with regard to tax avoidance policy or other fundamental points of the market-liberal approach. Moreover, their fundamental attitudes in the view of human rights are appalling.  That's why I choose to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. " We voted against the motion of censure of Europhobes and extremists, although the Socialists do not support Mr Juncker to be President of the European Commission. However, we were the first to ask you to appear in the European Parliament and to present an action plan against tax evasion and avoidance across Europe. In addition, an investigation into tax policy in Luxembourg is open. But what the Socialists are not going to do is fall into the trap of Europhobes and extremists to seize any opportunity to create chaos. We're not going to give them wings, and we're not going to align with Marine Le Pen and the extremists in their ends. We ask for explanations and they have been given. We call for reaction measures and they have been put in place. And we're asking for research and it's developing. Citizens today feel let down and deceived to learn that big businesses evade taxes while they are still being demanded of sacrifices. The Spanish Socialists will continue to work to end both.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. " The hearings of the Commissioners-designate could only cause concern. Some members of the Commission, of dubious competence or probity, owe their portfolios only to small arrangements between socialists and conservatives. Juncker said he was not "a friend of multinationals" when he was the head of a government whose administration encouraged minimal tax optimisation, partly to the detriment of the French taxpayer. Some observers even point out that Luxembourg could be just one link in a larger chain of tax evasion. The practices covered by the Luxembourg government led by Mr Juncker are at least ethically reprehensible. He dares to argue their legality. But where's the moral? I therefore vote in support of the motion of censure against the European Commission.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: In writing. "I rejected the motion of censure against the Commission because I believe that the President of the Commission must first defend himself before he is presumed guilty.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - President Juncker successfully passed the test of mistrust raised by the motion of censure on his cabinet, following alleged allegations of concessions to the payment of taxes offered to certain corporations during his time in charge of the Luxembourg executive. I have spoken out against the motion of censure in the first place, because, through my profession as a jurist, I understand that any possible accusation must above all be substantiated and investigated as such by the competent bodies. Secondly, I voted against it, because I am convinced of the need for a stable framework for the functioning of the Community institutions. Trust in the EU institutions is essential, any contrary effect can be economically disastrous, upsetting financial markets and increasing uncertainty among European citizens. Current issues such as the conflict in Ukraine, The threats of Islamic State, as well as the internal challenges of implementing the package for jobs, growth and investment need a stable climate at European level. The overwhelming vote against, by more than 61%, confirms the high level of confidence given to the Juncker Commission in the European Parliament.  Last but not least, the rejection of the no-confidence motion has once again demonstrated that Parliament remains united in the face of the destructive intentions constantly promoted by eurosceptic parties.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour. Juncker is not credible; the mechanisms aimed at tax evasion when he was prime minister aimed to increase the income of industrial groups and banking institutions. How boldly do you now propose to be a champion against the growth crisis in Europe?

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - The motion of censure tabled by the European Group on Freedom and Direct Democracy (EFDD) against Mr Juncker responds to the news revealed two weeks ago about a controversial fiscal framework that allows hundreds of multinationals to settle in Luxembourg and reduce their taxation to testimonial levels during the time juncker was Prime Minister. Not having supported Mr Juncker to be the President of the Commission and condemning these such socially unfair actions, the support of this motion by those who do not have as a priority interest to work definitively for the fight against tax evasion and evasion, as well as to harmonise taxation in Europe, but quite the opposite, to question the EU itself and the need to move towards more EU is not justified. However, any action in this regard is reprehensible by anyone, but especially by those who have had high responsibilities, especially when large economic adjustments were applied to 'standing' citizenship. It would therefore be desirable that even beyond the possible legality of these proceedings, the lack of ethical justification requires explanations and an investigation.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — An overwhelming majority of MEPs voted against the motion of censure tabled against the new European Commission by the Europhobes of this Assembly. I voted against it. Eurosceptics are bogging down legislative work. Their attempt, however, was counterproductive. Indeed, Jean-Claude Juncker's Commission received more support than at his inauguration.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted against this motion of censure today. I do not think it would be useful to show any tenacity, even at an early stage, to demonstrate the full resilience, reliability, efficiency and reliability of juncker-led COMMISSION communities and, therefore, I will not make any obstacles to the launch of the next investment plan, which is expected to mobilise EUR 315 billion.  I cannot concede anything to Euroscepticism and Europhobia. I am confident that Jean Claude Juncker will be able to demonstrate, beyond all expectations, a fully Pro-European vision, by curbing first-hand, by means of serious regulatory interventions, the phenomenon of companies that make profits and do not pay taxes and multinationals that make private agreements with certain countries.  It will be able to undertake, firmly, as it is asked, a determined fight against tax evasion and, immediately, to initiate real tax harmonisation of the Member States, capable of strengthening economic unity and increasing transparency, including through the publication of the budgets of multinationals. Finally, I would like to add my voice to those who, out of transparency and equality, are waiting for the European Commission, through Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager, to be independent, to make a rapid investigation and to provide concrete answers on the Grand Duchy.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion of censure against the European Commission because I consider it unacceptable that an already unelected democratically elected body can also afford to stay above the laws it imposes on the citizens of the EU Member States. Mr. Junker, because he is suspected of having promoted tax evasion, is now tainted by this case and therefore cannot remain legitimately at the head of an institution that continues to say to citizens "do what I say, not what I do!". I also welcome this initiative, which brought together all the patriots in Parliament, beyond political differences.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. — I have decided not to lend my support to a motion spearheaded by the far-right, and have instead co-signed a proposal to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate breaches of EU law in relation to tax rulings issued by Member States. Aggressive tax planning by multinational corporations has reached such a scale that its impact on EU Member States’ public finances is not just a matter of fairness and justice. It actually jeopardises our very ability to fund and pursue public policy necessary to meet our citizens’ needs. Schemes that allow big companies to get away with paying fractions of 1% in tax are unacceptable and insulting to everyone who works for a salary and pays income tax. Member States increasingly coordinate budgetary discipline and pro-market structural reforms with their EU partners, yet tackling extreme forms of tax competition remains taboo. In this context, the very least we can do is shed light on these practices and make sure that the rules we have are enforced in the first place.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Commission has faced a censure motion in the European Parliament after right-wing, and far-right Eurosceptic lawmakers united to put this motion on the table for plenary. A lack of support for the censure motion from most other parties always made it unlikely that a two-third majority required to force the Commission from office would be achieved. Instead we had nothing more than the populist parties trying to do what is popular rather than what is right. They have proven once again that they are more interested in being celebrates than lawmakers, looking to make headlines not laws. A headline does not provide help to the unemployed youth of Europe who are seeking jobs, action does, and initiatives do. So I say to those populist parties who cherish headlines, why not walk the walk, rather than talk the talk.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I too voted in favour of Mr Juncker. Such a motion of censure at the beginning of its term of office and with the reasons given is a real irresponsible act towards European citizens and businesses. I very much hope that this issue will be used as an opportunity to take a big step towards harmonising the tax systems of the 28 countries. No one before Juncker had shown such determination to affirm the need for the development of a fiscal union. The situation, as it is today, with 28 tax systems competing fiercely with each other, as well as being counterproductive, cannot work in the long term because it harms some Member States in favour of others. I have asked the Council and the Commission to take concrete action immediately to move - each within the scope of its own competences - towards harmonising the tax systems of the 28 on the path indicated by Juncker. It is time to be ambitious and courageous. We must not miss the opportunity to turn these ideas put forward by the President of the Commission into political proposals in the interests of all 500 million European citizens. In this way, we will take another important step towards political integration, which can no longer be delayed, in order to emerge from the crisis.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Commission should be allowed to do its job and not be made a player in a partisan political game. Furthermore, one cannot forget that tax issues are exclusively within the competence of the Member States.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. I can only endorse and vote in favour of this resolution on the motion of no confidence in the European Commission. It should be pointed out that aggressive tax avoidance was approved by the Luxembourg tax authority at a time when the new Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker was Prime Minister of the Grand Duchy. Tax avoidance agreements concluded between companies and the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg can raise moral and ethical issues for the millions of citizens currently facing the worst economic crisis of modern times. I believe that a person responsible for the creation, implementation, governance and monitoring of these aggressive tax evasion policies does not have the credibility to serve citizens as President of the European Commission.  For all these reasons and for many others, I cannot trust Jean-Claude Juncker.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Juncker and his Commission must be censured. Our group, GUE/NGL, proposed a motion of censure which unfortunately did not succeed, as neither the Greens nor the S&D Group agreed to sign it, implicitly supporting Juncker. We cannot sign in favour of this motion of censure that is presented to us because it has been proposed by the far right, which seeks only to take advantage of the climate that has been created in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, without making any criticism of the system that Juncker represents. That's why I abstained.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. – Today I voted for the Juncker-led Commission, because political stability should be maintained. However I do not agree with Mr Juncker’s view expressed during the Monday plenary debate that we could avoid the reoccurrence of the current situation only if we introduce tax harmonisation in the EU. I am of the view that tax harmonisation would not solve the problem. What is more, it would only worsen the overall situation. In my opinion, the key is not to provide exceptions and to prevent the possibility of trickery, which is not by any means equal to tax harmonisation. Introducing EU tax harmonisation would lead to the end of internal competition, which would encumber the situation of those Member States behind the EU average. It would significantly reduce their ability to contribute to their own economic development and in the end it would create new burdens for the EU. If Member States are not able to self-develop because their advantages from lower tax rates are eliminated by tax harmonisation, sooner or later it will be the EU who will finance their development through its funds. We should also bear in mind that in those Member States that apply lower tax rates wages and the standard of living are often also lower.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against the motion of censure on the Juncker Commission tabled by some of my colleagues. I voted against because it would have been irresponsible to sink the new European Commission the day after the presentation of the Juncker investment plan. With all its limitations, I believe that the announcement of this plan constitutes a first but significant and symbolic change of direction for Europe in economic policies with the overcoming of austerity alone and towards a new policy of growth and employment, as strongly requested by the Delegation of the Democratic Party and the Group of the Party of European Democrats. Level of guard against the LuxLeak case: we await the results of the investigations announced by Juncker himself in the Chamber, which we want rigorous and thorough. Furthermore, over and above any illegality profiles, we will continue to call loudly for a real breakthrough in European fiscal policies in order to finally overcome a situation of de facto fiscal dumping within the European market that is no longer tolerable in a Europe that wants to regain international credibility and competitiveness.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. - European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker and the newly formed College of Commissioners have been elected on a clear agenda. They must be in a position to work to best meet the expectations of European citizens affected by the crisis. As such, Mr Juncker has just presented an investment plan for Europe that will eventually mobilise EUR 315 billion to finance strategic growth projects, create jobs and adapt our economies to the challenges of the 21st century. Less than a month ago, I supported the College of Commissioners on that basis. This support remains intact. I therefore voted against this motion of censure.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I rejected this motion of censure against the European Commission proposed by the EFDD group chaired by Nigel Farage and supported by unregistered MEPs. By tabling this motion of censure, these MEPs wanted to punish Jean-Claude Juncker after the revelations about the tax evasion system put in place in Luxembourg when he was Prime Minister. The European Commission has launched an investigation into the tax practices of several countries, including Luxembourg. Let's wait for the results of the investigation.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. — As we go through an economic and political crisis, we need, more than ever, to be in order, to launch the necessary reforms and to have an innovative European Commission, the populist and Eurosceptic MEPs in the European Parliament have found nothing better than to try to destabilise the newly elected European Commission by a motion of censure for purely political reasons and in search of media visibility. So I voted against this motion of no confidence.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The compromise of the President of the Commission in Luxembourg's fiscal opacity is more than enough to justify this motion of censure which will relieve the peoples of Europe. Indeed, it seems scandalous that some countries do not participate in the same way as others in the effort imposed on the Member States. This inequality is unfair and indecent. The European Union is indeed a Soviet heir to it where "all men are equal but some are more equal than others," as Georges Orwell wrote.  What confidence could we have in Mr Juncker at the head of the European Union, when he is not being transparent about his political record in Luxembourg? It is also the question of Mr Moscovici's record that supports this motion of censure. The former French minister has participated in the ruin of my homeland, France, and is now fleeing to Brussels to escape the wrath of my compatriots. We say to this Commission that you cannot escape the duty of responsibility before the people.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — We are voting in favour because the revelations have simply come to confirm what we already thought, namely that Juncker is unfit to be President of the Commission. Especially now, under the weight of the scandal and the billions of euros indirectly lost to the income of the other Member States, we believe that Mr. Juncker should have already resigned on his own.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against the motion of censure on Thursday 27 November. The motion was an attempt by the far-right groups in the European Parliament to oust Juncker with no regard to a possible change in practices or a call for a thorough investigation. My group in the parliament have outlined a comprehensive plan to tackle the pervasive problem of large-scale tax avoidance, rather than looking for a scapegoat. I believe this approach is most productive, and in the best interests of my constituents in Wales.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. " We voted against the motion of censure of Europhobes and extremists, although the Socialists do not support Mr Juncker to be President of the European Commission. However, we were the first to ask you to appear in the European Parliament and to present an action plan against tax evasion and avoidance across Europe. In addition, an investigation into tax policy in Luxembourg is open. But what the Socialists are not going to do is fall into the trap of Europhobes and extremists to seize any opportunity to create chaos. We're not going to give them wings, and we're not going to align with Marine Le Pen and the extremists in their ends. We ask for explanations and they have been given. We call for reaction measures and they have been put in place. And we're asking for research and it's developing. Citizens today feel let down and deceived to learn that big businesses evade taxes while they are still being demanded of sacrifices. The Spanish Socialists will continue to work to end both.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The CFP and its group, the GUE/NGL, have done their best to give political and institutional expression in the European Parliament to the just indignation and social censorship sparked by the revelation of the scandal, involving the current President of the European Commission, of escaping the payment of taxes by hundreds of multinationals. To this end, the GUE/NGL prepared a motion of censure, which ultimately did not gather the minimum number of signatures to be discussed. It was the option of the green, social democrat and liberal groups not to endorse the GUE/NGL motion, thus making it impossible to discuss and vote. There is no question that the European Commission and its president deserve to be censured. But we cannot support or whiten the opportunism of the far right in this process. Having gathered enough signatures, they submitted the motion of censure now voted. They did so, however, in such terms that, pointing the finger at Juncker and the Commission, they whiten the system in which they both are and represent. Not a word is said about tax havens or the deregulation of the financial system – essential parts of the gear set up to exempt multinationals from their tax obligations. In fact, several of the signatories of this motion are well-known proponents of this same gear. Reasons for abstaining.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. - Mr President-elect of the European Commission was Prime Minister of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg during the huge scandal, when Member States lost billions of euros through tax evasion, through tax avoidance in Luxembourg, which makes him directly responsible for the situation that has arisen. The question is therefore whether he is competent to represent the people of the European Union and what his trust in citizens is. An independent commission needs to be set up to thoroughly investigate the 'Lux Leaks' case, which casts unfavourable suspicions on the new European Commission when it was created.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I am certainly voting in favour of the motion of censure on the Commission. As has been said several times, this Commission represents the continuation of a failed European policy unfortunately supported by the vast majority of Members.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting in favour of the motion of censure against the Commission. The revelations came simply to confirm what I already thought Juncker was unfit to be President of the Commission. Especially now, under the weight of the scandal and the billions of euros that were indirectly lost to the income of the other Member States, we believe that Mr. Juncker should have already resigned on his own.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted against the motion of censure tabled by far-right MEPs against the European Commission chaired by President Juncker. They will never find me voting alongside those who are only trying to destroy the political project that has given Europe its greatest time of peace and prosperity. I have complete confidence in the team that forms the current College of Commissioners and its President. The European Union must improve the fiscal practices of its Member States, move promptly towards greater harmonisation and fiscal convergence. However, I believe that the motion of censure presented has only one objective: to discredit and destroy the institutions of the European Union.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this motion of censure tabled in the wake of the Luxembourg leaks scandal, a vast system of tax evasion put in place by Luxembourg for its benefit and that of multinationals, to the detriment of European states, including France. Mr Junker, Prime Minister of Luxembourg from 1995 to 2013, could not ignore the existence of this unfair and unfair system. It is unthinkable that the European Union could effectively combat tax evasion with Mr Junker as President of the Commission. The motion also aimed to put each member of Parliament in front of their responsibilities, by counting those who are genuinely opposed to questionable financial and fiscal practices and those who are only in the position. Mission accomplished.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — We need urgent action to tackle tax fraud, tax evasion and tax avoidance but this motion is not the way forward.  Commission President Juncker still has questions to answer on how he will bring forward and enact proposals to crack down on tax avoidance across Europe. People are angry about legal loopholes and a lack of cooperation between European countries which mean that some people and corporations are still not paying their fair share in tax.  We need urgent action to tackle these problems, but this resolution does nothing to tackle tax avoidance. We need to agree that all multinational companies should be compelled to report what they earn, where they earn it and how much tax they pay. We need a common approach to tackle the use of tax havens once and for all and a blacklist of those companies that are engaging in tax fraud.  This resolution does not address these issues and I cannot support such a motion.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. - We voted against the motion of censure of Europhobes and extremists, although the Socialists do not support Mr Juncker to be President of the European Commission. However, we were the first to ask you to appear in the European Parliament and to present an action plan against tax evasion and avoidance across Europe. In addition, an investigation into tax policy in Luxembourg is open.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against this motion of censure tabled by a group of elected representatives that nothing unites except their hatred of European integration. It was a manoeuvre that was only intended to give publicity to Europhobes of all stripes and which wastes us precious time that we would gain from using more on much more crucial subjects such as jobs and growth.  If the objective of these elected officials is really to fight tax evasion, this strategy here is completely sterile. Much more, we need to advocate for increased cooperation in the automatic exchange of information on early tax decisions and to demand tax harmonisation rather than the tax competition that is taking place today. But it is clear that this is certainly not the intention of the authors of this motion. This motion of censure is therefore irrelevant.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. " We voted against the motion of censure of Europhobes and extremists, although the Socialists do not support Mr Juncker to be President of the European Commission. However, we were the first to ask you to appear in the European Parliament and to present an action plan against tax evasion and avoidance across Europe. In addition, an investigation into tax policy in Luxembourg is open. But what the Socialists are not going to do is fall into the trap of Europhobes and extremists to seize any opportunity to create chaos. We're not going to give them wings, and we're not going to align with Marine Le Pen and the extremists in their ends. We ask for explanations and they have been given. We call for reaction measures and they have been put in place. And we're asking for research and it's developing. Citizens today feel let down and deceived to learn that big businesses evade taxes while they are still being demanded of sacrifices. The Spanish Socialists will continue to work to end both.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. — I only voted 'long teeth' in voting to censure, because I fundamentally reject similarities with the far-right of Parliament. Here are the reasons: 1. Voting to the motion of censure is consistent, because I had already voted against the Commission before because of what I consider to be inappropriate persons Moscovici, Katainen and Juncker! 2. Never would the so-called 'leading candidate Juncker' have received such approval from the EPP from the electorate if they had been informed of the scandalous tax incidents in Luxembourg in good time before the European elections and not immediately after the Commission's confirmation. 3. On a proposal from the AfD, the ECR Group had tabled a more appropriate motion for a resolution than the motion of censure now tabled by the 'right-wing'. Not even the President of the Commission wanted this ("If things get serious, you have to lie!") Support Jean-Claude Juncker in unwavering loyalty to a grand coalition of Socialists and EPP (CDU/CSU). 4. In Berlin, the Grand Coalition is loudly opposed to the sly tax policy of its President of the Commission from his time in Luxembourg, and in Strasbourg it quietly lets him go through everything. It goes without saying that this vote is not a sign of the ongoing cooperation with the far-right of Parliament. Rather, it is a self-defence measure against the schizophrenic policies of the eu-romantic majority of Parliament.

name: Hölvényi György (PPE)
text: Writing. — We have made it clear today, by a large majority, that the European Parliament stands by the European Commission and the reform programme they want to launch. Eurosceptics' attempt to destabilise the EU institutions has failed. The motion of censure they tabled was an attack not only on the European Commission, but on the european Union as a whole, which was averted by the cooperation of several large factions, including the European People's Party. An effective and strong European institutional system is needed in order for the Union to respond adequately to the challenges it faces. A strong Commission that effectively solves problems is an essential element of this institutional system.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. "This motion of censure is, in my view, a demonstration of the worst demagoguery that exists. To come back from old issues when President Juncker has already explained himself and has pledged to fight tax evasion, for which we are waiting for concrete proposals, is to try to undermine the functioning of Europe and to mark a political coup to satisfy its electorate. It also hurts European citizens tired of gutter policy and lacks vision for Europe and its country.  Today, the priority is employment, it is purchasing power, it is to restore confidence to citizens and businesses, it is to propose a future for the continent and for France.  So let's get to work and don't waste any more time because the rest of the world is not waiting for us. You can count on my determination to judge the Commission on its actions and actions, but do not expect me to take part in these small manipulations which do not honour those who exercise them.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted against Mr Juncker's no-confidence motion against the Commission, as I believe that the commission of inquiry appointed in the case will determine whether there were actually irregularities in the so-called 'Lux Leaks case', and will act accordingly.  The European Commission, led by Mr Juncker, plays a really important and ambitious role, which would mean that the current crisis needs to be answered in the next five years and the credibility of the European Union should be raised. Therefore, the new Commission needs to be given the opportunity and support to address the serious problems currently facing the eu as a whole.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. - On 12 November 2014, European Commission President Juncker spoke at the Plenary session of the European Parliament in Brussels to give an explanation in relation to the LuxLeaks case concerning the possible tax evasion of several hundred companies. The ALDE Political Group, of which I am a member, responded to both the case and Juncker's speech by calling for a detailed investigation into the case by the end of this year. It also proposed the creation of an EP Special Committee to monitor the case and investigate it. This week, Parliament voted on a motion of censure against the Commission. I did not support the proposal because it lacks logic. The investigation into the case is ongoing and its results are unknown. And if the Commission were to be removed, it would not contribute to the investigation or anything else.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. - Why I did not take part in the vote on the motion of censure. The European situation is extremely critical. Europe is losing ground in the hearts. In particular, people's distrust of government-led policies is fuelling the rise of anti-European, often national-populist and xenophobic political forces. At the same time, the lack of courage of European leaders, the democratic deficit in our institutions and liberal policies are discrediting the european construction. Another Europe must be born.   Environmentalists have always fought for tax harmonisation, far from the outrageous practices exposed by the Luxleaks. The fight against tax evasion and pseudo-optimization is a non-negotiable priority. Today's motion of censure, carried by anti-European forces, far from advancing Europe, was aimed at a different purpose than the one it claimed to carry. It was merely a manoeuvre designed to show the strength of extremes in Parliament Because it was not desirable to mix my voice with that of the patented anti-Europeans, nor to give quitus to Jean-Claude Juncker and seem to absolve him of his past behaviour, I refused to take part in a vote that had everything of a trap.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted against the motion of censure against the European Commission chaired by Jean-Claude Juncker. The pretext used is misleading in that it establishes a link of responsibility between Luxembourg's tax practices, which are legal and have their equivalent in many other Member States, and Jean-Claude Juncker's past national responsibilities, even though he had no direct control over this practice. Far-right and far-left groups also fail to point out that it was Jean-Claude Juncker who has been behind initiatives in the past to harmonize taxation and its framework. Jean-Claude Juncker's assurances of his non-involvement in the European investigation that was launched and his commitment to European tax harmonisation, whose absence is the real culprit in tax engineering practices, convinced me to maintain the confidence I had placed in him in the past. The motion of no confidence was defeated by a majority of 461 votes against, 101 votes in and 88 abstentions. I welcome the continued appointment of Jean-Claude Juncker as head of the European Commission.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Jean-Claude Juncker and his Commission should be censured. GUE/NGL proposed from day one a motion of censure in plenary that unfortunately did not succeed. At the time we made it clear that we would not accept support from far-right groups and regret Verts/ALE and S&D's decision not to sign our motion, thus providing coverage to Juncker. We cannot vote in favour of today's motion of censure put to a vote because it has been tabled by far-right forces who just want to draw political gain from the climate created around the Luxembourg tax scandal without criticizing the system Juncker represents. That is why we have opted for abstention.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The motion of censure tabled by the populists of the European Parliament was just a wet firecracker. It has been largely rejected by serious MEPs of all political stripes. The populists would do better to finally address the fundamental issues: jobs, growth, immigration to Europe. Mr Farage and Ms Le Pen wanted to be talked about. It's done. But what energy and time spent organizing a vulgar political coup.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted against this motion. Mr Juncker still has questions to answer, both about his own conduct in the past and on how he will bring forward and enact proposals to crack down on tax avoidance across Europe. People are angry that legal loopholes and a lack of cooperation between European countries mean that some are not paying their fair share in tax. We need urgent action. This resolution however does nothing to tackle tax avoidance. It merely represents the hypocrisy of the Members who initiated it, as they have voted against tax transparency measures in the past.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. - As the ECR Group, we have always rejected Jean-Claude Juncker. He is the wrong man to be credible as President of the Commission. The ECR Group had already tabled its own request for clarification of the facts. The aim was to establish the responsibility of Jean-Claude Juncker and to call on him to resign. However, the request was rejected by other groups. It is therefore our duty to support this motion out of concern for the future of the European Union. The prosperous coexistence of European states depends to a large extent on the credibility and broad recognition of both top staff and EU procedures.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. - I voted against it in the vote of confidence in the Commission. However, not because I would consider all members of the Commission to be wrong. However, from the outset, the President inappropriately set up the Structure of the Commission by linking unrelated portfolios, in addition to confusingly move individual Commissioners between different portfolios and creating four Vice-Presidents who are now superior to the other Commissioners, which completely denied the meaning of the Commission's functioning. All of this did not inspire confidence in Mr Juncker. The highlight is the scandal that has been going on in recent weeks. It has become clear that one of the Commission's priorities, supported by our club, of limiting the leakage of corporate incomes into tax havens, is in the hands of a man who was Prime Minister of Luxembourg at a time when Luxembourg was a tax haven with minimal taxation for some multinational supranational firms. Luxembourg has thus de facto robbed the budgets of other EU Member States. Thus, the government under Mr Juncker's leadership acted directly contrary to the interests of the EU. Thus, the President of the Commission cannot be trusted not to give priority again to the interests of multinational corporations. This should also be realised by the Socialists and the People's Party, who support Mr Juncker and have thus taken responsibility for his possible future scandals. Mr Juncker says that he cannot assume political responsibility because he is no longer Prime Minister of Luxembourg, but he can certainly take responsibility by resigning as President of the Commission, as there is only one political responsibility.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. — In the vote of 27 November 2014 I chose to abstain. I therefore wanted to express my opposition to the two main lines formed in plenary: on the one hand, I did not want to identify with this group of MEPs who hypocritically promoted the motion of censure, namely the far-right of the French National Front in alliance with nationalist-Eurosceptics from the Unregistered. On the other hand, I wanted to express my radical opposition to the cover-up of the LuxLeaks tax avoidance scandal which is being borne by the President of the Commission by voting against the proposal by the majority of the largest groups in the European Parliament. Like all MEPs in the Group of the European Left, GUE/NGL, I am in favour of an in-depth investigation of the scandal by means of a committee of inquiry and of legislation that prevents tax competition between Member States and severely punishes tax avoidance scandals.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. - Member States lose eur 1 trillion, or EUR 1 000 billion a year, in unfair tax competition and tax avoidance. There is no longer any need to ask where, in this richest age, the money will disappear: it is literally in the asses of the gentlemen. At the same time, public debt is rising, services are being driven down, the burden on citizens is being increased and the ability to pay taxes is most required of those who have the least. This will lead to a serious social crisis for the whole of Europe. The requirements must be directed specifically at those who have the ability to pay taxes. The question now is whether this Commission will be able to target those it really needs to target. Or will the people continue to squat without blurring, without lottery, compensate the real villains in this world. Each of you knows that the left in Europe did not support Mr Juncker as President of the Commission. One of the heaviest reasons was his background as Prime Minister of Luxembourg, Europe's largest tax haven. Let us push for a strong discipline policy for others when the policies and morals of one's own country cannot stand the light of day. After the Lux Leaks data came out, we tabled a motion of censure against Mr Juncker, which S&D and the Greens refused to sign and announced that they would fight the Juncker system under his leadership. The far right has now been able to collect its own list of names, but they are targeting juncker alone. There are no intentions to do anything about a sick tax system. Tax avoidance and tax haven activity are not just a problem in Luxembourg, but the extreme right does not want to remember problems in England, for example, because that is where a large number of them come from. Since the content of the motion of censure was empty, I abstained.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have confirmed my support for the European Commission, led by President Juncker, because I believe it is a very good team, with the skills and skills necessary for the recovery of Europe. The programme before us focuses on growth, development and job creation, a priority with which I fully agree. Proof of this is the new Juncker Plan, which demonstrates the very short-term investment potential to accelerate the exit from the crisis.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. — The European Commission had to face an initial motion of censure concocted by a conglomerate of MPs, made up of Ms Le Pen's troops and those of the Eurosceptic British MP, Nigel Farage. But the European Parliament felt that there was no question of being dictated by people with demagogic and populist intentions, by rejecting, by a large majority, this motion of censure. This vote underlined the confidence of the vast majority of MEPs in the newly installed European Commission, which seems to us to have the political courage to "wake up Europe", revive growth and jobs, and pull Europe out of its sluggishness.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. "I have decided not to take part in the vote on the motion of censure because I refuse to join an initiative of the extreme right polluting the debate. The issue of competition and tax evasion depriving states of considerable resources, at a time when the European Union is demanding more and more budgetary efforts, is fundamental to the future of the welfare state. It is the subject of clear proposals on our part on the fight against tax evasion, tax harmonisation, and taxation systems that take money where it is: to capital, to speculation, not to work. Censorship of the Juncker Commission had been envisaged with the Socialists and Greens on the basis of a joint project aimed at re-founding the European project on the basis of social and ecological progress. In the absence of their support on our proposal, I support the creation of a parliamentary commission of inquiry into tax fraud practices. Not on an initiative of groups that have always fought social and human progress, who defend established interests, who have never proposed anything on these issues, refuse tax harmonisation and make agitation, confirming that they are more part of the problem than part of the solution.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the motion of censure because I consider that Jean-Claude Juncker is not worthy to preside over the European Commission. As Prime Minister of Luxembourg, he organized tax evasion, benefiting 340 multinational companies, of several hundred billion euros. This shortfall weighs heavily on national budgets, and on the Peoples of Europe, which are now being driven into austerity. With cynicism, Juncker who has become President of the Commission wants them to foot the bill for his own abuses! Voting to overthrow it is not just a political decision: it is a moral duty. The French people will remember that the Socialist and UMP deputies failed in this duty. To support such a man is to make the choice of plutocracy against democracy.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. - The N-VA today voted against the motion of censure against the Juncker Commission. The challenges facing the Member States and the EU are immense and treaties are not political games. Does this mean a blank cheque for Juncker? Anything but.  It is unethical for Member States to strike shadowy tax deals with post office companies that do not engage in real economic activity there, only to allow multinationals to pay little to no tax. If we want to reduce the tax burden for everyone, we need to make sure that everyone pays their fair share. And then we also have to make sure that companies pay taxes in the country where they operate effectively.  Together we must combat tax fraud and disloyal competition. Commissioner Vestager's investigation into the Luxleaks must be thorough, transparent and completely impartial and must be completed as soon as possible. If the investigation shows that unlawful acts were taken, then appropriate action is necessary. This is the only way to secure the EU's credibility.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I have not supported a motion of censure proposed by those who want to destroy the European project. I presented myself to the elections to the European Parliament in May with the desire and purpose of working to make another Europe a reality. A Europe that, among other things, eliminates tax havens and opens up to fiscal harmonisation and a new economic policy. Efforts must continue to be made to fight for an alternative Europe, but without giving encouragement to those voices who seek to end the European Union. My aim is to recover the soul of Europe, a project that was based on solidarity and social justice, and which today seems to be paid only for a cold economic project.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. " We voted against the motion of censure of Europhobes and extremists, although the Socialists do not support Mr Juncker to be President of the European Commission. However, we were the first to ask you to appear in the European Parliament and to present an action plan against tax evasion and avoidance across Europe. In addition, an investigation into tax policy in Luxembourg is open. But what the Socialists are not going to do is fall into the trap of Europhobes and extremists to seize any opportunity to create chaos. We're not going to give them wings, and we're not going to align with Marine Le Pen and the extremists in their ends. We ask for explanations and they have been given. We call for reaction measures and they have been put in place. And we're asking for research and it's developing. Citizens today feel let down and deceived to learn that big businesses evade taxes while they are still being demanded of sacrifices. The Spanish Socialists will continue to work to end both.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Juncker and his Commission must be censured. Our group, GUE/NGL, proposed a motion of censure which unfortunately did not succeed, as neither the Greens nor the S&D Group agreed to sign it, implicitly supporting Juncker. We cannot sign in favour of this motion of censure that is presented to us because it has been proposed by the far right, which seeks only to take advantage of the climate that has been created in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, without making any criticism of the system that Juncker represents. That's why I abstained.

name: Sabine Lösing (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. - Juncker and the Commission deserve today's no-confidence vote. We have tried everything to bring a motion of censure into the plenary session as a GUE/NGL itself. Unfortunately, we were not successful because the Greens and the Socialist Group refused to support Juncker. That is why I cannot vote against the motion of censure. Nor, however, can I vote in favour of this motion of censure tabled by the fascists/right-wing bloc, such as the National Front, Jobbik and others. They just want to take advantage of the mood surrounding this scandal and accuse Juncker, but not the entire system of tax havens and deregulation that is behind it. That is why I abstained.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motion of censure because The President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, does not have my confidence. His misconduct in not only condoning Luxembourg's tax haven policy for decades, but actively promoting it, deprives him of any credibility for the leadership of the European Commission. As President of the Commission, he is committed to promoting the common good. However, as Minister of Finance and Prime Minister of Luxembourg, he systematically evaded this common good by colluding with companies and allowing them to tax cheaply in Luxembourg, even though most of their production and value added did not take place in Luxembourg. Even if this was legal, it was not legitimate. It was clearly against the interests of the partner countries, which have lost important tax revenues. States rely on tax revenues to fund public services. States compete with each other with their public services and the taxes that finance them. I believe that this competition is important and right. Mr Juncker has massively disrupted this competition by allowing companies not to pay their taxes where they benefit from the public services of their country of residence. This was anti-European, anti-solidarity and deeply unjust. Mr Juncker therefore does not have my confidence.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. - I do not support this proposal since I believe that such a measure is not in the interest of the European Union as a complete community of 28 countries. Furthermore, such an act is a clear attempt to weaken the European Union by Europhobes.  Instead of such extreme measures, a constructive approach is needed in the form of a reform plan that will ensure the realisation of economic growth and development and job creation in the European Union.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. — Today's vote of no confidence against the Juncker Commission has expected to fail with the support of only 101 colleagues in the European Parliament. The strong majority of 461 representatives in the ANTI EP showed that the overall vote was untenable and failed to mobilise more serious support from political groups. The desired effect was not achieved. On the contrary, expectations of a shake of trust in the European Commission and personally its President met the exact opposite reaction – juncker was supported by more MEPs on this vote than when he was elected President in October. Moreover, the procedure for this vote was also indicative of the role and capabilities of the far-right and anti-European parties in the European Parliament, namely: low support, inability to have a quality debate and the presentation of predominantly populist arguments.  The real effect was the single position of a majority of parties from across the political spectrum in Parliament, as well as the further stabilisation of Jean-Claude Juncker's positions.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - I was among the 88 Members who abstained. The issue of Juncker's tax havens is more than topical and important. This is also a question of the principles of Juncker. And I am in for all these cases to be investigated thoroughly and for the public to receive answers. However, this issue has been raised by the EFDD political group, which aims to destroy the European Union. That's not my goal. Because the right question was put by the wrong politicians, I decided to abstain. But Juncker needs to answer and get clear.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against the motion of censure on the new Junker Commission in order to be consistent with my vote the previous month, but above all to renew my support and that of the entire PPE for the programme which the new Commission intends to implement. A democratically elected Commission with a large majority, which has once again received the support of this Parliament to tackle and resolve the problems of growth and employment through political confrontation and economic planning.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) The tabling of a motion of no confidence against the Commission chaired by Jean Claude Juncker, who has just taken office, was, in my view, an act of mere provocation by a deeply populist fringe of the European Parliament. The motion of censure is, of course, an instrument of a democratic nature. However, it should not be used for propaganda purposes, as in this case. It is for these reasons that I voted against a document devoid of political content, aimed solely at striking at the very esteemed figure of Mr Juncker.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I believe that Jean Claude Juncker and his Commission should be censured. For the same reason, the GUE/NGL proposes a motion of censure which, having not obtained support from the parliamentary groups of the Greens and the Socialists and Democrats, has not reached the number of signatures required. I cannot, however, support a motion of censure supported by the far right, which removes the political system that allows tax fraud, evasion and avoidance to exist in Europe, directing it only to the President of the Commission. That's why I abstained.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
