text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motion of censure against the Commission with the full estout. President Juncker was not interested in working with the Commission during his time as Prime Minister of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. This, and the fact that the tax affair involving the multinational clients of PricewaterhouseCoopers came to a climax during his term of office in Luxembourg led me to vote in favour of this request.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - My group was a forerunner in the desire to censure the Juncker Commission by trying to table a motion at the last session. Since the Greens and the PS refused to sign our motion, we were unable to present it to the Assembly, leaving room for the far right to hypocritically seize this theme. The far right has thus been able to seize the will of censorship. I refuse to want to bring down Juncker by the right, to mix my vote with those of the extreme right which opposes in France tax and tax harmonisation in Europe. But I also denounce the refusal to act by the European PS and the Greens, which condemns us to abstention

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted against this motion of censure because I believe it appears for the worst reasons. Its signatories are not interested in discussing the goodness of this new Commission, but only in jeopardising the EU itself. When the National Front and the EFD are united to jointly propose a motion of censure to this Commission, they are not censure, they are censured by the EU itself as it exists today. So under no circumstances could i agree with it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted against this motion because the claims have already been addressed by the Commission. It is a thinly veiled attempt by Euro-sceptics to discredit and weaken the Commission and the EU. I strongly support the establishment of new initiatives for more transparency in regards to Member States’ tax regimes and look forward to the Commission’s proposals on this issue.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I opposed the motion to censure the Commission and its President, Jean Claude Juncker. This is an act of populism exploited by the Europhobes and the elected representatives of the National Front of this Assembly. In the face of the many challenges we face, it would be irresponsible for us to jeopardise the Commission in the very after it takes office.  There are many projects to be implemented. I think it would be particularly sensible to make progress on the issue of tax harmonisation, notably by releasing the proposal for a directive, again in the Council, from March 2011 on 'a common system for calculating the tax base of companies active in the European Union (ACCIS)". Let us not forget that in tax matters, it is the Member States - and therefore the Council of Ministers - who have the power of the last word.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted against the motion of censure on the Commission.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. - The motion of censure was a gift for the Juncker Commission: it allowed it to be reconfirmed and re-legitimised politically. Its rejection by an overwhelming vote by all the mainstream political parties was natural: it would have been irresponsible to plunge Europe into a major crisis at the behest of populist parties. That said, my vote was one for reason more than for persons, and I hope clarity will be brought on all the matters that may cast a shadow over the mandate of this Commission.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. - Just days after taking office, the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, finds himself at the heart of the LuxLeaks scandal, these documents revealing the deliberate policy of tax dumping that he put in place for 18 years as Prime Minister of Luxembourg. The credibility of the Commission as a whole is thus called into question, while its stated objectives are called transparency and the fight against tax evasion, the reduction of Member States' deficits or the fight against unfair competition. At the initiative of the Euro-realist MEPs, a motion of censure was tabled.  I voted in favour of this motion, which received 101 votes in favour but was not adopted.  The members of the EPP and the S-D have once again supported Mr Juncker, thereby endorsing his practices and the double language in the face of the logics of money.  In this, they are faithful to the hypocritical discourses they have held in France for decades, indignant at the consequences of free movement and unbridled competition, having been the sole instigators and thus bear full responsibility for it.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union is governed by a grand coalition of the right, the left and their liberal and Green allies. Each decision is therefore the result of consensus and compromise, to the detriment of the people and of course to the benefit of multinationals and high finance. Mr Juncker, President of the Commission, is also a former leader of Luxembourg, a state that has introduced a system to facilitate tax evasion (some 300 companies have been able to reach an agreement with that state in this regard). France, therefore, suffered a real leak of its tax revenues, a shortfall which was of course filled by greater tax pressure on French households and middle classes. This technique of tax evasion was put in place during the era of Mr Juncker. Today, the Commission tells us that it wants to carry out a thorough investigation into luxembourg's (LuxLeaks) practices. Will she be impartial? Or will the keys to the chicken coop be given to the fox? Rejecting this Europe of Magouille and arrangements, I voted for this motion of censure.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted against the motion of censure against the European Commission. The College of Commissioners was invested less than a month ago, after a long process of appointment and hearing that was transparent and resulted in consensus. We need the new European Commission to be at work quickly to get Europe out of the crisis. This motion, signed mainly by Mr Farage's group and the National Front, proves once again that their action in the European Parliament is only slowing down the decision-making process and that they are far from the concerns of European citizens.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. "I obviously voted against this motion of censure, which had no other purpose than to block the European Union. We need today the new Juncker Commission to work to improve the lives of European citizens. Censoring the Commission would be blocking all the reforms we need to boost growth; as such, the supporters of this motion of censure voted against the peoples.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — President Juncker was not interested in working with the Commission during his time as Prime Minister of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. This, and the fact that he is responsible for creating, implementing, implementing and monitoring this aggressive policy of tax avoidance, deprives him of the credibility of serving the citizens of the Union as President of the Commission. I therefore voted in favour of the motion of censure with deep conviction.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - I did not support the motion of no confidence in the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, because it would weaken Europe and is not justified. The head of the European Commission, which has only just started to work, has been put forward a vote of no confidence by MEPs from those political forces who oppose the further development and strengthening of the European Union. The so-called Luxleaks investigation is not yet complete, but it is already seeking a condemnation. In the current international situation, the European Union needs unity and strengthening, while the new European Commission's attempt at distrust is countering it and is not in the interest of a strong EU.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece, in the wake of the revelations of monopoly tax evasion in Luxembourg under Prime Minister Juncker, has highlighted from the out out0s not only Juncker's responsibilities, but the EU as a whole, which serves the profitability of capital in every way. The Jrc voted against the Commission and its president in their election, as it did with all previous EU Committees, stating that it simultaneously votes against the whole of the EU's unpopular policy and totally opposes this transnational imperialist union.  In this respect, the Communist Party was not involved in the disorienting voting process of a resolution tabled primarily by nationalist, racist and fascist political forces of the urban arc. These forces, on the one hand, appear, provocatively, to be complaining about corporate tax exemptions, while on the other hand they are oiling the EU and the anti-labour strategy of competitiveness and profitability of business groups, to which the initiators of the resolution also bow, calling for identical measures in favour of capital.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the motion of no confidence in Mr Juncker. The deep crisis in Europe requires a radical change of course. This change can only take place if it is built on entire ethical qualities and an absolute political foresight of individuals in senior roles within the Commission. The LuxLeaks scandal has shown that Juncker is completely unfit to serve as President of the European Executive.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. - I voted against the censure of Juncker, but nevertheless I believe that tax policy in the European Union should be unified in the long term. Juncker is a person who knows these matters well and can come up with a proposal for a solution. However, I would like to know who will support these solutions, because it is in the interests of some major countries not to change anything. We are against a serious problem, because tax-less favourable environments mean discrimination, on the one hand, and a privilege on the other, because some do not pay the same taxes as most. That's a problem.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - Taking into account that all Member States in their tax system have acts that give tax benefits to multinational companies, we must recognise the difference between relief and tax evasion that is illegal. Tax systems in eu member states are not harmonised, and it is clear that there are no elements in Luxembourg's tax system that would be illegal. The question remains about the fairness of the existing context. Jean-Claude Juncker took over as President of the European Commission with 423 votes in the European Parliament at a time when the European Union was in a difficult situation. With clear guidance and an engaged start, Juncker demonstrated his willingness to tackle all problems in the Union. I was therefore against President Juncker's no-confidence motion against the Commission.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against the motion of censure on the European Commission and its President, Jean-Claude Junker, because the accusing fact does not exist, but I believe that the time is ripe for harmonizing the tax systems of all the Member States and I hope that the new Junker Commission will be able to take over this battle of great economic and social value.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. — The recent revelations about the creation of a system of targeted tax avoidance in Luxembourg under then-Prime Minister Juncker are just the tip of the iceberg. Moreover, these findings are hardly surprising. Although this Commission also has individual glimmers of light, it is characterised in many areas by incompetence and self-righteousness. To give confidence to this Commission as a whole and to its President in particular would be a slap in the face to the taxpayer! As a representative of the German electorate, it is my duty, with my vote, to express the distrust of this Commission, which is throwing billions of dollars around it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. "The audacity of certain political groups no longer surprises me. The European Commission has just returned to the post that they already want to dissolve it. This motion of censure was nothing more than a communication stunt. Like an overwhelming majority, I therefore vote against this motion, which, ironically, reinforces the legitimacy of the Commission, which a Europhobic fringe thought could compromise.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted against this motion of censure because it is a pure instrument of political exploitation of party forces opposed to European integration. I record the ambiguity of the radical left in the face of this radical right initiative. I welcome the political will expressed by the President of the Commission and the Commission to make a consistent effort of fiscal convergence to put an end to the current imbalances and relative injustices which, although legal, distort the main objectives of economic and monetary union.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. - I have today decided against the motion of censure against the European Commission. This is not a carte blanche, but a clear mandate from the European Parliament to the European Commission. Juncker must now get his head around tax fraud and quickly end corporate trickery at the expense of European citizens.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. - We voted against the motion of censure of Europhobes and extremists, although the Socialists do not support Mr Juncker to be President of the European Commission. However, we were the first to ask you to appear in the European Parliament and to present an action plan against tax evasion and avoidance across Europe. In addition, an investigation into tax policy in Luxembourg is open. But what the Socialists are not going to do is fall into the trap of Europhobes and extremists to seize any opportunity to create chaos. We're not going to give them wings, and we're not going to align with Marine Le Pen and the extremists in their ends. We ask for explanations and they have been given. We call for reaction measures and they have been put in place. And we're asking for research and it's developing. Citizens today feel let down and deceived to learn that big businesses evade taxes while they are still being demanded of sacrifices. The Spanish Socialists will continue to work to end both.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. — I voted against because two issues cannot be shaken: the Commission's labour and tax avoidance scandal. I understand that the scandal that has caused has disappointed many people and intensified mistrust of the European institutions. However, by expressing mistrust at the recent launch of the Commission, we would bring more instability and confusion. On the other hand, a vote against censure does not mean that it does not have to do important work to curb tax avoidance. On the contrary, the Greens want to give the European Commission a chance to regain the trust of citizens and to prove that the European Commission understands the importance of the problem and is ready for immediate change. If the Commission does not act, then there will be nothing but to express its distrust.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — The significant result of the vote against this motion of censure on the Commission with only 15.5 % of the votes in favour- basically of the groups situated on the far most right in the European Parliament and by non-registered Members, denotes well the extemporaneousness, impertinence and rejection of this initiative. I also record that all Portuguese Members (present at the vote) voted against this motion, with the exception of Members belonging to the GUE/NGL Parliamentary Group, who abstained.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted against the motion of censure that had been tabled against Jean-Claude Juncker's new European Commission.  The new Commission took office on 1 November, and Jean-Claude Juncker has already come to present his plan to mobilise 315 billion euros to fight unemployment, create jobs and boost growth in Europe.  I remain in my support for Jean-Claude Juncker's Commission and would like to stress that the vote on this motion of censure has strengthened the confidence given to the Commission by the European Parliament, with the obtaining of additional votes in relation to the vote of the October session (the vote of approval of the Commission by Parliament).

name: Sofia Sakorafa (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. - GUE/ NGL was the first political group to propose a motion of censure in plenary against Juncker on Luxembourg's tax havens. This proposal was not limited to what was revealed about Luxembourg, but focused on the causes of such phenomena and is no other than the neoliberal system itself which, while producing and relying on them, hypocritically "reveals" them. It is well known that other countries in the EU's hard neoliberal core follow the same tactics as Luxembourg. For these very reasons, the Greens and S&D refused to co-sign the proposal, thereby covering both Juncker and these policies and the system they serve.  The proposal put to the vote, supported by far-right Members, serves exactly the same purpose: to treat the Luxembourg phenomenon as an isolated and "self-contained" phenomenon and not as a dominant derivative and pillar of the neoliberal system and those who serve it. I refuse to take a stand on such false dilemmas.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - My abstention expresses the will of the coalition to which I represent to cast a touch of attention on President Juncker because of his involvement in the so-called 'LuxLeaks'. We cannot support a motion of censure from the far right and the Europhobes, with many anti-European connotations, but we do see clear indications of a performance by Mr Juncker which casts doubt on his suitability as President of the European Commission. This abstention is a call for it to act, to give further explanations, for Parliament to investigate thoroughly, to its last consequences (resignation included), in order to clear the action of any member of the European Commission in any shadow of doubt.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Juncker and his Commission must be censured. Our group has already voted against Juncker's election as President and also of the Commission, because it is a Commission designed to further deepen the neoliberal and austerity policies that are causing so much suffering to our peoples. Our group, GUE/NGL, proposed a motion of censure which unfortunately did not succeed, as neither the Greens nor the S&D Group agreed to sign it, implicitly supporting Juncker. I cannot vote in favour of this motion of censure before us because it hides the hypocrisy of the far right, which seeks only to take advantage of the climate that has been created in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, without questioning or criticizing Juncker's system. That's why I abstained.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — Today I voted against the motion of censure on the Commission.  Aggressive corporate tax avoidance schemes in EU Member States, particularly the one applied in the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, have caused the loss of billions of euros in potential tax revenues to other EU Member States.  Corporate tax avoidance schemes are contradictory to the values of ensuring a fair share of contributions by all sectors of society, including business. However, a motion of censure on the Commission is not an effective way of addressing the issue of the tax avoidance scheme in Luxembourg.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. — Today I voted in favour of the removal of Mr Juncker as President of the European Commission. A politician should be consistent in his work and in his statements. Jean-Claude Juncker, on the one hand, declares that he will actively fight tax evasion, but his past actions say otherwise.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE)
text: Writing. — It is necessary, even now, to react, to investigate all cases and to close immediately and effectively all tax avoidance windows on European soil. Automatic exchange of tax information is necessary. It is clearly unacceptable to ask citizens living in countries in crisis such as Greece to pay unaffordable taxes, when at the same time, in prosperous countries, business giants do not pay their fair share of taxes. Everyone has to comply and pay if they've been misled. But why is Juncker's political weakening operation now under way, when everything was known long before his election? A few days before the vote to elect him President of the Commission, the Financial Times had published all the information repeated today. Juncker is the first President of the Commission elected by the European Parliament since the verdict of European voters. Juncker presents a 315 billion euro leverage plan, adds the growth dimension to fiscal discipline and openly raises the need for rapid financing of the European machine. Of course I voted against the motion of censure, but I certainly felt that the extreme voices of EFDD and Mrs Le Pen did not have the power to lead the Juncker Commission out.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. — The European Commission has clear objectives ahead of it, in particular in promoting growth and improving the employment situation. This also has to do with tax policy, where we must clearly distinguish between unacceptable tax evasion and the necessary stimulation of growth through tax policy.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. — I vote against this proposal because it is unfounded. I believe that the European Commission, like its President Mr Jean-Claude Juncker, is doing a good job. They prioritised creating growth and creating new jobs. They are committed to the Digital Single Market where they primarily want to break down national barriers in teleoperater regulation, for better legislation, for copyright and data protection, for radio wave management and for better competition rights.  They want to negotiate a sensible and balanced trade agreement with the United States, but they want to be very clear that they will not sacrifice European security, social norms and data protection in Europe for the price of free trade.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. - I supported the dismissal of the current European Commission, also in the wake of the Scandal of President Juncker. It is extremely hypocritical that jean-Claude Juncker, who is now keenly fighting tax havens and tax optimisation as President of the European Commission, has supported favoured tax regimes for firms as Prime Minister of Luxembourg. I also disagree with Juncker's response to this scandal – in order to avoid such cases in the future, to harmonise taxes directly throughout the European Union. Tax harmonisation is harmful and leads to less economic freedom and thus lower prosperity. It is not only for these reasons that I believe that the current European Commission, led by Jean-Claude Juncker, should not continue.

name: Neoklis Sylikiotis (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Juncker and his Commission should be censured. GUE/NGL had proposed a motion of censure to the plenary which unfortunately did not succeed, as the Greens and S&D refused to co-sign it, covering in this way Juncker. We cannot vote in favour of the existing motion because it has been proposed by extreme right-wing forces which only want to take advantage of the climate that has been created around the scandal, without criticising the system Junker represents. For this reason we ABSTAIN.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The revelations simply came to confirm what we already thought, namely that Juncker is unfit to be President of the Commission. Especially now, under the weight of the scandal and the billions of euros indirectly lost to the income of the other Member States, we believe that Mr. Juncker should have already resigned on his own.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. - I refused the motion. Europhobes and far-right parties have united for the first time in an attempt to make Europe ungovernable and to bring a deep crisis to European citizens. Luxleaks is an alibi. Indeed, it has already been several weeks since the European far-right parties contacted each other to table the said motion of censure, long before the revelations implicating the former Juncker government. However, it is true that multinationals cannot be above tax laws. But it would also be unfair to revive a deep crisis for European citizens. We demand that tax harmonisation be put in place, and that each Member State proposes the same taxation for businesses to avoid tax dumping. According to the saying, poachers are the best gamekeepers. The president plays his own credibility on this issue and every mistake will play the game of anti-Europe

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The motion of censure filed against the President of the Commission is led by the European far right. From our group we also criticise Jean-Claude Juncker and we have another way of understanding what politics and the economy should be in the EU, especially with the tax system. But we, who voted against his candidacy last month, cannot support this motion of censure because of the great chasm that separates us from what the far right wants and because we give the President of the Commission some time to fulfil some of his commitments and our demands.  I do think it necessary for a parliamentary committee of inquiry into the 'LuxLeaks' case to bring to light all available information and to point out the policy makers of the case, debugging responsibilities.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted to censure this Commission because it is illegitimate in the government of the French people.  This commission is also headed by Mr Juncker, a man who has been at the head of Europe's biggest tax haven for so long. His insolent aplomb when he mentions this massive fraud makes the adoption of this motion of censure mandatory.  Its rejection by the EP further condemns these institutions, which have lost all sense of the common good, dignity and honour, to the abyss in which the European peoples and the French people in mind will soon throw them away.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) I co-signed and voted for the motion of censure because I find it unacceptable that this Commission, the institution which by definition represents the general European interest, was chosen and is led by those who for over twenty years have only trampled on it, turning the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg into the greatest tax haven and the greatest protectorate of Europe's mega tax evaders, with enormous damage to other European partners. In Luxembourg, the multinational giants have found a safe haven for billions of capital which could have financed investment and public services in the partner countries instead of enriching the Grand Duchy. Today, unfortunately, the majority of this united Parliament wanted to reiterate its support for Juncker and his Commission. One side voted against censure, not because it does not share our reasons, but because it prefers not to be politically associated with parties whose ideological approach it does not share. The other is because, 'in everyone's interest', it does not want to postpone the start of the Commission's work. However, by rejecting censorship, it has only shown that it has a different kind of interest: those of multinationals and strong powers, certainly not those of Europe and the citizens.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Juncker and his Commission must be censured. Our group, GUE/NGL, proposed a motion of censure which unfortunately did not succeed, as neither the Greens nor the S&D Group agreed to sign it, implicitly supporting Juncker. We cannot sign in favour of this motion of censure that is presented to us because it has been proposed by the far right, which seeks only to take advantage of the climate that has been created in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, without making any criticism of the system that Juncker represents. That's why I abstained.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR)
text: in writing. - I believe that a national government should be free to create an advantageous tax regime in its own country. However, I do not approve of Mr Juncker’s appointment as Commission President and there seems to be a basic incompatibility between his present and previous roles. I await the outcome of the inquiry before passing judgement. In accordance with my ECR political group, I therefore abstained.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted against the motion of censure against Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker’s team in Thursday’s vote. The damage that would have ensured had this vote been successful would have undermined not only the Commission, but also the wider Union.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — I abstained on the European Commission's motion of censure, presented by the European far right and the British extreme right. The responsibility of the former Luxembourg finance minister and former prime minister-turned-President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, for the institutionalised tax evasion, organised under the name of "tax optimisation" and established as the economic engine of his country, is beyond doubt in my opinion. My group of the European Unitarian Left/Nordic Green Left has therefore organised a plenary action. Neither Juncker nor Le Pen. However, voting in favour of such a resolution is unacceptable, because it is not a question for me to mix my voice with that of the extreme right both for reasons of form and substance, but for real measures to combat tax fraud and evasion just like tax havens, for a real taxation of financial transactions, finally!

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Juncker and the Commission widely deserve to be censured. On the part of the GUE/NGL Group, everything was done to bring a motion to the plenary. Unfortunately, it was not possible because the Greens and S&D refused to signed it, supporting Juncker and his policy.  However, we cannot also vote in favour of an opportunistic act of the far right. Indeed, they want to take advantage of the climate created around this scandal to blame Juncker without blaming the system he represents – a system from which tax havens, notably in the City, offshores and deregulation of the financial system are constitutive parts. That is why we will abstain, making it clear what our reasons are.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. — Not only did President Juncker, during his time as Prime Minister of Luxembourg, create a tax haven for multinationals and corporations at the expense of other Member States, but I believe that a number of Commissioners whom he has chosen are involved in dubious webs with industry and capital. He is therefore responsible for creating and implementing an aggressive policy of tax avoidance. At a time when EU citizens are facing increasing poverty, tax burdens and unemployment, this Commission is neither a model nor meets the standards it repeatedly sets out for the guarantors. That is why I voted in favour of the motion of censure with full conviction.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR)
text: in writing. — Mr Juncker was prime minister of one of the tax havens and therefore cannot be the one to fight tax havens, as he wrote in the European Commission's programme. At the same time, it cannot use its personal problem to promote tax harmonisation and tax unification within the European Union. His associates, or those who support him, cannot suggest that Mr Juncker's criticism is something that weakens the European Union and plays into Moscow's hands. On the contrary, it is Mr Juncker who is weakening the European Union, that he is untrustworthy, and that he is sticking to his place and does not intend to address his responsibility in any way. It is therefore entirely appropriate to try to censure him.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. We can be satisfied that we have definitively exposed those in here who claim to be against tax avoidance, evasion and havens, but who then in practice confirm their confidence in one of the leading experts and supporters of these policies, namely the former Luxembourg Prime Minister, Mr Juncker. They are probably the same people who also believe that Juncker has divine powers, to turn twenty billion into over three hundred: perhaps they have confused Brussels with Lake Tiberias. Certainly in his Luxembourg past Juncker has taken billions from many, to all European citizens, through agreements with large multinationals that have deprived several countries of huge tax revenues. But, as I said on Monday, here we are in the temple of European hypocrisy, as our GUE comrades have shown again today, brandishing signs in this House against tax havens, but not by voting for our motion. In any case, we will continue our battle on this front, and from today I think it is clear to everyone that we have remained the only ones truly credible, even in Europe.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece, in the wake of the revelations of monopoly tax evasion in Luxembourg under Prime Minister Juncker, has highlighted from the out out0s not only Juncker's responsibilities, but the EU as a whole, which serves the profitability of capital in every way. The Jrc voted against the Commission and its president in their election, as it did with all previous EU Committees, stating that it simultaneously votes against the whole of the EU's unpopular policy and totally opposes this transnational imperialist union.  In this respect, the Communist Party was not involved in the disorienting voting process of a resolution tabled primarily by nationalist, racist and fascist political forces of the urban arc. These forces, on the one hand, appear, provocatively, to be complaining about corporate tax exemptions, while on the other hand they are oiling the EU and the anti-labour strategy of competitiveness and profitability of business groups, to which the initiators of the resolution also bow, calling for identical measures in favour of capital.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: Writing. - Given that the investigation into information on unfair tax collection policies of the Luxembourg Government, at a time when the current President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, was Prime Minister of that country, has not yet been concluded, I abstained in the European Parliament's vote to distrust the European Commission. While there are serious concerns that for a long time the Juncker Government has set up unfair tax optimisation schemes, with the appropriate deception of the possibility of collecting taxes fairly for other European Union countries, I, as well as a significant proportion of members of my ECR group, nevertheless believe that correctness must be maintained and the results of the investigation should be awaited. However, despite his position in today's vote, I believe that it will be very difficult for Juncker to prove that the scandalous information recently released about tax collection schemes is not true, or that he, as head of government at the time, is not responsible for the country's tax policy, thereby causing blame on tax administrators. Consequently, trusting in a fair investigation procedure on this issue, I suppose that the participation of President Juncker in the unfair fiscal optimisation of Luxembourg has been 7:499, in future votes on this issue, not only for me and for my group, but also for the other members of the political groups represented in the European Parliament, to be different from those expressed in today's vote.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The CFP and its group, the GUE/NGL, have done their best to give political and institutional expression in the European Parliament to the just indignation and social censorship sparked by the revelation of the scandal, involving the current President of the European Commission, of escaping the payment of taxes by hundreds of multinationals. Thus, the GUE/NGL prepared a motion of censure, which ultimately did not gather the minimum number of signatures to be discussed. It was the option of the green, social democrat and liberal groups not to endorse the GUE/NGL motion, thus making it impossible to discuss and vote. There is no question that the European Commission and its president deserve to be censured. But we cannot support or whiten the opportunism of the far right in this process. Having gathered enough signatures, they submitted the motion of censure now voted. They did so, however, in such terms that, pointing the finger at Juncker and the Commission, they whiten the system in which they both are and represent. Not a word is said about tax havens or the deregulation of the financial system – essential parts of the gear set up to exempt multinationals from their tax obligations. In fact, several of the signatories of this motion are well-known proponents of this same gear. Hence our abstention.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. - I am aware of my responsibility, which is why I voted against the censure of the European Commission. I would like many of the Commission's good projects to succeed in the future. The promoters did not inspire confidence from the outset, as they have always sought to destabilise the European Commission and the EU through their extreme and Eurosceptic appearance and the doubts about Juncker's work that emerged with the Luxleaks affair. They have failed to do so, as members of moderate political groups supported the Commission, and the result of the vote was even better than when the Commission was approved last month. Notwithstanding my support for Juncker, However, I have repeatedly stressed the need for an independent and comprehensive investigation into the Luxleaks affair. Unfair tax policies in the EU should not be tolerated.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution. The Delegated Regulation provides for the establishment of the Single Resolution Board of credit institutions and certain investment firms within the framework of a Single Resolution Mechanism and a Single Bank Resolution Fund. It is proposed that this Board should have an autonomous budget which is not part of the Union budget and which should be financed by contributions from the banking sector, in particular contributions to the administrative costs of the Board to be paid by credit institutions, parent companies, investment firms and financial institutions covered by the MUR Regulation.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I do not believe that British banks should foot the bill for such expenditures.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — The establishment of a Single Resolution Board, which will act as an EU agency, is foreseen from 19 August 2014. The smooth functioning of the Board from 1 January 2015 requires the establishment of its funding structures by 1 January 2015. I support the regulation on the establishment of a financing structure for the Board.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — This Single Resolution Council is supposed to operate from 1 January 2015, but I oppose this proposal to leave the scope open to the Commission on the provisional system of instalments on contributions to cover the administrative expenses of the Single Resolution Council during the transitional period. An unfavourable vote was therefore required.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Since the onset of the financial crisis in 2008, the European Commission has pursued numerous initiatives to save the single currency that is the euro.  With the worsening debt crisis in the euro area and the interdependence of countries sharing the euro, the European Commission and the European institutions, within the framework of the Banking Union, have agreed to establish a single supervisory mechanism (SSM) and a single resolution mechanism (MRU) for banks. The Banking Union applies to euro area countries, with countries outside the euro area also able to participate. The Single Resolution Council, on the other hand, has broad powers to analyse and define the approach to a bank's resolution: which instruments to use and what intervention of the European Resolution Fund.  We are therefore asked here not to object to the provisional system of instalments on contributions to cover these CRU expenditures over the transitional period and, thus, to support this system, which is why I voted against this recommendation.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because I believe it is necessary to be able to give resources to the body that oversees the European banking supervision mechanism.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution. The Committee of the Regions must have a budget independent of that of the EU and financed by contributions from the banking sector, in particular through contributions to the Committee's administrative expenditure to be paid by credit institutions, parent companies, investment firms and financial institutions covered by the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — On 14 July 2014, the Council officially adopted Regulation (EU) No 806/2014 establishing the Single Resolution Mechanism for Banks in Disresus, and with it the Single Resolution Committee and the Single Resolution Fund were set up. This Committee is a decision-making body responsible for initiating and managing the crisis resolution procedures of credit institutions. Of course, in order to make this Committee, as well as the future Agency of the European Union, fully operational from 1 January 2015, it will be necessary to provide it with an autonomous budget.  I personally agree with the payment of contributions in order to be able to cover the first administrative costs in order to facilitate the proper functioning of this decision-making body.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Article 42 of Regulation (EU) No 806/2014 provides for the establishment of a Single Resolution Committee in the form of an EU agency, which must have an autonomous budget, which is not part of the Union budget and which is financed through contributions from the banking sector, in particular through contributions to the Committee's administrative expenditure to be paid by credit institutions, parent companies, investment firms and financial institutions covered by the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation. I voted in favour of this resolution because the Committee of the Regions will have to have the relevant financing mechanisms in place as soon as possible, so that the first administrative expenditure can be covered from its own resources and must not be burdened with public resources.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.  — I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution. The Delegated Regulation provides for the establishment of the Single Resolution Board of credit institutions and certain investment firms within the framework of a Single Resolution Mechanism and a Single Bank Resolution Fund. It is proposed that this Board should have an autonomous budget which is not part of the Union budget and which should be financed by contributions from the banking sector, in particular contributions to the administrative costs of the Board to be paid by credit institutions, parent companies, investment firms and financial institutions covered by the MUR Regulation.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — That Regulation provides for a detailed procedure for the establishment of a Single Resolution Mechanism in the form of a Union body. This Mechanism will aim at the resolution of credit institutions as well as certain undertakings in the Participating Member States, but, above all, it will have an independent budget so that taxpayers' money is not spent, because this will protect financial stability without burdening the taxpayers of the Member States.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation does not object to the Commission's delegated Regulation on the provisional system of advances on contributions to cover the administrative expenditure of the Single Resolution Board during the transitional period. It therefore aims to make this Council operational. Our position on this recommendation is inextsideable from our position, more generally, with regard to the Single Resolution Board itself and the bank union project in which it is included. We reject the option of centralizing the surveillance mechanisms, amputating significant portions of sovereignty that states have preserved until now. This crisis should rethink the entire architecture of the financial system, focusing on the need for public control of banking and financial institutions as the only way to ensure the proper functioning of the economy. Given the essentially technical nature of the recommendation, we have chosen to abstain.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) In favour of the report because we believe it is right that the Committee should have an autonomous budget, which is not part of the Union budget and which should be financed by contributions from the banking sector, in particular through contributions to the Committee's administrative expenditure to be paid by credit institutions, parent companies, investment firms and financial institutions covered by the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting in favour of the Commission's delegated regulation on the temporary system of advances against contributions to cover the administrative costs of the Single Resolution Board during the transitional period, because I believe that this will protect financial stability without burdening the taxpayers of the Member States.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for an EP resolution on a temporary system of partial contribution payments to cover the administrative expenditure of the SRB during the interim period, as I consider it necessary to define as soon as possible the funding to cover the first administrative costs of the SRB.  A temporary system should be implemented that will allow the Committee to raise funds at the initial stage to cover costs by the end of 2015, including e.g. part of staff and infrastructure.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the European Commission's recommendation for a delegated act on the provisional system of instalments on the contributions of the Single Resolution Council. This delegated act establishes the funds allocated to the Single Resolution Council to cover its administrative expenses. The recommendation supports the implementation of these funds. The recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have no objections to the delegated regulation. It will allow the Single Resolution Board to operate smoothly.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of this recommendation because I believe that the Single Resolution Committee must necessarily have an autonomous budget which is therefore outside the Union budget. Considering that its operation must start on 1 January 2015, it is necessary for it to have access to the relevant financing mechanisms as soon as possible.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution. The Delegated Regulation provides for the establishment of the Single Resolution Board of credit institutions and certain investment firms within the framework of a Single Resolution Mechanism and a Single Bank Resolution Fund. It is proposed that this Board should have an autonomous budget which is not part of the Union budget and which should be financed by contributions from the banking sector, in particular contributions to the administrative costs of the Board to be paid by credit institutions, parent companies, investment firms and financial institutions covered by the MUR Regulation.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour because the committee responsible drafted the resolution well and qualitatively and was fully in line with the position of my political group.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting against this regulation because I do not agree with the temporary system of advances on contributions to cover the administrative costs of the Single Resolution Board during the transitional period.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution. The Committee of the Regions must necessarily have a budget independent of that of the EU and financed by contributions from the banking sector, in particular through contributions to the Committee's administrative expenditure, which must be paid by credit institutions, parent companies, investment firms and financial institutions covered by the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) In view of the fact that the Single Resolution Committee must necessarily have an autonomous budget, outside the Union budget, financed by contributions from the banking sector, and whereas, with the objective of ensuring its proper functioning from 1 January 2015, it is necessary for it to have the relevant financing mechanisms at its disposal as soon as possible, I felt it appropriate to vote in favour of the recommendation , which does not raise any objections to the delegated regulation.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — Since the Single Resolution Committee must be rejected as a whole, I have also rejected the request for advance contributions for the same. The creation of another committee, the sole purpose of which is to patronise the various European nation states, is unnecessary and, moreover, to be avoided.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I had opposed the single resolution mechanism which establishes the Troika as the supreme saviour of the European banking sector. I therefore object to the establishment of interim funding for this single resolution council (CRU) that organises it. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — I share the rapporteur's position of non-objecting to the Commission's delegated Regulation on the provisional system of advances in contributions to cover the administrative expenditure of the Single Resolution Board during the transitional period.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution as it will allow the Commission greater flexibility and efficiency when assisting banks in the euro area. Taxpayers will therefore be spared unnecessary expenses should banks in their Member States encounter any difficulties.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. Since the beginning of the financial, economic and banking crisis of 2008, the Commission has been doing everything it can to save the single currency. The dramatic increase in member states' debt in the euro area and the domino and devastating effect observed in the countries sharing the euro have led the Commission and the European institutions to put in place control tools to maintain the banking union. This is the Single Monitoring Mechanism (SSM) and the Single Resolution Mechanism (MRU). The Single Resolution Council has significant powers, allowing it to define, for example, which instrument to use and how much of the European Resolution Fund to grant to a bank. We are asked here to accept the interim system of instalments on contributions to cover CRU expenses. As the rescue of the euro led to austerity plans and the impoverishment of the peoples of Europe, I voted against it.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — Since the Single Resolution Committee must be rejected in its entirety, I have also rejected the request for advance contributions. The creation of another committee, the sole purpose of which is to patronise the various European nation states, is completely unnecessary.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Commission's delegated regulation on the provisional system of advance payment of contributions to cover the administrative expenditure of the Single Resolution Committee during the interim period, because everything falls under the ordinary procedure and Parliament and the Council, if necessary, would have raised objections. In addition, in order for the Committee to function properly, it must have the necessary financing mechanisms as soon as possible in order to be able to carry out its activities.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — The operation of the Single Resolution Council undoubtedly requires the allocation of funds. I therefore vote in favour of this grant.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — Article 42 of the SRM Regulation provides for the establishment of a Single Resolution Board, which should be fully operational from 1 January 2015. In accordance with the powers conferred on it in Article 65(5) of the SRM Regulation, the Commission adopted on 8 October 2014 a delegated regulation on the provisional system of advances on contributions to cover the administrative expenditure of the Single Resolution Board during the transitional period. However, in view of the fact that the regular functioning of the Council from 1 January 2015 requires that it has established its financing arrangements as soon as possible and, in any event, before 1 January 2015, so that it can cover its first administrative expenditure (staff salaries, infrastructure, administrative and operating expenses) with its own resources and considering that the Council will also have an autonomous budget , which is not part of the Union budget and is financed by contributions from the banking sector, I voted in favour of this Decision not to object to that Commission delegated regulation of 8 October 2014.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — — I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution. The Delegated Regulation provides for the establishment of the Single Resolution Board of credit institutions and certain investment firms within the framework of a Single Resolution Mechanism and a Single Bank Resolution Fund. It is proposed that this Board should have an autonomous budget which is not part of the Union budget and which should be financed by contributions from the banking sector, in particular contributions to the administrative costs of the Board to be paid by credit institutions, parent companies, investment firms and financial institutions covered by the MUR Regulation.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in support of the draft decision on the provisional system of instalments on contributions to cover the administrative expenditures of the Single Resolution Board during the provisional period. The Board will have an autonomous budget which is not part of the Union budget and will be financed through contributions from the banking sector. In particular, contributions for the administrative expenditures of the Board are to be paid by the credit institutions, parent undertakings, investment firms and financial institutions that are covered by the SRM Regulation.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. — I support this resolution not objecting to the Commission Delegated Regulation of 8 October 2014 on a temporary system of partial contribution payments to cover the administrative expenditure of the SRB during the interim period, as the SRB will have an independent budget that is not part of the Union budget and will be financed by contributions from the banking sector, in particular contributions to the SRB's administrative expenditure to be paid by credit institutions , parent companies, investment firms and financial institutions covered by the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation. It is also important to stress that the smooth functioning of the Committee by 1 January 2015 requires the establishing of funding mechanisms as soon as possible, allowing the Committee to cover the first administrative expenditure, namely employee salaries, infrastructure and operating costs from its own resuses, but also for the Committee to be fully operational as of 1 January 2015, as required by Article 98 TFEU. Regulation on the Single Resolution Mechanism.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — Financial stability must be protected without burdening the taxpayers of the Member States.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the European Parliament's draft decision not to object to the Commission's delegated regulation of 8 October 2014 on the provisional system of instalments on contributions to cover the administrative expenses of the Single Resolution Council during the transitional period.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We understand the need to make the policy decisions decided by the Commission and the Council operational. We understand that the Single Resolution Board already needs the means to be able to start operating as early as January 2015. However, we reject these regulatory policies, idealized under the effect of the financial crisis, which centralize surveillance mechanisms to the detriment of the sovereignty of countries. We therefore believe that this crisis should rethink the entire architecture of the financial system, focusing the discussion on the need for public control of banking and financial institutions as the only way to ensure the proper functioning of the economy. As such, we refuse to be associated with this single mechanism of resolution, thus opting to abstain.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. — In view of the fact that the creation of another committee is only intended to give further powers of the Member States to Brussels and that this is, after all, a paternalism in the sense of a Brussels EU centralism, which I strongly oppose as such, I voted against the request for advance contributions.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, because delays in the programming for cohesion policies mean that in England, European structural investment fund programmes might not be approved this year. One of the key reasons is that the UK Government has, crucially, failed to provide the vehicles responsible for implementing the funds with the appropriate delegated powers. This means that the UK Government is effectively jeopardising the allocation of EUR 909 million in funds to my region, the West Midlands, which could be used to deliver growth in our towns and cities. Partners are ready and willing to act, but it appears that the crucial obstacle is the UK Government’s continued reluctance to delegate the most minimal of powers to get these programmes agreed with the Commission.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE). -
text: I voted in favour because we must ensure that the maximum number of operational programmes is approved and thus their implementation is accelerated. Given the delay already in the European Commission, I believe that it is necessary to allow additional absorption in 2015.  Otherwise, Mr President, I want to give you great praise for the way you are chairing this meeting.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE). -
text: I also voted in favour of this proposal, saying that I consider the importance of cohesion policy to be indisputable for the economic growth of the European Union. That is why I have decided to support this proposal, while also saying that it goes hand in hand with president Juncker's support for economic growth and what package he has presented.  I consider the cooperation of the Vice-President for Budget and Human Resources and the Commissioner for Regional Development to be particularly important. My previous spokesman, My colleague Zdechovský, has already pointed out the delay in implementing cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. I am concerned whether, for example, the opening up of the Multiannual Financial Framework could also pose a risk to beneficiaries of this policy, as Member States may wish to raise the issue of the level of their commitments in the new period. I'd like to avoid that.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE). -
text: I also agreed with this motion for a resolution and also co-signed it. This proposal is, in my opinion, extremely important because – it has already been said here – the preparation of individual funds under cohesion policy is being neglected at the moment, especially for 2014.  It is clear that the issue of cohesion policy and the question of those funds is particularly important for the economically less powerful states of the European Union, where it is simply an important investment achievement and significant public money that helps in the development of infrastructure. I am from the Czech Republic and I can say the numbers for the Czech Republic. Since the Czech Republic's accession to the European Union, the Czech Republic has managed to raise over CZK 333 billion more than the money it has provided to the European Union budget.  So it is clear that, despite the problems of drawing on this money, these funds have a positive impact on the states and need to continue to exhaust at least some of the money in 2014.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of the cohesion funding resolution because my home region, the North-East of England, benefits from millions of pounds in European funding which goes to support projects across the region. These projects have created and continue to create jobs, improve our skills base and grow our regional economy. The current delay in agreeing England’s regional operational programme is jeopardising that crucial investment, and I believe that the UK Government is endangering the funds. Not only did the government unilaterally abolish the established and respected regional development agencies but, to add insult to injury, they have not done enough to ensure that the replacement local economic partnerships are adequately resourced or accountable. My constituency is caught in the centre of this, and I strongly support the resolution’s call for the Commission and national governments to show responsibility in resolving this situation as quickly as possible. With the highest overall unemployment and youth unemployment in the UK and with GBP 724 million foreseen in the next seven years, we have a lot at stake.

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, I supported the motion on the delays in the start-up of cohesion policy. I want to send a very clear message to the Commission and the national governments that they must get their acts together. Over GBP 400 million in EU funding for the south-east of England risks being delayed if operational programmes are not formally adopted in time. That means local projects to create local jobs, train young people and improve infrastructure, all at risk of being put on hold. The Commission must do all it can to speed up this process to enable those projects to begin on time; procedures must be followed, but there should also be some flexibility in this. They should make sure that implementation can begin as soon as they agree in principle to the programmes. That way, local authorities can begin to apply to get vital projects funded and up and running as soon as possible.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR). -
text: Mr President, the whole cohesion project must be reckoned one of the most measurable failures since its introduction under the Maastricht Treaty. The idea was to level the poorer areas up by spending more money in them. Well, what was the biggest per capita recipient of EU funds? It was Greece. How did that work out? The truth is that if you tax wealthy countries in order to pay poor countries, you end up with fewer wealthy countries and more poor countries. Whole states – just as individuals – can become dependent on subsidy. Perverse incentives lead them to construct their affairs around the receipt of the grants. We have heard from some of my British colleagues about how important it is to get money for projects in the UK. But of course, not only are we net contributors in the UK, so that they are seeing and counting only the gains rather than the tax; these are not projects that create jobs; these are jobs primarily designed to advertise and aggrandise the European Union rather than to stimulate local growth. If you really want to help the stricken areas of Europe, we should be doing the opposite of cohesion. We should be encouraging diversity, pluralism and, specifically, allowing them to leave the euro, price themselves back into the market and export their way back to growth.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! I voted in favour of the resolution and I would just like to make three comments. The first comment is that cohesion policy is important and should also lead to an approximation of living conditions. We must, of course, look under the heading of better spending to ensure that the money is properly used. However, I would like to encourage and also to say that cohesion policy has not only proved its worth in my region, but that there is also movement going on. The new Länder in Germany, the East German Länder, are increasingly out of the so-called target area status. They are getting better, not least because of European cohesion policy. Secondly, it's the same game every seven years, it doesn't really start. That is why we should also set in motion transitional political provisions so that the programmes really go through, so that this procedural freeze does not always occur. Thirdly, I would ask the Member States once again to finally transfer their outstanding membership fees so that we have enough money in the coffers for this cohesion policy.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. Cohesion policy for the period 2007-2013 has not achieved its objective of harmonious development, for the responsibility of both the EU and the regions of many Member States. The serious shortcomings found, such as the insufficient and distorted use of the resources allocated in relation to the ambitious objectives set and poor quality control and programming instruments that have automatically proved ineffective, seem to be the same as they have been since the start of the new phase. The aggravating factor in detecting a considerable delay in previous payments, and even in the mere presentation of operational programmes by many regions, reinforces the awareness of the need to adopt widespread counter-measures to prevent the re-proposal of these degenerative dynamics in the future. I am voting in favour of this motion by continuing to exercise my duties to encourage improvement, continuous vigilance and denunciation.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution because the Council and the Commission can enter, as they have entered, into a battle over who has responsibility for the delay in the implementation of cohesion policy, but the truth is that what has failed so far is the design of cohesion policy itself and its management. The implementation of the new regional policy should be more efficient and simpler, quite the opposite of what is happening in reality: approved but unpaid invoices, operational programs pending implementation, municipalities that cannot participate as partnerships... We are witnessing an increase in inequalities between different regions of the EU. And it is therefore urgent that the EU act to reverse this trend because, as always, it is European citizens who are paying for the duck.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. - There have been significant delays in the implementation of cohesion policy for 2014-2020. Only one fifth of all operational programmes will be adopted before the end of the year, although the submission and adoption should have taken place by the end of January 2015. Cohesion policy is one of the most important strategies for investing in the real economy: with over €350 billion by 2020, it is a major contribution to creating growth and jobs in the EU. It is therefore negligent to allow important time to pass. Implementation of the programmes must start as soon as possible so as not to hinder investment in jobs, growth, renewable energy and cross-border projects. The government and the Commission must get their heads around it and speed up the process effectively so that further damage is averted. We also urgently need a solution to the outstanding payments of EUR 23 billion from the 2007-2013 funding period.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The policy itself is misguided, and will not achieve its intended effect.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I express my sincere concern regarding the delay in adoption of the operational programmes and delays in implementation of cohesion policy for the period of 2014-2020. It is expected that only about half of the total programmes will actually be adopted by the end of this year and the rest will face a long delay in the start of implementation because of the appeared requirement of technical revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). In 2015 Europe might face a significant downturn in growth, a missed opportunity for investments and creation of jobs. This is a risk which must be avoided. Thus I call upon the Commission and the Member States to streamline internal procedures in order to ensure that as many programmes as possible are ready for adoption by 31 December 2014. Furthermore, the adoption of the MFF revision must be conducted as early as feasible and the solutions for limiting the damage must be envisaged very clearly. This scenario cannot happen again in the future. The price is too high and the lessons must be learned.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to encourage the Commission and the Member States to draw up and approve cohesion policy programmes for the period 2014-2020 as soon as possible. Cohesion policy is the EU's main policy of investment in the real economy and a tool to promote growth and jobs in the EU, with more than EUR 350 billion allocated by 2020. the budget of eur 100 million. Today, not only is there a delay in the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, but also delays in payments for the 2007-2013 programming period, both of which undermine the credibility of cohesion policy. I support the calls for the Commission and the Member States to adopt as many operational programmes as early as 2014. It is essential that the Commission try to simplify its internal procedures to allow for faster approval of programmes.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text because it does not pose the fundamental problem of the lack of transparency in the management of these funds allocated by the European Union, not least because their management has been transferred from the State to the regions.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — The cohesion policy for 2014-2020 is obviously a major programme with regard to socio-economic development and solidarity within the European Union. The added value of the Structural Funds for the troubled regions of the Member States is obviously undeniable. They allow for in-depth action to support the redeployment of these regions. They have created tens of thousands of jobs. It is therefore essential that the launch of the new programming period does not experience a significant delay and that the 2014 appropriations are deferred in 2015.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. At a time when the European Union intends to launch a vast investment plan of more than EUR 315,000,000 and the Cohesion Policy is endowed with more than EUR 350,000,000,000 by 2020, the European Union now faces a very serious problem of unpaid debts (23 billion euros for the period 2007-2013 and probably nearly 28 billion by the end of 2014). It is totally inconceivable that Brussels will call on Member States to be more rigorous and fiscally disciplined even as these unpaid debts grow year after year.  In addition, it is becoming urgent for the European Union to more rigorously control its spending on cohesion policy, which has an "error" rate of 6.9%, according to the European Court of Auditors in its 2013 report.  That is why I abstained on this report in order to avoid botching operational programmes with a possible risk of further fraud.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which not only denounces the delays in implementing cohesion policy 2014-2020 but also underlines the seriousness of the fact that there is still a backlog in payments of around EUR 23 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — It has only been twenty-one days after the new Commissioner for Regional Policy took office. It is very little time to be able to make any kind of reproach for the exercise of his functions. It is true, however, that the European solidarity represented by cohesion policy does not have the hundred days of grace that we grant in democracy to those who assume a new role of government. Despite the delay since January this year, I am confident, as my group does, of the new Commissioner's ability to give the programming of the European cohesion policy the impetus she needs. The process of adopting operational programmes needs to be accelerated to the maximum in order to avoid further developments in their implementation. The College of Commissioners must find urgent solutions and clear commitments on the problems linked to the lack of co-financing and non-payment incurred by the Commission itself, which also substantially affect the normal development of cohesion policy, to the detriment, precisely, of those citizens and those regions and countries most hit by the crisis and by unemployment and most in need of European solidarity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because cohesion policy is an essential tool for the European Union (EU) strategy, helping to reduce regional disparities and inequalities, contributing to increasing diversity and adapting to industrial change, contributing to economic, social and territorial cohesion. This policy is a key EU-wide investment instrument for the economy, growth and jobs, which has received more than EUR 350 billion by 2020. the budget of eur 100 million. The European Parliament is particularly concerned about the significant delays in the implementation of the cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. Recalls, furthermore, that the current delays pose difficulties for national, regional and local authorities in terms of capacity to plan and implement effectively in the period 2014-2020. european structural investment funds. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission and the Member States to act responsibly and to take all possible measures to prepare and approve as many programmes as early as this year.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. — Rationalising and simplifying cohesion policy is a priority that cannot be postponed in order to use the funds efficiently and quickly. The Cohesion Funds are a fundamental and proven catalyst for growth and employment in the countries of the European Union. This can be further strengthened at this stage if it is coordinated with the commission's extraordinary investment package. Despite the enormous potential of the resources available, however, we are seeing a considerable delay in the adoption of operational plans and in the application of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, due to the limitations of the multiannual financial framework and the slow programming process. Just over 100 programmes will be adopted by the end of the year. A revision of the multiannual financial framework to facilitate the operating programmes is therefore necessary. That is why I support this resolution.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because I believe that we must remind the Commission of its duty to effectively plan and organise programmes and funding for cohesion policy for the current programming period.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour. I agree with the denunciation of the delays in implementing cohesion policy 2014-2020. I agree with the emphasis on the existence of a backlog in payments of around EUR 23 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period. I agree with the observation that these delays are causing problems for national and regional authorities.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - The implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 should have begun in January this year, but the programming period is far from over. It is estimated that only one hundred programs will be operational by the end of the year.  The REGI Commission is addressed to the European Commission to learn about the status of partnership agreements, operational programmes (POs) and the timetable for their implementation, as well as the problems encountered and the measures it intends to take.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Delays in launching new operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 are causing growing concern.  I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because the delays that are accumulating in the programming of the European Structural Funds 2014-2020 risk disrupting the Community machine in many regions in the main beneficiary countries, such as Poland, Spain and Italy, with the serious danger of having to reopen the debate on the financial perspectives that were laboriously approved a year ago.  Yet the 2014-2020 programmes represent an investment in the future and an investment in Europe: cohesion policy is entrusted with the crucial task of reducing member states' territorial development gaps in relation to Europe 2020 priorities and targets.  I believe that the Commission must speed up programming and equip itself with stricter performance control instruments, in order to better allocate resources to ensure new investments.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. – The delays that have accompanied the establishment of the multiannual financial framework are, unfortunately, entailing a shift in the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020.  At a time of serious and profound economic crisis, such as the one we are experiencing, it is essential that cohesion policy is activated as soon as possible, not only to restart public funding, but also because, for many regions, the Structural Funds are the only resources for planning local development and triggering processes of economic recovery.
