On Monday afternoon, Commissioner Creţu informed us that he is making rapid progress with the approval of the operational programmes and I hope that we will continue in this direction.  With the vote on today's resolution, I support this House's call for the Commission to step up its efforts to launch cohesion policy quickly, including by streamlining the procedures for approving operational programmes, but above all I very much hope that every effort will be made to prevent late payments.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this text because I believe that the delays in cohesion policy 2014-2020 can be a serious damage to the already compromised economic situation of Europe's regions. Cohesion policy is today the main means of investment throughout the Union and must be seen as an essential means of economic recovery and growth.  Postponing further the adoption of the operational programmes would irresponsibly delay the launch of cohesion policy 2014-2020, which, as already mentioned, is the financial instrument par excellence capable of ensuring the revival of European regions and consequently the growth of employment and the reduction of poverty and social exclusion.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I believe that delays in implementing cohesion policy 2014-2020 can further aggravate europe's already difficult economic situation. Since the latter is extremely important for reviving growth in Europe, further delaying the adoption of the programmes would be a mistake, and that is why I believe it is urgent for the Commission and the Member States to do everything possible to speed up the adoption of the operational programmes as soon as possible, putting aside every possible obstacle to the initiation of the procedure.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. - Cohesion policy represents the main EU-wide investment policy in the real economy as it forms a major part of the EU strategy to redress regional imbalances and inequalities. In most Member States it forms the principle source of public investment. For this reason Member States have to show responsibility and do their utmost to speed up the adoption of maximum operational programmes in 2014. In the light of the delay in payments at the start of the implementation of the new operational programmes, the Commission must put forward solutions for limiting the damage as far as possible. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Cohesion policy, with a budget of over EUR 350 billion until 2020, is the main investment policy in the real economy at EU level and an excellent engine of growth in Europe. I voted in favour of this resolution in order to urge the Commission and the Member States to show a sense of responsibility and to do everything in their power to speed up the adoption of the maximum number of operational programmes as early as 2014, as well as to ensure that as many programmes as possible are 'ready for adoption' by 31 December 2014, in order to benefit from the carry-over procedure , in accordance with Article 13(2)(a), the Financial Regulation and Article 4 of the detailed rules for its application. The Commission should optimise its internal procedures to ensure that operational programmes resubmitted after the deadline of 17 November 2014 are also taken into account in order to conclude the inter-service consultation by the end of the year and are treated as ready for adoption if they meet the quality requirements.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution because the Council and the Commission can enter, as they have entered, into a battle over who has responsibility for the delay in the implementation of cohesion policy, but the truth is that what has failed so far is the design of cohesion policy itself and its management. The implementation of the new regional policy should be more efficient and simpler, quite the opposite of what is happening in reality: approved but unpaid invoices, operational programs pending implementation, municipalities that cannot participate as partnerships... We are witnessing an increase in inequalities between different regions of the EU. And it is therefore urgent that the EU act to reverse this trend because, as always, it is European citizens who are paying for the duck.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Due to delays in the validation of operational programmes for the period 2014-2020, a necessary step to enable the Structural Funds to finance projects in our territories, this resolution calls on the European Commission and Member States to take, with the help of the European Parliament, all necessary measures to enable the payment of pre-financing planned for 2014.  In France, 84 French programmes are financed under the European Structural and Investment Funds (FEDER, ESF, FEADER and FEAMP). It is therefore essential for project owners, public authorities, private companies and our territories concerned that programming for the period 2014-2020 can be undertaken without further delay.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With a budget of more than 350 billion euros, cohesion policy is an important public investment tool for our territories, all the more so in a tense budgetary context. This is why it is essential to facilitate the adoption and implementation of the 2014 operational programmes aimed at implementing cohesion policy while remaining vigilant about the quality of their development, on the one hand, and the fight against fraud, on the other.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. The implementation of cohesion policy was due to begin in 2014, with the implementation and adoption of partnership agreements and operational programmes by the end of August 2014 and the end of January 2015 respectively, according to Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013. To date, we are faced with a clear delay where only a limited number of operational programmes will be adopted by 2014 and the others will come into operation in mid-2015. I voted in favour of this resolution so that the process of adopting operational programmes can be speeded up by 2014, in order to ensure that they are adopted by the Member States and their regions as soon as possible.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — The European Union is facing a clear delay in the Structural Funds' programming process for the period 2014-2020. While only half of the operational programmes for the period are expected to be adopted by the end of the year, there are fears that 2014 budget commitments may be lost.  This situation is not acceptable. These funds represent about 34% of the EU budget and enable regions to invest in major infrastructure projects that can create jobs and economic growth. We must therefore help and encourage states to make better use of this funding. If these funds are to be an effective tool for regional development, procedures must be simplified, local and regional authorities to independently manage the use of grants, and ease barriers to project co-financing.

name: Deutsch Tamás (PPE)
text: Writing. - Cohesion policy is the most important EU investment policy, the engine of Growth and Jobs in Europe, with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion for the period up to 2020. A major problem for the effectiveness of cohesion policy is the strong delay in the programming process, as only a small part of the planned operating programmes will be adopted by the end of 2014. Of course, it is important that quality operating programmes are developed and adopted in order to avoid future reprogramming, but the current delay makes it difficult for national, regional and local authorities to make effective use of the 2014-2020 Structural Funds.  It is also a problem that, since cohesion policy (supplemented by member states' co-financing) represents the largest share of public expenditure on growth in the Union, we are hampering the efficiency of investment with any delay. In addition to the delay in the programming process, the problem of recurring unpaid arrears, which currently amounts to EUR 23 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period, is a further problem. This deficit significantly undermines the credibility, effectiveness and sustainability of cohesion policy. It is important and urgent to reach an agreement on the arrears as soon as possible, on the basis of new proposals from the European Commission. Furthermore, it is essential that as many programmes as possible be placed in the 'ready for adoption' category by the end of 2014.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of this Resolution, understanding that the motion raises a coherent and critical view of the Commission's delays in cohesion policy. We consider it very serious that the Commission should be delayed in mobilizing cohesion policy funds which constitute its only expenditure on social policy. However, the Resolution makes an ambiguous mention of the Juncker stimulus plan which we do not understand and which we believe has no place when it comes to cohesion policy. Under no circumstances should our support for this Resolution be understood as support for the Juncker stimulus plan.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — The Commission must assume its responsibilities and promote solutions to the problems presented. The EU wants it to be called economic union and therefore it must, if anything, prove this by providing timely solutions to economic issues.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — Cohesion policy is the main EU-wide investment policy in the real economy and a recognised catalyst for growth and jobs in the EU, with a budget of over €350 billion by 2020 and is therefore an important part of the EU strategy to correct regional imbalances and inequalities, promote diversification and adaptation to industrial change and achieve economic cohesion , social and territorial. In addition to the delay in implementation for the 2014-2020 programming period, cohesion policy also faces a delay in payments amounting to around EUR 23 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period, which should be of concern. Having said that, it is essential that the Commission and the Member States show responsibility and make every effort to speed up the adoption of a maximum number of operational programmes in 2014.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this resolution as it expressed deep concern at the significant delays in implementing cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. It also recognises that these delays represent a challenge (pass the euphemism) to national, regional and local authorities in the effective planning and implementation of the Structural Funds. In fact, it is not just about challenges, when reality shows the objective difficulties in obtaining financing. In this way, Parliament puts pressure on the Commission and member states that have not yet paid their share to the budget in order to speed up the adoption of the maximum number of operational programmes by 31 December 2014.  Operational programmes, which are not ready for adoption by the end of 2014, involve a procedure for revising the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 (MFF) by 1 May 2015, and Parliament therefore invites the Commission to start a debate with the three institutions as soon as possible, with a view to setting out a review of the MFF as early as possible in 2015 , which we agree to argue that the MFF is need-specific, in particular in the field of economic and social cohesion.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. — Cohesion policy, together with co-financing involving Member States, is a source of major public expenditure relating to the growth of the European Union. Any delays associated with the implementation of cohesion policy in 2014-2020 undermine the ability of national authorities to plan and use the European Structural Funds effectively. It is therefore very important for the European Commission to push and appeal for the implementation of operational programmes as soon as possible, thus not hampering the flow of European funds into the Member States.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of this resolution because it denounces the delays in implementing cohesion policy 2014-2020 and highlights how these delays are causing problems for national and regional authorities.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting in favour of the reports on delays in the launch of cohesion policy 2014-2020 because the Commission must assume its responsibilities and promote solutions to the problems presented. The EU wants it to be called economic union and therefore it must, if anything, prove this by providing timely solutions to economic issues.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. — We are faced with a clear delay where only a limited number of operational programmes will be adopted by 2014 (about 100 out of over 300). For Italy, we hope that a good number of operational programmes can be ready by the deadline of 31 December 2014. It will be very important for the Commission to do its utmost to speed up its internal procedures for approving OOs as well so that the inevitable use of the revision of the multiannual Financial Framework under Regulation 1303/2013 is launched quickly and is completed on time, ensuring that the entire budget for Italy scheduled for 2014 is available in full and on schedule. I voted in favour because I hope that the Commission, together with Parliament and the Member States, will be able to find the most appropriate response in order to overcome the long-term challenges by effectively speeding up the implementation of programming. We are waiting for the Commission to give us more information on how it intends to launch the task force that it announced yesterday, informing Parliament of the future agenda. In view of the new 2014-2020 programming, I am sure that concrete and transparent measures will be taken, not punitive decisions, such as the reduction of public co-financing, but rather initiatives aimed at creating constructive synergies between the different actors acting on the ground.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because cohesion policy is of course aimed at harmonisation and cohesion in the development of European regions, but it is also one of our main investment strategies. In the current context of underinvestment and sluggish growth, its usefulness is being strengthened.  However, we are facing a delay in the programming process and only a very limited number of operational programmes are expected to be adopted by the end of 2014. The Commission and Member States must do all they can to speed up the process of adopting these programmes. I am also concerned about the level of arrears of payment, as well as the current deadlock in the adoption of the draft amending budget and the 2015 budget, which makes the situation regarding unpaid bills even more critical.  What impact will these late payments have on the start of the implementation of the new programs and what solutions could limit the extent of the harm caused by this situation? I hope that the Commission will be able to find answers to these questions. The reputation and credibility of the European institutions will not be able to withstand such a situation for long without suffering.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - The negotiation of operational programmes is undoubtedly a difficult and complex process for both the Member States and the European Commission, and the efforts made by both sides in this dialogue must therefore be appreciated. Unfortunately, however, delays in the implementation of cohesion policy appear to be difficult to avoid. We need to be aware of the great challenge for local and regional authorities to make such a shift. I therefore believe that it is particularly important that as many operational programmes as possible have a statute ready for adoption by the end of this year. I know, on the basis of Polish country, how determined our authorities are and how hard they are working to achieve this goal. I believe that a similar determination is on the part of the European Commission and we will avoid the need for a difficult procedure for revising the Multiannual Financial Framework, or at least minimise it. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of this Resolution, understanding that the motion raises a coherent and critical view of the Commission's delays in cohesion policy. We consider it very serious that the Commission should be delayed in mobilizing cohesion policy funds which constitute its only expenditure on social policy. However, the Resolution makes an ambiguous mention of the Juncker stimulus plan which we do not understand and which we believe has no place when it comes to cohesion policy. Under no circumstances should our support for this Resolution be understood as support for the Juncker stimulus plan.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a resolution on delayed implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, as currently cohesion policy is in crisis, which in particular shows lagging behind in unpaid bills, and a major delay in operational programmes.  It is necessary that the implementation of new programmes starts as soon as possible, and that internal procedures are simplified, in order to stimulate the increase in growth and jobs. I believe that cohesion policy should be one of the key EU policies, with local and regional authorities playing the same relevant role, i.e. the principle of subsidiarity being the best solution.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution on delays in launching the cohesion policy for 2014-2020. This text underlines the worrying delay in the validation of operational programmes, which is essential to implementing the new cohesion policy. The Commission will have only validated half of the programmes before the end of the year, whereas it was due to have validated all of them in autumn 2014. This delay will create significant difficulties for projects requesting pre-financing in 2014, as validation will extend until 2015 and may potentially require a review of the Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF). The resolution therefore calls on the Commission and Member States to take all measures to validate as many programmes as possible before the end of 2014, and to prepare as early as possible with Parliament the procedures for revising the MFF before the fateful date of 1 May 2015. This resolution was adopted by a very large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I welcome the adoption of this resolution which warns of delays in the launch of the Cohesion Policy for 2014-2020, when it is, in the crisis period, a major catalyst for growth for the Union's territories and the main investment strategy in the real economy at European level.  Firstly, there is an urgent need for a solution to the problem of arrears of payment for operational programmes 2007-2013 because it calls into question the credibility and effectiveness of cohesion policy itself. In addition, with regard to the 2014-2020 programming period, the Commission and Member States must accelerate the adoption of as many operational programmes as possible by the end of 2014, as the delays in the 2014 programme call into question the ability of regional and local authorities to adequately plan and implement the European Structural and Investment Funds (EFSI).  It is therefore important for the Commission to present To Parliament a timetable for action and the measures it intends to take, as soon as possible, to facilitate the implementation of operational programmes in all Member States.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. I am extremely concerned about the significant delay in implementation of the cohesion policy for 2014-2020. Cohesion policy represents the main EU-wide investment policy in the real economy and is a catalyst for growth and jobs in Europe. It forms a major part of the EUʼs strategy to redress regional imbalances and inequalities, to assist diversification and the adaptation to industrial change, and to achieve economic, social and territorial cohesion. It is imperative to start the implementation of the new programmes as soon as possible in order to maximise the results of the investments, boost job creation and raise productivity growth. We must not lose time and must put forward solutions for limiting the damage of delays as much as possible. The EU bureaucracy should focus more on the real needs of the European people, regions and industrial sector and start to act in an efficient and proper manner. The overall goal should be building an innovative and competitive Europe which is functioning to fulfil the needs of European people.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. - I strongly support this motion. European funding is crucial to the North-West region and brings lots of benefits to the people. Any delay in the Council agreeing the programme with the Commission could jeopardise a lot of projects. Many regions, many small businesses and many non-governmental organisations rely on EU funds to invest and act on the ground. We therefore urge the Council to face up its responsibilities. We need the jobs and we need the investment.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - We are all aware of the fundamental role played by EU cohesion policy in the development of our territories. Unfortunately, national or regional authorities are not always able to make the most of the resources that Europe makes available to reduce development gaps between the different Member States. With the start of the new programming, for the period 2014-2020, which foresees some delays, this fact becomes more evident. I therefore support the text of this report in calling on the Member States to speed up the programming of new resources.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. — Cohesion policy is the eu-wide policy of investing in the real economy and a tool to promote growth and jobs in the EU, with more than EUR 350 billion by 2020. the budget of eur 100 million. This sentence starts with the document that we voted on today.  It should also be emphasised that cohesion policy is the main source of investment in some Member States. The new President of the European Commission is deeply concerned about the delay in the implementation of an important EU policy instrument, but the implementation of a high-quality action programme can easily avoid future errors, fraud and opaque management of funds in the Member States. The aim is therefore to reach an agreement on the timetable for the implementation of the measures by the end of 2014 and to complement the Cohesion Policy Fund with EUR 315 billion. The financing of investments provided for by the new European Commission.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I am concerned about the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, which should have started in January this year and accumulates a significant delay. Parliament has adopted a resolution which shows its concern not only for the current programming, but for the possible defaults that may be in relation to the previous period. We look forward to speeding up the process and avoiding further details.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution because the Council and the Commission can enter, as they have entered, into a battle over who has responsibility for the delay in the implementation of cohesion policy, but the truth is that what has failed so far is the design of cohesion policy itself and its management. The implementation of the new regional policy should be more efficient and simpler, quite the opposite of what is happening in reality: approved but unpaid invoices, operational programs pending implementation, municipalities that cannot participate as partnerships... We are witnessing an increase in inequalities between different regions of the EU. And it is therefore urgent that the EU act to reverse this trend because, as always, it is European citizens who are paying for the duck.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - We cannot dwell on a sector as vital to the EU as cohesion policy. I voted in favour with our group.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution because it criticises the delay in launching cohesion policy for 2014-2020, as, among other things, operational programmes could at least now ease the enormous social impact caused to Greece by the troika's mandates and the resulting measures of the Memorandum of Understanding.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — The delays in cohesion policy 2014-2020 are a serious damage to the already compromised economic situation of Europe's regions.  Postponing the adoption of operational programmes further would irresponsibly delay the launch of cohesion policy 2014-2020. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - Cohesion policy mobilises funding totalling EUR 351 billion. The relevant funds account for about a third of the EU budget for the period 2014-2020. It makes a net contribution to growth, and job creation, in many Member States. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution, which calls for an acceleration of cohesion policy for the new 2014-2020 programming period.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — In general, the draft cohesion policy of 2014-2020 should be approved. However, before implementation for the 2014-2020 programming period, the arrears of EUR 23 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period must be settled. Otherwise, there is no support for financing the new project before the previous one is even completed.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - The cohesion policy, also known as the 'Regional Policy', aims to help strengthen the economic and social cohesion of the European Union. It represents a significant part of the European budget, as it is the second largest expenditure item after the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). This resolution condemns the delay in the implementation of the 2014-2020 programme, but also the arrears of payment amounting to some 23 billion euros for the period 2007-2013. It calls for the investment programme announced by the Commission to be fully added to the cohesion policy allocations for 2014-2020. I vote for it because I can only subscribe to these fine intentions. But I regret that their authors are also those who vote in Parliament on the austerity budgets that contradict them.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — Cohesion policy is the main EU-wide investment policy in the real economy and a recognised catalyst for growth and jobs in the EU, with a budget of over €350 billion by 2020. Cohesion policy is an important part of the EU strategy to correct regional imbalances and inequalities, promote diversification and adaptation to industrial change and achieve economic, social and territorial cohesion. In some Member States, this policy is the main source of public investment. So we have to condemn the delays in implementing cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this motion because of the serious need to begin the implementation of the cohesion policy. The delay is impeding national, regional and local authorities’ capacity to strategise the effective use of public expenditure intended to boost growth in the EU. Since the cohesion policy and the funds allocated to it are the main investment tool of the EU, it is crucial that cohesion policy moves forward in order to begin delivering the Europe 2020 goals.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. - I am deeply concerned about the delayed start of the implementation of cohesion policy for 2014-2020, which was due to start immediately in 2014, but this year has almost passed and we have not made progress in adopting operational programmes in the Member States. As we already know from the experience of the previous programming period 2007-2013, such a significant annual delay will cause significant delays throughout the coming period and undermine the credibility and functionality of cohesion policy. In particular, regions that have legitimate expectations and where specific investments are not going to be made due to delays in programming are likely to suffer in 2015. It should not be forgotten that weakened investment dynamics also have an impact on job creation, economic growth and competitiveness. I therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to step up their efforts in adopting operational programmes.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am concerned about the delay in implementing the cohesion policy. These delays undermine regional and local authorities and their ability to effectively manage the Structural Funds. These funds are a catalyst for growth in Europe and therefore need to be given special attention in these difficult times. It is essential that the Commission come to Parliament to explain the action it wishes to take to remedy this. It is about our growth and well-being.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on delays in the start-up of cohesion policy for 2014-2020 calling for swifter adoption of operational programmes for the Structural Funds 2014-2020. The resolution calls on the Commission to ‘show responsibility’ and do all it can to ensure that as many programmes as possible are ‘ready for adoption’ by the end of 2014.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union is facing a very serious problem of unpaid debts (23 billion euros at the end of 2013 and probably nearly 30 by the end of 2014). Not to mention the 220 billion RAL (remains to be liquidated)... This year, in view of this more than tense budgetary situation, payment delays are emerging at the level of programmes co-financed with the Structural Funds.  The latest cohesion plan 2007/2013 is already experiencing countless payment delays on programmes and projects that have yet to be implemented. Local authorities and businesses are therefore heavily penalised financially as they have paid the bill and are, to this day, still awaiting CO-financing from the EU.  In addition, it is feared that the recent and hasty transfer of management of European funds to the regions will cause a significant delay in the assembly of the next programmes. Finally, some Member States are now in a particularly difficult situation, simply because of their economic and financial inability to follow the cohesion policy put in place by the EU. In such a context, how can we believe that the EU is seeking to improve the quality of life of peoples... So I abstained.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which describes the delay at European and regional level in the implementation of the new financial programme.  This resolution echoes the inability of the French socialist regions to implement European funds at the local level. While France already lags far behind in the use of European funds, the scrambled and uncomfted territorial reform is not likely to solve this delay.  One year after the start of the new programming, the new map of the French regions will probably lead to a renegotiation of the allocation of European funds from scratch, which will make us lose another year. The first victims will be citizens, businesses and associations who need European investment more than ever in a period of sluggish growth and unprecedented deterioration of the labour market, in addition to a drastic reduction in the allocations paid by the French State to local authorities.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text because the rapid implementation of the Structural Funds for the period 2014-2020 must be a priority for the European institutions. The answer lies in the simplification of procedures: we are in crisis, it is essential to mobilise these funds which will be factors of growth.

name: James Nicholson (ECR)
text: in writing. – The Cohesion Fund lies at the heart of the EU’s growth agenda, and as such is the largest instrument available to the EU to drive investment and to promote growth and jobs. A streamlined cohesion policy has real potential for addressing economic disparities among Member States and regions, reducing unemployment and encouraging growth. Northern Ireland has benefited immensely from European Structural and Investment Funds, and it was hoped that the Cohesion Fund would simplify the funding process. It was expected that Operational Programmes would be up and running by the end of 2014. However, we are facing a clear delay at the level of the programming process, and it estimated that only a small number of OPs will be adopted by the end of this year. It is vital that there are no further delays. Many organisations in Northern Ireland depend on this funding, and the onus is on the Commission and Member States to do their utmost to encourage the adoption of a maximum number of Operational Programmes, and on the Commission to present the measures it intends to undertake to proceed with the implementation of the Operational Programmes.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — In general, the draft cohesion policy of 2014-2020 should be approved. However, before implementation for the 2014-2020 programming period, the existing arrears of EUR 23 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period must be settled. I am strongly opposed to giving citizens an 'A' for an O and have been campaigning for clarity in the EU's financial policy for years. I do not see this clarity and transparency in this respect. I have therefore voted against the motion.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - I supported the proposal because cohesion policy is an investment policy for the whole of the European Union with EUR 350 billion and a strong driver of economic growth. I am concerned that the implementation of cohesion policy will be significantly delayed. The Commission and the Member States must demonstrate a sense of responsibility and make every effort to ensure that operational programmes are adopted as soon as possible. The Commission needs to present a specific plan to be taken to save the situation.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. — Cohesion policy is the eu's main form of investment in support of growth and employment. At a time of severe crisis such as the one we are experiencing, it becomes all the more strategic in order to restart the engine of the real economy. In line with the Europe 2020 objectives, the more than 350 billion resources allocated have been programmed for the targeted implementation of a limited number of strategic objectives such as innovation and research, training and education, the digital agenda, support for SMEs, the eco-sustainable economy and infrastructure. Given the high potential of these objectives, any slowdown in the programming process poses a threat to recovery. The delays are already there: there will only be just over 100 operational programmes adopted by 2014. This situation has already been weighed down by a late payment of around EUR 23 billion for the period 2007-2013. Given that the 315 billion package launched by President Junker is to be part of Europe 2020, the Commission must speed up the implementation of the programmes, ensuring, on the one hand, the quality of the programmes and, on the other, protection against fraud, in order to restore credibility and effectiveness to cohesion policy as soon as possible.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I supported MP Iskra Mihaylova's initiative on delays in the start of cohesion policy implementation for 2014-2020. We are familiar with the fact that cohesion policy implementation was due to start in 2014, but at the end of the year the programme phase is far from over. Only a small number of operational programmes have been approved and the commitments foreseen for 2014 can only be preserved by transferring the amount unused in 2014, in accordance with Article 19 of the Regulation. regulation on the multiannual financial framework. The problems we face are problems of lack of coordination and poor macroeconomic performance and in programme capacity through lack of strategic development and poor financial audit. The direct consequence will be significant delays in the start of project implementation. I would also like to stress the high staffing fluctuations, lack of resources and overlapping of the programme. I believe it is necessary for the rules to be harmonised and for professional and administrative support to be strengthened through the rationalisation of intermediate bodies and a clearer sharing of responsibilities.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) Here too, I voted in favour because I believe that the delay in implementing cohesion policy 2014-2020 is excessive and leads to a considerable slowdown in the implementation of the new programmes. I understand the desire to adopt high-level operational programmes in order to avoid subsequent reprogramming which would create further delays but, in a complex and difficult period such as the one we are experiencing, it is absolutely necessary to implement the new programmes as soon as possible in order to give a new boost to investment, increase productivity and create new jobs. The Commission and all the Member States have a great responsibility towards the citizens of Europe and must commit themselves to ensure that the maximum number of operational programmes is adopted as quickly as possible.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE)
text: In writing. — I co-signed, and voted in favour, the resolution on delays in launching the cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020.  Indeed, it is essential that local and regional authorities, especially those in the outermost regions, be able to launch their operational programme as soon as possible.  Cohesion policy plays an important role in supporting the economic and social development of our outermost regions.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. — While the Juncker Commission is already announcing its purported 315 billion stimulus package, it is lagging behind in cohesion policy. With the resolution I support, we call on the Commission to take a determined and careful approach to the EU's actual stimulus measures in cooperation with the Member States.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Delays in the adoption of operational programmes by the Commission and Member States, including France, put many projects in our territories on hold, sometimes even at risk. I insist that every effort be made to speed up their implementation.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — Cohesion policy represents a large proportion of public expenditure linked to growth in the EU, with a budget of over EUR 350 billion by 2020, and it is therefore imperative to start implementing the new operational programmes as soon as possible in order to maximise investment results, stimulate job creation and promote increased productivity. I therefore find very worrying the considerable delays in the programming and implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, as well as the situation of late payments under cohesion policy for the operational programmes for the period 2007-2013. For this reason, I voted in favour of this resolution, and I therefore would like to call for every effort to be made to ensure that as many operational programmes as possible are ready for adoption by 31 December 2014 and for the Commission to come up with solutions to alleviate the losses resulting from the delay in payments.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — It has only been twenty-one days after the new Commissioner for Regional Policy took office. It is very little time to be able to make any kind of reproach for the exercise of his functions. It is true, however, that the European solidarity represented by cohesion policy does not have the hundred days of grace that we grant in democracy to those who assume a new role of government. Despite the delay since January this year, I am confident, as my group does, of the new Commissioner's ability to give the programming of the European cohesion policy the impetus she needs. The process of adopting operational programmes needs to be accelerated to the maximum in order to avoid further developments in their implementation. The College of Commissioners must find urgent solutions and clear commitments on the problems linked to the lack of co-financing and non-payment incurred by the Commission itself, which also substantially affect the normal development of cohesion policy, to the detriment, precisely, of those citizens and those regions and countries most hit by the crisis and by unemployment and most in need of European solidarity.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. - On 24 November 2014, I voted in favour of the draft motion for a resolution on delays in the start-up phase of the cohesion policy 2014-2020. Europe, and I regret this, is struggling to emerge from the economic crisis, as the latest economic forecasts of the European Commission have come to remind us. The low growth forecasts to come, coupled with high unemployment and low inflation, are all indicators that remind us that we lack investment in Europe. Cohesion policy aims to strengthen growth and employment and reduce disparities in levels of development between European regions. Any delay in the start-up phase of the 2014-2020 cohesion policy therefore further prevents economic recovery and job creation, particularly in the least developed regions. Citizens, less and less enthusiastic about the European project, expect Europe to have prospects for their future but also for their children. That is why I have decided to fully support this motion for a resolution, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to speed up the adoption of partnership agreements and operational programmes.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour because I fully share Parliament's concerns about delays in the approval of cohesion programmes. Despite the fact that cohesion policy programmes were due to start at the beginning of this year, there is a real risk that a significant part of them will not be implemented in 2015. It must be acknowledged that the information provided by the European Commission that Member States may not wait for the approval and implementation of programmes, if they do not give rise to any doubt to the EC, is not acceptable. Member States may not risk funds which may subsequently be declared ineligible. It is common knowledge that cohesion policy, in line with co-financing by Member States, covers a significant part of the public expenditure on growth in the European Union. How can we promote job creation, to deal with a crisis when we are crossing the branch on which we sit at the same time. Delays in the approval of cohesion policy programmes, cohesion policy 2007-2013, payment delays in operational programmes contribute to the stagnation of the economy in Europe. I don't think that's what we want. In this context, I call on both the European Commission and the Council to address these problems.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — Following the oral question to the Commission on delays in launching cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, we voted on a Joint Motion for A Resolution on the same subject, endorsed by the 7 parliamentary groups of the European Parliament and voted in favour by 608 of the 666 Members of the European Parliament present at the time of the vote. With this position so clear, we would like to send a signal to the Commission and the Council that they should resolve this incomprehensible and embarrassing situation as soon as possible, which, together with the delay in payments for the commitments made during the 2007-2013 programming period, is currently the greatest concern for a large majority of elected Members, in which I am included. In today's resolution, some solutions are pointed out not only to these issues, but also to the parallel budgetary debate between the three institutions.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — Delays in the operational programmes of the 2014-2020 period of European cohesion policy have significant consequences for the financing of projects under the Structural Funds. This situation requires the implementation of special procedures up to a review of the multi-year financial framework to be carried out before 1 May 2015, in order to allow the payment of pre-financing planned for 2014.  It was therefore essential to remind the Commission and the Member States of the importance of validating the current operational programmes as quickly as possible. The Council also had to be asked to prepare negotiations with Parliament in advance on the revision of the financial framework in order to reach an agreement by 1 May 2015.  It is in this sense that I have supported this text, in order to be able to quickly address the delays in the launch of the Cohesion Policy 2014-2020, a European Union policy that directly affects European citizens.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour because this resolution: - Denounces the delays in implementing cohesion policy 2014-2020; - Stresses that it is serious that there is still a backlog in payments of around EUR 23 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period; - Remember how these delays are causing problems for national and regional authorities; - Calls for Juncker's proposed €300 billion investment plan to complement cohesion policy 2014-2020.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of this Resolution, understanding that the motion raises a coherent and critical view of the Commission's delays in cohesion policy. We consider it very serious that the Commission should be delayed in mobilizing cohesion policy funds which constitute its only expenditure on social policy. However, the Resolution makes an ambiguous mention of the Juncker stimulus plan which we do not understand and which we believe has no place when it comes to cohesion policy. Under no circumstances should our support for this Resolution be understood as support for the Juncker stimulus plan.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported the joint resolution on the issue of delay in the start of the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, which we are asking the Commission to examine all options that would lead to an acceleration of the preparations for the implementation of the new Multiannual Financial Framework. I consider cohesion policy to be one of the most important common instruments of the European Union, which is an expression of its solidarity with less developed regions. The principle of cohesion must also be an integral part of the forthcoming investment package of the new Commission. As a result, this package must not lead to a potential outflow of funding from projects that will not be able to be submitted and commitment in time due to the delay in the start of the implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution because the Council and the Commission can enter, as they have entered, into a battle over who has responsibility for the delay in the implementation of cohesion policy, but the truth is that what has failed so far is the design of cohesion policy itself and its management. The implementation of the new regional policy should be more efficient and simpler, quite the opposite of what is happening in reality: approved but unpaid invoices, operational programs pending implementation, municipalities that cannot participate as partnerships... We are witnessing an increase in inequalities between different regions of the EU. And it is therefore urgent that the EU act to reverse this trend because, as always, it is European citizens who are paying for the duck.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the motion for a resolution on delays in the start-up of cohesion policy for 2014-2020. Cohesion policy represents the main EU-wide investment policy in the real economy and is an established catalyst for growth and jobs in the EU, with a budget of over EUR 350 billion until 2020.  The delay in implementation for the 2014-2020 programming period is challenging national, regional and local authorities’ capacity to plan effectively and implement the European Structural and Investment Funds for the 2014-2020 period.  Cohesion policy forms a major part of the EU’s strategy to redress regional imbalances and inequalities, to assist diversification and adaptation to industrial change and to achieve economic, social and territorial cohesion.  I support the request that the EUR 315 billion investment package should be fully complementary with the 2014-2020 cohesion policy. In addition, the Commission should present the measures it envisages taking and the planned timeline to Parliament, as soon as possible, to facilitate the implementation of the Operational Programmes.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. - I supported the joint motion for a resolution and fully share it because I consider the delay in the start of the implementation of cohesion policy for 2014-2020 to be very serious. The end of the Commission's term of office and the election of a new one certainly contributed to this, but that cannot be an excuse. A year ago, we approved derogations for Romania and Slovakia so that they could apply the rule for the absorption of n+3 EU funds. If we postpone the start of the implementation of cohesion policy for 2014-2020 until next year and the operational programmes are approved as before, I fear that, before 2020, we will once again approve exemptions for all states that will not be able to invest in growth, development and employment with funding from the various Structural Funds. The Commission should therefore submit to Parliament as soon as possible the measures it intends to take in order to facilitate the implementation of operational programmes as soon as possible with an expected timetable.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE)
text: Writing. — We are in the transitional phase between the previous programming period and the new one with regard to the implementation of Cohesion Policy. In addition to the delays in payments for the period that it closes, there are unfortunately also significant delays in the process of approving the operational programmes that will implement Cohesion Policy at a particularly critical time, primarily for countries affected by the crisis and which do not have sufficient national resources to implement a development policy. In a recent report, the International Employment Agency announced that in order for Greece to regain some of the lost ground it would have to boost employment through forward-looking co-financed actions. The forecast for when Greece will regain its level of employment at pre-crisis levels is for 2034. I am therefore particularly concerned by the delay in the start-up of cohesion policy, as it will obviously have a significant impact on the difficult effort to uplift European economies. That is why I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. — Cohesion policy 2014-2020 is the European Union's main investment instrument for meeting the Europe 2020 targets. As this strategy prioritises the creation of growth and jobs and the promotion of small and medium-sized enterprises, it is essential that the European Union ensure the timely implementation of cohesion policy. Only in this way will it be able to meet its goals.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. — I am concerned about the significant delay in the implementation of cohesion policy 2014-2020, but I recognise the importance of adopting quality operational programmes at the beginning of the programming period in order to avoid further amendments.  In my view, the Commission and the Member States should show seriousness and do their utmost to accelerate the adoption of the maximum number of operational programmes back in 2014. and also make sure that as many programmes as they are ready for adoption by the end of the year.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution which evaluates the current state of play in the implementation of cohesion policy and highlights concerns regarding the delays in adoption by the European Commission of Operational Programmes (OPs). In Wales last week, we secured the approval of our European Regional Development Fund programmes and formal approval of our European Social Fund programmes is expected in the next few weeks. Whilst I am pleased to know that these additional funds are on their way to Wales, it is clear that overall we are facing a delay at the level of the programming process, with just a limited number of OPs foreseen to be adopted by the end of 2014. These delays cause uncertainty and project planning problems for actors at local, regional and national level and I was therefore pleased to support this resolution’s request for the Commission to outline clearly how it intends to facilitate, as soon as possible, the implementation of the Operational Programmes.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The Commission must assume its responsibilities and promote solutions to the problems presented. The EU wants it to be called economic union and therefore it must, if anything, prove this by providing timely solutions to economic issues.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. - I do not agree with the proposal because I do not see the delayed start of the implementation of cohesion policy for 2014-2020 as a problem. I also disagree with the text of the proposal that intends to use this policy to maximise the results of 'investment, promoting job creation and increasing productivity growth'. Since all these funds are used to the detriment of taxpayers, the promotion of investment, employment and productivity certainly cannot be talked about. I also do not agree that the cohesion policy programme should be complemented by the investment package announced by the European Commission of EUR 315 billion. This investment package, as well as cohesion policy projects, continues to drain resources from the productive economy and continues to increase the centrally planned redistribution at the expense of the market.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. - We must keep in mind that re-budgeting, from the 2014 financial year to the 2015 financial year, amounts not committed under Article 19 of the MFF implies a revision of the MFF to 1 May 2015 which, although technical in nature, must comply with the multi-year budgetary procedure: a proposal for a revision of the MFF submitted by the Commission, the approval of Parliament and the unanimous adoption by the Council. I would also point out that the adoption of operational programmes also requires the approval of a corresponding draft amending budget, which includes, under 2015, the commitment appropriations concerned, which implies, at best, a postponement to mid-2015 of the effective launch of the implementation of those programmes.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because the delay in the implementation of cohesion policy 2014-2020 means that programmes financed by the Structural Funds may not be approved. We need to ensure that we have as many operational programmes as possible and that we can speed up their implementation. Further delays in the implementation of cohesion policy may threaten jobs and infrastructure improvement, a precondition for programmes financed by the Structural Funds.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution because the Council and the Commission can enter, as they have entered, into a battle over who has responsibility for the delay in the implementation of cohesion policy, but the truth is that what has failed so far is the design of cohesion policy itself and its management. The implementation of the new regional policy should be more efficient and simpler, quite the opposite of what is happening in reality: approved but unpaid invoices, operational programs pending implementation, municipalities that cannot participate as partnerships... We are witnessing an increase in inequalities between different regions of the EU. And it is therefore urgent that the EU act to reverse this trend because, as always, it is European citizens who are paying for the duck.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. - As a co-signatory of this resolution, I fully supported todayʼs vote which raises concerns about the delays in starting up the next round of cohesion policy. Significant delays in agreeing operational programmes will cause problems for national, regional and local authorities across the EU. I am particularly concerned about the effect this will have on English regions and their ability to get projects up and running. I wholeheartedly agree that both the Commission and the Member States should work together to speed up the process of agreeing the operational programmes and that the Commission in particular should put forward solutions to limit damage caused by late implementation. I am concerned by the budgetary impact that these delays will cause, but above all, I am extremely worried about the impact the late approval of operational programmes will have on English regions and the ability to deliver EU-funded projects within an acceptable timeframe.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The delay in the implementation of the cohesion funds planned for 2014-2020 is already a reality. The delay in the approval of partnership agreements was, in this Portuguese, dramatic and is conditioning the finalisation and approval of operational programmes. The impasse over the Community budget could in the same way seriously jeopardise the whole process, at a time when late payments are already around EUR 25 billion. At a time when the EU is stagnant from the economic point of view and still under the threat of deflation, there is an urgent need to forge an ambitious public investment plan that can boost the economy.  I therefore believe that the Commission, instead of shuffling the agenda with its 300 billion plan which no one has yet quite understood, should have concentrated on the transition between the two multi-annual frameworks, thus avoiding yet another unnecessary gap, which is highly damaging to our economies.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. — The fact that the payment arrears of EUR 23 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period still have to be paid before implementation for the 2014-2020 programming period have led me to vote against the draft cohesion policy for 2014-2020. It is not acceptable for funding for new projects to be incurred before the old ones are completed.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the joint resolution on the delays in the start of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. Moreover, I was among the initiators of the motion for a resolution of the EPP Group in the EP on this issue.  Delays in the implementation of cohesion policy 2014-2020, in conjunction with the arrears that are recorded in the payment of invoices for the 2007-2013 programming period, undermine the credibility of the European Commission. It is extremely important that the EC and the Member States show responsibility, all the more so since cohesion policy funds, together with co-financing from Member States, represent a significant percentage of public expenditure closely linked to economic growth in the EU. It is necessary to implement new programmes aimed at strengthening investment, stimulating job creation and increasing labour productivity as soon as possible.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this resolution as it expressed deep concern at the significant delays in implementing cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. It also recognises that these delays pose a challenge for national, regional and local authorities in the effective planning and implementation of the Structural Funds. However, it is not just about challenges, when reality shows the objective difficulties in obtaining financing. In this way, Parliament puts pressure on the European Commission and the Member States to speed up the adoption of the maximum number of operational programmes by 31 December 2014 in order to benefit from the transitional procedure provided for in the financial regulation, which makes it possible to use the appropriations not used in the previous budgetary year.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on delays in the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, which I am a co-promoter of, as any major delays would be very damaging to the European economy. European funds for some Member States, including Slovenia, in times of crisis, represent almost the only source of funds for the realisation of investment projects and job creation. All agreements and programmes should be ready by the end of the year, but this seems unlikely. In the event of long delays, European entrepreneurs and citizens will suffer in particular. More responsible behaviour is needed in the implementation of cohesion policy, in the adoption of partnership agreements and operating programmes. The Commission and the Member States must now do everything to ensure that major delays do not occur.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution as I very much doubt that the Commission's impact assessments on SMEs will be credible. In my view, these assessments are a mere formality, a procedure which in no case calls into question the interests of the great lobists, who are the ones who set the EU's legislative proposals. Helping SMEs should end the EU's neoliberal policies, end the privatisations, liberalisations, cuts and austerity, which are killing the internal market of different EU countries.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. - As part of our efforts to better support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), we must be fully aware of the costs to SMEs when drafting regulations and directives. SMEs are still one of the most important factors in Europe for creating growth and employment. The costs required to comply with a regulation can be ten times higher for SMEs than for larger companies. An independent impact assessment for SMEs is useful in order to avoid major difficulties for these companies, which often involve the implementation of complicated administrative rules. These companies must not be stifled by excessive bureaucracy. That is why I am in favour of the consistent implementation of the SME test for legislative projects at European level.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The impact of legislation on SMEs in particular is a key issue, but I am far from certain that this resolution would have the effect of limiting the legislative burden on SMEs.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to review the Commission's Impact Assessment (IA) guidelines. Impact assessment, as a tool in the early stages of legislative development, plays an important role in the EU decision-making process in order to provide detailed facts about the nature of the problem to be addressed. An appropriate and independent impact assessment is essential for SMEs, as they often face more difficulties than large companies when it comes to adapting to new legal and administrative requirements. I support the proposals set out above for clearer procedures relating to the Impact Assessment Board, to strengthen its independence, and for the PVV to consist only of highly qualified persons. It is important that the Impact Study on SMEs assesses all aspects: economic, social and environmental.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — Impact analyses can only be beneficial, if they are carried out properly, I voted in favour of this text, which I note that it claims to "think first of SMEs": we must indeed support SMEs in the face of unfair competition from multinationals who take advantage of the stubbornness of the Euro-globalists to reject in principle any protectionism, national or continental.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. In order to collect useful data and assess whether the objectives have been achieved, the Commission is conducting assessments to determine the effects of the policies carried out and assess their impact. The findings of these evaluations serve to refine policies.  The impact analysis is pre-decision-making and implementation. These analyses are carried out in particular within the framework of employment policies as is the case here with this resolution on the revision of the Commission's guidelines on impact assessment and the role of the SME test.  Currently, the European Union has more than 20 million SMEs, which account for 99% of European businesses.  In this resolution, we are reminded that SMEs often have more difficulty than large companies in complying with a legislative act and the Commission does not hesitate, not without irony, to declare that it has made the principle of "thinking smEs first" the "cornerstone of the Small Business Act for Europe"... However, the reality is quite different and multinationals and financial powers still dominate the European market.  Nevertheless, on this recommendation I have spoken in favour, because it will have a positive impact on SMEs, which I support, and this text guarantees independence from the Commission.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — I think it is right to carry out an impact assessment on: effectiveness, burdens, subsidiarity and proportionality of EU legislation. If an external advisory body contributes to the investigation, perhaps more in contact with the real world than the Commission, it is even better. However, the new Commission has not yet clarified how it intends to proceed with REFIT, which is why I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — Impact assessments are a key tool for decision-making in all EU institutions and for providing transparent, comprehensive and balanced evidence of economic, social and environmental effects, the added value of EU action, the expected regulatory and administrative burden, and the costs and benefits of alternative avenues of action for all parties involved in the legislative process.  However, impact assessments cannot replace political assessments and decisions and therefore the parliamentary committees of this house should systematically review the Commission's impact assessments. In addition, impact assessments need to take a particular look at the effect on SMEs of future legislation. Given that the cost of an SME to comply with regulations can be up to ten times that of large enterprises, conducting an independent, rigorous and high-quality impact assessment is vitally important. I voted in favour of this resolution to urge the Commission to include all these issues in the draft revised impact assessment guidelines.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because impact assessment, as a measure in the early stages of legislative development, plays a key role in the Commission's smart regulation agenda in order to provide transparent, comprehensive and proportionate facts on economic and social impacts. In addition, impact assessment is an important tool for decision-making in all EU institutions and an important part of the better regulation process. I would like to draw attention to the fact that the impact assessment must be thorough, thorough and based on the most accurate, objective and comprehensive information available, with an analysis that is proportionate and focused on the objective of the proposal, so that an informed political decision can be taken. It is therefore important to consult all relevant stakeholders at an early stage of the impact assessment process so that their contribution can be taken into account in the preparation of the impact assessment without prior publication. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to present a new draft of the revised guidelines for impact assessment, which takes into account the points highlighted in this resolution and the new structure of the Commission, in particular the role of the new Vice-President responsible for better regulation.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. - The purpose of this resolution is to call for the strengthening of the impact analysis of the SME test. The impact assessment is a tool that provides information on the economic, social and environmental effects of the Union's legislative acts. The draft resolution reminds us that the costs that SMEs have to incur in order to comply with an EU law can be up to ten times higher than those incurred by large companies. As such, a clear example corroborates this analysis: the new regulation of helicopter transport activities, which now prohibits the overflight of areas at risk by single-engine aircraft, which could have the effect of doubling the cost of a helicopter to purchase and operate. Anything that supports a better impact study of legislative and regulatory production and avoids the occurrence of economic and social tragedies is a good thing. However, strengthening the impact analysis will not produce the desired results. Indeed, it is the technocratic structure of the European Union that is the main cause of the production of legislation and regulations totally unenforceable by the Member States. However, in order to support our SMEs, I voted for this resolution.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. I abstained. It is right to carry out an impact assessment on the effectiveness, burdens, subsidiarity and proportionality of EU legislation. If an external advisory body contributes to this, perhaps it is more in contact with the real world than the Commission, and that is a good thing. However, the new Commission has not yet clarified how it intends to proceed with REFIT.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The European Commission's impact assessments have a predominant place in European legislation. These analyses are made ahead of a legislative proposal to determine whether the direction taken by the Commission in the development of a legislative proposal is relevant. This process is determined by guidelines for impact assessments.  Parliament believes that these guidelines need to be amended to be as effective and transparent as possible.  The same goes for the SME test. It has long been established that SMEs have a prominent place in the European economy. The same must be true of European legislation. Any legislative act must take into account the specificities related to the nature of SMEs. The Commission's guidelines on the SME test also need to be changed. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. I have today voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Commission's guidelines on impact assessment. Impact assessments are conducted to predict the likely consequence of EU legislation on citizens and the economy as a whole. However, they are often controversial and opaque.  I believe that a major challenge facing the new European Commission is to break down its impact assessment mechanisms from political imperatives that all too often guide the preparation of its proposals and instead to rely on mere scientific evidence. There are countless examples in which European policy-makers have bickered about scientific evidence, including on extremely technical issues. I therefore believe that we need to develop a new system for collecting evidence within the Commission itself, which completely disconnects the collection of evidence from the political imperative. Setting up a special department at the Commission, with the role of evaluating policy proposals on the basis of mere scientific evidence, would be important in ensuring that the Commission's assessments are efficient, independent and transparent.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on better drafting of regulations relating to European SMEs. Given that the principle of 'thinking small first' must always be borne in mind, the European institutions in general and, even more so, the European Commission should commit themselves to making legislation more appropriate to the needs of SMEs, which find it more difficult than large amounts to adapt to legal and administrative obligations because of their size and capacity. We should therefore first of all prevent SMEs from being disproportionately penalised or affected and aiming for a quality of legislation. Not only that. The European Commission should continue to use the impact assessment instrument also for all legislative proposals that have a very important economic, social and environmental impact, as well as for non-legislative proposals defining future European policies and for delegated or implementing acts.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of this resolution because I believe that impact assessments, as a tool to be used at the initial stage of drafting legislation, play a key role in the Commission's programme for smart regulation, with the aim of providing transparent, comprehensive and balanced elements on the nature of the problem to be addressed, the added value of EU intervention, as well as the costs and benefits of alternative solutions for all stakeholders.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution as I very much doubt that the Commission's impact assessments on SMEs will be credible. In my view, these assessments are a mere formality, a procedure which in no case calls into question the interests of the great lobists, who are the ones who set the EU's legislative proposals. Helping SMEs should end the EU's neoliberal policies, end the privatisations, liberalisations, cuts and austerity, which are killing the internal market of different EU countries.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Mindful of the quality and fair calibration of European regulations, I agree with the comments made in this joint resolution on the revision of the Commission's guidelines on impact assessment and the role of the SME test. In particular, I think it is very important to integrate the SME test. Based on the principle of "thinking first" to SMEs, a structuring principle of the Small Business Act of 2008, this test allows, in fact, to take into account upstream the interest of SMEs in the development of policies so that the legislation is more favourable to them.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The European Commission has initiated a process to amend the impact assessment guidelines. Impact assessments are an objective study prepared by the Commission for each legislative proposal. In our experience in Parliament we have seen how the committee's impact assessments give arguments against the Commission's own legislative proposals, for example by showing greater environmental sensitivity. In any event, they require an objective and general view on the effects of legislative initiatives. The Commission's proposal is less specific in terms of the scope of the studies, by leaving more to the arbitrariness of the relevant directorate-general the decision on whether impact assessments are necessary and on what issues, opening the door for them to be dispensed with in many cases. That is why we voted in favour of the Joint Resolution of the European Parliament, which calls for the obligation and completeness of impact assessments to be maintained as far as possible.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — Although we are not entirely negative about the resolution, which, for the most part, improves a rather bad situation, we nevertheless disagree and vote against it because it creates institutions completely free of parliamentary control and, moreover, because it reduces the self-government of the Member States. After all, the conclusion drawn from the experience of the various independent authorities so far is that they are not really independent and that the lack of the possibility of direct political control leads to their control through practices which are not acceptable to us.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We agree to improve the rigour and credibility of the impact assessment (IA) process by ensuring that economic, social and environmental aspects are assessed in equal depth and that the approach takes place in all initiatives – legislative proposals; Commission's Legislative and Work Programme; non-legislative initiatives defining future policies; delegated or implementing acts of the Commission which may have significant identifiable impacts. But that is not the case for the proposals put forward by the Commission and its President, on the contrary. We have the greatest reservations about the advisory body called Better Regulation, referred to in the resolution. If national experts are concerned, the proposal makes perfect sense, given the need to comply with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, while the representatives of the interested parties, do not translate more than an added weight of the lobbiates throughout the legislative process from the source. Furthermore, under the pretext of preventing SMEs from being disproportionately affected or harmed by the Commission's initiatives vis-à-vis larger companies, it is actually intended to further weaken the IA instrument. In the face of such contradictions, we were not able to vote in favour.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — It is right to carry out an impact assessment on the effectiveness, burdens, subsidiarity and proportionality of EU legislation. However, the new Commission has not yet made it clear how it intends to proceed with REFIT, which is why I shall be abstaining.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
