text: Writing. - Although I am not negative about the resolution as a whole, which, for the most part, improves a rather bad situation, I nevertheless disagree with the Commission's guidelines on impact assessment and I vote against them because institutions are created completely free of parliamentary control and, moreover, because the possibility of self-government of the Member States is limited. After all, the conclusion drawn from the experience of the various independent authorities so far is that they are not really independent and that the lack of the possibility of direct political control leads to their control through practices which are not acceptable to us.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in the affirmative to review the impact assessment of European legislation as a first step in the Union on the road to simplifying SME rules to promote the creation of occupation.  It should be remembered , as I said in my speech last Monday , that in EU countries, SMEs occupy about 70% of the working population, a percentage which in the Spanish state rises to 98%. That's why we have to be much more ambitious. We need to achieve better-directed guidelines that really help businesses across the EU to have higher productivity, and to collaborate in the growth and creation of jobs in the 28 Member States, but especially in those suffering worryingly high unemployment rates that remain over time.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the revision of the European Commission's guidelines on impact assessment and the role of the SME test. The resolution calls on the European Commission to reinstate the 'SME test' in the impact analyses published at the time of the release of new EU texts. Continuing to analyse the impact of EU regulation on SMEs is essential. There is also a need to define more clearly the role of the impact assessment committee and to integrate its opinion into the European Commission's decision-making process. Our SMEs must not be the victims of European policies, so I welcome this resolution which is going in the right direction!

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The European Commission has initiated a process to amend the impact assessment guidelines. Impact assessments are an objective study prepared by the Commission for each legislative proposal. In our experience in Parliament we have seen how the committee's impact assessments give arguments against the Commission's own legislative proposals, for example by showing greater environmental sensitivity. In any event, they require an objective and general view on the effects of legislative initiatives. The Commission's proposal is less specific in terms of the scope of the studies, by leaving more to the arbitrariness of the relevant directorate-general the decision on whether impact assessments are necessary and on what issues, opening the door for them to be dispensed with in many cases. That is why we voted in favour of the Joint Resolution of the European Parliament, which calls for the obligation and completeness of impact assessments to be maintained as far as possible.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the Commission's impact assessment guidelines, as this further improves impact assessment procedures, and it is important that social, administrative and economic aspects are assessed in the same way.  In my view, the impact assessment should be based on complete and objective data to help them make decisions in the EU institutions and should involve all relevant stakeholders with a view to better consultation.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I am glad that the Parliament voted in favour of the resolution on the revision of the Commission’s impact assessment guidelines. This is one of a number of aspects which should be addressed in the push for better regulation on a European level. Businesses should be encouraged to flourish through a sound regulatory framework, and should not be overburdened with cumbersome regulations. The ALDE Group in the European Parliament will be pushing strongly for further measures to create a more business-friendly environment in the EU.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the revision of the Commission's guidelines on impact assessments which are published at the time of the publication of new Community texts.  The Commission proposes to reintroduce the 'SME test', which analyses the impact of EU regulation on SMEs. The resolution stresses the importance of adapting the analysis to the proposed text and integrating the opinion of the Impact Analysis Committee into the European Commission's decision-making process, while strengthening its independence. The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. " I wished to be a co-signer of this resolution on the revision of the Commission's guidelines on impact assessment and the role of the SME test. In order to avoid costly and counterproductive regulations, impact assessments are an important means of decision-making assistance in all European institutions. They are also an essential part of the regulatory improvement process for the first Vice-President of the new Commission.  When legislative proposals are amended prior to adoption by the College of Commissioners, impact assessments should be updated to ensure consistency between the points discussed and the proposals ultimately adopted. As part of Parliament's legislative work, it would be necessary to use a parliamentary impact assessment when substantive changes are made to the Commission's original proposal.  Furthermore, it is regrettable that the SME test is not mentioned in the Commission's draft guidelines, even though it has made a clear commitment, as part of the review of the European Small Business Act, to strengthen this test. This test, which must be implemented before any new EU legislation is adopted, aims to prevent the emergence of new obstacles to the proper functioning of SMEs in the EU.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Markus Pieper because I believe that impact assessments play a strategic role in the Eu ropean Union's decision-making process, ensuring transparent information on the issues dealt with. In addition, I consider impact assessments to be very important for small and medium-sized enterprises which often encounter problems of adaptation to new legislation.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution as I very much doubt that the Commission's impact assessments on SMEs will be credible. In my view, these assessments are a mere formality, a procedure which in no case calls into question the interests of the great lobists, who are the ones who set the EU's legislative proposals. Helping SMEs should end the EU's neoliberal policies, end the privatisations, liberalisations, cuts and austerity, which are killing the internal market of different EU countries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution because the assessment of the impact of European Legislation is an important activity and because the present resolution, among other things, accepts that the impact of the measures being adopted on SMEs will also be examined by the Commission.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. — We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, which, as a whole, attempts to simplify the processes of adapting to standards for SMEs, supports SMEs and micro-enterprises, and, above all, encourages greater independence from the Commission by establishing Impact Assessment Committees made up of national experts and representatives of Member States.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the Pieper report, as I believe that impact assessments are a fundamental instrument for guaranteeing legislative quality.  They play a key role in the Eu ropean Union's decision-making process by providing transparent and balanced information on the issues dealt with.  I also believe that impact assessments are particularly beneficial for SMEs, which sometimes find it more difficult to adapt to new legislation.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the impact assessment guidelines which play an important role in the Commission’s smart regulation agenda. IAs are an early-stage tool in developing legislation and can effectively contribute to providing transparent, comprehensive and balanced evidence on economic, social and environmental areas. They also determine possible difficulties, costs and benefits of the addressed issue. IA guidelines make the SME legislation friendlier in adapting to new legal requirements and changes.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - Impact assessments are tools used upstream, at the legislative stage. They provide information on the economic, social and environmental effects, on the benefits of EU action and on the foreseeable regulatory and administrative constraints of the new legislation. Parliament's resolution is highly critical of the Commission's proposed revision, particularly with regard to the vagueness of the scope of impact assessments. It also calls for the systematic use of the "SME test". What for? The completion of an impact assessment is of particular importance to SMEs. They often have more difficulty adapting than large companies to the new legal and administrative provisions. Finally, it calls for the parliamentary impact study to be used more systematically. I'm voting FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — IAAs, as an instrument at an early stage in the drafting of the legislative framework, play a crucial role in the Commission's smart regulatory agenda, with the aim of providing transparent, vast and balanced data on economic, social and environmental consequences, the added value of EU action, the expected administrative and regulatory burdens, as well as the costs and benefits of alternative lines of action for all actors.  This is to welcome the Commission's commitment to regularly review the Guidelines on IA with a view to improving their procedures.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution as it calls for a more rigorous and comprehensive internal assessment by ensuring that environmental, social, economic and administrative aspects are assessed equally. It is also ensured that all relevant stakeholders are consulted in the early stages of the internal assessment and that their opinions are taken into consideration.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The European Commission regularly conducts assessments to see if the objectives of its policies have been achieved and what the impact has been. The conclusions of these evaluations should theoretically help refine future policies and actions.  The impact analysis (or ex ante assessment) is located before the decision-making and, of course, its execution. These analyses cover all the different policies pursued by the European Union. This resolution proposes to review the Commission's guidelines on impact assessment and the role of the SME test. There are some 20 million SMEs in the European Union, which account for 99% of European businesses. In this resolution, it is noted that SMEs face more difficulties than large companies. M. de Lapalisse could not have said it better... The Commission says it wants to 'think first about SMEs', 'cornerstone of the Small Business Act for Europe in 2008'... The document does not specify that the European Union is at the root of many of the difficulties faced by these same SMEs (imposed ultraliberalism, the so-called "detached workers" directive, regulations and binding administrative standards, etc.). Anxious to favour SMEs, PMI and TPE, I voted in favour.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which calls on the European Commission to take small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) into account in the drafting of its legislation.  This is usually often the case. However, in a draft revision of the working method, the Commission is considering no longer making this accountable systematic. Taking into account our SMEs, which account for more than 90% of businesses and jobs, is vital at every stage of the legislative process. No provision, no text should penalize our SMEs. So I supported the idea of keeping the "SME tests". I also voted in favour of the provisions that strengthened these tests.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – I support the resolution on the Commission’s impact assessment guidelines calling for more stringent impact assessments before EU legislation is proposed. Nevertheless this should not lead to deregulation and a lowering of protection for EU citizens. The impact assessments should have more involvement by industry stakeholders and consultation with these stakeholders should take place at an earlier stage in the drafting process. Last but not least, the Commission must ensure that economic, social, administrative and environmental aspects are assessed in equal depth.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - The rules and policies we adopt in the European Parliament apply to all Member States, so we need to involve all interest groups, primarily including citizens, in their creation process. We are witnessing a recent crisis in the European Union, so it is all the more necessary to carefully anticipate all the advantages and disadvantages that individual regulations can bring, taking into account the differences within, but also the project of uniting. We must not be late in the decision-making process and we must develop impact assessment guidelines for the benefit of all CITIZENS of the European Union, using the principles of transparency, comprehensiveness and balance. I therefore supported the adoption of the resolution.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — Regular review of the guidelines for impact assessment is certainly necessary and useful for improving the procedures in this area and I welcome the Commission's commitment in this direction. I hope, of course, that the impact assessments will be carried out with the absolute precision, rigorously, independently and comprehensively, with the final objective of the proposal clear. Let us remember, however, and I would like to stress this, that evaluations serve to ensure that political decisions are taken with greater knowledge of the facts but must not replace them.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. — Small and medium-sized enterprises make an indispensable contribution to german and European economic strength. The innovative power of small and medium-sized enterprises protects jobs and our location. This makes it all the more important that the Commission takes a careful approach in its actions. However, in its concern for large companies, the EU regularly forgets that they depend on the strength of SMEs. I therefore agree with this draft, which calls on the Commission to improve the impact assessment, involving the parliamentary committees.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. As the jurist Jhering declared - "The sworn enemy of arbitrariness, form is the twin sister of freedom" - I am thus in favour of a resolution to control the review process of the impact studies carried out by the European Commission. The realities must be best identified by the European authorities, and their content cannot be altered during the European legislative process. The balance between the european Commission's room for manoeuvre, the economy of the means and the accuracy of the facts requires regular revisions of these guidelines in terms of context.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — Impact assessments are an important tool to support the decision-making process in the legislative process, as they allow data to be collected on the economic, social and environmental consequences of legislative proposals, the added value of EU action, the expected administrative and regulatory burdens, and the costs and benefits of alternative lines of action. It is therefore clear that we welcome the Commission's initiative to review the guidelines on impact assessments with a view to improving their procedures. The draft revision, however, suffers from a number of shortcomings that need to be addressed, in particular as regards clarifying the role of the IAPs and enhancing its independence, introducing the reference to the SME test, the approach to excluding micro-enterprises from the scope of legislative proposals and updating impact assessments following the changes introduced during the legislative process. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which rightly calls on the Commission to present a new draft guidelines on impact assessments, taking due account of the above-mentioned aspects.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. — In the current climate in which citizens sometimes question the added value of European legislation, the quality of impact assessments makes sense. Well done, they should enable the Commission to better clarify the origin and expected impact of its proposals, and should give the legislature an objective basis for making informed decisions and deciding on the appropriateness of the chosen legislative approach.  I voted in favour of this resolution, which details ways that we believe are useful in improving the quality of these studies, and I encourage the Commission (and the Council) to take into account the key elements that we are making.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — Impact assessments are a key tool for decision-making in all EU institutions and for providing transparent, comprehensive and balanced evidence of economic, social and environmental effects, the added value of EU action, the expected regulatory and administrative burden, and the costs and benefits of alternative avenues of action for all parties involved in the legislative process.  However, impact assessments cannot replace political assessments and decisions and therefore the parliamentary committees of this house should systematically review the Commission's impact assessments. In addition, impact assessments need to take a particular look at the effect on SMEs of future legislation. Given that the cost of an SME to comply with regulations can be up to ten times that of large enterprises, conducting an independent, rigorous and high-quality impact assessment is vitally important. I voted in favour of this resolution to urge the Commission to include all these issues in the draft revised impact assessment guidelines.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — Impact assessments play a key role as an instrument prior to the development of the legislative framework, with a view to providing transparent, broad and balanced data on the economic, social and environmental consequences of EU action. For this reason, I congratulate and approve of the Commission's commitment to the draft revision of the legislative guidelines, in particular with regard to impact assessments. This promotes an improvement in legislative procedures and ensures a careful assessment of the economic, social and environmental aspects associated with them. I voted in favour of this proposal, as it advocates rigorous, comprehensive and accurate and objective information assessments based on a balanced analysis focused on the scope of the proposal, so as to allow political decisions to be made with knowledge of the facts. In addition, they should be updated in order to ensure continuity between the elements contained therein and any other proposal that will finally be adopted by the Commission. Once these requirements are met, impact assessments are an important means of supporting the decision-making process in all the institutions of the European Union, as well as an essential element in the Better Regulation process.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I supported this resolution so that the European Commission, in its revision of the guidelines on impact assessment and the role of the SME test, would continue to analyse the impact of EU regulation on SMEs (small and medium-sized enterprises).  In particular, it will be useful if the practice of the SME test is disseminated at Member State level and that the SME test is also improved at European level.  SMEs play a central role in the European economy and the European Union must continue to take them into account in a specific way in its policies.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to abstain because, on the one hand, I think it is right to carry out an impact assessment on the effectiveness, burdens, subsidiarity and proportionality of EU legislation, but on the other hand I would have preferred an external advisory body to contribute to it, perhaps more in contact with the real world than the Commission. However, the new Commission has not yet clarified how it intends to proceed with REFIT.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The European Commission has initiated a process to amend the impact assessment guidelines. Impact assessments are an objective study prepared by the Commission for each legislative proposal. In our experience in Parliament we have seen how the committee's impact assessments give arguments against the Commission's own legislative proposals, for example by showing greater environmental sensitivity. In any event, they require an objective and general view on the effects of legislative initiatives. The Commission's proposal is less specific in terms of the scope of the studies, by leaving more to the arbitrariness of the relevant directorate-general the decision on whether impact assessments are necessary and on what issues, opening the door for them to be dispensed with in many cases. That is why we voted in favour of the Joint Resolution of the European Parliament, which calls for the obligation and completeness of impact assessments to be maintained as far as possible.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution as I very much doubt that the Commission's impact assessments on SMEs will be credible. In my view, these assessments are a mere formality, a procedure which in no case calls into question the interests of the great lobists, who are the ones who set the EU's legislative proposals. Helping SMEs should end the EU's neoliberal policies, end the privatisations, liberalisations, cuts and austerity, which are killing the internal market of different EU countries.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the revision of the Commission’s impact assessment guidelines and the role of the SME test. Impact assessments, as an early-stage tool when legislation is being developed, play a key role in the Commission’s smart regulation agenda with the purpose of providing transparent, comprehensive and balanced evidence on the nature of the problem to be addressed.  The existing IA guidelines assign the Commission’s Secretariat-General and the Impact Assessment Board (IAB) a central role in deciding whether or not an impact assessment is necessary for a specific initiative. However, this resolution highlights that the draft revised IA guidelines do not include any provisions on IAs for SMEs and more specifically the SME test. An independent impact assessment is of particular relevance for SMEs as they often encounter greater difficulties than large enterprises in adapting to new legal and administrative requirements. Due to their size they are less capable of anticipating regulatory changes at an early stage. I support the opinion that the Commissions impact assessment guidelines need to be revised to include provisions on IAs for SMEs.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. — As we have a number of tools at our disposal to enable the effective implementation of the 'Let's Start from Young People' programme , from the beginning I support its objective of taking into account the interests of SMEs at a very early stage in order to better adapt legislation to them, and I definitely support this resolution.  On the other hand, I am concerned that the role of the Impact Assessment Committee in the impact assessment process has not been more clearly defined in the draft revised guidelines. In addition, I am concerned about the implementation of this principle, as the Commission has already expressed regret that only eight Member States have included the SME test in their national decision-making processes. I believe that the Impact Assessment Committee should continue to work as an independent quality control body within the European Commission and I demand that its independence be strengthened.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — Although we are not negative about the resolution as a whole, which, for the most part, improves a rather bad situation, we nevertheless disagree because it creates institutions completely free of parliamentary control and, moreover, because it limits the possibility of self-government of the Member States. After all, the conclusion drawn from the experience of the various independent authorities so far is that they are not really independent and that the lack of the possibility of direct political control leads to their control through practices which are not acceptable to us.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. - We stress that REFIT cannot be used as a pretext for lowering the level of ambition on issues of vital importance to the safety and wellbeing of employees, or on the protection of the environment. I warn against the promotion of a deregulation agenda using the pretext of better regulation or of reducing the burdens on SMEs. We call on the Commission not to lower its level of ambition and call for public policy objectives including environmental, social, and health and safety standards not to be jeopardised.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the revision of the Commission’s impact assessment guidelines and the role of the SME test. Indeed, I took an active part on the drafting of the text and supported proposal to additionally include on the agenda. The adoption of this resolution is I hope a statement of intent from this new Parliament. Better regulation can strongly contribute to improving European competitiveness, growth and creation of jobs. Reducing EU red tape is also key to ensure a business environment that small and medium sized companies can grow in.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution as I very much doubt that the Commission's impact assessments on SMEs will be credible. In my view, these assessments are a mere formality, a procedure which in no case calls into question the interests of the great lobists, who are the ones who set the EU's legislative proposals. Helping SMEs should end the EU's neoliberal policies, end the privatisations, liberalisations, cuts and austerity, which are killing the internal market of different EU countries.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. — The need for the Commission to regularly review the Impact Assessment guidelines towards SMEs is vital when we consider that the cost for an SME to comply with any regulation can be 10 times greater than for larger companies; at the same time there is a need to ensure that regulation which benefits workers is not undermined. To alleviate this problem the resolution calls for the Commission to establish a high-level Better Regulation Advisory Body involving both stakeholder expertise and national experts, which is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We agree with the aim of improving the impact assessment (IA) process by covering economic, social and environmental aspects. The approach should be carried out in all initiatives: legislative proposals and the Legislative Programme, as well as the Commission's Work, legislative proposals not included in that programme which have clearly identifiable economic, administrative, social and environmental impacts, non-legislative initiatives defining future policies and delegated or implementing acts of the Commission that may have significant identifiable impacts on the same terms. However, we regret that this resolution intends to establish an advisory body called Better Regulation. The EU, as always, gives with one hand to take with the other, and therefore the resolution supports the maintenance of SME tests, to prevent SMEs from being disproportionately affected or harmed by the Commission's initiatives vis-à-vis larger companies, naturally accepting that SMEs are harmed, only that this damage is not disproportionate. In the face of such contradictions we were unable to vote in favour.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We agree with the objective of improving the impact assessment (IA) process by ensuring that economic, social and environmental aspects are assessed in equal depth and that the approach takes place in all initiatives that are: legislative proposals in the Commission's Legislative and Work Programme, legislative proposals not included in that programme that have economic impacts , clearly identifiable administrative, social and environmental, non-legislative initiatives defining future policies and delegated or implementing Commission acts that may have significant identifiable impacts on the same terms. However, we regret that this resolution intends to establish an advisory body called Better Regulation, composed of representatives of national stakeholders and experts, to complement the Commission's work on IA, in particular with regard to subsidiarity and proportionality. The EU, as always, gives with one hand to take large with the other, and therefore the resolution supports the maintenance of SME tests, to prevent SMEs from being disproportionately affected or harmed by the Commission's initiatives vis-à-vis larger companies", naturally accepting that SMEs are harmed, only that this injury is not disproportionate. In the face of such contradictions we were unable to vote in favour.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I wholeheartedly support this motion for a resolution, because I fully agree that children’s rights should be at the heart of EU policies. The awful news of child neglect, abuse, trafficking and exploitation that reaches us on a daily basis demonstrates the urgent need for additional measures to protect our children. All children, whatever their social or ethnic background, should receive the highest level of education and care, and protection of migrant children in particular has to be scaled up, because this is one of the most vulnerable groups that is suffering from the inadequate migration laws and too often falling through the gaps in existing policies.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL). -
text: A Uachtaráin, táim i bhfabhar an rúin seo ar chomóradh fiche cúig bliain den Choinbhinsiún um Chearta an Linbh agus táim sásta go bhfuil an seans againn cearta páistí agus daoine óga a chur cun tosaigh ar chlár an Aontais Eorpaigh. Caithfimid cearta páistí a chur cun tosaigh ar fud an domhain agus a chinntiú go bhfuil ceart acu maireachtáil in áit gan chogadh agus na rudaí uafásacha a thagann leis. Chomh maith leis sin, caithfimid díriú ar pháistí mar gurb iadsan a gortaíodh agus a ionsaíodh le linn na géarchéime mar gheall ar na beartais déine go léir.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today, on the occasion of the 25th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, the European Parliament has strongly stressed the absolute need to protect children and to ensure that the Union's policies are geared towards guaranteeing their protection and well-being.  Celebrating anniversaries is not a ritual choice, let alone a repetitive aspect. It helps to take stock of the situation, in our case to see how much of the demanding document on children's rights, after 25 years, has been implemented, with what quantitative but above all qualitative results, and more explicitly what of the established indications has become reality, where, how, with what impact in culture, legislation, services, support for minors and their families. Unfortunately, much remains to be done. Moreover, talking about the rights of children and children is about the present and the future of our society. I must point out that, unfortunately, from my point of view, in the text of the resolution that I also voted for ....... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Charles Tannock (ECR). -
text: Mr President, of course, I too celebrate the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, and I condemn absolutely, without any reservations whatsoever, the horrific things going on in the world, like child malnutrition, child soldiers, child suicide bombers, forced child marriages and trafficking, and the issue of female genital mutilation, which may even still be occurring in the city of London, which I represent. Of course, we have seen the recent horrors of Boko Haram in Nigeria and ISIS in Iraq, raping and enslaving young girls with impunity. However, there are some aspects of the resolution I have concerns about. First of all, it is the Member States, not the EU, which have primary competence here. Secondly, as a father of three small children myself, I believe that some of the issues concerning early sexualisation and gender identity give me concerns that these may be usurping my parental rights, so I abstained on this motion.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! I voted in favour of the resolution and, from the point of view of the Committee on Petitions, I would like to make three comments. Firstly, it should be made really clear that the violation of children's rights is not only a problem in developing countries, but is also taking place in the Member States of the European Union. Secondly, when it comes to the rights of children, we in the Committee on Petitions always have the problem of the Member States repeatedly pointing out their own responsibilities and doing quasi-closed shop, in other words, often having little dialogue with the institutions of the European Union. Thirdly, a very important experience: especially when it comes to children's rights, we should try to introduce a speedy procedure, because the law is one thing, the enforcement of the law is the other. If it takes several years in the European Union for various legal issues to be resolved, this is not good for the best interests of the child. It is precisely in these places that we should continue to work.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE). -
text: A Uachtaráin, is dóigh liom gur ceart agus gur cóir dúinn díriú ar chearta an linbh, go háirithe an bhliain thábhachtach seo – 25 bliana tar éis Choinbhinsiún na Náisiún Aontaithe.  Cé go bhfuil dul chun cinn maith déanta ina lán slite, ag an am céanna caithfear i bhfad níos mó a dhéanamh go háirithe ó thaobh oideachais de, ó thaobh sláinte de agus ó thaobh cothromaíochta de.  Maidir le hoideachas, ba chóir go bhfaigheadh gach páiste oideachas a oireann dá dtallann agus a thabharfaidh seans dóibh jab maith a fháil ag deireadh na dála. Gan sláinte, ní féidir saol sásúil a bheith ag duine. Go háirithe, ó thaobh cothromaíochta de; níl cothromaíocht ghnéis ann idir buachaillí agus cailíní ina lán áiteanna, mar a dúirt Charles Tannock cúpla nóiméad ó shin. Dá bhrí sin tá sé an-tábhachtach dúinne san Aontas Eorpach a bheith ar an airdeall agus rudaí mar sin a chur i bhfeidhm.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The alarming figures on the continuing violations of children's rights in every part of the world, the case of which reflects deplorable acts and situations that the international community as a whole should have eradicated for a long time, confirm once again that international legal standards have been, and continue to be, consistently disregarded. My vote can only be in favour of this resolution. I am aware, however, that the statutes of principle alone are totally inadequate to ensure effective and concrete protection of individuals in the age of innocence, unless they are accompanied by the daily action of the institutions responsible at all levels to make their respect mandatory and unacceptable.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. - Progress has been made in these twenty-five years, but we remain far from meeting the objectives set out in the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Old unresolved challenges add new problems that deprive millions of children of their rights. The current economic crisis has its sharpest reflection in the increase in child poverty, a phenomenon which, far from being confined to regions of the developing world, also seriously affects many European countries, and in particular Spain. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution which, while it could go further in its complaints, calls for Member States with high rates of child poverty to redoble their efforts and investments in reducing and combating the social exclusion of minors. The Socialists will continue to demand that a minimum income for income-free families with children in their care be guaranteed, co-financed between the European Social Fund and national budgets.  Specific measures are also essential to protect the rights of girls, whose worldwide violation is even more severe, victims of gender-based violence and discrimination.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution as it is an opportunity to put children's rights on the political agenda. Many things have changed since the united Nations Convention was created and adopted, for better and worse. And this has been taken into account in the Resolution that we have adopted. We must place children and young people at the heart of our policies and involve them in decision-making processes. We must empower them to maintain their integrity and fundamental rights, such as education and food. Unfortunately, no country, not even the signatories, has created the full conditions for the full implementation of the Convention. There are more than 20% of children affected by austerity, which prevents them from having access to basic services and being able to fully exercise their fundamental rights.  Violations of children's rights are especially painful when we talk about migrant minors, especially in terms of health. The example of child soldiers is bleeding. The interests of the belligerents are put before the interests of minors.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. - On the occasion of the 25th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, the European Parliament adopts an opinion as a large number of abuses (the situation of orphans, child soldiers, child poverty and sexual abuse of children) remain. The EU is obliged to promote the rights of the child under the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. In this context, the European Parliament calls on the Member States and the Commission to continue to regard the rights of the child as a priority in their domestic policies and relations with third countries. International and European conventions must be respected and improved in this regard.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Many of the votes on this issue related to principles which should be determined by each sovereign nation, not by the European Union.  The culture in France is rather different to the culture in Ireland with respect to sex education, for example.  I voted therefore against motions which would have curtailed the freedom of countries to determine their own policies in accordance with the democratic wishes of their citizens.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. — A few weeks ago we celebrated the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, which is the most widely ratified human rights convention worldwide, including ratification by all EU Member States. Progress towards safeguarding children’s rights has been made since its adoption but new challenges have emerged and children’s rights continue to be breached in many parts of the world as well in the EU. Many children are still victims of violence, war, poverty, social exclusion and rights violations. Also more needs to be done in our relationship with the third world countries to see how we can better harness the influence and resources of the EU to protect children in the conflict zones. We must continue to push children’s rights globally and ensure that all children have the right to a childhood free from war. Thus we cannot cease and must work further to ensure full implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child in policy and in practice and to take additional measures to ensure respect for the rights of every child everywhere, especially the most vulnerable. I call on the EU institutions and the Member States to join forces and cooperate to improve the situation of children.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — This year marks the 25th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to ratify all optional protocols to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. The protection and promotion of the rights of the child are clearly stated objectives of the EU. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child defines standards for the promotion and protection of the rights of the child as a comprehensive set of international legal standards for the protection and well-being of the child. I support calls on the EU and its Member States to make the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) a top priority in their internal policies and in their relations with third countries. It is also important to pay a clear attention to the issue of children in the context of the European Semester, in the preparation of the Annual Growth Survey and in the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. It is essential that the EU and its Member States invest in public services for children, including childcare, education and health.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. " Here, as elsewhere, many declarations of intent can only be subscribed to. However, under the guise of a noble cause, this text contains several recommendations which I do not agree with, including Article 23 which "calls on all Member States to facilitate family reunification".

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. - This anniversary is an opportunity to recall the measures, and to take additional measures, to ensure that the rights of every child are respected. The European Union has been heavily involved in this issue and I welcome the commitments it has made under the Stockholm programme.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution highlights much progress in the world but also highlights the significant failures that remain, according to UNICEF's Executive Director. For example, another 11% of girls are married before the age of 15 and nearly 168 million children between the ages of 5 and 17 are working.  However, the principles contained in this convention should not be recalled because "Nothing reveals the soul of a society better than the way it treats its children" (Mandela).  Nevertheless, the European Union will not be able to influence all world policy and should focus on respecting these rights of the child within it.  It is nevertheless interesting to note that this motion for a resolution, under the guise of defending a noble cause, calls on "all Member States to facilitate family reunification" or the establishment of the European Union's framework for national Roma integration strategies and the Union's equality and non-discrimination policy.  In light of this analysis, I abstained on this point.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I can only join in the chorus of celebrations for the 25th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. I voted in favour of this resolution in the belief that, in this area, we have done well so far, but more needs to be done!

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — Progress has been made in these twenty-five years, but we remain far from meeting the objectives set out in the Convention on the Rights of the Child. To old unresolved challenges, new problems are added that deprive millions of children of their rights. The current economic crisis has its sharpest reflection in the increase in child poverty, a phenomenon which, far from being confined to regions of the developing world, also seriously affects many European countries, and in particular Spain. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution which, while it could go further in its complaints, calls for Member States with high rates of child poverty to redoble their efforts and investments aimed at reducing them and combating the social exclusion of minors. The Socialists will continue to demand that a minimum income for income-free families with children in their care be guaranteed, co-financed between the European Social Fund and national budgets.  It is also essential to develop specific measures to protect the rights of girls, victims of violence and gender discrimination, which are violated around the world even more severely.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution on the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, to which I also contributed as co-author. As I said during the debate yesterday, I would like to welcome the greater results achieved and to enjoy even more of the beautiful anniversary of the Children's Rights Convention, but the reality shows that we have not been able to achieve much of what we promised the children of the world 25 years ago. We also talked about children's hunger, malnutrition and malnutrition in developing countries during this session. By the way, many children are currently in poverty not only in the developing regions of the world, but also in the rich countries of the European Union. Of course, child poverty and hunger are associated with high unemployment in all regions of the world, with underemployment, family poverty and exclusion, and the inability to maintain large families. I therefore hope that in the future we will be able to unite the efforts of the authorities, non-governmental organisations and every human being, and we will not leave any child to the fate.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: In writing. "I naturally voted for this text because we in the European Union must have a particularly progressive approach to children's rights. In particular, we must protect the best interests of the child and we call on our partners, such as the United States, to ratify this document.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour. Net of the most controversial points, we can join the chorus of celebrations of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. We have done well so far, but more needs to be done!

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - Twenty-five years after the adoption by the United Nations General Assembly of the Convention on the Rights of the Child on 20 November. Since then, significant progress has been made, from reducing child mortality to improving the schooling rate, especially for girls, but remains to be done. Old challenges, not yet solved, add new ones.  The situation of children in relation to armed conflict is one of the five strategic priorities of the Subcommittee on Human Rights.  Taking advantage of the presence of the High Representative/Vice-President of the Commission, the debate on this item in plenary addresses the issue of increasing child poverty. Among other issues, the text calls on Member States with above-average child poverty rates to set national targets and prioritize investments aimed at reducing them and combating the social exclusion of children and young people. It also asks them, together with the European Commission, to integrate a specific child and youth approach into the European Semester, the Annual Growth Study and a renewed Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The rights of the child must be respected in every Member State of the European Union. Too often, children are victims of violence, abuse and abuse.  The 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is an opportunity for the European Parliament to reiterate its full support for child protection. Children must have a significant place in European legislation and should be given special attention.  I voted in favour of this resolution, which recalls the commitment of the European Union and its Member States to the rights of the child.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 25th anniversary of the UNITED Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, which allows us to take stock of the great progress that has been made, for example on child mortality and access to education, but at the same time to analyse what still remains to be done.  Children are a fundamental part of our society, representing the future and hope of families, communities and nations. The European Union cannot, therefore, and must strongly condemn the labour exploitation of children, the presence of child soldiers in war zones and the inability of as many as 57 million children to go to school.   I therefore hope that the European Commission will seize the opportunity of the mid-term review of the financial framework to ensure that EU funds fund more instruments to help the most disadvantaged and vulnerable children.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — Twenty five years ago, world leaders made a promise: to protect and fulfil the rights of all children. Rights to grow up safe and healthy, to express their views, and fulfil their potential. But the reality is that, 25 years on, that promise remains unfulfilled for millions of children throughout the world. Today, 18 000 children under the age of five still die every day from preventable causes; as many as 1.5 billion children are at risk of violence annually; and 1 in 3 children in developing countries are malnourished. These are just some of the statistics which prove that, while much progress has indeed been made, much remains to be done. The EU has a key role to play in changing this picture and fulfilling the rights of all children – both within the EU and beyond.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — It is 25 years since the United Nations General Assembly approved the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and Adolescents. It includes 54 articles on the themes of life, protection and development, and is based on the principles of non-discrimination, well-being and listening to the child. The Convention has changed the way children see it. For the first time, childhood has been defined as a protected age. Children are considered to be full individuals, with their own opinions that they have the right to express. In view of the extraordinary importance of the Convention and the commitment that the 194 states, which have ratified it, have made to children, we can provide a positive picture of the progress made by the Convention. Reducing infant mortality, the right to education, vaccinations, reducing HIV, birth registrations and reducing child labour are among the many steps forward made by the Convention. The greatest progress has been made in Africa and Asia in the area of the right to life and development. This anniversary is an opportunity to welcome the great progress that has been made, and at the same time it must also be a warning to look at what still needs to be done.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. - Children are our future and our present - individuals in their own right with inherent dignity. Infrastructure must secure their intellectual, psychological and emotional development holistically. Children have a voice and judicial decisions that affect them must take it into consideration, particularly in family disputes with cross-border elements. Not all Member States recognize this in an equal manner and often children’s voices are the least heard. This is unacceptable. The Union must ensure that children with mental health issues receive the best standard of mental health care within health facilities that respect their dignity, and that their educational and social development is facilitated rather than further hampered. For children in care the first priority is to facilitate and support structures that strengthen family-based care. Where family based care is not possible we must ensure that alternative care facilities provide a high standard of care ensuring their full development. My own country, Malta, must show a true commitment by enacting child rights legislation, providing adequate funding to social welfare institutions in which children at risk find solace, better facilitating family-based care and ensuring that children with mental health difficulties are provided with the best care. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. The Millennium Development Goals are the main priority of the internal policies of the European Union and the Member States in their relations with third countries. These objectives, in particular poverty eradication, access to universal education and gender equality, will only be achieved through the development of public services accessible to all. The Commission must ensure greater coordination within the various services, in order to effectively include children's rights in all eu legislative proposals, policies and financial decisions and to monitor full compliance with the European Union's acquis on children and the obligations arising from the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. For all these reasons and in order to ensure that the mandate and resources available to the Coordinator for Children's Rights adequately reflect the European Union's commitment to systematically and effectively integrating children's rights into its policies, I could only vote in favour of this resolution. I also vote in favour in order to urge Member States to implement the rules set out in the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child for children deprived of parental care.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution as it is an opportunity to put children's rights on the political agenda. Many things have changed since the united Nations Convention was created and adopted, for better and worse. And this has been taken into account in the Resolution that we have adopted. We must place children and young people at the heart of our policies and involve them in decision-making processes. We must empower them to maintain their integrity and fundamental rights, such as education and food. Unfortunately, no country, not even the signatories, has created the full conditions for the full implementation of the Convention. There are more than 20% of children affected by austerity, which prevents them from having access to basic services and being able to fully exercise their fundamental rights.  Violations of children's rights are especially painful when we talk about migrant minors, especially in terms of health. The example of child soldiers is bleeding. The interests of the belligerents are put before the interests of minors.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Convention on the Rights of the Child is ratified almost universally, but is far from being applied universally, with children's rights continuing to be violated in many parts of the world as a result of violence, abuse, exploitation, poverty, social exclusion and discrimination.  Humanitarian crises continue to have a devastating impact on children, with more than 59 million children directly affected by the crisis in 2014, especially in conflict zones. Currently, it is estimated that there are 250,000 child soldiers in the world, 40% of whom are girls. We must condemn the use of children for terrorist or military activities and provide psychological support and assistance to all children who have been exposed to violent events or are victims of war. We need effective measures to protect children from the effects of armed conflict, to stop using children in the armed forces or in armed groups, and to curb impunity for crimes against children. The promotion and protection of children's rights is a priority of EU human rights policy. It is fundamental to defend children involved in armed conflict not only because they are suffering today and because the future belongs to children, but also because they have inherent and inalienable rights.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the initiative to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child by adopting a resolution. This Convention is the most ratified UN Convention; however, there are still millions of children in need all over the world, suffering mainly from poverty, malnutrition, violence and abuse. We should not be mistaken that these issues concern only the developing world. There are also cases when children in the EU are in need and the circumstances for their development and carefree childhood are not guaranteed everywhere. As mentioned in the resolution I would like to call on the Commission, in revising Regulation (EC) No 2201/2003, to take serious note of the best interests of the child, in view of the loopholes in the implementation and enforcement of this regulation in the Member States as regards parental and custody rights and furthermore to put forward specific measures to ensure that the adoption practices carried out in the Member States are in the best interests of the child. I ask the Member States to take their obligations stemming from the Convention and its Optional Protocols seriously as it is the best investment into the next generation.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child highlights the many violations of these rights that persist in the Member States of the European Union, all of which have ratified the Convention.  This anniversary is an opportunity to recall that, all too often, children are subjected to violence, social exclusion, poverty, discrimination, sexual exploitation and many other evils against which we must fight relentlessly. I am particularly committed to the fight against all discrimination, whatever it may be, based on gender, ethical origin, religion, sexual orientation, or disability. The principle of the best interests of the child must be taken into account in all European legislation, including access to justice, access to health care and education.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. It is now 25 years since the adoption of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and Adolescents on 20 November 1989. The Convention has had the merit of carrying out a "cultural revolution" in jurisprudence, recognising the child not only as an object of protection and assistance, but also as a subject of law, and therefore the holder of rights himself. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because this anniversary has certainly made it possible to welcome the great steps taken to defend the rights of the smallest in the world, but at the same time it has made us reflect on what remains to be done.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — The celebration of the 25th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, adopted by the Un General Assembly on 20 November 1989, is an opportunity to recall that while the Convention has promoted changes in national laws to protect children, much remains to be done.  As rapporteur of the European Parliament on the recommendation on the protection of minors and human dignity and on the right of reply in conjunction with the competitiveness of the European audiovisual and online information services industry, I attach particular importance to the protection of children on the internet. Uninformed about the risks, especially related to child pornography, who are not well informed about the privacy settings, they are the most vulnerable public and therefore the one to be protected as a priority.  It is the duty of States and the EU to do everything possible to effectively protect children and young people from the dangers of the digital world, which is not, idea to fight, a virtual world without risk or consequence. Regulation of online content, strengthening of the signage of illegal content, judicial-police cooperation between Member States and with third countries, these are actions to be taken quickly.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this Resolution in considering that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCITRAL) and its optional protocols constitute a fundamental rule on the promotion and protection of the rights of the child, and that it contains a broad set of international legal standards for the protection and well-being of children and establishes clear legal obligations for all EU Member States with regard to the promotion of , the protection and enforcement of the rights of all children in your jurisdiction. In addition, I believe that UNCITRAL, as well as the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, respect the rights of the child to be heard and to express their opinion and to take this into account in all matters affecting them according to their age and maturity, which is fundamental in addressing the issue of child labour and its regulation; an example of this is bolivia's recently passed Code of Girl, Child and Adolescent.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — We are voting against this motion for a resolution because it refers to the sexual identity of children, because it refers to ethnic roma integration and alleged discrimination against this minority and, moreover, because it refers to the participation of children in parliamentary actions and also in the decision-making process. It also calls on the Commission, through humanitarian aid and funding, to protect children where necessary. We consider that children do not have a sexual identity, at least not different from the one with which they were born. We believe that there is no discrimination against Roma, but discrimination of Roma against Europeans. We also believe that the effort to nationally integrate the Roma is directed against the interests of this minority and against the interests of the European peoples. We defend the right and the need of every people to protect their identity.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. - In the years following the adoption of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, more progress was made in the realization and protection of children's rights than in any other comparable period in human history, and the rights of the child are now more important than ever in political agendas. The almost universal ratification of the Convention reflects the commitment of the world, as well as the EU, to the principles underpinning children's rights. In all parts of the world, special institutions, structures, programmes and measures have emerged to promote children's rights.  Together with its three optional protocols, it contains a fairly comprehensive set of legally binding international standards for the promotion and protection of children's rights. With other international and regional standards, including those adopted by the Council of Europe, these instruments provide a solid basis for the enjoyment of human rights by all minors without discrimination of any kind, while providing a benchmark for promoting and monitoring progress in the exercise of children's rights.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — In 2012, around 6.6 million children under the age of 5 died, mostly due to preventable causes; 168 million children aged 5 to 17 are involved in some form of child labour; 11% of girls marry before reaching the age of 15; more than 59 million children have been directly affected by crises, mainly linked to conflicts and there are about 250,000 child soldiers in the world. In 2012 alone, almost 9,5000 children and adolescents under the age of 20 were victims of homicides, almost one billion children aged 2 to 14 were subjected to physical punishment, one in three adolescents aged between 13 and 15 were victims of harassment, about 70 million young people aged 15 to 19 were victims of some form of physical violence and 120 million girls around the world were forced to have sex at some point in their lives. Figures that deserve reflection on the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, are also an opportunity to ensure their full implementation in the programmatic and practical terms and to take additional measures to ensure respect for the rights of children, especially the most vulnerable.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — Progress has been made in these twenty-five years, but we remain far from meeting the objectives set out in the Convention on the Rights of the Child. To old unresolved challenges, new problems are added that deprive millions of children of their rights. The current economic crisis has its sharpest reflection in the increase in child poverty, a phenomenon which, far from being confined to regions of the developing world, also seriously affects many European countries, and in particular Spain. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution which, while it could go further in its complaints, calls for Member States with high rates of child poverty to redoble their efforts and investments aimed at reducing them and combating the social exclusion of minors. The Socialists will continue to demand that a minimum income for income-free families with children in their care be guaranteed, co-financed between the European Social Fund and national budgets.  It is also essential to develop specific measures to protect the rights of girls, victims of violence and gender discrimination, which are violated around the world even more severely.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — 25 years after the adoption of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, it is necessary to reflect on the path taken to promote a future with better conditions of well-being and dignity for children.  The Convention, despite its agreement, is not being applied in many countries of the world. In several Member States, children's rights are being called into question by eu austerity policies. Policies that lead to the deprivation of various rights, such as the right to education, health, housing and a healthy diet that is adequate to their physical and psychic growth. Only the urgent break with these policies will prevent the worsening of the living conditions of children and the attack on their rights. We welcome the adoption of our amendments calling for the extension of the public network of kindergartens, crèches and utilities that provide recreational activities for children; member states to protect or increase maternity and paternity rights and to ensure compulsory and free secondary education for all. It is significant and regrettable that PSD and CDS have voted against several of these proposals. And that the PS has also voted against references to the effects of austerity policies.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. — One of the European Union's most fundamental values is the protection of children's rights, and the Union seeks a thorough implementation of the Convention and appeals to the Member States to continuously improve their national legal order and adopt new laws for the protection of children. However, the European Union must continue to develop integrated guidelines and legislation to ensure that all children across the Member States are protected from any form of violence. The main task of the European Commission is to ensure that the most disadvantaged and vulnerable children receive the necessary financial assistance from the multiannual financial framework. It is very important for the European Union to continue initiatives that provide psychological assistance and assistance to children who have been victims of war or violent events and to ensure that they have access to quality education in the future.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting in favour of the report, bearing in mind that the Convention on the Rights of the Child is a fundamental step in the history of our time and it is right and proper that we should make every effort to do more.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting against this motion for a resolution because it refers to the sexual identity of children, because it refers to ethnic Roma integration and alleged discrimination against this minority and, moreover, because it refers to the participation of children in parliamentary actions and also in the decision-making process. It also calls on the Commission, through humanitarian aid and funding, to protect children where necessary. We consider that children do not have a sexual identity, at least not different from the one with which they were born. We believe that there is no discrimination against Roma, but discrimination of Roma against Europeans. We also believe that the effort to nationally integrate the Roma is directed against the interests of this minority and against the interests of the European peoples. We defend the right and the need of every people to protect their identity.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. On 20 November 1989, the representatives of the states of the world, meeting in the UN General Assembly, unanimously approved the text of the International Convention on the Rights of the Child. Today in this House we have all been in favour of the resolution on the occasion of the 25th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.  Everyone understands this and it is widely shared that the first commitment of those who have the honour of being the protagonist of decision-making must be children.  Yet we still cannot say that in the 191 States that have ratified the Convention, children enjoy all the rights listed, from the right to life to the right to development. That is why, in order to emphasise the way still to go, the commitment to be put in place, that I voted in favour of this resolution.  I hope that the efforts made by all EU countries to ratify the Convention will be an example and a driving force for the United States, with which we are negotiating TTIP today, to give a signal of openness so as to ratify the Convention.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — In 1989, the United Nations created the Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC), a human rights treaty designed specifically to safeguard the rights of children. 2014 marks the 25th anniversary of this convention, but sadly there is still work to be done. This resolution is important as new issues have arisen since the CRC was first ratified; for example, the rise of cyber-attacks on children and the use of children in terrorist activities.      While all EU Member States have ratified the CRC, children’s rights continue to be violated. We must do more to develop an integrated EU strategy to effectively promote and safeguard the rights of the child and to increase the participation of children in parliamentary activities. By creating a parliamentary intergroup that will promote children’s rights across the EU the European Parliament is demonstrating its commitment to furthering children’s rights and monitoring progress in this area.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. - Progress has been made in these twenty-five years, but we remain far from meeting the objectives set out in the Convention on the Rights of the Child. I voted in favour of this resolution, as it calls for Member States with high rates of child poverty to redoble their efforts and investments aimed at reducing them and combating the social exclusion of minors. The Socialists will continue to demand that a minimum income for income-free families with children in their care be guaranteed, co-financed between the European Social Fund and national budgets.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. — It is crucial for the European Parliament to reiterate its commitment to the defence of children's rights. Twenty-five years after the adoption of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, the account is unfortunately still not there in the EU.  However, the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, EU directives and the EU's agenda on the rights of the child demonstrate a strong commitment by the EU in this area. If there is a clear framework, then it is implementation that is the problem. We are often told that a child is first and foremost a child, but, for example, in the case of migrant children, if everyone agrees on the principle of the best interests of the child, in practice, the fears of abuse and misappropriation of procedure take precedence, and it is the child's residence permit or absence that prevails.  Too often, they are treated as adults, with little or no consideration for their obvious vulnerability. While the resolution adopted here reminds us of each other's commitments, above all it must enable the full implementation of an existing and well-provided legal and operational framework.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. — Progress has been made in these twenty-five years, but we remain far from meeting the objectives set out in the Convention on the Rights of the Child. To old unresolved challenges, new problems are added that deprive millions of children of their rights. The current economic crisis has its sharpest reflection in the increase in child poverty, a phenomenon which, far from being confined to regions of the developing world, also seriously affects many European countries, and in particular Spain. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution which, while it could go further in its complaints, calls for Member States with high rates of child poverty to redoble their efforts and investments aimed at reducing them and combating the social exclusion of minors. The Socialists will continue to demand that a minimum income for income-free families with children in their care be guaranteed, co-financed between the European Social Fund and national budgets.  It is also essential to develop specific measures to protect the rights of girls, victims of violence and gender discrimination, which are violated around the world even more severely.

name: Eduard-Raul Hellvig (PPE)
text: in writing. — A quarter of a century after the adoption of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, millions of children worldwide continue to be abused, discriminated against, harassed, exploited through labour or sex, deprived of basic rights to education and health, subjected to slavery, violence, forced marriages or military enlistment at an early age.  Unfortunately, even in EU Member States, violations of children's rights are still being recorded, with an obvious correlation between the level of education and the standard of living of the family and the trauma suffered by children. This is why greater efforts are needed to combat child poverty and ensure access to free elementary school education for all children.  We have at our disposal the framework defined by the EU Agenda for the Rights of the Child, so the Member States and the European institutions must act more firmly to eradicate poverty and combat the vicious circle of defavoration. Increased attention is needed to counter violence against children, their harassment and exploitation both online and through illegal cross-border trafficking of people. I call on the European for a to monitor more closely in this regard the application by the Member States of Directives 2011/36/EU and 92/2011/EU.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. — Of course, every reasonable person is committed to the rights of the child. It is indeed depressing to see how often today children still grow up under poverty, exploitation, malnutrition, disease, lack of education and lack of affection. It is heartbreaking to see girls being treated in particular compared to boys in Islamic countries. It is horrible to see every day how children suffer the consequences of war. But why are children's rights not covered by human rights? Are they not human beings? When are there resolutions for the elderly, the elderly and the very old? Since no resolution will change the way our children are treated, and since human rights apply to all people anyway, I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution!

name: Hölvényi György (PPE)
text: Writing. — At today's plenary session of the European Parliament, it discussed the most pressing issues affecting children's rights in the context of the 25 years since the UN adopted the Convention on the Rights of the Child. On the 25th anniversary of the signing of the Convention, EU Member States should reaffirm their commitment to respect and protect children's rights in practice. It is of the utmost importance to protect the rights of the child both within and outside the Union, since respect for children's rights is as much a legal as a moral obligation. Hungary also sets a good example in this area. Think of child-friendly justice or the new elements of the Hungarian Penal Code that better protect children.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this Resolution in considering that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCITRAL) and its optional protocols constitute a fundamental rule on the promotion and protection of the rights of the child, and that it contains a broad set of international legal standards for the protection and well-being of children and establishes clear legal obligations for all EU Member States with regard to the promotion of , the protection and enforcement of the rights of all children in your jurisdiction. In addition, I believe that UNCITRAL, as well as the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, respect the rights of the child to be heard and to express their opinion and to take this into account in all matters affecting them according to their age and maturity, which is fundamental in addressing the issue of child labour and its regulation; an example of this is bolivia's recently passed Code of Girl, Child and Adolescent.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
