text: Written. — I voted for a resolution on the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, as it calls on all institutions of the European Union, Member States, local authorities, social partners and society as a whole to jointly improve the situation of children in the European Union and around the world.  Nowadays, more than before, children face many dangers, various forms of violence, virile abuse, sexual exploitation, trafficking in human beings, and many other undesirable situations and problems on a daily basis, so it is extremely important that their rights are not violated.  Strengthening additional measures to ensure respect for children's rights develops effective guidelines for better and more effective protection of children and their rights.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Resolution on the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child since the conviction that we have made great progress in the protection of children in this fourth century, but we still have a long way to go. In less developed countries, including some Latin Americans, hundreds of thousands of children live in extreme poverty, are forced to work, do not have access to education, or are abused of all kinds. From the EU we must keep this reality in mind and help combat it, as we must also combat the reality of child poverty when it takes place here in Europe. The countries that have suffered the most from the scourshell of the crisis, for example Spain, have once again seen the terrible face of child poverty, which we thought we were forgotten, and before which the Spanish Government opts for inaction, even refusing to collect data on the phenomenon. However, denying reality does not help change it, on the contrary.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. - On the occasion of the 25th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, I supported Parliament's motion for a resolution on this matter. I am glad that the Convention has been ratified in almost every country in the world.  On 26 November 2014, I raised the subject during the EP plenary session in Strasbourg, to highlight in particular the very worrying situation in South Sudan, where malnutrition threatens the lives of tens of thousands of children.  South Sudan, torn by armed conflict, is one of the few countries that has not ratified the Convention. At the same time, I appreciated that the High Representative/Vice-President of the Commission promised in plenary that she would take steps to bring the European Union as a whole into this fundamental international convention.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the 25th anniversary of the Un Convention on the Rights of the Child. The text calls on the Commission to better coordinate its services to include children's rights in all EU legislative proposals, policies and financial decisions. It also stresses that Member States must ensure that the best interests of the child are respected in all legislation and better prevent human trafficking, forced labour and sexual exploitation, which still affects too many children. Finally, the resolution expresses the wish to see the Union accede to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I welcome the vote of this parliamentary resolution on the 25th anniversary of the Un Convention on the Rights of the Child. Twenty-five years after its adoption, the figures remain edifying and show how the protection of children needs to be strengthened globally: nearly 6.6 million children under the age of five died in 2012 (most of them from preventable causes), 168 million children aged five to 17 work, 11% of girls are married before the age of fifteen), 168 million children aged five to 17 work, 11% of girls are married before the age of fifteen , one in ten children dies before the age of five in sub-Saharan Africa, more than 59 million children were directly affected by crises and conflicts in 2014, and there are 250,000 child soldiers worldwide. In addition, 76.5 million children live in poverty in rich countries.  Respect for the rights of every child must be at the heart of Member States' social policy and be a priority for the EU's foreign policy vis-à-vis the rest of the world. The new High Representative must therefore address this subject systematically in political dialogues with third countries and in discussions on conflict resolutions.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. - Despite the UN Convention’s achievements, millions of children across the world remain vulnerable. Children’s rights must be at the heart of EU policies and the 25th anniversary of the Convention is an opportunity to ensure its full implementation in policy and to take additional measures to ensure respect for the rights of every child, everywhere.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of this resolution because it calls on the European Commission to offer greater support to children who are victims of violence, abuse, exploitation, social exclusion, religious, sexual, ethnic discrimination, etc. Unfortunately, children's rights continue to be violated in many parts of the world, including the European Union, so I consider this resolution to be particularly important.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. — Guaranteeing children's rights must be a priority for each of us, both within and outside the EU Member States, especially in non-democratic states, in war zones. Even according to the latest report by the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef) on child poverty in rich countries, since 2008, 2.6 million people have been affected by child poverty in the rich countries. children living in the world's richest countries are below the poverty line– we can see that the situation is worrying and children are the most sensitive part of society. Investing in children, a kind of policy towards children, improving their social situation in the ways chosen by the Member States through education programmes, education, community support, support for families, will certainly produce results in the near future. On the other hand, the exceptional harm to children is still caused by the humanitarian crisis in the world. In 2014, over 59 million people were affected by the children's lives have been directly affected by the crisis associated with conflicts, and today there are around 250 000 child soldiers, of whom as many as 40% are girls. An integrated policy towards children, together with the EU Neighbourhood Policy or development policy, can therefore deliver results. The fight against child poverty and exploitation must take place today. Accession of states such as Somalia or South Sudan to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child should take place immediately, if not under pressure from the international community. In the European Parliament, we regularly pay attention to children's rights, their violations, and last year's Sakharov Prize is an illustration of that. Malala, who fought for children's right to education, became a winner not only of Sakharov, but also of the Nobel Peace Prize.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against the decision, voted by Parliament by 327 votes to 316, to organise "complete sexual education for children to combat stereotypes" because it aims to stuff our children's heads with the elucidations of gender theory. Libertarian indoctrination is now!

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - Twenty-five years of unanimous approval by the United Nations General Assembly in 1989 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child have been completed on 20 November. The Convention acquired binding status in September 1990 after being ratified by twenty States and almost all States have now acceded to it.  Remarkable progress has been made in this quarter of a century, from reducing child mortality to improving the schooling rate, especially for girls, but this symbolic date also serves to remind us of how much remains to be done. New problems have added to old challenges that deprive many children of both their rights and the benefits of development. In this context, Unicef decided to declare 2014 the Year of Innovation for Equity in order to focus global attention on the presentation and development of innovative solutions that promote the well-being of children.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. — Progress has been made in these twenty-five years, but we remain far from meeting the objectives set out in the Convention on the Rights of the Child. To old unresolved challenges, new problems are added that deprive millions of children of their rights. The current economic crisis has its sharpest reflection in the increase in child poverty, a phenomenon which, far from being confined to regions of the developing world, also seriously affects many European countries, and in particular Spain. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution which, while it could go further in its complaints, calls for Member States with high rates of child poverty to redoble their efforts and investments aimed at reducing them and combating the social exclusion of minors. The Socialists will continue to demand that a minimum income for income-free families with children in their care be guaranteed, co-financed between the European Social Fund and national budgets.  It is also essential to develop specific measures to protect the rights of girls, victims of violence and gender discrimination, which are violated around the world even more severely.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution as it is an opportunity to put children's rights on the political agenda. Many things have changed since the united Nations Convention was created and adopted, for better and worse. And this has been taken into account in the Resolution that we have adopted. We must place children and young people at the heart of our policies and involve them in decision-making processes. We must empower them to maintain their integrity and fundamental rights, such as education and food. Unfortunately, no country, not even the signatories, has created the full conditions for the full implementation of the Convention. There are more than 20% of children affected by austerity, which prevents them from having access to basic services and being able to fully exercise their fundamental rights.  Violations of children's rights are especially painful when we talk about migrant minors, especially in terms of health. The example of child soldiers is bleeding. The interests of the belligerents are put before the interests of minors.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted in favour of this declaration because the UN Convention emphasises the fundamental rights of children, the enforcement of which is an important task of the international community in all countries. These include, for example.B the right to education, protection against physical abuse, protection against sexual abuse, etc. However, I do not agree with calls to codify children's rights of defence against their parents' educational mission. Raising children is the right and duty of parents. An intervention by a supranational body or a national legislature in this core area of the family is justified only in the case of serious breaches of duty by the parents or significant impairments of the child's physical, mental or social developmental opportunities.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. This year marks the 25th anniversary of the Convention. Poland was the initiator of this most important document on children's rights. The anniversary is a good time to take stock of the situation regarding respect for children's rights. In this context, I wanted to highlight the issues of protecting children from poverty. One provision of the Convention is the right of every child to a standard of living corresponding to his or her physical, mental, spiritual, moral and social development (Article 27). Poverty means depriving children of these rights, as well as depriving them of the rights to survival, protection and development, including those enshrined in the Convention.  Although the number of people in extreme poverty has fallen worldwide, almost half of the poorest population is 18 years old or less. Poverty is not just about the poorest countries. According to a recent UNICEF report, more than 30 million children in the world's richest countries live in poverty. In Europe, a quarter of children under six are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. The lack of protection of children from poverty has tragic consequences for children themselves and society as a whole. Therefore, combating poverty must be a key priority for any government. At European level, it is crucial to introduce a separate child poverty reduction target in the European programme to combat poverty and social exclusion.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. — Every year, over 7 million child deaths worldwide could be prevented, over 59 million children are victims of humanitarian crises, and over 1 billion children are victims of abuses such as neglect, abuse, sexual exploitation, kidnapping, human trafficking, and many other rights violations in the European Union, in the EU’s partner states, as well as worldwide. Twenty-five years ago, all the Member States of the European Union ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. The promotion of children’s rights is a fundamental objective of the European Union’s policies.  Despite this, the progress made in the last 25 years, although remarkable, is insufficient. Presently, in the EU alone, between 10 and 20 million children will have suffered some form of assault during their childhood. It is imperative that we take all the steps necessary to ensure that the most vulnerable, and at the same time the most important citizens of the EU, the children, receive adequate protection and support, and, as such, I fully support this initiative.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. - On November 20, 1989, the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child was adopted in New York City. This document, in its 54 articles, ensures their rights and the protection of children who, due to their physical and mental immaturity, need specific protection and care measures, including appropriate legal protection before and after birth.  I support this resolution and all efforts of organizations and institutions to take care of children's rights. I believe that the most important thing is to provide all children with equal conditions for growing up - protection from any form of violence, providing basic living conditions, enabling education and growing up in peace. Today, children's rights are systematically violated in underdeveloped countries where children are exploited as cheap labour while being abused in war zones and living in extremely poor conditions.  It is time to come up with a long-term plan to solve these problems, but also to define new forms of child rights endangerment such as "cyber-bulling" and how to combat them.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - Despite the anniversary of such an important convention, children's rights are not respected and not always respected everywhere in the world. The European Union still has a lot to do to ensure that all children on our planet are fed, happy and fully-fledged and educated citizens of their countries. I voted in favour!

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution because this resolution aims to protect the rights of the child worldwide and in particular in the countries of the European South.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that children's rights must be at the heart of European Union policies. The 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is an opportunity to take further measures to ensure that the rights of every child, in particular the most vulnerable, are respected everywhere.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - 25 years have passed since the adoption of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Although much progress has been made over time, children's rights continue to be violated in various parts of the world, including the European Union.  Many children continue to be victims of violence, abuse, exploitation, social exclusion, religious, sexual, ethnic discrimination, etc... It is for these reasons that I felt it necessary to express my agreement with a resolution which, with strength and determination, calls on the European Commission to offer greater moral and economic support to disadvantaged children.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: in writing. - Children play an important role in our society and are the most vulnerable. However, in many countries children’s rights are still often violated and many are abused, exploited and denied access to education. Each child should be guaranteed the rights of survival, development and wellbeing. I was in favour of the EU’s commitment of mainstreaming children’s rights in the EU and around the world.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is an international treaty adopted by the United Nations in 1989 to recognize and protect the specific rights of children. It is a children's specific variation of human rights as provided for by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The resolution, full of good intentions, aims to promote its full implementation at both the political and practical levels. I note, however, that not for a moment does it mention the fact that, of the 193 UN-recognized states, only the United States, Somalia and South Sudan are not parties to this treaty. It is therefore not envisaged to question relations with countries that deny the rights of the child in this way. Nevertheless, I would like to celebrate the anniversary of this convention and I vote FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and its optional protocols are the norm for the promotion and protection of the rights of the child, encompassing a wide range of international legal standards on the protection and well-being of children.  The rights of the child are at the heart of EU policies and the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is an opportunity to ensure its full implementation in the programmatic and practical terms and to take additional measures to ensure respect everywhere for the rights of children, especially the most vulnerable. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. - As one of the initiators of this report, I am proud to have voted in favour of this resolution. It is essential that the principle of the best interests of the child is respected in all legislation at both the EU and national level. It is time for the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child to be fully implemented across the EU Member States. It is our hope that the Commission will now see the need for a Child Rights Strategy, inclusive of a concrete Action Plan for the next five years.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Because of their vulnerability, the child must be given special attention, guaranteeing the rights to develop, learn and flourish, make his voice heard and reach his or her full potential. Twenty-five years have passed since the signing of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. Progress has been made, but there are still many children whose rights remain violated.  Even in Europe, many children are still victims of violence, abuse, exploitation, social exclusion and poverty. Paraphrasing Kofi Annan, I believe that "nothing is more important than building a world in which all our children will have the opportunity to reach their full potential and grow up healthy, peaceful and dignified."

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – It has been 25 years since the adoption of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and some progress has been made, but unfortunately children's fundamental rights continue to be violated not only in the world, but also directly in our country, in the European Union. I stress that the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and its protocols are only an essential standard for protecting the rights of the child and his or her quality of life. However, modern 21st-century society should make a commitment to deepening the fundamental rights of the child, in accordance with the principles of the best interests of the child and non-discrimination, as well as the child's right to life, survival and development. I highlight, above all, the fundamental right, namely the right to life, on which all the other rights of the child depend. Unfortunately, the right to life is not explicitly guaranteed or protected at the prenatal stage, thus allowing practices that destroy human life before birth and even allocate public funds to them. I consider such practices, like the two million EU citizens who have officially supported the 'One of Us' citizens' initiative, to be inadmissible and contrary to the rights of the child. I therefore reiterate my call on the European Union and the Member States to adopt coherent legislation and policy on the protection of children's rights and not to overlook the need to protect their lives and integrity at a prenatal stage.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – Twenty-five years after signing the Convention, children’s rights continue to be dishonoured in many parts of the world and millions of children around the world are still victims of cyberbullying, trafficking, sexual exploitation, social exclusion and discrimination among many other abuses. Much more needs to be done to address children’s needs and to make the vision of the Convention a reality for all children around the world. Therefore I fully support the Parliament resolution on the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. While the Convention contains many positive elements, including some progress on the right to education and health for an increasing number of children around the world, it is nevertheless true that clear failures remain, even by the UNICEF Executive Director' admission. These negative points concern, for example, child labour or early and forced marriages (nearly 168 million children, aged 5 to 17, work and 11% of girls are married before the age of 15). Of course, we can only regret that children's rights are not being respected around the world. However, the European Union will not be able to solve all the world's problems and it is time for it to refocus on respect for children's rights in Europe. In 2011, there were 25 million poor children in the EU. It should also be noted that, under the guise of defending a noble cause, the Union calls on "all Member States to facilitate family reunification", to encourage the establishment and development of national Roma integration strategies or to accelerate the policy of equality and non-discrimination. So I abstained.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution. The 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is an opportunity for us to remind us that children are still victims, including in Europe, of abuse, violence or exploitation. Our fight against these intolerable acts must continue unabated.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - I supported the decision because children's rights must be at the heart of European Union policy. Each child is unique and very valuable and must be protected without prejudice, regardless of race, nationality, social class or nationality of his or her parents. Children's rights must be protected and recognised through the European Union's internal and national policies, supporting the implementation of Member States' strategies.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. — In general I supported the resolution. Thus, I respect the principle of subsidiarity in areas where I consider each Member State has to make its own decisions and establish its own levels of subsidiarity. I refer to areas such as education in sexual and reproductive health and rights. On the other hand, in view of the considerable number of cases alleging that public authorities in some Member States have proceeded with forced adoption without parental consent, I agree that the Commission puts forward specific measures to ensure that the adoption practices carried out in the Member States are in the best interests of the child!

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - By accepting the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child in 1989, children were for the first time internationally recognised as human beings with innate rights. Since its acceptance, the Convention has become the fastest and most widely ratified human rights treaty in which children's rights are equated with those of adults. The most important aspect is that children born after the adoption of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child have much more opportunities and rights than children born in 1989.  Children today have the right to independently report violations of their basic rights knowing that their safety will be guaranteed. The courage of children marked this year when a young women's education activist from Pakistan, Malala Yousafzai, and children's rights activist from India, Kailash Satyarthi, were selected as nobel peace prize winners. To support children in war-affected countries, the European Union has launched the EU Children of Peace initiative, which provides more than 108,000 children with education.  The Republic of Croatia has been included among those advanced countries that have undertaken the obligation to ensure and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms. Violence against children and 25 years after the signing of the Convention is a cruel reality and we are obliged to ensure that every child has adequate access to justice and respect for the right to identity starting from birth.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I believe that children's rights and the protection of minors in all its forms must be given a fast track in all EU actions and policies. The 25th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, to which I voted in favour, represents a good opportunity to ensure the full implementation of additional measures that guarantee and strengthen respect for the rights of every child, especially those children who are in extremely vulnerable conditions. As the resolution says, I very much hope that the Commission will present an ambitious and comprehensive strategy and action plan on children's rights for years to come based on the EU's Children's Agenda and that there will be closer cooperation with the UNITED Nations and Unicef. I also hope that there will be the necessary ways to allow the EU to unilaterally accede to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. — The family is the base cell of the whole society! Children's rights are not conceivable without parental rights and obligations. And when we celebrate children's rights here today, it should not be forgotten that every child has parents. However, they have a right to society's contribution to the preservation of them. In addition to their importance for their own children, children are the prerequisite for a society's continued existence. One can see in the refusal of the dominant parties to express and promote this clearly, their contempt for the contribution of parents! Children's rights are human rights, special children's rights against their own parents are not needed.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. —It is right on the twenty-fifth anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Children to recall the way forward to respect the best interests of the child in Europe and around the world. The European Union still has a long way to go, and I ask the Member States to agree to a coherence of their positions on this subject. I therefore vote in favour of such a resolution.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — Although, since the adoption of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, significant progress has been made in the defence of the rights of the child, the truth is that these rights continue to be violated in many parts of the world as a result of acts of violence, abuse, exploitation, poverty, social exclusion and discrimination, and it has been found that, even in rich countries, 2.6 million children have lived below the poverty line since 2008 , bringing to about 76.5 million the total number of children in the developed world living in poverty. However, given that the promotion of the rights of the child is an explicit objective of EU policies, this resolution proposes a set of additional measures to be taken by the EU and its Member States (such as the ratification of all optional protocols of the UN Convention by Member States and the full implementation of the Package on the Common European Asylum System) to promote and effectively safeguard the rights of children , thereby ensuring the full implementation of the Convention and the EU's commitment to the Stockholm Programme.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. - The European Union must take the opportunity of the 25th anniversary of this convention, which is very essential, to adopt new measures in favour of the promotion of children's rights. The Charter of Fundamental Rights requires that the best interests of the child be taken into account in all EU policies. Respect for the rights of children should apply to all without discrimination, regardless of their origin. The most striking example is that of unaccompanied minors who, before being migrants, are above all potentially endangered children and must be protected as such. Through this resolution, the European Parliament calls on Member States to fully implement the common European asylum system in order to improve the situation of these particularly vulnerable minors. MEPs reaffirm the urgent need to end the detention of migrant children, an inhumane practice unworthy of our values.   Member States, having all ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, are obliged to protect and ensure the well-being of all of them. It is time for the European Union to also join this Convention, with the promotion of children's rights at the heart of the European ideal and our concerns.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. — Seven-year-old Serba works in slate mines. From six o'clock in the morning, he breaks the stones and saws the slates for six rupees a day. Half of the sawmill workers are children.  6.5 million children under the age of five die each year from preventable causes, 168 million children between the ages of five and 17 work, 58 million children of school age are out of school, and an estimated 250,000 child soldiers are killed.  On the occasion of the 25th anniversary of the Un Convention on the Rights of the Child, the EP wanted to recall how far we have come, but also and above all to draw attention to all that remains to be done. Since 1989, dramatic progress has been made in protecting and promoting rights, as well as promoting equality. Nevertheless, the figures on child abuse, in Europe and elsewhere, remain unacceptable. The need for this Convention is of obvious relevance, and its scope must continue to be extended to all children, without discrimination of nationality, social status, gender or religion. Every child is first and foremost a child!

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. - Progress has been made in these twenty-five years, but we remain far from meeting the objectives set out in the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Old unresolved challenges add new problems that deprive millions of children of their rights. The current economic crisis has its sharpest reflection in the increase in child poverty, a phenomenon which, far from being confined to regions of the developing world, also seriously affects many European countries, and in particular Spain. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution which, while it could go further in its complaints, calls for Member States with high rates of child poverty to redoble their efforts and investments in reducing and combating the social exclusion of minors. The Socialists will continue to demand that a minimum income for income-free families with children in their care be guaranteed, co-financed between the European Social Fund and national budgets.  Specific measures are also essential to protect the rights of girls, whose worldwide violation is even more severe, victims of gender-based violence and discrimination.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. One hundred and sixty-eight million children between the ages of 5 and 17 are working, 11% of girls are married before the age of 15; in sub-Saharan Africa, one in 10 children dies before the age of five... The 25th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child must be an opportunity to ensure its full implementation at both the political and practical levels, and to take additional steps to ensure that the rights of every child, especially the most vulnerable, are respected. The vote on this resolution was a priority.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 25th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child is celebrated. This is the perfect opportunity to put them at the heart of the European Union's policies and to ensure their full implementation, not only on a programmatic level, but above all in practice, by adopting measures to ensure respect for their rights and interests, especially those most vulnerable. It is a fact that all the Member States of the European Union have already ratified the UN Convention. However, it is important to make a view to making the US, Somalia and South Sudan also do so in order to make their ratification universal. But it's not enough! We still need to ensure that what is in theory ratified is implemented in practice. There are still several scourges to combat: cyberbullying, child violence, child pornography, genital mutilation, among others. About 170 million children are subject to child labor and a quarter of a million are child soldiers. Nothing justifies and can justify these inothermane and horrendous atrocities. This resolution makes an important contribution to the guarantee, safeguarding and protection of the rights of the child, making a set of priority recommendations for the eradication of these terrible scourges, with a view to the development of future generations.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. "I supported this text, which was drafted and presented in plenary session following a request and initiative by the EPP Group.  Twenty-five years after the signing of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which has been ratified by all EU Member States, children continue to be victims of violence and abuse. In the face of this unbearable situation, it was essential to ask the European Commission to present a strategy for children's rights and including an action plan for the next five years.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour because, despite the most controversial points, we can join the chorus of celebrations for the 25th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this Resolution in considering that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCITRAL) and its optional protocols constitute a fundamental rule on the promotion and protection of the rights of the child, and that it contains a broad set of international legal standards for the protection and well-being of children and establishes clear legal obligations for all EU Member States with regard to the promotion of , the protection and enforcement of the rights of all children in your jurisdiction. In addition, I believe that UNCITRAL, as well as the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, respect the rights of the child to be heard and to express their opinion and to take this into account in all matters affecting them according to their age and maturity, which is fundamental in addressing the issue of child labour and its regulation; an example of this is bolivia's recently passed Code of Girl, Child and Adolescent.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, I supported the European Parliament resolution on the 25th anniversary of the adoption of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. Commemorating this anniversary is not just an empty phrase, even after a quarter of a century since the Adoption of the Convention, respect for the fundamental rights of children is not self-evident. Since the beginning of the economic crisis, the number of children living below the poverty line in the developed world has increased to 76.5 million, according to a report by the UNITED NATIONS Children's Fund. Children are also particularly affected by cuts to social security systems and cuts to social benefits. I consider these figures unacceptable, stronger protection of children's rights must be at the heart of any European policy. Children are the weakest and most vulnerable group of the population, and we must make sure that each of them has hope for a good future.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution as it is an opportunity to put the rights of girls and boys on the political agenda. Many things have changed since the un Convention was created and adopted, positively and negatively. This has been taken into account in the Resolution adopted. We must put children and young people at the heart of our policies; involve them in decision-making processes and empower them to maintain their integrity, their fundamental rights such as education, health and food. Unfortunately, no country (not even the signatories) has created the full conditions for the full implementation of the Convention. Worldwide, millions of people suffer from hunger and malnutrition; also in the peoples of southern Europe, because of debt and austerity policies. In Galiza, my country, more than 20% of children live at risk of poverty and social exclusion. These same policies prevent them from accessing basic services and being able to fully exercise their fundamental rights. Violations of children's rights are especially painful when we talk about migrant minors, especially in terms of health. The example of child soldiers is bleeding.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in support of the resolution on the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. All the EU Member States have ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and have clear legal obligations to promote, protect and fulfil the rights of every child in their jurisdictions. Children are particularly affected by poverty and by cuts in social security systems and key social benefits such as family allowances, and such cuts have increased in the EU since 2007. The post-2015 framework for global development will represent an opportunity to invest in the rights of all children, in every place in the world – regardless of the child’s gender, ethnicity, race or economic, disability or other status.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. — We are 25 years old since the adoption of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which us have begun a new era of looking at a child as a human rights holder. Under the current legislation of several European countries, conceived children have the right to inherit, be endowed and have the right to a dignified burial. Yet they are legally denied the right to be born. I believe that it is in the best interests of the child to be conceived and conceived in the marriage of one man and one woman. He has the right to be conceived and carried in his mother's womb.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. — As we celebrated the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child on 20 November, we can say that a lot has been done in 25 years when it comes to children and their fundamental rights. This is an opportunity to reflect on these 25 years and we can attest to how much the world has changed, from the fall of the Berlin Wall, whose anniversary we also marked in Brussels, and the globalisation and expansion of the European Union to today's 28 members.  While much has been done in the past 25 years in terms of children and their rights, we are still witnessing problems such as poverty and education for all and other problems that we still have to actively work on to combat. One of these problems is the new trend of cyber bullying or violence that children find on social networks and the Internet, and it can really have negative effects on children who are victims, so we need to play an active role in raising awareness in this matter.  Perceptions of gender equality and strengthening girls' rights from an early age are also developing. I welcome the work done so far when it comes to the protection of children and support the remote work and positive guidelines for the protection of children and their development that will be valid for all children of the Union, including children from Croatia.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — This motion for a resolution refers to the sexual identity of children. It refers to ethnic Roma integration and alleged discrimination against this minority and also refers to the participation of children in parliamentary actions and in the decision-making process. We consider that children do not have a sexual identity, at least not different from the one with which they were born. We believe that there is no discrimination against Roma, but discrimination of Roma against Europeans. We also believe that the effort to nationally integrate the Roma is directed against the interests of this minority and against the interests of the European peoples. We defend the right and the need of every people to protect their identity.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. - I believe that children's rights are at the heart of EU policies and that the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is an opportunity to ensure its full implementation at both the political and practical levels, and to take additional measures to ensure respect for the rights of every child, anywhere in the world , especially the most vulnerable. The European Union's commitment to the Stockholm programme to develop an integrated European strategy to effectively promote and protect children's rights within the framework of the Internal and External Policies of the European Union, as well as to support Member States' efforts in this area, should also be welcomed. calls on the Commission to present an ambitious and comprehensive strategy, as well as an action plan on children's rights for the next five years, based on, and updating, the EU Agenda on the Rights of the Child.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child was adopted in 1989 with the aim of promoting and protecting the rights of children. After twenty-five years, and while we can see progress in this area, violations of the rights of this vulnerable group continue to be committed.  Many millions of children continue to be victims of violence and poverty. It is therefore essential that the EU considers the protection of children's rights in all areas of its foreign policy a priority. In addition, infringement of these rights occurs not only outside the EU's confines, but also within its Member States. Children are particularly vulnerable to social cuts that have fostered aggressive Troika-led austerity policies. The EU and its Member States need to promote additional measures to address this situation, for example by increasing and prioritizing investments to reduce poverty and social exclusion among children and young people. That is why I voted in favour of the Resolution on the Twenty-Fifth Anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution which includes a lot of useful recommendations regarding better protection of the rights of the child, especially those on the issues of poverty and social exclusion. According to Eurostat data, in 2013 almost every fourth European lived at risk of poverty and social exclusion. In many Member States relative rates were higher among the population under the age of 18, i.e. among children. In general, 27.6% of European children lived at risk of poverty and social exclusion. In the twelve new Member States this figure was as high as 34.8%.  According to Statistics Estonia, in 2012 9.5% of Estonian children had an income lower that the absolute poverty threshold, i.e. the estimated subsistence minimum. The same year 18.1% of all Estonian children lived in relative poverty, i.e. their income was lower than 60% of the median equalised yearly disposable income of household members. These statistical data are very worrying and justify substantial cooperation of the European Commission and Member States to fight children’s poverty in the European Union, including elaboration of minimum social standards to be met by all EU countries, in close cooperation with Union institutions and other Member States.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I support this resolution and want to highlight one aspect that is particularly important in my opinion. It is very important for the European Union to start working towards improving joint cooperation in the search for missing children. Child abduction is a common and very serious crime that threatens not only children, but also leads to the suffering of both parents and entire communities.

name: Elena Valenciano Martínez-Orozco (S&D)
text: in writing. - Progress has been made in these twenty-five years, but we remain far from meeting the objectives set out in the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Old unresolved challenges add new problems that deprive millions of children of their rights. The current economic crisis has its sharpest reflection in the increase in child poverty, a phenomenon which, far from being confined to regions of the developing world, also seriously affects many European countries, and in particular Spain. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution which, while it could go further in its complaints, calls for Member States with high rates of child poverty to redoble their efforts and investments in reducing and combating the social exclusion of minors. The Socialists will continue to demand that a minimum income for income-free families with children in their care be guaranteed, co-financed between the European Social Fund and national budgets.  Specific measures are also essential to protect the rights of girls, whose worldwide violation is even more severe, victims of gender-based violence and discrimination.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution as it is an opportunity to put children's rights on the political agenda. Many things have changed since the united Nations Convention was created and adopted, for better and worse. And this has been taken into account in the Resolution that we have adopted. We must place children and young people at the heart of our policies and involve them in decision-making processes. We must empower them to maintain their integrity and fundamental rights, such as education and food. Unfortunately, no country, not even the signatories, has created the full conditions for the full implementation of the Convention. There are more than 20% of children affected by austerity, which prevents them from having access to basic services and being able to fully exercise their fundamental rights.  Violations of children's rights are especially painful when we talk about migrant minors, especially in terms of health. The example of child soldiers is bleeding. The interests of the belligerents are put before the interests of minors.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this european Parliament resolution which reaffirms its commitment to the universal defence of children's rights. Adopted on 20 November 1989 by the United Nations General Assembly, the Convention defines the principles, rights and freedoms that every child can avail himself of in each of the major areas of his or her life (health, education, citizenship, etc.). It is thus the backbone of universal protection for children. Taking stock of progress and setbacks in all the fields concerned, this resolution establishes a framework for action for the years to come. I welcome the fact that the GUE/NGL Group has succeeded in imposing a large number of amendments calling for full and real implementation of this Convention, in particular by insisting that "all policies on the rights of the child incorporate a gender equality perspective", arguing for an "urgent break" with austerity policies that call into question the progress made over the past 25 years, and recalling that the protection of children must be the foundation of our asylum system for unaccompanied minors.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We agree that the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and its optional protocols are the norm for the promotion and protection of the rights of the child, encompassing a wide range of international legal standards on the protection and well-being of children. The resolution recognises that, although progress has been made since the adoption of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child 25 years ago, these same rights continue to be infringed in many parts of the world, including in EU Member States. However, the resolution does not go to the bottom of the underlying factors that are at the root of all these violations. Nothing mentions about austerity. There is nothing to mention the decrease in social expenditure of states. It does not mention the devastating effects of economic liberalisation policies, the deregulation of industrial relations. Without this diagnosis, there can be no effective remedies.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — The motion for a resolution on the 25th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child is unacceptable, both in its procedure and in its content. It was negotiated behind closed doors and presented to Members only in plenary.  Of course, political correctness demands not to be against children's rights. However, the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child expressly recognises children (minors, under 18 years of age) as independent entities ("full-year") without parents (guardians) and natural reference frameworks (family with father and mother).  In its resolution, the EP also mentions 'family' only when welfare cuts are criticised, fathers or mothers are in prison or their migrant background gives rise to discrimination. Parents as social cases, detainees or immigrants provide the EU with the pretext of defining and perceiving the rights of all minor children until they reach the age of majority. At the same time, the EP calls for comprehensive sex education for minors. Only the demand for free and free access to contraceptives and abortion was voted out on the initiative of the ECR Group (not on the initiative of the EPP/CDU-CSU).  In 2002, the Social Democrats called for "air sovereignty over cots" – in the EU Parliament, the CDU and CSU, together with the SPD, vote in favour. This resolution provides proof. I voted against.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour of the Motion for a resolution on the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. This resolution reiterates the EU’s commitment to the protection of children and their rights as human beings. While having ratified this important convention there still remain important and ever-present issues that have a direct impact on the rights of children. One such issue is that of the children of detained or imprisoned parents. Therefore, it is vital to assess the impact of detention policies and criminal justice systems on children. It is clear, in the case of children from the EU, that their rights are directly affected when living in detention facilities with their parents. Recent estimations show 800 000 children in the EU are separated from an imprisoned parent each year, which impacts the rights of children in several ways. It is my hope that continued attention does not waver from the UN document and we can ensure that the principle of the best interests of the child is respected in all legislation, in decisions taken by government representatives at all levels and in all court decisions.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. Although the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child was adopted 25 years ago, there are still many problems relating to the protection of children, both in Europe and outside. We therefore need a strong relaunch of the European Union's commitment in this area for all children who are victims of armed conflicts, for working children or victims of sexual violence, for children forced to flee their homes, for children who are victims of natural disasters or who are growing up without their rights being respected. The European institutions, the Member States, local authorities, the social partners and civil society must join forces and work together at all levels to improve the situation of children in the EU and the rest of the world. On the occasion of the 25th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, as on any day of the year, it is important that the international community works with commitment and perseverance so that every child can enjoy their rights.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. - I am glad that the European Union is paying the greatest possible attention to the protection of human rights, but we still lack sufficient protection for the most vulnerable EU citizens, European children. I therefore consider this resolution to be very important and I believe that we will continue to work together to ensure the rights of children not only here on paper, but above all in practice. However, our society must also ensure that children's rights are not used against children themselves, as is the case when, for example, children are taken from parents and distributed to other families. I drew attention here to the case of Czech Michalak children in Norway, when, in my opinion, the validity of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child was violated.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The Convention on the Rights of the Child was adopted in November 1989 and ratified by Portugal a year later. We know that the Convention, as is the case with other human rights instruments, is not being applied in many countries of the world. In several EU countries, children's rights are being called into question by the austerity policies imposed by the European Union, which leads to the deprivation of various rights, such as the right to education, health, housing and healthy eating that is appropriate to their physical and psychological growth. Only the urgent break with these policies will prevent worsening of the living conditions of children and their rights. We welcome the adoption of our amendments advocating the extension of the public network of kindergartens, crèches and utilities that provide recreational activities for children, increased maternity and paternity rights, the guarantee of compulsory and free secondary education for all as a basic condition for the exercise of the right to equal opportunities. Members of the PSD and CDS, contradicting statements on the need to reverse the current problems of demographics in Portugal, voted against amendments aimed at supporting children and their families.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the 25th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, of which I am a co-author. Over the last 25 years, the situation of children around the world has improved and our work is not yet complete. There are still serious violations of children's rights around the world, especially in developing countries: children die from malnutrition, forcibly involve them in armed conflicts, sexually abuse them, use them for hard work. Violations of the rights of the child are unacceptable and we must do everything we can to remedy them. There is still work to do within the EU, too: under European legislation, for example, we need to better protect children from mixed laws, which are in a very difficult situation after parents divorce. We must also protect European children from poverty, physical and psychological violence. I would also like to remind you that for a normal development children need understanding, but also respect for authority, which parents often forget today. In the past, many have raised children in a very authoritarian way, which was bad, but today many parents are doing their children harm with too many permissive upbringings that do not give them appropriate direction.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, because it is high time that the Commission backs up its promises on the Digital Single Market with concrete action. Not only are we missing out on EUR 260 billion in efficiency gains for each year the digital divide is left gaping – money that could be well used to sustain our recovery from the economic crisis – but completion of the Digital Single Market would also allow us to put Europe firmly on the path of innovation, job creation, competitiveness and growth. This cannot be achieved unless the Commission takes stronger action to curb the commercial dominance of Google in European search engines. A successful Digital Single Market is based on competitive conditions that allow all consumers, internet users and online businesses to benefit, instead of one single company.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE). -
text: I voted for this resolution because the Digital Single Market is the implementation of the third and final wave of the technological revolution, namely the digital revolution. The interconnection of markets is an essential condition for the functioning of the European Union's economy, and the ability to adapt to technological developments is an inevitable measure to maintain global competitiveness. The digital economy must respond to market challenges by increasing technological capacity, with high-performance results in multiple areas and which can bring many employment opportunities to the labour market.  However, the Digital Single Market faces many challenges due to the stratification of European markets. Today, the diversity of these markets creates obstacles, both between potential users in Member States and those in third countries. There are successful initiatives, such as the European Public Procurement Portal, which has created new cross-border development opportunities for SMEs. The expansion of e-commerce activities has created new opportunities for European firms, but in some countries this process has started more difficult due to low consumer confidence. However, the creation of a single certification system for companies operating in the online environment would increase consumer confidence.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI). -
text: Mr President, I voted against this digital single market, which is presented to us as having considerable potential and which should help to stimulate growth and build confidence. After Article 3 of the 1992 Treaty on the European Union establishing the European single market and free movement, the Commission now wants to liberalise digital circulation.  It is true that new technologies are a sector in constant development and that Europe is lagging behind the United States in this area. For example, one in five citizens in rural areas does not yet have access to the internet. However, it will be necessary to monitor the development of this market which appears to be the Trojan horse of the Commission sweeping national sovereignty.  Finally, it is clear that the introduction of free service provision and the freedom for all Europeans and businesses to benefit from the digital services of their choice, wherever they come from in the EU, should be monitored in order to avoid any risk of dumping, as is already the case with video-on-demand platforms, such as Netflix.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE). -
text: I voted in favour of this proposal, I also co-signed it. I want to comment on a specific section, the last sentence of Article 10, which provoked a great media reaction and was perceived by some journalists as an attack on a particular company, google. There is no company named in the approved material, it just says that the European Parliament is calling on the Commission to consider proposals to separate search engines from other commercial services, which is one possible long-term way to achieve the above objectives.  My personal view is that there is an effort by the European Parliament to draw attention to the possible monopolies that may arise here in the combination of search services and the provision of other commercial services, and that such monopolies are always at the expense of consumer rights, harming the citizen-customer. It is therefore logical that the public power, in this case the European Commission, should address this. It is only one solution, a last resort, and I hope that this is how it will be perceived.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! I also voted in favour of this report for at least three reasons. Firstly, it has been said that we need to catch up. This is the modern infrastructure of the 21st century. We have a common internal market and, of course, we must also incorporate digital technology into this internal market. This means freedom of movement for everyone. However, this also means that monopolisation must be prevented. Secondly, it is precisely in the case of networks and mobile phones that we have found that the economy does not solve everything. It is thanks to the European Union that we have been able to jointly reduce roaming charges and other special taxes that mobile operators have come up with. This is a good signal, including for consumers. Thirdly, on my own, I am a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development and I am particularly pleased that the European Union always has a heart for rural areas. It has been said time and again that rural areas in particular need to catch up, and economic development in rural areas also needs digital networking.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! I too voted in favour of the resolution on strengthening consumer protection rights in the Digital Single Market, because I believe that we also need a level playing field in the digital world. I would like to make three brief observations. First, bottlenecks used to be bottlenecks in access to the Internet – internet service providers. This has now shifted, just as market power has shifted towards the major platform operators. That is why it is politically important to focus on the platform operators and keep an eye on what is taking place there. Secondly, we need a broad political, public debate to do this. I reject the instrument of unbundling, that is to say the separation of business areas, as also formulated in the resolution, which is a means that goes too far. But the question of how to create fair conditions here must be discussed politically intensively. Finally, it is not a question of pillorying individual corporations. However, it is fair that we, including MEPs, are looking at what is going on in the digital world.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE). -
text: A Uachtaráin, dar ndóigh aontaímid go léir go bhfuil sé an-tábhachtach an margadh aonair a thabhairt isteach go hiomlán chomh luath agus is féidir agus cabhróidh sé sin linn éalú as an gcúlú eacnamaíochta agus jabanna agus fás agus borradh a bheith againn san Aontas.  Vótáil mé leis an ngrúpa sna vótaí go léir, ach le heisceacht amháin. Sin an leasú ar an dara cuid de pharagraf 10 – an vóta trí ghlao rolla, mar labhraíonn sé faoi ‘unbundling of search engines from other commercial services’. Is dóigh liom féin go bhfuil sé beagáinín róluath a bheith ag caint ar nó ag déanamh rudaí mar sin, mar caithfimid féachaint ar cad a tharlóidh má dhéantar é. Go háirithe, ceapaimid go gcuirfeadh sé isteach go mór, b’fhéidir, ar fhiontair bheaga agus mheánmhéide inár dtír féin agus b’fhéidir i dtíortha eile. Dá bhrí sin, vótálamar i gcoinne an leasaithe sin cé gur glacadh leis le móramh mór.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. Using the numbers at their disposal, S&D and PPE tabled and voted on a resolution on the digital single market. It is a resolution which, although formally appearing to be aimed at defending consumer rights, affecting integrated operators such as Google and, by that means, promoting competition, has several obscure profiles. Firstly, it does not provide an explicit, clear and precise definition of net neutrality, thus leaving the door open to possible deviations from this principle considered by many to be indispensable and fundamental. Secondly, in contrast to the position adopted by the European Parliament in a resolution of September 2013 which stated the need for the phasing out of roaming charges by 2015, there is a major step backwards. In fact, the elimination of roaming charges has been postponed because it is not clear what reason, perhaps to meet pressure from lobbies. Other aspects (copyright, cloud computing, cybercrime and non-discrimination) also merited greater clarity.  The 5-Star Movement, in favour of digital and consumer fundamental rights, has consistently voted against this resolution, which was adopted by socialists and the people in favour of lobbies.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — What really should be ensured is net neutrality, which should be explicitly enshrined in the Regulation. In order to ensure full consumer protection, there should be a legislative package with that objective, which unfortunately does not exist, which allows secret services to spy on citizens at their own length. I find this resolution insufficiently demanding in this regard, so I abstained.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. - The creation of a digital single market is a huge opportunity for the European Union. However, in order to ensure fair competition, a level playing field is needed, which does not currently exist. These include the creation of international standards for the protection of personal data and privacy, standardised consumer protection and security rules for online purchase and trade, and the protection of intellectual property on the Internet. When using search engines, search and search results should be free of distortions in order to preserve diversity of content and access to competition. In order to avoid an abusive market position, large search engines should even be persuaded to split up their business areas. Equally important are high-performance broadband and telecommunications networks in all regions of the EU, as well as the abolition of roaming charges within the EU. The demands of this motion for a resolution are to be welcomed, as the digital market knows no borders and there is much less control at national level for establishing effective rules.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The digital Single Market considers all of the benefits but none of the costs of implementation.  I abstained on an amendment about net neutrality; whilst I support net neutrality, this should not in itself be a matter for the European Union.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this non-binding resolution, which aims to discuss plans for the completion of the Digital Single Market. In some areas of the digital single market, there are shortcomings caused by dominant operators. I support calls for the rapid implementation of internal market rules for services and for the enforcement of rules such as the Consumer Rights Directive, the Alternative Dispute Resolution and Electronic Dispute Resolution Mechanisms. It is necessary to ensure a level playing field for companies operating in the digital single market, which is essential for them to be able to compete. It is important to urgently adopt a new modernised data protection package in order to strike the right balance between a high level of protection of personal data, consumer security and the control of personal data, a stable and predictable legislative environment. The Commission and the Member States must allocate the resources needed to combat cybercrime through legislative measures and law enforcement cooperation at both national and EU level. All internet traffic should be subject to a level playing field, non-discriminatory treatment.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which calls on the Commission to consider proposals to separate search engines from other commercial services of Google. It is important to be able to ensure neutral access to online searches for all citizens. It is therefore essential for consumer protection to combat any abuse of a dominant position.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against this text because I do not agree with its overly optimistic estimates of the potential impact in terms of GDP and jobs of online commerce and network development, and I do not agree with its excessive references to the role and merits of the European institutions in the development of this sector.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. - I've abstained. I certainly support the wording on, among other things, net neutrality and the proposals for action against Google. But on the other hand, I am critical of the weak wording on data security issues. There is also nothing on occupational safety and health issues.  That's why I choose to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — According to The Community authorities' calculations, achieving a genuine digital single market would bring EUR 260 billion of additional growth throughout the legislature to the EU, resulting in a significant boost to employment; not for nothing is it estimated that the demand for workers in the ICT sector until 2020 will amount to 900,000 jobs of high qualification, quality and remuneration. The Commission has expressed its commitment to make it a reality in this parliamentary term. You have to go from words to deeds. Europe cannot afford twenty-eight fractured national markets in crucial areas such as telecommunications, data protection, copyright, cloud computing. Only 25% of European citizens have 4G coverage (in rural areas, 4%), while in the United States it has 90% of the population. Progress is needed, and quickly, to correct this situation, by investing in quality network infrastructures that enable citizens and businesses to develop in the new environment. It is urgent to end the fragmentation of twenty-eight current digital markets, ensure universal network access and make network security, network neutrality and consumer confidence the keys to MUD.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because the digital market not only brings economic benefits, but also has a particularly significant impact on the daily political, social and cultural lives of consumers and citizens in the European Union. The digital single market is one of the most innovative sectors of the economy and is therefore essential for the competitiveness of the European economy and contributes to economic growth through the development of e-commerce. However, it must be acknowledged that there are shortcomings in some areas of the digital single market. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to ensure the swift implementation of the rules on the internal market for services and the implementation and enforcement of provisions such as the Consumer Rights Directive, the Alternative Dispute Resolution and Electronic Dispute Resolution Mechanisms, while ensuring a reduction in administrative burdens. Calls also on the Commission and the Member States to further develop and implement EU and national regulatory frameworks with a view to establishing an integrated and secure market for internet and mobile payments, while ensuring the protection of consumer and consumer data.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on the motion for a resolution on strengthening consumer rights in the Digital Single Market. Indeed, while digital technology, a source of wealth and growth, is a major economic issue, the European Union's digital strategy is presented by the resolution as capable, on its own, of solving the ills that Europe suffers from. The growth prospects announced are extremely ambitious.  This market is, by its very nature, cross-border. In the absence of tax harmonisation, which is in fact the exclusive competence of the Council, one can only fear an amplification of the current excesses due to the exploitation of the flaws of this system by multinationals who repatriate their profits to privileged tax Member States.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text because I believe it is essential that we develop the virtual single market. This must be done on an equal footing for all territories as well as for the people. The security and protection of personal data must also be at the centre of any development.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. I voted against. I do not agree with some of the points in the text voted on including: 1) overly optimistic estimates of the potential impact in terms of GDP and jobs given by online commerce and network development; (2) excessive references to the role of the European institutions and to the merits of the Union's internal market, which are in fact not acceptable.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The new Commission has shown its commitment to building an efficient and competitive digital single market. To do so, we must ensure that consumers' rights are respected and that there is no situation contrary to European competition standards.  By voting in favour of a resolution on strengthening consumer rights in the digital market, the European Parliament is sending a strong signal to US giant Google. The latter should not take advantage of its dominant position in the digital market to circumvent the rules of fair competition. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is essential to remove all existing obstacles to the development of the digital single market, ensuring a level playing field for companies operating in the digital single market in order to give them the opportunity to compete. I therefore call on the Commission to apply the EU competition rules correctly in order to avoid abuse of a dominant position. We need more choice in the market for data and search engines because monopolies are bad for consumers and weaken the competition that is crucial to market growth, access and consumer choice. We also need a new data protection package to ensure a high level of protection of personal data, the security of users and control over their personal data. I therefore call on the Commission to allocate the necessary resources to combat cybercrime at Community level.  The issue of copyright must also be addressed by the Commission, which must ensure an efficient framework for the protection of intellectual property rights that is geared to the reality of the digital economy, finding the right balance between the interests of users, intellectual property issues and works on the Internet.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. After the rejection of the amendment I had proposed on copyright protection, it was impossible for me to vote on the resolution on the Digital Single Market. Although I strongly condemn the Gafa monopoly, and encourage the European Commission to do so, I cannot accept that this is at the expense of copyright. This situation of heisting of European innovation can no longer last.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The digital single market is undoubtedly the big bet in the coming years, being one of the most important sectors of the European economy in stimulating competitiveness and economic growth, including through electronic growth and the removal of administrative barriers, and is extremely important in the impact it has on consumers and citizens in general, on their daily, cultural and social lives. I support this resolution because I believe that the existing digital divide needs to be tackled by Member States and institutions through a comprehensive strategy of effective digital market implementation in order to stimulate competitiveness, competition and job creation.  Developments pose risks in the context of data protection and privacy of communications, which should not and cannot be overlooked. Respect for fundamental rights, data protection, consumer rights and human dignity must always, as in any policy, be at the heart of its structure.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — The digital single market is one of the most innovative and constantly evolving sectors, a source of economic growth through the development of e-commerce and positive change in the quality of life of citizens. We are well aware that digital technologies by their very nature know no borders, so the European Union must ensure that this market is completed as soon as possible, not only by eliminating the digital divide between the various Member States but by strengthening the regulatory framework linked to the protection of personal data, the protection of copyright and intellectual property rights. It is also essential to create healthy competitiveness between companies operating in the digital sector, avoiding discrimination, restrictions or interference of any kind. Having said that, I can only be in favour of improving this market and of investing, especially if they are aimed at opening up access to digital content to disabled people, including under international regulations, which should be adopted and implemented as soon as possible.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
