text: in writing. – The digital single market must be one that finds a proportionate balance between the benefits it provides to commercial activities as well as to consumers. No-one must be left out from enjoying the benefits of the digital era. While recognising the investment of private industry in providing such services, net neutrality is to be promoted and services must ensure consumer protection within the digital single market. Furthermore, roaming charges must be eliminated as it is unacceptable in a Union of free movement to retain extra charges for persons travelling within the EU.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The Digital Single Market is one of the evolving sectors that could offer the possibility of achieving high efficiency gains, which could contribute to Europe's recovery from the crisis. The full application of European competition rules in the digital single market will be crucial for market growth, consumer access and choice and long-term competitiveness. However, I was unable to vote in favour of this resolution because the non-acceptance of the amendments we have tabled does not in fact guarantee net neutrality and the cancellation of roaming charges.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — What really should be ensured is net neutrality, which should be explicitly enshrined in the Regulation. In order to ensure full consumer protection, there should be a legislative package with that objective, which unfortunately does not exist, which allows secret services to spy on citizens at their own length. I find this resolution insufficiently demanding in this regard, so I abstained.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have signed and backed this resolution to protect consumer rights in the digital market, to promote the further development of the European digital single market, and to encourage fair competition by having a more just and discrimination-free digital single market creating more competition-friendly conditions.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on consumer rights in the digital single market. This text has the merit of providing a clear and comprehensive roadmap for the development of a genuine digital single market within the European Union that fully involves citizens and is at the service of consumers. In order to unlock all the potential for development, economic growth and social inclusion that the digital sector offers, however, it is necessary to remove the many remaining obstacles and overcome the current fragmentation. In particular, it will be necessary to work at legislative level to combat the existing digital divide, to ensure the full inclusion of all citizens and their rights without discrimination, to increase the level of network and information security and to ensure effective competition between economic operators.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The vote on this resolution illustrates the importance of the challenges of implementing the Digital Single Market in Europe in the coming years. The European Parliament expresses its desire to put in place a comprehensive European strategy in order to develop this sector.  Attached to the respect of the competitive rules on the Digital Single Market, I voted in favour of the paragraph which calls on the European Commission to put forward proposals to separate search engines from other commercial services. The European Commission must play its rightful role in preventing excessive market concentration and abuse of dominance.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. The Digital Agenda must become a priority for the European Union, because the creation of a digital single market will be a great means for the growth of employment and business. The EU internal market has indeed been a huge engine of development over the last twenty years and, in the face of the current economic crisis, it is necessary to focus on this in order to relaunch competitiveness and the economy. I supported this resolution because I am convinced that betting on the digitalisation of the business environment and on a digital economy is the right choice to restart growth and employment in Europe.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. - The creation of a digital single market is an eminent domain for the N-VA where the EU can provide added value for increasing competitiveness and creating growth and jobs, with firm guarantees on privacy and data protection.  The resolution contains many positive elements, such as accessibility for people with disabilities, as well as ensuring online safety for children. Nevertheless, we abstained from voting in the final vote because of the indirect reference to the Google case, and in particular the unbundling of search engines from other commercial services. Parliament should not prejudge the Commission's investigation into whether or not Google abused its dominant position. It is not for Parliament to judge on specific antitrust cases; this is the commission's exclusive competence.  The N-VA supports search neutrality and the open and neutral nature of the Internet. Among other things, we aim to ban operators from deliberately blocking or slowing down certain traffic and for opportunities for operators to offer new services with guaranteed quality (specialised services), provided that the regular best-effort Internet remains of adequate quality.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — The draft resolution before Parliament promotes the emergence of a political form of economic activity that is therefore utopian and not economic reality.  Worse still, the extension of massive data from the internet is at the heart of this project of a digital internal market, an area without limits, no borders, and intrusive, therefore, without security or individual freedom. I voted against this text which offers no guarantees to citizens in terms of privacy and which introduces free-trade ideology into this market.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted against this Resolution on the Digital Single Market because, despite the immense economic, political and social potentials that digital space opens up to European societies, the logic of the Community legislature has an impact time and time again on the principles of liberalisation, deregulation, privatisation and the principle of free competition as the sole criterion of regulation. We have supported those amendments which seek to democratise and facilitate access to the digital space of citizens, and which seek to dismantle monopoly positions within the single market. But we believe that the regulation of digital space should meet democratic and social utility criteria rather than the logic of private benefit. The digital space must be open to citizenship, not just consumers.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — We are voting against, as we do with any text that limits the possibilities for Member States to define their markets. We are also voting against, because governments, under the cloak of the protection of minors, are given the opportunity to attack their political opponents by characterising their websites as dangerous, as we have seen first-hand in Greece.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The digital single market is one of the evolving areas that, while with challenges, offer possibilities for significant efficiency gains, which can amount to EUR 260 billion per year, and can therefore help Europe out of the crisis. This is one of the most innovative sectors of the economy and therefore plays an important role in the competitiveness of the European economy but not only offers economic benefits, but also has a profound impact on the cultural, social and political life of EU consumers and citizens. However, this market cannot be competitive without fast, high-speed broadband and telecommunications networks in all REGIONS of the EU, including peripheral regions, and it is essential that Member States make sustained efforts to implement and implement existing regulations as part of a comprehensive strategy. It is resemable that e-commerce alone could save consumers more than €11.7 billion a year if they could choose from the full range of EU goods and services when shopping online.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The aim of this resolution is to put an end to all the obstacles hindering the development of the digital single market, i.e. the liberalisation of the digital market, based on a global strategy, which the EU believes is the panacea for the evils of the capitalism crisis and thus create economic growth, employment, strengthening competitiveness and its resilience in the world economy. More than theoretical considerations about the harmful effects of market liberalisation, reality shows that such liberalisation strategies lead to the closure of businesses, concentration of wealth in countries and monopolies in the liberalised sectors, weakening of national production in Member States of weaker economies, and therefore increased redundancies, increased exploitation of workers, who in the face of such levels of unemployment are forced to work for less pay and in worse working conditions. This is the result of the deepening of capitalist integration, in its various aspects. We voted against the principle advocated in this resolution, as well as against the ambition to liberalise the service market, the current deregulation on the protection of personal data and individual freedoms. Although the EU's concerns include issues such as net neutrality and improving consumer protection, nothing is actually guaranteed in this respect.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. — It is very important that the Member States and the European Commission actively work to remove all existing barriers and constraints that hinder the development of the Digital Single Market, which is necessary to achieve economic and employment objectives and, last but not least, to strengthen the European Union's competitiveness and position in the global economy. The development of a single European digital market also needs the accelerated adoption of a new package for the protection of personal data and the need to increase investment in the fight against cybercrime through legislative measures.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) The imco committee's texts are usually in favour of this. This time, however, the report cannot be supported because it contains overly optimistic estimates of the potential for impact in terms of GDP and jobs given by online commerce and network development and excessive references to the role of the European institutions and the merits of the Union's internal market.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR)
text: in writing. – Unlocking the benefits of the digital world is key to delivering competitiveness, jobs and growth. The EU needs to work with partners across the world and avoid a fortress Europe approach. It is extremely important that we have an open, accessible and safe internet. Against this backdrop, anti-competitive behaviour is not acceptable and as in all sectors, dominant players should not abuse their market position to the detriment of others. However, the ECR group position is that anti-trust investigations must remain independent, and it is not for the European Parliament to interfere or prejudge the legal process of any investigation. This is a competition law issue and the EU commissioner for Competition must be allowed to follow the correct legal processes. This resolution should not be read as an instruction to the competition Commissioner on what action to take on her current investigation.  The ECR amendments focus on the benefits of e-commerce for growth and competitiveness and on the real actions we can take to tear down the barriers our digital entrepreneurs face, so that the single market is fit for the digital age.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting against the reports on the Digital Single Market, as I do with any text that limits The Member States' ability to define their markets. I also vote against them because they enable governments, under the cloak of the protection of minors, to attack their political opponents by characterising their websites as dangerous, as we have seen first-hand in Greece.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — Completing the digital single market is something which will be of immeasurable benefit to consumers right across Europe. I want to see a more equal and discrimination-free digital single market. Users should be able to choose between competitors and a more level playing field will result in more options and choices and even better services in the future. By unbundling search engines from other commercial services we are trying to increase competition in the digital single market and create a level playing field. This will also help to support European innovation, particularly for new start-ups, to foster their potential. I want to see fairer and more transparent competition on the EU market. We cannot allow the monopolisation of the EU search engine market. If a situation arises where one company dominates the market then it is only right that we should support the concept of unbundling search engines from other commercial services in order to create this level playing field. It should not matter if the market is offline or online; companies must fairly compete with one another in order to deliver optimal and neutral results for EU citizens.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution because it defends the idea of a fairer and more indiscriminate digital single market, as well as the establishment of more favourable conditions for competition. In the current context, we must directly support European innovation, especially start-ups, in order to strengthen their potential.  That is why I voted for the amendment calling for a unbundling between Google's research activities and other commercial services; Internet users should have a choice between several competitors, whose services could be even better in the future. Opening up competition to more players will also help to increase transparency for net users, and that is where we need to move in the right direction.

name: Gyürk András (PPE)
text: Writing. — Creating an EU single digital market is of paramount importance for citizens and companies, as this will create millions of new jobs and enable Europe's GDP to grow by 4% by 2020. Strengthening consumers' rights strengthens the climate of trust and, ultimately, the economy, so I voted in favour of the Commission doing everything possible to ensure a level playing field for companies providing this type of service in the online search market. The legislative framework for data protection and the proper protection of intellectual property rights has not yet been finalised and should therefore be highlighted in this resolution.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. - Secondary copyright legislation for consumers in the different Member States has led to a distinction in access to content. This type of legislation is abused by digital service providers to be double-paid for their services. I don't think that's right. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution on the digital single market.

name: Eduard-Raul Hellvig (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution, as the Digital Single Market is one of the most innovative sectors of the economy, with a major role to play in relaunching the EU's competitiveness, from e-commerce to telecommunications. I believe that greater support is needed for European initiatives in the new technologies, given their potential in the EU's recovery after the crisis. We are currently facing some major problems, which the EU must respond to with a coordinated strategy for the development of a digital single market. I mention, in particular, the problem of market fragmentation, the lack of interoperability in the European Union and the protection of personal data and privacy. Last but not least, it affects our differences in European citizens' access to the internet, especially in some rural regions.  The excessive concentration of the market and the abuse of a dominant position by some operators are also worrying. Concrete action is required in this respect to ensure a level playing field, and I am referring, in particular, to the separation of search engines from other commercial services, as there is a risk that search engines will market secondary services on the basis of the information they obtain.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. — The vote on this resolution reframes the debate on the digital market around consumer rights, and I welcome that. This market, largely dominated by Americans and Asians, must be designed in a way that frees up the creativity of European companies and allows them to develop rather than curbing talent and stifling them with competition at all costs. That is why the EPP group to which I belong defends copyrights, which I believe are the best way to protect the creativity and innovation of authors and cultural and creative industries.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted against this Resolution on the Digital Single Market because, despite the immense economic, political and social potentials that digital space opens up to European societies, the logic of the Community legislature has an impact time and time again on the principles of liberalisation, deregulation, privatisation and the principle of free competition as the sole criterion of regulation. We have supported those amendments which seek to democratise and facilitate access to the digital space of citizens, and which seek to dismantle monopoly positions within the single market. But we believe that the regulation of digital space should meet democratic and social utility criteria rather than the logic of private benefit. The digital space must be open to citizenship, not just consumers.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted for the proposal for a resolution on the Digital Single Market, as today's community is fully oriented towards the digital age and the European Union lags behind in certain segments.  The digital age is becoming a kind of fifth European freedom, as it represents not only data and consumer protection, but an essential issue and way of life. Therefore, it is essential that the European Union becomes more competitive globally in order to ensure a sustainable digital single market, and further encourage the development of research and innovation.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I supported the ALDE resolution on the Digital Single Market. I don’t believe it is the European Parliament’s role to interfere in ongoing cases relating to Competition. The ALDE resolution is more balanced, in this respect, than the EPP and S&D resolution as we do not specifically call for the unbundling of search engines at this moment. It is important, in my view, that search engines are fair and balanced and we as parliamentarians should ensure that the necessary legislative framework is in place for this. We want a dynamic and adaptable Digital Single Market, and we must continue to press in order for this to be achieved.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the Digital Single Market. In particular, this text recalls Parliament's support for net neutrality and the reduction of the digital divide, and calls on the European Commission to take all measures to enforce competition rules, including through the separation of search engine activities from other commercial services. In the context of the European investigation into Google that has been going on since 2010, it was important to remind the Commission that it had to be firm with regard to companies whose practices threaten European digital companies.  I regret, however, that the call for a balanced reform of copyright, taking into account the need for fair remuneration for creators as well as the new habits of consumers, has been abolished under the impetus of the Socialists, who have preferred to put European cultural diversity on the back burner. Nevertheless, I welcome the adoption of this resolution by 384 votes in person, 174 against and 56 abstentions.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The completion of the Digital Single Market is a key issue for European businesses and consumers, but also for the EU's technological independence and strategic autonomy from its US and Asian competitors.  The development of the digital economy in Europe must not be achieved at the expense of creators and European cultural diversity. That is why I have defended copyright protection by obtaining the removal of parts of the text that only mention the interests of consumers and internet users.  Copyright is too often seen as a barrier to innovation and free access to cultural content, while the existence and future of cultural and creative industries in Europe are based mainly on fair remuneration for creators and respect for rights holders. I also welcome Parliament's message about the abuse of Google's dominant position, which allows political pressure to be maintained on the Commission so that a level playing field is guaranteed in the European digital market.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. — I supported the motion for a resolution at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg on safeguarding consumer rights in the Digital Single Market, as this proposal will enable consumers to take advantage of the benefits that the Digital Single Market could bring. The completion of the Digital Single Market requires a clear know that consumers, for example when making online purchases, will be protected from various cybercrime, privacy or other breaches. This proposal also highlights the importance and benefits of the creation of the Digital Single Market, which can reach up to EUR 260 billion per year. This would be of great benefit to Latvian entrepreneurs and citizens in general. However, I voted against paragraph 10 of this resolution, which calls on the Commission to consider proposals aimed at dividing large Internet technology companies, such as Google, into separating search engines from other commercial services, as such a proposal threatens the functioning of the free market. It is important to remember the laissez faire slogan, which means that governments do not have to be involved in economic processes in order to maintain the balance of the market mechanism.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution. An estimated EUR 260 billion in gains could come out of a fully integrated and completed digital single market. This money could be re-invested amongst others into the very ambitious plan President Juncker has just presented for the future of Europe, for growth, competitiveness and innovation.  Investments and good partnerships are needed between the public and private sectors to set up highest-capacity broadband and telecommunications and to ensure adequate flows into innovation and research. The EU also needs to invest in enabling unhindered access for its citizens to these networks, and considerably boost efforts to overcome the digital divide. To turn Europe into e-Europe, the citizens also have to turn into e-citizens.  E-government, e-services, e-commerce would simplify life and reduce administrative burdens for all levels, from individual to European. For that a comprehensive European e-certification, e-identification, digital signature system is needed.  Lastly, the EU has to find a solution to geo-cashing and ensuring the EU as a whole is targeted as one digital single market without any prejudice towards country of origin. This is not only a question of free market and competition, but also of treating all Member States and their citizens on the same merits.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution as the text contains strong and important points that would protect consumers and encourage further integration of the Digital Single Market.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of this resolution because I believe that the digital single market must be properly regulated in the light of the economic, social and cultural benefits it could generate for all EU citizens. The proposal, in fact, provides for the adoption of a package aimed at ensuring proper protection of users and a stable regulatory environment in which companies operating in the sector can grow.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Digital Single Market creates millions of jobs and can create the conditions for create an additional 4% of GDP in Europe. A competitive digital single market cannot exist without high-speed and high-capacity broadband and telecommunications networks in all regions of the EU. It is encouraging that Lithuania continues to maintain its leadership position in Europe in terms of penetration of broadband internet on fibre lines (33.9%). According to this indicator, Lithuania ranked 7th in the world. In 2013, statistics show that 69% of the population used the Internet in Lithuania, 28.5% of fixed broadband penetration and 67% of households had broadband Internet access. So we have great opportunities to further develop this area, which brings a lot of added economic value.  At the same time, we would like to point out that cyber and electronic communications and network security are priority issues in the Digital Single Market that need to be addressed urgently and collectively.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. — We have adopted a resolution on the future of the digital market in Europe which has, in a way, 'made headlines'. We have dared a number of requests, made some demands and advocated guidance to the European Commission for which strengthening the European digital market is a priority. The European Commission must therefore continue to consider proposals to free up and secure online services, communication services and e-commerce, all in the interests of European businesses and consumers.  But it was important to remember that the development of the digital economy in Europe must not be achieved at the expense of creators and European cultural diversity. That is why the French delegation of the EPP Group defended copyright protection by obtaining the removal of parts of the text that only mention the interests of consumers and internet users. Finally, we have sent a message to the European Commission to offer some ideas on the abuse of the dominant position of certain search engines, which we believe should be separated from other commercial services.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - The joint resolution on the Digital Single Market has a resolutely "all-competition" approach.  However, in this case, this approach allows us to denounce the de facto monopolies of internet giants such as Google and even to call for a separation of business activities between search engine and the provision of commercial services. I support this approach to break Google's monopoly and its non-compliance with the right to intellectual property, as well as its repeated violations of the right to be forgotten despite the injunctions of national privacy authorities. However, many questions were put aside in the drafting of this text and in its vote: universal access to internet services is being put back into the competition, the issue of net neutrality avoided, and the reference to better protection of intellectual property rights being erased. As these important points do not appear or more in the text presented, I have chosen to abstain so as not to go against a resolution which pushes the Commission to be more severe towards the internet giants who believe that they are allowed everything.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted for the protection of 'net neutrality', which Parliament has unfortunately rejected. I wanted to allow all Internet users to access the internet on an equal footing. Clearly worked by powerful lobbies, the majority of MPs preferred to pave the way for two-speed access: those who can pay will take priority over others.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - Achieve a true digital single market (MUD) in a real priority. An estimated 900,000 ICT-qualified people will be sued in Europe in the coming years. For this reason, training has to be a priority for Europe, considering the opportunity it entails for the creation of young and skilled employment.  The digital single market therefore opens up new opportunities to boost the economy. There is a clear correlation between high levels of online sales and gdp per capita increase. That is why progress is needed to achieve true cross-border e-commerce and advance cloud computing. One of the main objectives is to end the fragmentation of today's 28 digital markets, as well as to ensure universal network access and to make network security, net neutrality and consumer confidence mud cornerstones. E-administration would also save EUR 100 billion per year in the EU and the use of electronic invoices would save 40 billion.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — What really should be ensured is net neutrality, which should be explicitly enshrined in the Regulation. In order to ensure full consumer protection, there should be a legislative package with that objective, which unfortunately does not exist, which allows secret services to spy on citizens at their own length. I find this resolution insufficiently demanding in this regard, so I abstained.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. — The fragmentation of the digital market in the European Union has been a significant barrier to the expansion of the ITC private sector. The need to be compliant with the legislations of multiple Member States is an expensive bureaucratic burden for established enterprises, while for many SMEs and entrepreneurs it is simply unfeasible. This severely hampers not only the growth of the digital sector in the EU, but also of adjacent service sectors. According to the estimates, the implementation of a European digital single market would create millions of jobs and contribute to a 4% increase of the GDP of the EU by 2020. This would be a welcome boost in a period of high unemployment and stagnant economy throughout the EU. I support this initiative as I believe it benefits both sides of the argument. As stated in this resolution, on one hand, businesses will have easier access to a wider market, implicitly leading to job creation and economic growth, while on the other, consumers will benefit from cheaper, better and more varied digital services.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. - I support this resolution aimed at accelerating the establishment of the Digital Single Market. The Digital Single Market can contribute at least 4% to Union GDP growth by 2020. It offers possible solutions to key European challenges: economic recovery, better labour markets, more efficient operation of public services and a smarter, i.e. "greener" Union economy.  Then, it can be a key driver of productivity and competitiveness, while stimulating growth and innovation, while also offering great benefits to consumers through low prices, better quality and more choices Action is necessary for a better online business environment, strengthening consumer confidence, infrastructure foundations and a legal framework for protecting intellectual property online. The introduction of the Digital Single Market can deliver the necessary and desired economic growth.  We can conclude that the lack of a Digital Single Market has unfortunately partially impeded the growth of entrepreneurship in the Member States, and this has been particularly reflected in the field of ICT. I believe that in the future this situation will change as soon as possible thanks to the strengthening of the single market in the area of labour digitisation.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - Overall, I voted in favour of the resolution, but I could not support some amendments. The digital market is the future of the European economy, but the interests of large countries and corporations have also been felt in this document as well as in the debate. But in general, Latvia will only win in the future by developing a digital orientation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution because the resolution paves the way for the EU to rely on the knowledge economy, investment in education, new technologies and innovation, in order to strengthen the competitiveness of the European economy.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted for the digital single market resolution because the implementation and completion of a digital single market would offer great economic benefits and would have a positive impact on the daily life of EU consumers and citizens. The digital single market will also create new jobs especially for highly skilled workers and will make an important contribution to the creation of quality and sustainable employment. I voted for the enforcement of EU competition rules in the digital single market, which will boost competitiveness and the growth of the market. This resolution is a step further for development of e-commerce, consumer access and choice of goods and services in the long term. And last but not least, the digital single market is one of the areas of progress which would help the EU to recover from the economic crisis because through the digital market the possible economic gain is up to EUR 260 billion per year.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — The digital single market is one of the most innovative economic sectors which plays a key role in the competitiveness of the European economy. In addition to contributing to economic growth through the development of e-commerce, it ensures a level playing field for companies operating in the digital single market, giving them the opportunity to be more competitive.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - The digital single market not only offers economic benefits, but also has a profound impact on the political, social and cultural life of EU citizens. I therefore believe that it needs to be properly regulated.  That is why I supported this motion for a resolution, which calls for the adoption of an updated data protection package, which guarantees, on the one hand, proper protection of users, and, on the other, a stable regulatory environment in which companies operating in the sector can grow.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — In view of the fact that the Digital Single Market is a source of high-quality and sustainable employment and that the volume of trade in the Digital Single Market can make a significant contribution to overcoming the economic crisis, I voted in favour of this request. However, this is conditional on the protection of the final consumer. In order not to distort the image of the market, the Commission is required to strictly prevent the commercial re-use of personal data. We hope that the data protection directives will be enforced as consistently as they are formulated in the motion, because only in this way can a profitable digital internal market be created and become a pillar of the European economy.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - This resolution concerns the establishment of the Digital Single Market. Certainly, the digital market is in full development. It could bring growth and prosperity. But the resolution proposed to us remains focused on the logics of competition and the market. It thus states that "strict enforcement of EU competition rules within the Digital Single Market will play a key role in market growth, access and consumer choice, as well as long-term competitiveness." It also calls on the Commission to speed up the application of the so-called 'services' directive, which threatens public services, particularly local ones. Liberalisation will not solve any of the problems related to digital: equal access, net neutrality... I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — The obstacles hindering the development of the digital single market need to be put to an end.  Only a developed digital single market, and in which everyone complies with the rules, will allow the protection of all consumers. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because of the need for the Council to open negotiations with the Parliament on the proposal for a regulation concerning the European single market for electronic communications and to achieve a Connected Continent. Ever since I was elected in 2013, I have consistently called for mobile phone roaming charges in Europe to end. There is absolutely no justification for consumers to face huge bills just because they used their phone while traveling in the EU. The end of roaming must become one of the cornerstones of a true European Digital Single Market. The resolution also highlights the importance of all legislation regarding the digital single market complying with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I think it is important to let the Commission continue its work in this area. This resolution implicitly targets Google's activities by emphasizing the need to split search engine activities and other commercial services. The Commission has been working on this for some time. It does not seem to me to be relevant for Parliament to interfere at this stage in the regulation of the internal market and respect for competition.  It would be more relevant to focus on the paths that will accelerate the integration and unification of the European digital market. Indeed, the lack of Europe in this area currently costs at least 260 billion euros per year. We need to develop a coherent and cross-disciplinary strategy to maximis develop the digital economy, a source of growth. I the european Commission thereby expects the European Commission to propose an ambitious legislative package that finally meets the expectations of European citizens.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – I backed the Parliament resolution on the Digital Single Market, which aims at protecting consumer rights in the digital market. In particular, it seeks to encourage fair competition in this market and as a socialist and democrat I agree with the S&D calling for a more just and discrimination-free digital single market and the creation of more competition-friendly conditions. All internet users should have the option of choosing between competitors whose services could potentially be even better in the future.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. — Whether economic or social, the cost of not accelerating the completion of our digital single market is simply too high. However, one must proceed in a fashion that strikes the perfect balance between consumer protection and enhancing the competitiveness of our sluggish continental economy. In this context, I voted in favour of a resolution that emphasises the urgency of doing away with barriers that prevent reaping the benefits of a truly Connected Europe: legal uncertainties and an uneven playing field for businesses, slow internet access, restricted internet traffic or roaming charges. It is a sensible initiative that flags our deficiencies and points Digital Europe in the right direction.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution concerns the Digital Single Market, which is presented as having "considerable potential" and which should "stimulate growth and strengthen confidence". After Article 3 of the 1992 TUE establishing the European single market and free movement, the Commission continues its mad race towards liberalisation in all areas. It now intends to liberalize digital traffic. While it is true that new technologies are a sector in continuous development and that Europe is lagging behind the United States (e.g. in the EU, 1 in 5 citizens in rural areas does not always have access to the internet), it is nevertheless true that we must remain attentive to the development of this market.  This means ensuring that the Commission does not override the sovereignty of the nations (28 national telecommunications regulators have thus been abolished as "brakes", and have simply been replaced by a single European regulator.  Finally, it will be necessary to ensure the implementation of the free provision of services, the only guarantee for all Europeans and businesses to retain the freedom of choice of digital services. I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because Europe must be a major player in digital technology at the global level. Achieving this goal can only be achieved within the framework of European regulation. I have dissociated myself from my political group in order to protect copyright.  It is important that creators can make a living from their work through fair remuneration. I also supported paragraph 10 to separate search engine activities from other activities. It is obvious that the ultra-dominance of an actor can be detrimental to the creation and development of new businesses. I am extremely committed to freedom of enterprise and success, but when they are carried out in accordance with the rules of the market and our laws.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — We are convinced that the digital single market is one of the most innovative and leading economic sectors capable of playing a fundamental role in the competitiveness and growth of the European economy. It is therefore very desirable, through constant efforts to implement the regulations in force and to ensure compliance with them within the framework of a global strategy, to remove all existing obstacles to the development of a digital single market in the European Union. In this regard, we call on the Council to make rapid progress and to overcome the impasse that has arisen during the negotiations with Parliament on the proposal for a regulation laying down measures concerning the Single European Electronic Communications Market, as this would effectively put an end to roaming charges within the EU, provide greater legal certainty with regard to net neutrality and improve consumer protection in the digital single market.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted for this text, which reminds us of the importance of consumer rights in the field of e-commerce. The protection of their data must be guaranteed as well as access to purchase on the internet. A stable and balanced legal framework will be a factor in business development.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — The Digital Single Market now employs thousands of people across Europe and the volume of trade in the Digital Single Market has the capacity to make a significant contribution to overcoming the economic crisis. However, it is always important to define data protection standards and to monitor their compliance. In order not to distort the image of the market, the Commission is required to strictly prevent the commercial re-use of personal data. I hope that the data protection directives will be enforced as consistently as they are formulated in the motion. Only in this way can a profitable digital internal market be created and become a pillar of the European economy. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - I supported the European Parliament resolution on supporting consumer rights in the digital single market. The Digital Single Market is one of the most innovative sectors of the economy, so it plays an important role in increasing competitiveness and job creation. Member States must continue to make and make efforts to remove barriers and create a single market where everyone has a level playing field in order to make the most of the opportunities available to this market.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party voted against the joint resolution of the People's Party and Social Democrats on the 'Single Digital Market' because it treats the new technology sector as a golden field of profitability for monopolies and because it promotes its further surrender to business groups. The disorienting debate on so-called 'resolution-blow' to specific monopolistic groups, as well as the overall content of the resolution, reflects the fierce struggle between monopoly giants and parts of the capital active in the digital technology sector and competing for dominance in the sector and maximising their profits. These developments initiated by the EU, urban governments and the parties of capital and the Euro-one way are to the detriment of workers, because they are the ones who will continue, either to pay for access to digital technologies, or to remain completely cut off from them, or to be ballast of the use of these technologies for surveillance and file by state, employer and other mechanisms. Only when they become popular property will new technologies and the achievements of science and technology be able to unleash all their productive potential, which monopolies are currently committing and braking. Only when the people have come to power will new technologies be able to contribute to meeting modern popular needs.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution by which the European Parliament calls on the EU Member States and the European Commission to remove obstacles to the development of the digital single market. Parliamentarians have also stressed the need to prevent dominant companies from over-concentration in the market and abuse of a dominant position, including by ing search engines from packages with other commercial services, if necessary. The digital single market could generate up to €260 billion a year, helping to recover Europe from the crisis and to the competitiveness of the European economy, the text says. At the same time, it also recalls the need to address important challenges such as market fragmentation, lack of interoperability and the growing digital divide between generations and regions.

name: Morten Helveg Petersen (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted against the resolution on the Digital Single Market. I did so because the resolution called on the Commission to fragment companies that have both internet search engines and other activity. The implicating is that companies like Google should be divided into two independent companies.  I think that is an undue interference by politicians in how companies should be run. On the other hand, the Commission, and margrethe vestager in particular, as Commissioner for Competition, must ensure that no one exploits a dominant position, even on the Internet.  I am very sceptical when it comes to politicians who want to predict or decide how private companies should be run. Business models vary from one company to another - especially on the Internet - and it is incredibly important that politicians interfere as little as possible in the running of private companies.  Politicians need to solve the problems that people experience every day. So until the Commission has examined whether there is really a problem with Google's way of doing business, Parliament should not overreact. It's about people - and it's about solving the problems that people have and experience.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I think it is important to emphasise the meaning of the Digital Single Market, which will create a harmonised and integrated European market for barrier-free digital and online technologies. Creating a single market will strengthen investment in new technologies and create a market with a strengthened cross-border online trade.  The single market has great potential to help grow European industry by creating infrastructure for companies of the future and increasing investment in start-ups. Even at a high unemployment rate, the internet offers a possible 5 jobs for every 2 lost. I would focus on the economic impact of the Digital Single Market, which would increase the use of ICT and online services in the private and public sectors, resulting in the growth of innovation and productivity of EU companies in all sectors.  In line with the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee's report on the new digital market, I would highlight the possibility of an annual increase in G.D.P. relative to the current estimate of €656 billion per year. Through constant changes in all walks of life and the unstoppable development of new technologies, everyone needs digital skills to participate in today's fully digitized world. I therefore believe that creating a Digital Single Market would have a major impact on the EU's social and economic development.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — As you can see, the digital single market is one of the most innovative and evolving sectors we have and it plays a leading role in European competitiveness and influences the political, social and everyday life of EU citizens. That is why I am in favour, as the report says, of policies that give greater support to the rights of consumers, which are end-users. In addition, all companies operating in the digital single market must be guaranteed a level playing field by establishing clear rules to prevent, as is still the case, companies in a dominant position. Finally, I hope that what the resolution calls for will be respected, and that the updated data protection package will be adopted shortly, in order to ensure consumer confidence with a stable regulatory framework.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. — A common Digital Single Market gives all Member States the chance for the EU to weigh its weight in order to guarantee citizens the protection of their privacy. Data protection, privacy and consumer protection can be effectively defended by the size of the internal market. The EU is called upon to protect children in particular from the depths of the Internet. In addition, the Digital Single Market, which I advocate, promotes innovation, economic growth and, ultimately, job creation throughout Europe.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — There is an urgent need for the European Union to adopt a digital industry that is at the height of its market power. I therefore vote in favour of a resolution promoting consumer rights within the single market and, by the same token, the autonomy of the European Union in this area.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — The creation of a European digital single market offers the possibility of making significant gains in economic efficiency, which could amount to EUR 260 billion per year, assuming as a powerful growth engine for the European economy that could allow for a 4% increase in European GDP by 2020 and the creation of 3 million quality and sustainable jobs between 2013 and 2018. In addition, the development of cloud computing, in the context of reducing the digital divide and connectivity of the continent, should be accompanied by the defence of digital entrepreneurship, copyright and intellectual property, as well as the protection of consumer rights (the protection of personal data, the protection of children, access to information and the right to privacy).  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for the completion of the European digital single market and the removal of obstacles preventing it from being fully implemented (such as the restriction of service providers for certain countries or territories, refusal to sell, automatic rerouting and unjustified diversification of sales conditions), as well as the protection of consumer interests.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. " I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on strengthening consumer rights in the digital single market because this text, even if it is not perfect, echoes many of my concerns. In particular, we welcome the growth of e-commerce, call for creating a legislative environment that encourages creativity and innovation, while worrying about closing the digital divide, or removing existing barriers that continue to hinder the full deployment of the Digital Single Market. Second, we are clearly addressing the need to ensure a level playing field in the online research and advertising sectors. In this regard, the Commission must act firmly in its investigations into potential abuses of dominance. On the other hand, we need to focus on improving the situation in the long term, and there are several options. Decoupling activities as search engines for other commercial services may be one of the avenues to explore. In any case, it is time to take firm options. The improvement in the situation will benefit consumers, internet users, potentially aggrieved online businesses, and growth.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — According to eu authorities' calculations, achieving a genuine digital single market would bring EUR 260 billion of additional growth to the EU throughout the legislature, which would translate into a major boost to employment; not for nothing is it estimated that the demand for workers in the ICT sector until 2020 will amount to 900,000 jobs of high qualification, quality and remuneration. The Commission has expressed its commitment to make it a reality in this parliamentary term. You have to go from words to deeds. Europe cannot afford twenty-eight fractured national markets in crucial areas such as telecommunications, data protection, copyright, cloud computing. Only 25% of European citizens have 4G coverage (in rural areas, 4%), while in the United States it has 90% of the population. Progress is needed, and quickly, to correct this situation, by investing in quality network infrastructures that enable citizens and businesses to develop in the new environment. It is urgent to end the fragmentation of twenty-eight current digital markets, ensure universal network access and make network security, network neutrality and consumer confidence the keys to MUD. That is why I supported this resolution with my vote.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I supported this motion adopted by the European Parliament on the Digital Single Market which calls on the European Commission to consider unbundling between Google's research activities and other commercial services... Google, which now captures 90% of the online search market and is currently under investigation by the Commission's competition services to determine whether it is abusing its dominant position. Google must comply with European rules and Internet users should be able to choose between several competitors. That is my view.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. — Search engines should not use their dominant position to promote their interests in other markets. That is why I supported today a european Parliament resolution to protect consumer rights in the digital market. This resolution aims in particular to encourage fair competition in this market. It calls on the European Commission to "consider submitting proposals to separate search engines from other commercial services". This resolution is a strong sign that things must change. The interests of consumers must take precedence. By allowing for greater transparency, consumers could benefit from better services, and a greater diversity of players could intervene in the market under undistorted competitive conditions.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Digital Single Market (MSD) is an important bet for Europe to grow more rapidly in economic terms and its completion would, according to some projections, allow Europe's GDP to grow by potentially 4% by 2020. It is projected that the computer application smarket alone will triple revenues between 2013 and 2018, with the creation of 3 million jobs in this period, in addition to allowing the inclusion of all citizens in the society of the digital age, regardless of their income, social condition and geographical location. However, as the European Parliament rightly points out in this resolution, it is absolutely necessary to take account of the protection of consumer rights on that market. Thus, the protection of personal data and privacy, cybersecurity, the security of electronic communications and networks must be a reality in the MUD.  It is expected, as this report states, that any legislative proposal on the Mud will take into account the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, so that the rights enshrined therein are fully protected in the digital field. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — In order to unlock untapped potential, create many jobs and boost European competitiveness, the European Union must remove barriers to the growth of the digital market.  I supported this resolution because the Digital Single Market could generate EUR 260 billion a year, a considerable sum at a time when Europe is in crisis.  However, the development of the digital economy must not be at the expense of authors, consumer rights and cultural diversity. As such, the French EPP delegation strongly defended the protection of copyright and intellectual property rights.  It was also important to insist that search engines, such as Google, be separated from other commercial services in order to ensure competitive conditions within the digital single market.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against it for the following two reasons: overly optimistic estimates of the potential impact in terms of GDP and jobs given by online commerce and network development, and excessive references to the role of the European institutions and the merits of the Union's internal market.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted against this Resolution on the Digital Single Market because, despite the immense economic, political and social potentials that digital space opens up to European societies, the logic of the Community legislature has an impact time and time again on the principles of liberalisation, deregulation, privatisation and the principle of free competition as the sole criterion of regulation. We have supported those amendments which seek to democratise and facilitate access to the digital space of citizens, and which seek to dismantle monopoly positions within the single market. But we believe that the regulation of digital space should meet democratic and social utility criteria rather than the logic of private benefit. The digital space must be open to citizenship, not just consumers.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. - I supported the resolution on promoting consumer rights in the Digital Single Market, because setting up a consumer-friendly digital internal market is undoubtedly one of the main tasks of the new Commission, and this resolution is parliament's first contribution to the debate on how to achieve this objective. The Digital Single Market must be based on non-discriminatory access and create the conditions for fair competition. I consider it equally important to set a high level of consumer protection in the digital environment. I therefore welcome the call on the Commission to oversee the implementation and enforcement of existing rules, such as the Consumer Rights Directive, Alternative Dispute Resolution and Online Dispute Resolution. The resolution also focuses on internet search engines. Internet searches are already an integral part of the daily lives of European citizens. I therefore welcome the fact that the resolution opens up a debate on how the rules on the market will be set.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — What really should be ensured is net neutrality, which should be explicitly enshrined in the Regulation. In order to ensure full consumer protection, there should be a legislative package with that objective, which unfortunately does not exist, which allows secret services to spy on citizens at their own length. I find this resolution insufficiently demanding in this regard, so I abstained.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on supporting consumer rights in the digital single market.  The digital single market is one of the most innovative sectors of the economy and is therefore playing a major role in the competitiveness of the European economy and contributing to economic growth through the development of e-commerce, while also facilitating the administrative and financial compliance of businesses and presenting consumers with a wider choice of goods and services. In addition, I welcome the announcement of further investigations by the Commission into search engine practices and the digital market in general.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported today's resolution on the Digital Single Market, taking into account the interests of citizens-consumers. Data and user data protection must be respected, a level playing field for internet companies and, in particular, net neutrality. Favouring the status of big players would fundamentally jeopardise user equality and freedom of information dissemination, the basic principles on which the Internet is built.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. — The digital sector plays an important role in creating growth and jobs. In order for Europe to compete with other players in the world, the Digital Single Market needs to be complete as soon as possible. It will not only provide European citizens with a better functioning public sector, but will also enable the development of innovative high-tech technologies in cooperation with private entrepreneurs.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. — Achieving the digital single market as one of the most innovative sectors of the economy would significantly contribute to the competitiveness of the European economy and economic development through e-commerce. Furthermore, by achieving the Single Market, the life of consumers and citizens of the European Union would be significantly easier and businesses and companies operating globally would have the opportunity to offer customers easier access to products. It is assumed that the Single European Market would enable job creation and potentially allow growth of 4% of the EU's GDP. The protection of personal data and privacy and the security of electronic communications must be mentioned in order for citizens of the European Union to have confidence in the single market system. I welcome the positive innovations that benefit the citizens of Croatia and the European Union.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. - I agree with the proposal to abolish administrative barriers in the digital market in the EU, as well as to abolish all other administrative barriers between countries. However, in addition to disturbing this administrative burden, the proposal also calls for a significant increase in other administrative burdens or significant market interventions elsewhere, which is why I did not support the proposal. The biggest market intervention presented in the proposal is the attempt to separate internet search engines from other commercial services and to try to influence the results in these search engines, for example if they are deemed to be 'discriminatory', that they do not maintain the 'diversity of information sources' and so on.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — We are opposed to any text that limits the possibilities for Member States to define their markets. We also disagree because it enables governments, under the cloak of the protection of minors, to attack their political opponents by characterising their websites as dangerous, as we have seen first-hand in Greece.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. - We have tabled this text which proposes to put an end to the abuse of dominant position by certain search engines. They would no longer be considered commercial services like any other. The objective of the approach is twofold. On the one hand it would allow for healthier competition, on the other hand greater transparency and more beneficial to the citizen. To stifle the market is to kill creativity, prevent the growth of many small and medium-sized enterprises, to curb hiring and to deprive citizens of the opportunity to make a choice. The text voted on Thursday is to ring the end of the recess. It is time to cut the threads that make European citizens, consumers or decision-makers the puppets of these multinationals thinking they can decide everything for us.  It's time for sanctions.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted against the resolution that calls for the unbundling of Google. Indeed, I believe that the European Parliament should not interfere in the internal functioning of companies. The role of our institution is to ensure fair competition and consumer choice. What we need is an ambitious Digital Single Market package, a global vision and not a debate on the Google case. I also would like to remind that it is the responsibility of the Commissioner Vestager to investigate and to take actions to protect the Digital Single Market and the consumer if she thinks it is necessary.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: in writing. — I am a clear supporter of the completion of the Digital Single Market and, in this sense, I support a number of points in the resolution. However, I could not support the approved text as a whole, because it also contains points with which I disagree. In particular, it is a question of separating search engines from other commercial services.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I have been studying closely the Google Antitrust case for the past two years with Andreas Schwab in a constructive way. We proposed last week the ‘rotation mechanism’ as a possible solution. I have listened to the arguments of the 22 official complainants, including the European Consumer Organisation! So it is not only a Microsoft or German publisher problem: Google gives a preferential treatment to its own services: this is the central issue, diverting traffic from rival links. Now Google has 90% of the market share in many EU Member States. European enterprises are losing revenues and people are getting fired. European consumers are not having the most pertinent choice, because of Google’s preferential treatment to its own services. I am not against Google or any other US company! I am against monopolies and I want a level playing field in the European digital market. We want fair and neutral search in the interest of consumers. A final question: will Google really move to find an agreement with the European Commission only with the threat of a fine or the threat of unbundling?

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. " The integration of the single market is a truth revealed for this Commission. It is a political aberration and a financial waste for me.  All the hopes of the technocrats in Brussels are now focused on the digital single market, which will bring growth, wealth and economies. The report on the cost of non-Europe is edifying with imbalance. The annihilation of the last recalcitrant national barriers, as the Commission and Parliament fervently desire, will have the opposite effect of the long-awaited one.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I am in favour of the digital single market and I believe that the time has come to take action on its implementation. The completion of the Digital Single Market would undoubtedly stimulate innovation and technological development in Europe and would be a major boost to economic competitiveness. I believe that it is important for the European Union to develop a strong and modern infrastructure.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — What really should be ensured is net neutrality, which should be explicitly enshrined in the Regulation. In order to ensure full consumer protection, there should be a legislative package with that objective, which unfortunately does not exist, which allows secret services to spy on citizens at their own length. I find this resolution insufficiently demanding in this regard, so I abstained.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of breaking down the barriers to the growth of EU’s digital single market. The digital single market is an important step in bringing growth and prosperity to Europe. The digital single market could generate an additional EUR 260 billion a year for the EU economy, as well as boosting the competitiveness of Wales and Europe.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — I voted against this resolution on the achievement of the Digital Single Market tabled by the EPP and S -D political groups. The resolution underlines the growing importance of this sector in all areas of our lives, its economic potential and job creation, the need to respect privacy and net neutrality.  I am pleased that the resolution calls on the Commission to consider putting forward proposals to separate search engines from other commercial services, which is aimed at Google, even if it is not mentioned, in order to combat the potential transformation of search engines into filters and the commercialization of the information obtained. The resolution says nothing about how to combat the digital divide. Nothing about equal and universal access thanks to affordable prices and on all the territories especially rural and mountainous. When it comes to the single market, we know what this means: competition law with more flexibility, more liberalisation, more public-private partnerships, etc. In this and other areas, the public interest should always guide public policy. Now, beyond words, it is only a question of the law of the "market".

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The aim of this resolution is to liberalise the digital market, with the Commission believing that this will create economic growth, employment, strengthen competitiveness and its resilience in the world economy. More than theoretical considerations about the harmful effects of market liberalisation, reality shows that such liberalisation strategies lead to the closure of businesses, concentration of wealth in countries and monopolies in the liberalised sectors, weakening of national production in Member States of weaker economies, and therefore increased redundancies, increased exploitation of workers who are forced to work for less wages and worse working conditions.  We voted against the principle advocated in this resolution, as well as against the ambition to liberalise the service market, the current deregulation on the protection of personal data and individual freedoms.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. — The Digital Single Market will certainly be one of the most important economic pillars for Europe in the future, which can make a significant contribution to overcoming the economic crisis through high-quality and sustainable employment. It is important that the Commission ensures that data protection is sufficiently ensured and largely prevents the commercial re-use of personal data. As I firmly believe that the Digital Single Market is a crucial factor in the development of Europe, I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party voted against the joint resolution of the People's Party and Social Democrats on the 'Single Digital Market' because it treats the new technology sector as a golden field of profitability for monopolies and because it promotes its further surrender to business groups. The disorienting debate on so-called 'resolution-blow' to specific monopolistic groups, as well as the overall content of the resolution, reflects the fierce struggle between monopoly giants and parts of the capital active in the digital technology sector and competing for dominance in the sector and maximising their profits. These developments initiated by the EU, urban governments and the parties of capital and the Euro-one way are to the detriment of workers, because they are the ones who will continue, either to pay for access to digital technologies, or to remain completely cut off from them, or to be ballast of the use of these technologies for surveillance and file by state, employer and other mechanisms. Only when they become popular property will new technologies and the achievements of science and technology be able to unleash all their productive potential, which monopolies are currently committing and braking. Only when the people have come to power will new technologies be able to contribute to meeting modern popular needs.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The aim of this resolution is to put an end to all the obstacles hindering the development of the digital single market, i.e. the defence of digital market liberalisation, based on a global strategy, which the EU believes is the panacea for the evils of the capitalism crisis. More than theoretical considerations on the harmful effects of market liberalisation, reality shows that such liberalisation strategies lead to the closure of businesses, concentration of wealth in countries and monopolies of the liberalised sectors, weakening of national production stalifires of Member States of weaker economies, and, consequently, increased redundancies, increased exploitation of workers who, in the face of such levels of unemployment , are forced to work for less pay and in worse working conditions.  We voted against the principle advocated in this resolution, as well as against the ambition to liberalise the service market, the current deregulation on the protection of personal data and individual freedoms, which, despite being eu concerns, such as net neutrality and consumer protection, is not guaranteed in this regard. We voted in favour of the proposal to separate search engines from other commercial services, which could potentially reduce the concentration of economic activities.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, it is totally unacceptable that more than 170 million children under five are undernourished or have stunted growth and 55 million children suffer from severe malnutrition. These numbers should be a wake-up call for us, not only to seriously step up coordination of humanitarian and development aid but also to look at the broader picture and address the root causes of this unacceptable suffering, like drought caused by climate change and political disruptions. We owe it to these children, the communities in these countries and ourselves to leverage all our power to achieve step change in this crucial area.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last week the FAO International Conference on Nutrition was held in Rome. The figures given are impressive: 805 million people in the world suffer from chronic hunger; 161 million children under 5 years of age have a growth lag for this; 44.5% of children's 6.9 million deaths are due to malnutrition.  I believe that the European Union can strengthen its action at international level and further mobilise resources and long-term investments, in cooperation with actors such as the United Nations agencies, the G8 and the G20, international organisations and non-governmental organisations, and also call on the states that have joined Expo 2015 to launch initiatives leading to binding commitments and targets to combat hunger and malnutrition through diversified strategies , from sustainable agriculture to cooperation.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE). -
text: Mr President, this topic is somewhat related to the previous one about the 25th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. The first thing anybody needs in life is to be able to eat enough, and particularly eat enough of the proper foods. As has been said, this is, unfortunately, not happening in many parts of the world and maybe also within the European Union. Nevertheless, I do not think the European Union deserves any criticism, because we have the record of being the biggest donor in development humanitarian aid in the world. At the same time, we can always improve, and certainly, where there are issues which are highlighted in this report, it is very important that we look at them and see how we can improve matters, particularly in helping these countries – third countries in particular – to do things better from the point of view of sustainable agriculture and general practices. So I think this was a good motion, and I was pleased to support it and vote with my group in all matters.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of this resolution on child malnutrition in developing countries, which could have been better if Amendment 3 had been accepted. This amendment is part of the conclusions of the UN Special Rapporteur, Olivier De Schutter, on the development of agriculture in disadvantaged areas to produce the necessary food and on the priority of this agricultural policy in development policies. However, the EPP, which is based on the Pope's message, heard in plenary, on the fight against inequality and poverty, has clearly not understood the message. Pope Francis should not be very proud of his faithful in this chamber, who applaud him during the message but who do not translate these applause in the vote and who turn their backs on these general principles of poverty reduction, which are necessary.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE). -
text: Mr President, just one point of order. I was going to raise it during the votes but I did not want to be holding up the House and I did not want to put you, Mr President, who has done an excellent job, perhaps in a comprising position. It was in relation to the oral amendment – I think it was Amendment No 11 – which we discussed in relation to the impact assessment. We took a roll call vote and then the ALDE representative stood up and put an oral amendment. That is the way I understood it. Normally I would have seen oral amendments being taken before the amendment is put. So I was just wondering: is that an explanation for it, rather, an explanation of vote?

name: Der Präsident. -
text: I also have the answer. But i think Mr Kelly couldn't let it sit on him that I said: "This week, Mr Tarabella is putting the parliamentary end to it." In other words, we voted on Amendment No 11 by roll-call vote. Then the honourable Member took the floor and tabled an oral amendment to the original text of paragraph 11 – not to Amendment No 11, which was in a very different place in the document – and this oral amendment was adopted. That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution, although in my view it falls short of the ambition of the objectives and the direction of policies that the EU has with regard to third countries.
