Hunger kills people, and millions of children suffer and die from malnutrition in Third World countries, but not only there: in the Spanish state, to give an example, there are more than 20% of infants living below the poverty line, and the percentage of Spanish citizens who are at risk of falling into poverty and social exclusion rises to 60%.  This catastrophic situation is due to the neoliberal orientation of European policies towards third countries, which take precedence over the interests of multinationals, opening the door to the expolio of the natural resources, lands and agriculture of those countries.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. - At least 225 million children under the age of five suffer from acute and chronic malnutrition and growth delays worldwide as a result of chronic malnutrition. It is estimated that 2.6 million of these children die each year in developing countries. These terrible figures show that we urgently need an integrated approach and coordinated action in a number of areas related to malnutrition. It is clear that the steps taken so far have not resulted in a lasting solution to the problem in many regions. With this motion for a resolution, which I strongly support, we in Parliament call on the Commission and the Member States to adopt consistent and long-term development strategies. An important demand in this context, for example, is to increase the Commission's commitments in relation to food-specific interventions. In particular, small farmers on the ground must be allowed to produce more effectively and sustainably.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – There is a terrible problem here; it is incumbent upon everyone to do their utmost to improve this appalling situation.  But the European Union itself does not always help.  For example, EU policies have harmed fish stocks – in areas where fish form the main source of protein as part of the average diet.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — Almost a billion people are suffering from hunger and about 225 million people are affected by hunger. children under the age of five suffer from severe chronic ineating. In developing countries, 2.6 million people die every year. such children. There are many reasons for malnutrition: inefficient economic structures, uneven allocation and unsustainable use of resources, poor governance, over-reliance on individual crops, discrimination against women and children, inadequate health systems, and insufficient education. I support calls on the authorities to ensure that food is accessible – it must be possible to feed directly when working on the ground; 'access to food' means economic and physical access to food; and fitness – food must be safe and ensure the nutritional needs of each person. It is necessary to include the dimension of nutrition, food safety and sustainable agriculture in all its development policies. I support the calls for the Commission and the Member States to follow coherent long-term development strategies and to make efforts to reduce the level of non-food, including in the context of emergencies and humanitarian interventions.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. "Despite the good intentions displayed in this text, I do not believe that the problem of child undernourishment in developing countries can fall within the competence of the European Union, and I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — Nearly one billion people worldwide still suffer from hunger and at least 225 million children under the age of five suffer from acute and chronic undernourishment and stunted growth due to chronic child and maternal undernourishment. An estimated 2.6 million of them die each year in developing countries. According to the WHO, undernourishment is by far the leading cause of infant mortality. It's obviously unbearable. The European Union must step up its efforts to ensure universal access to adequate food. It must continue its work to address the mostly human-caused causes of child malnutrition and to implement an integrated approach in areas affecting undernourishment (health, education, agriculture, water, access to health infrastructure, etc.). The international community must ensure that international targets to reduce stunting for children under five are met by 2025 and that all forms of malnutrition are achieved by 2030.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The findings of this motion for a resolution, based on an oral question on the state of child malnutrition in the world, are damning.  Nearly one billion people worldwide still suffer from hunger, including at least 225 million children, and high poverty is one such cause. The European Union is thus proposing support to developing countries of 3.5 billion euros by 2020 at a time when poverty is growing in the EU. The proposal even calls for an increase in the budget devoted to it, at a time when Europeans are subject to increasing austerity.  By the economic policies they impose on developing countries and by the dictatorship of multinationals, developed countries, like those in the EU, are also directly responsible for malnutrition problems. It is no longer enough to raise awareness by distributing European funds which can sometimes be questioned as useful, often diverted for non-food or sanitary purposes, but a genuine policy of responsible co-development must be initiated, and that is why I abstained on this proposal.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution promoted by the Committee on Development, which touches on an issue, that of the malnutrition of children in developing countries, through arguments that we broadly support.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — More than 225 million children under the age of five worldwide experience chronic and acute malnutrition or stunting as a result of chronic child and maternal malnutrition, of which approximately 2.6 million die each year in developing countries. The Commission Communication 'Improving maternal and child nutrition in foreign aid: an EU strategic framework', March 2013, stressed the need to coordinate humanitarian aid and development aid, and identified measures to achieve a 40% reduction in 40% of children under the age of five who are stunted (70 million) and to reduce and keep below 5% the percentage of children under the age of five years of age who are wasted. I voted in favour of this oral question with a resolution to request a medium-term review of the measures taken and, if necessary, to reallocate the funds already committed (EUR 3.1 billion for nutrition interventions and EUR 400 million for specific programmes) in an effort to achieve the targets set for 2025.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because almost a billion people are still suffering from hunger and at least 225 million people are affected by hunger. children under the age of five suffer from severe chronic ineating or chronic disordered development caused by child and maternal inemetic. In addition, it is estimated that 2.6 million people die each year in developing countries. such children. Malnutrition or malnutrition in such countries increases birth defects, develops a large number of diseases and, of course, increases mortality, especially in children. There may be many reasons for children's non-food, but most of them are the consequences of human activity, so they can be avoided and we need to do so as soon as possible. These include inefficient economic structures, uneven allocation and unsustainable use of resources, discrimination against women and children and poor health caused by inadequate health systems, as well as insufficient nutrition education. The fight against child intake and universal access to adequate nutritious food should therefore remain at the heart of the post-2015 development agenda.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, because the problem of child malnutrition is one of the main factors preventing developing countries from leaving poverty and children being able to have a chance at life.  Improving children's nutrition is a key factor in the development of a healthy population, which automatically also leads to economic growth and social progress in these countries. A number of researches have shown that malnutrition derives from the lack of essential elements such as calcium, iron, vitamin A, but also from problems that occur during the lactation period. These conditions can cause growth delays or even deaths due to illness of the mother or child.  Therefore, developing countries cannot get out of poverty and progress economically if populations do not reach a level of nutritional security. And for this to materialise, it is necessary for the European Union and developed countries to intervene, in order to lend a hand in treating and combating child malnutrition.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour. These statements are often for their own sake, but the content does not pose any problems for convincing support.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - The EU's role in aiding development and combating child malnutrition must be recognised. However, since 2008, food and financial crises have again increased the numbers of child malnutrition, which is now the leading cause of death at this stage of life. This prevents compliance with the MDGs if no further action is taken. The Commission's announcement of EUR 3.5 billion to counter this situation is positive, but more effort is needed. The actions carried out and the implementation of a multisectoral plan should be reviewed to include the main axes of action outlined by Unicef, of which it is worth highlighting: care in the first thousand days of the child , considered critical , promotion of small-scale agriculture and crucial prominence of women. Families where women manage resources suffer from less malnutrition. Women must therefore be empowered, land owners and programme coordinators promoted in places of action, and women's and girls' education encouraged.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — Malnutrition and undernourishment are overwhelming and recurrent phenomena, particularly in developing countries. We must do everything in our power to rectify this situation. This requires both humanitarian mobilization and structural assistance for the agricultural sector in these countries.  Malnutrition and undernourishment have serious and often irreversible consequences on the human body. These phenomena affect a significant part of the population, and the consequences will still be suffered by future generations. I voted in favour of this resolution, which is a testament to the European Union's commitment to the fight against world hunger.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on child malnutrition in developing countries. I find it unacceptable that 225 million children under the age of five are still suffering from malnutrition or growth delays as a result of malnutrition and that malnutrition in developing countries causes the deaths of 2.6 million children every year. If children are starving in the poorest areas, there are more and more obese children in the richer areas. This paradox should make the European Commission reflect, which should develop serious policies against food waste and coordinate the mobilisation of more resources to combat malnutrition by involving other players such as the United Nations, the G8, the G20 and emerging countries. I also believe that, in order to combat such a deep-rooted problem, the European Commission is obliged to develop integrated and long-term actions to encourage the governments of countries at risk of nutritional emergency to promote reforms that enable small farmers to produce efficiently to ensure sufficient nutrition for their families.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. The conclusions of the second International Conference on Nutrition held in Rome last week reminded us that more than 800 million people are subject to chronic hunger and, of these, more than 200 million are children under the age of five. Also in 2013, malnutrition was the leading cause of infant mortality in the world. In the face of this continuing tragedy, I believe that we must be very rigorous in identifying its true causes and equally rigorous and consistent in dealing with its consequences.  Among the causes, I believe that there is also the great disproportion, in developing countries, between agricultural resources intended for export, often by and for the benefit of foreign companies, and the resources allocated to the internal market for subsistence purposes.  The resolution, on the basis of the observation that food production would be sufficient to feed the entire world population, identifies and urges a number of important measures which can and must be taken, in particular, by the Commission and the Member States. That is why – although I am aware that there are still many other steps to be taken – I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — With 3.1 million child deaths each year in developing countries, undernutrition is the single biggest contributor to mortality in under-fives. NGOs have pushed for the fight against child undernutrition, and provision of universal access to adequate nutritious food, to remain one of the major targets of the post-2015 Millennium Development Goals’ agenda for both the EU and the broader international community. The WFP calculates that EUR 2.5 billion is needed per year to reach all 66 million school-age children in developing countries suffering from hunger. The WFP emphasises also that, if women farmers had the same access to resources as men, the number suffering from hunger in the world could be reduced by up to 150 million.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — While rates of childhood obesity are rising in the West, hunger continues to be combated in developing countries. Around 200 million children under 5 suffer from growth delays as a result of chronic maternal and child malnutrition. Malnutrition, a combination of several factors such as protein insufficiency, sugars, frequency of diseases and infections, food ignorance, consumption of non-potable water, lack of medical controls and lack of hygiene, strikes slowly and silently, slowing down the physical and intellectual development of the child, causing permanent delays and finally eroding the body's ability to successfully react to infections and diseases. Today, reducing or even eliminating malnutrition is possible and is one of the commitments of the Millennium Development Goal. Breastfeeding, the supply of iodato salt, vitamin A and micronutrients are simple low-cost but highly effective measures put in place by UNICEF and partner organisations. I am of the opinion that global commitments on food security, food and sustainable agriculture can be useful in addressing the causes of child and maternal malnutrition in countries such as Asia and Africa where 90% of children at risk live.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution as it seeks to bring about more effective action towards eliminating child under-nutrition in developing countries. Three key tools towards this goal are shaping our education, health and economic policies justly.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution, although in my view it falls short of the ambition of the objectives and the direction of policies that the EU has with regard to third countries. Hunger kills people, and millions of children suffer and die from malnutrition in Third World countries, but not only there: in the Spanish state, to give an example, there are more than 20% of infants living below the poverty line, and the percentage of Spanish citizens who are at risk of falling into poverty and social exclusion rises to 60%.  This catastrophic situation is due to the neoliberal orientation of European policies towards third countries, which take precedence over the interests of multinationals, opening the door to the expolio of the natural resources, lands and agriculture of those countries.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. - It is known that child undernutrition is linked to food insecurity and household poverty, inadequate care and feeding methods, unsanitary living conditions and inadequate health services. Nearly one billion people continue to starve and, even worse, at least 225 million children up to five years of age worldwide suffer from acute and chronic malnutrition and growth retardation as a result of chronic infant and maternal malnutrition, with an estimated 2.6 million of them dying annually in developing countries. I voted in order so that ensuring universal access to nutritionally adequate food and combating child malnutrition remain the most important targets within the overall hunger eradication target of the post-2015 agenda, and here I also refer to the eradication of all forms of malnutrition, planned by 2030. We are therefore 25 years after the adoption of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, and I am disappointed that some signatory states have not yet been able to create a conducive environment that guarantees children access to adequate nutrition.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The point of this resolution is to call the European Commission, our States and the countries concerned to do more to address the challenges of child undernourishment and malnutrition. Even today, about one billion people are hungry worldwide, including many children.  In particular, this resolution has the merit of promoting a more integrated vision of European policies, and this at two levels: better coordination of policies affecting undernourishment, on the one hand, and between emergency and development programmes, on the other. Such an approach will make EU-funded projects more efficient for the benefit of local people.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. Malnutrition causes the deaths of 3.1 million children in developing countries every year. Although more than two hundred million people have stopped suffering from a lack of food in the last twenty years, the road to solving this serious world problem remains very uphill. Asia is still the continent with the most malnourished people: out of 805 million hungry people in the world, 526 million live in Asia. In sub-Saharan Africa the numbers are smaller, but the ratio is higher: one in four people suffers from hunger. Defeating malnutrition in the world, however, is not an impossible task. The economic development of these areas and the coordination of aid from states and international organisations are the recipe for winning this battle that has been going on for too many years. For these reasons, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. " Child malnutrition is a scourge. It kills and causes irreversible damage to children. This scourge will be combated, of course, by acting on the substance, in the long term, with a good development policy. It is the question of water, it is the question of school, it is the question of agriculture, it is the question of food self-sufficiency, it is the question of land management. This is obvious. But if we want immediate results, if we want to save children today, then we have to change the paradigm. And allow development policy to take ownership of the results of humanitarianism. We know how to reduce child mortality. This has been done in the Sahel, as part of humanitarian actions, thanks to the support of ECHO: one million children treated since 2006 with 50 dollars a year. Ready-to-use therapeutic food is given to a child in the form of a sachet and saved. The World Bank has largely endorsed this approach. We all need to think about whether the 11th EDF takes this approach into account, learns from humanitarian practice, organizes it on a large scale. So that the children who are suffering from malnutrition today in the world will be saved tomorrow.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — The report presents an excessive number of amendments that make the text complex and cumbersome. The implications will be confused, a damaging thing on such an important subject and whose real causes, such as global imbalances induced by uncontrolled globalization, are not sufficiently addressed. I have the decision to abstain on this vote.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We believe that the universal right to food and good nutrition is fundamental to achieving the Millennium Development Goals. However, around 225 million children under the age of five worldwide experience chronic and acute malnutrition or stunting as a result of chronic child and maternal malnutrition, of which approximately 2.6 million die each year. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution, which considers the reduction of funds for agriculture in the tenth European Development Fund (EDF) to be a mistake and which calls on the EU to increase the assistance provided under its development aid programmes in order to achieve sustainable agricultural production , based on small, peasant and medium-scale farms, and aimed primarily at local consumption, and to invest in participatory plans aimed at national level and implemented at the local level in cooperation with farmers and their representatives, local and regional authorities and civil society organisations.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — We are voting against, because, although we agree that the problem of malnutrition is very important and that solving it could also help to tackle other problems, such as illegal immigration, it is nevertheless impossible for us to support the financing of third countries when Greece is in the vise of the Memorandum, when it has been treated hostilely by many other Member States and when there are hundreds of thousands of children in our country who are malnourished but the EU is indifferent to it.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. – Currently, 225 million children are malnourished and, according to the World Health Organization, 35% of child mortality is due to malnutrition. Faced with this serious situation, the European Parliament, in this Resolution, urges the Commission and the Member States to make the fight against child malnutrition one of the axes in their development policies. The EU must strengthen its cooperation ties with the United Nations, NGOs and civil society to find new and better ways of financing for the fight against child malnutrition. In this regard, it is essential to provide local authorities in developing countries with tools to improve production and bring it closer to the population in need. This Resolution considers three key principles for successful combating child malnutrition: availability of productive resources and food; accessibility to food, both physical and economic, and adaptation of these foods to nutritional needs. The fight against child malnutrition is also a guarantee for the protection of human rights.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — Some 1 billion people are still suffering from hunger, and in the world at least 225 million children under the age of five suffer from acute and chronic malnutrition, with an estimated 2.6 million of these children dying every year in developing countries. Around two billion people worldwide, or one in three people in developing countries, suffer from a chronic deficiency of essential vitamins and minerals. Almost 20 million children still suffer from acute malnutrition in the last degree, either in emergency situations or in non-urgent situations, and only 10% of these children have access to treatment; It is therefore crucial that governments reaffirm the right to food and commit themselves to halding, i.e. from 840 million to 420 million, the number of hungry and malnourished people by 2015. The EU should increase support for small and medium-sized sustainable agriculture that produces mainly for local consumption and invests in participatory national initiative plans to be carried out at local level, in cooperation with farmers and their representatives, local and regional authorities and civil society organisations.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — It is evidence that child malnutrition and malnutrition are a serious global problem, mainly affecting developing countries and countries with armed conflicts, which has dramatic consequences for the independence, development and sovereignty of these countries. As is also clear that this is not an exclusive reality of these countries and the situation that is currently living in the EU is about to demonstrate it. More than godly statements, it is necessary to go to the root of your problems. This is where the waters are divided: in the causes and solutions. In the resolution, little or nothing is said about the favoring of the agro-industrial model of exporting nature and its repercussions, such as the qualitative impoverishment of the world agricultural sector, the disinvestment in small and medium-sized agriculture, the agricultural abandonment and the liquidation of family agriculture. Nothing is said about market fundamentalism, privatisation and liberalisation policies and free trade. Child hunger and malnutrition are the result of an unjust, exploitative and oppressive system and, therefore, historically condemned.  Humanity now has sufficient knowledge and resources to eradicate these problems. But this will not happen within the framework of the system that generated them.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. — The right to food and good nutrition is one of the crucial areas for achieving and achieving the Millennium Development Goals. Nevertheless, more than 170 million children under the age of five suffer from malnutrition or other forms of disease. By 2025, the European Union aims to substantially reduce the number of malnourished children it intends to achieve through the coordination of rural development policies, sustainable agriculture, public health, hygiene, social security and education. It would be appropriate for the European Commission to carry out a future review of the measures taken and the objectives achieved and, if necessary, for realocation to be made, of the funds already promised, thus contributing to the achievement of the targets set for 2025.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — In favour of the report. Combating child malnutrition in a society such as the West, where thousands of tonnes of food are literally thrown away, is absolutely necessary.

name: Lampros Fountoulis (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting against report B8-0253/2014, because, although I agree that the problem of malnutrition is very important and that its possible resolution can also help to tackle other problems, such as illegal immigration, it is nevertheless impossible for me to support the financing of third countries, when Greece is in the vise of the Memorandum, when it has been treated hostilely by many other Member States and when there are hundreds of thousands of children in my country who are malnourished but the EU is indifferent to it.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which highlights the complexity of the problem of undernourishment and malnutrition in the world. Undernourishment is a real challenge that largely determines the achievement of global development goals. The resolution rightly stresses that the response to undernourishment is not only a global political commitment, but also a response that integrates the different dimensions (agriculture, education, health, infrastructure, access to drinking water, rural exodus, sanitation, etc.), a response that must be achieved through a coherence between internal and external policies of the European Union. In addition, the role of women is paramount in the fight against undernourishment and needs to be further taken into account in the policies and initiatives put in place by the European Union: women are at the forefront of breastfeeding, producing, purchasing, preparing and distributing food within the family. Accurate identification of the causes of undernourishment and malnutrition in each affected country or region is needed to provide an appropriate response.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Resolution on Child Malnutrition and Malnutrition in Developing Countries, bearing in mind that nearly one billion people continue to be hungry and that at least 225 million children under the age of five worldwide are chronically and acutely malnourished, with the serious consequences of this, and, even more terrible, , approximately 2.6 million die each year in developing countries, with hunger being the leading cause of child death, according to world health organization data. In recent years, despite agreements reached by States at the 1996 World Food Summit, rather than reduced, the number of people suffering from hunger and malnutrition has increased. Global food production is sufficient to feed the world's population, but despite this, a substantial part of humanity, largely underage, is starving and malnourished. We cannot allow part of the population to be guaranteed in the 21st century, the most basic of rights, that of food.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. – 6.9 million children die every year in the world – 19 000 every day – from easily preventable causes, and 99% of these deaths occur in developing countries. Looks like a massacre we can't stop. And yet there is also good news: in 1960, 20 million children between 0 and 5 years old died. In 2011, deaths fell to 6.9 million. This shows us that a timely strategy and, more importantly, its careful, precise and timely implementation can save many lives. As was pointed out last week at the FAO International Conference on Malnutrition, coordinated action is needed between the different actors in all relevant sectors at international, regional, national and Community level to combat malnutrition. Agricultural and food systems, including crops, livestock farming, fisheries and aquaculture, must be regulated through concerted public policies, taking into account resources, the environment, people, the processes by which food is produced, processed, distributed, prepared and consumed.  EXPO MILANO 2015 will be dedicated to "feeding the planet, energy for life" and, among all other relevant events and venues, will be an opportunity to underline the importance of food security and nutrition as well as to raise public awareness; it is up to us not to waste this opportunity.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. "This resolution is above all a statement of intent. It ignores a major cause of malnutrition: international food exports. In countries affected by malnutrition, there is competition between local and food agriculture and monocultures for export to developed countries.  It is more profitable for developing countries to turn to exporting animal and plant products in order to benefit from more promising markets. This leads to the disappearance of local food agriculture, which people need to feed themselves. The gradual disappearance of trade barriers in the agricultural sector exacerbates this phenomenon, as the export of food is still favoured at the expense of local populations.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of strong and coherent EU action on child malnutrition in developing countries, which every year involves the deaths of nearly three million children under the age of five. Food is a right, and it is the obligation of governments, both developing and developed countries, to secure and maintain it as a political priority, promoting national plans for child and maternal nutrition, as well as specific policies on food security in general, access to safe water, access to land, etc. Children are our future. There is no more important task for any government than building a world in which all children can grow up to their full potential, with health, in peace and with dignity.

name: Eduard-Raul Hellvig (PPE)
text: in writing. — As a billion of our people are starving and this scourge affects hundreds of millions of children, victims of chronic malnutrition and child mortality, I support the resolution calling on the EU to further support, through its development aid programmes, action to combat hunger in developing countries. Undernutrition is the leading cause of infant mortality, accounting for more than a third of children's illnesses up to five years of age. That is why I believe that sustained efforts must be made to combat food speculation, improve purchasing power, help small farmers and more efficiently distribution of food. Unfortunately, some progress since the 1996 World Food Summit was reversed by the food crises of 2008 and 2011. The vicious circle between rural to urban migration and extreme poverty is also perpetuated in many poor regions of the world. In those circumstances, it is clear that the reduction of agricultural funds under the 10th European Development Fund was a mistake and I am also asking the Council to reverse this harmful amputation.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - In developing countries, around 2.6 million children die every year from malnutrition, which means that on average every 12 seconds one child dies of starvation. It is not by chance that the reduction in the number of malnourished people in the world is listed as the first of the Millennium Development Goals. One of the main causes of hunger is poverty, which unfortunately creates a vicious circle. A hungry child is unable to develop properly, has problems with learning and concentration, which consequently deprives him of the chance to work well and to get out of poverty.  The assistance of the international community is therefore necessary in combating this phenomenon. I believe that the European Union's commitment to the fight against hunger is significant, such as the food instrument or the Millennium Development Goals initiative, both with budgets of EUR 1 billion. However, it should be borne in mind that not only nutrition aid but also structural support is needed, inter alia by supporting rural development and sustainable agriculture, public health, water management and education. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We believe that the universal right to food and good nutrition is fundamental to achieving the Millennium Development Goals. However, around 225 million children under the age of five worldwide experience chronic and acute malnutrition or stunting as a result of chronic child and maternal malnutrition, of which approximately 2.6 million die each year. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution, which considers the reduction of funds for agriculture in the tenth European Development Fund (EDF) to be a mistake and which calls on the EU to increase the assistance provided under its development aid programmes in order to achieve sustainable agricultural production , based on small, peasant and medium-scale farms, and aimed primarily at local consumption, and to invest in participatory plans aimed at national level and implemented at the local level in cooperation with farmers and their representatives, local and regional authorities and civil society organisations

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on child malnutrition in developing countries, as I believe that an integrated approach and concerted action in many areas can effectively address child malnutrition, especially in the crucial period of their development, which is the first 1 000 days of life.  In addition, the resolution focuses on the importance of descriptiveness and education, especially girls, who will one day become mothers-to-be, and investing in them will increase the likelihood that their offspring will live healthier and more productive lives. With better policies, global and local action, resolutions call for the creation of a suitable environment for better nutrition and health of children.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the resolution on child undernourishment in developing countries. It regrets that nearly one billion people are still suffering from hunger, including at least 225 million children under the age of five, who are chronically undernourished. The resolution stresses that the causes of undernourishment are largely human and therefore preventable. Possible actions must address the inefficiency of economic structures, the unequal distribution of resources or their unsustainable use, poor governance, discrimination against women and children, and the shortcomings of health and education systems. The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — While every year in Europe more and more healthy and edible foodstuffs (up to 50% according to some estimates) are wasted throughout the agri-food chain to the consumer stage and become waste, 79 million European citizens live below the poverty line and 16 million depend on food aid.  Globally, malnutrition is a real scourge: nearly one billion people are still hungry and at least 225 million children under the age of five suffer from acute and chronic undernourishment and stunted growth due to chronic child and maternal undernourishment.  I therefore welcome the political message sent by the European Parliament through this resolution on child malnutrition and the European Commission's commitment to invest EUR 3.5 billion between 2014 and 2020 to improve nutrition in some of the world's poorest countries. However, further efforts will be needed to achieve the goal of reducing the number of stunted children under five by seven million by 2025.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – It is shocking that 805 million people in the world do not have enough food to lead a healthy active life and that poor nutrition causes nearly half of deaths in children under five living in developing countries, or 3.1 million each year. The fight against child under-nutrition, and provision of universal access to adequate nutritious food, must therefore remain one of the major targets of the post-2015 Millennium Development Goals’ agenda for both the EU and the broader international community.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. — The available information shows that almost a billion people worldwide are suffering from hunger, at least 225 million people in the world. children under the age of five experience severe chronic non-food or developmental disorders. In developing countries, 2.6 million people die every year. such children. The lack of trace elements is also one of the serious problems that cause 7% of diseases worldwide, especially among newborns and young people. Women and girls are the most vulnerable group, accounting for 60% of victims of chronic hunger. Although women produce 60-80% of food in developing countries, 80% of farming work is carried out, and they officially own only 2% of the land. In order to address the problem of child inaccessible, development cooperation, as well as in humanitarian and natural crises, requires an integrated approach, coordinated action in the areas of health, education, agriculture, water, access to energy resources and sanitation, which affect children's inemission.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - More than 165 million children worldwide under the age of five are malnourished or rickety; some 52 million children are severely malnourished and an estimated 2.6 million people die annually in developing countries. The right to food and good nutrition is fundamental to the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals, in particular Goals 1 and 4. The Commission Communication 'Improving maternal and child nutrition in foreign aid: an EU strategic framework' highlights the necessary coordination of humanitarian aid and development. It recommends a multisectoral approach that ensures coordination of rural development policies, sustainable agriculture, public health, water and sanitation, social security and education. The oral question calls for a medium-term review of the measures taken and, if necessary, the re-allocating of the funds already committed (EUR 3.1 million for nutrition interventions and EUR 400 million for specific programmes), in an effort to achieve the targets set for 2025.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution, although in my view it falls short of the ambition of the objectives and the direction of policies that the EU has with regard to third countries. Hunger kills people, and millions of children suffer and die from malnutrition in Third World countries, but not only there: in the Spanish state, to give an example, there are more than 20% of infants living below the poverty line, and the percentage of Spanish citizens who are at risk of falling into poverty and social exclusion rises to 60%.  This catastrophic situation is due to the neoliberal orientation of European policies towards third countries, which take precedence over the interests of multinationals, opening the door to the expolio of the natural resources, lands and agriculture of those countries.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I supported the resolution on child malnutrition in developing countries. Malnutrition causes the deaths of more than 3 million children per year and results in a high incidence rate among children under the age of 5. Stressing that access to food is a human right, combating malnutrition, hidden hunger and increasing food safety must undoubtedly be key objectives of the post-2015 development agenda.  In order to combat these problems effectively, we need greater coherence in many areas, i.e. agriculture, food security, health, social protection and education. In addition, an effective nutrition policy and monitoring of the effectiveness of the measures taken are essential. We must also focus our efforts on tackling the causes of malnutrition among children, including, above all, poverty. Poorer children are three times more likely to suffer from malnutrition than children from wealthier countries. Ultimately, investment in education is the best means of eradicating poverty, reducing child and neonatal mortality, reducing malnutrition and improving children's health.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. — At least 225 million of the world’s children under the age of five are suffering from acute and chronic undernutrition or from stunted growth as a result of chronic child and maternal undernutrition. There is estimated data of 2.6 million of such children dying every year in developing countries. Also one out of three people in developing countries are suffering from chronic deficiency of essential vitamins and minerals, which drastically increases their susceptibility to birth defects, infection and compromised development. The fight against child undernutrition and the provision of universal access to adequate nutritious food should remain one of the most important targets of the post-2015 agenda. It is thus critical to make every possible effort to ensure that this goal is properly achieved. I welcome the Commission’s commitment to investing EUR 3.5 billion between 2014 and 2020 in improving nutrition in some of the world’s poorest countries. I call on the Commission to scale up its commitments as regards nutrition-specific interventions in order to meet its objective of reducing by 7 million the number of stunted children under the age of five by 2025.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. - Malnutrition and malnutrition are the cause of at least a third of the deaths of children in developing countries and the main cause of death for 20% of mothers. We should be aware that the root of this problem is human nature, so accordingly it is our responsibility to avoid the problem. It is necessary to act in a timely way through humanitarian and other forms of assistance, and to provide food and drinking water, social protection, public health, energy and education.  I support this resolution because it is our duty to fight to ensure the normal living conditions of future generations. If we look at the bigger picture, we can consider this to be also an economic problem that affects the global potential of society, reduces economic productivity, the potential incomes of individuals and the human capital of states.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - I unconditionly supported this resolution because we Europeans sometimes did not even think that at the beginning of the 21st century there are thousands and hundreds of thousands of children who have not been fed and even die from food shortages. Much remains to be done to ensure that the newly developed countries have a standard of living, at least in the European Union average. And it would n't be the terrible thing that can be—the death of child hunger.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution because this resolution contributes to measures to stop the spread of child malnutrition, not only in developing countries but also in Greece, where the troika and memoranda have caused a huge humanitarian crisis with 40% of the population living below the poverty line and the unemployed having reached 1.5 million.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — The fight against child malnutrition and adequate and nutritious nutrition should continue to be one of the most important aims of the post-2015 agenda as part of the hunger eradication target, calling for an end to all forms of malnutrition by 2030 and for the internationally agreed targets for decay in children under five years of age to be achieved by 2025.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. - 20 million children worldwide continue to be victims of acute malnutrition, and only 10% of them have access to the necessary care.  I therefore think it is important for international public authorities to take appropriate action to guarantee the right to food and proper nutrition.  My vote in favour of the resolution stems from the awareness that only an integrated approach, supported by coordinated action in a number of sectors that affect this phenomenon, such as health, education, agriculture and water resources, can ensure proper management of the problem.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: in writing. - Of about a billion people suffering from hunger, approximately 225 million are children under the age of five. Children’s undernutrition is the biggest contributor to child mortality and diseases worldwide. I supported the resolution which should not only guarantee the right to food, life, health, education and water, but mainly for the EU to implement development aid programmes for small and medium agriculture production which would provide food to its citizens and help to build economies in developing countries.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Two hundred and twenty-five million children under the age of five are undernourished. Yet the causes "are mostly human-caused and therefore preventable." The resolution recalls international commitments and calls for better coordination of key policies in this area (excessive dependence on monoculture, inadequacies in health care systems, etc.). It also denounces budget cuts in the European Development Fund or an "unequal distribution of resources" and "speculation on raw materials". There are some ridiculous formulations from the additions of the right of the Assembly in this text. Thus morbidity and decreased productivity are juxtaposed as consequences of undernourishment. Nevertheless, I encourage the good feelings of this text without concrete application. I'm voting FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — Unfortunately, around 1 billion people are still suffering from hunger, and in the world at least 225 million children under the age of five suffer from acute and chronic malnutrition, growth retardation as a result of chronic child and maternal malnutrition, with an estimated 2.6 million of these children dying each year in developing countries.  We must therefore channel our efforts to end this scourge. As long as there's a hungry child in the world, we can't be satisfied.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because of the importance of safeguarding the lives and well-being of children. The resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to include the importance of ensuring food security in their development policies and utilising a holistic approach from the local to the global level. In my view this will offer the best chance of effectively tackling under-nutrition and malnutrition.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. - I welcome and support the adoption of the European Parliament resolution on the lack of nutrition and malnutrition of children in developing countries.  I find it unacceptable that, 14 years after the adoption of the Millennium Development Goals in the world, around a billion people and 225 million children under the age of five continue to suffer from hunger and acute chronic malnutrition, of which more than 2.5 million die every year in developing countries from chronic malnutrition. As a doctor, I must also draw attention to the issue of 'hidden hunger', which affects almost two billion people suffering from chronic shortages of important vitamins and nutrients. This condition significantly weakens immunity and increases susceptibility to birth or developmental defects, but also infections. I am aware that the scale of the problem requires a global approach and, above all, a focus of development policy and its funding on clear objectives and priorities. I therefore stress the need to focus primary attention on the care of pregnant women and children under three years of age, who have specific nutrition requirements in view of growth and development, but also of susceptibility to diseases. Finally, I would like to express my delight that the United Nations Standing Committee on Nutrition has adopted a plan to improve nutrition.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – Two billion people globally are suffering from ‘hidden hunger’ and millions of children are still suffering from severe acute malnutrition, which is the biggest contributor to child mortality. More than ever, we need to raise global awareness and to create an enabling environment in which children’s access to adequate food can be secured. Therefore I fully support the Parliament resolution on child undernutrition, which is an important initiative sending out a very strong political message to the international community and public opinion.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report, which has been excessively burdened by amendments that go in all directions. In fact, while child malnutrition in developing countries is a terrible problem and, of course, requires the attention and assistance of rich countries, it is nevertheless true that each country must remain free to ensure its development in the way it sees it and according to its context and internal realities. Once again, the essential notion of the right of peoples to self-determination must be respected by the European Union. Nor should we forget that, all too often, the problem of child malnutrition in developing countries is greatly aggravated by the very policies of interference or the geopolitical maneuvers of large nations.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. "I supported this resolution. In parallel with the vote on the 25th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, we held a more specific vote on the issue of child malnutrition. This is a serious problem because it affects the overriding human right to be able to feed themselves.  As part of the Millennium Goals, we must commit to effective partnership policies to eradicate the scourge of malnutrition. An estimated one billion people are still hungry, including at least 225 million children under the age of five. Official development assistance must be targeted and better controlled to ensure that every penny paid cannot be diverted for other purposes.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. In order to tackle the problem of child malnutrition and malnutrition in developing countries, we need to adopt an integrated approach and coordinated action in a number of areas that affect this phenomenon, such as health, education, agriculture, water resources, access to energy and health infrastructure. We call on the Commission and the Member States to adopt coherent long-term development strategies, including in the context of emergency situations and humanitarian intervention, integrating nutrition, food security and sustainable agriculture into all their development policies. In order to be more effective, development and emergency programmes will have to be closely linked in order to anticipate and prevent food crises, help to reduce the damage caused and facilitate recovery. I therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to mobilise long-term resources and financial investments for nutrition, in cooperation with actors such as UN agencies, the G8/G20, emerging countries, international and non-governmental organisations, academic institutions, civil society organisations and the private sector, as well as to identify nutrition as a priority of innovative funding.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - I supported the bill on the malnourished and malnourished children in developing countries. The International Declaration of Human Rights deals with the right to food as part of the standard of living. At least 225 million children under the age of five suffer from malnutrition worldwide. The European Union must increase its contribution to development aid programmes and make them more targeted.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted for the resolution on child undernutrition and malnutrition in developing countries. I deplore that close to a billion people still suffer from hunger, and at least 225 million of the world’s children under the age of five suffer from acute and chronic undernutrition and stunted growth as a result of chronic child and maternal undernutrition, of which it is estimated that 2.6 million die every year in developing countries. The causes of child undernutrition are numerous and most of them are man-made and therefore avoidable, ranging from inefficient economic structures, unequal distribution of resources and/or their unsustainable use, poor governance, over-reliance on individual crop and monocultural cropping practices, discrimination against women and children, and ill-health caused by deficient health systems, as well as lack of education, especially for mothers. From a life-cycle perspective, the most crucial time to meet a child’s nutritional requirements is in the first 1 000 days of life, including the period of pregnancy, as during this time the child has increased nutritional needs to support rapid growth and development, is more susceptible to infections and is totally dependent on others for nutrition, care and social interactions.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I supported MP Linda McAvan's initiative on the topic of child underuse in developing countries. I would remind you that physical and cognitive impairments resulting from malnutrition in the first thousand days of a child's life are irreparable and can no longer be cured.  I therefore find it worrying that more than 165 million children under the age of five are malnourished, while around 52 million suffer from severe malnutrition. We must understand that malnutrition is also an economic problem that affects the global potential of society, reduces economic productivity, the potential incomes of individuals and the human capital of states.  In order to fight child underuse, we must act in a timely and effective manner. I would emphasise the importance of an integrated approach and coordinated action in a number of sectors that align policies in rural development, sustainable agriculture, public health, water supply and sanitation, social protection and education, together with responsible involvement of all stakeholders.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — The EU is and must lead the way in all aspects of humanitarian assistance, especially in cases such as this one on child malnutrition. In my opinion, this is a priority emergency, which is why I voted in favour.  The ultimate aim must be to improve child and maternal nutrition and ensure good food security.  I am well aware that great efforts will be needed to bring about effective and coordinated action within the various policies of this complex sector: rural development, the use of effective and sustainable water resources, the protection of ecosystems and biodiversity, adequate health services, the reduction of climate change and sustainable production and consumption.  Member States should pay more attention to nutrition, food security and sustainable agriculture in all their development policies, seeking to channel resources and financial investment to improve global food security, in cooperation with UN agencies, emerging countries and international organisations.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE)
text: In writing. — I supported the resolution on child undernourishment and malnutrition in developing countries as it recalls the fundamental challenges to ensure that the entire population has access to adequate decent food.  Today, two billion people suffer from "invisible hunger" and every year 2.6 million children under the age of five die in developing countries. It is therefore essential to put pressure on the international community to ensure that everyone has access to quantitatively and qualitatively sufficient food.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. — The human right to food, especially that of children, is constantly being violated. If this Parliament is serious about combating malnutrition, immediate action must be taken against the increasing use of arable land for organic fuel. Nor must our agricultural policy cause food cultivation to suffer in critical regions. Here, the majority parties of the House are called upon to face the effects of their actions! Take responsibility!

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — I am voting in favour of a resolution calling on the European Union and its Member States to take into account the problems related to malnutrition for which swift and effective measures can be adopted. It is equally important to recall the mechanisms in place and the progress made, as this resolution provides, in order to better coordinate joint actions.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — Article 25 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights 1948 recognises the right to food as part of the right to an adequate standard of living. On the other hand, MDDS 1 and 4 aim at eradicating extreme poverty and hunger by 2015 and reducing infant mortality. However, around 225 million children under the age of five suffer from acute and chronic malnutrition worldwide and an estimated 2.6 million of these children die every year in developing countries. Addressing this problem of child malnutrition requires an integrated approach and coordinated action in a number of policies and sectors, such as health, education, agriculture, access to water, energy and sanitation, as well as the responsible involvement of all international actors and other stakeholders. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which includes a number of proposals to combat this scourge, in particular, welcoming the European Commission's commitment to invest EUR 3.5 billion between 2014 and 2020 to improve nutrition in some of the world's poorest countries.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. - Child malnutrition is to developing countries what childhood obesity is to developed countries, a preventable health scourge. A stain on humanity unable to protect the most fragile among us, 800 million children are concerned, and to distribute equitably the food needs on the planet. In fact, calls are growing from international organizations such as WHO and FAO and are urging states to better combat malnutrition. It is by far the leading cause of infant mortality, accounting for 35% of the burden of disease in children under 5 years of age. "There is enough food for everyone to eat properly. It is the availability of food that is the problem. We need to rethink our food systems," SAID FAO Director-General José Graziano da Silva, opening the second International Conference on Nutrition last week. We can only prove him right. Our global food system is out of breath and needs to be completely redesigned by, of course, focusing on local production, the end of monocultures, by prioritising access to health care and education.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — More than 225 million children under the age of five worldwide experience chronic and acute malnutrition or stunting as a result of chronic child and maternal malnutrition, of which approximately 2.6 million die each year in developing countries. The Commission Communication 'Improving maternal and child nutrition in foreign aid: an EU strategic framework', March 2013, stressed the need to coordinate humanitarian aid and development aid, and identified measures to achieve a 40% reduction in 40% of children under the age of five who are stunted (70 million) and to reduce and keep below 5% the percentage of children under the age of five years of age who are wasted. I voted in favour of this oral question with a resolution to request a medium-term review of the measures taken and, if necessary, to reallocate the funds already committed (EUR 3.1 billion for nutrition interventions and EUR 400 million for specific programmes) in an effort to achieve the targets set for 2025.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — One billion people are still hungry around the world. At least 225 million children under the age of five suffer from acute and chronic undernourishment and 2.6 million of them die each year in developing countries.  The lack of a quick solution to child undernourishment in the context of development cooperation and humanitarian interventions risks undermining all aspects of human development.  On the occasion of the vote on this resolution, I therefore called for the effectiveness of development and emergency programmes to be strengthened. They need to be more closely coordinated to prevent food crises. I also took the opportunity to deplore the reduction in the funds allocated to agriculture under the 10th European Development Fund (EDF) compared to the 9th and urged the Council to re-examine this issue and put in place corrective measures.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour because I support the resolution calling for the necessary steps to save 2.6 million children each year. It is both children in developing countries, or 30 children under the age of five, dying per minute due to chronic inemetic-induced development. I agree with the objectives set out in the resolution, which provide for specific support of EUR 3.5 billion. in order to improve nutrition. It is also important that the resolution talks about a clear view that climate change will have a negative impact on agricultural production. We must therefore think more broadly when it comes to hunger. Without living marine organisms and other ecosystems and biodiversity protection, deforestation and climate change mitigation, sustainable and secure access to energy resources, decent employment, product redistribution, we will not be able to achieve the ambitious target of preventing any type of malnutrition by 2030.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. "About 870 million people suffer malnutrition worldwide - it is estimated that by 2020 it will be 1.2 billion. Almost a third of them are children.  97% of malnourished people are in developing countries. I would remind you that the eradication of hunger was one of the millennium development goals for 2015. Unfortunately, it will not be fulfilled.  About 2.6 million children die every year in these countries. One in three people in developing countries suffer from a chronic deficiency of essential vitamins and minerals. These are terribly overwhelming numbers. Diametrically, we are confronted with malnutrition, the origin of diseases such as obesity and others associated with it (i.e. diabetes, heart diseases).  For those suffering from malnutrition, the right to food is synonymous with the right to life. It seems clear to me that the EU and the other global actors have to look for viable solutions to the glaring inequality that occurs in the distribution of food resources on a global scale. I have voted in favour of this Report so that the Commission and the Member States feel that the EP requires that firm emergency policies be put in place, to mobilise investments and financial resources to pursue consistent long-term development strategies to eliminate this scourge.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — The European Union, the world's largest provider of development aid, is taking the problem of child undernourishment very seriously in developing countries. Nearly 20 million children are currently suffering from severe acute malnutrition, with serious consequences for their growth; this situation must not continue, and solutions must be found quickly.   I voted in favour of this text to encourage the European Commission to continue its efforts in its fight against child undernourishment. It is essential that the Commission continues its actions: it has committed to invest EUR 3.5 billion between 2010 and 2020 to improve nutrition in the world's poorest countries; it has also set a target of reducing the number of stunted children under five by seven million by 2025.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour of a resolution promoted by the Development Commission, which touches on a very important issue such as the malnutrition of children in developing countries. Even if they are sometimes statements for their own sake, the content does not pose any problems for convinced support

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I believe that the universal right to food and good nutrition is fundamental to achieving the Millennium Development Goals. However, around 225 million children under the age of five worldwide experience chronic and acute malnutrition or stunting as a result of chronic child and maternal malnutrition, of which approximately 2.6 million die each year. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution, which considers the reduction of funds for agriculture in the tenth European Development Fund (EDF) to be a mistake and which calls on the EU to increase the assistance provided under its development aid programmes in order to achieve sustainable agricultural production , based on small, peasant and medium-scale farms, and aimed primarily at local consumption, and to invest in participatory plans aimed at national level and implemented at the local level in cooperation with farmers and their representatives, local and regional authorities and civil society organisations.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution, although in my view it falls short of the ambition of the objectives and orientation of EU policies, both internal and external. Hunger kills people, and millions of children are malnourished in southern countries. I again report that neoliberal and austerity debt and policies, among other factors, are causing situations of hunger and malnutrition that were eradicated. Free trade and association agreements impose agricultural and food policies on behalf of transnational corporations, primalizing the interests of multinationals and opening the door to the exposure of natural resources, land grabbing, water privatization, seed control, etc., and imposing industrial agriculture and models of marketing unsustainable and unaffordable food.  At the second recently held International Conference on Nutrition we have seen this, as well as the zero progress in this field. I therefore hope that this declaration will be a starting point for the implementation of agricultural and food policies within the framework of the food sovereignty of peoples, outside international trade agreements. If not, we will continue to count people killed by hunger and malnutrition despite this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in support of the resolution on child undernutrition and malnutrition in developing countries.  Close to a billion people are still suffering from hunger and at least 225 million of the world’s children under the age of five are suffering from acute and chronic undernutrition or from stunted growth as a result of chronic child and maternal undernutrition, with an estimated 2.6 million of such children dying every year in developing countries. Addressing child and maternal undernutrition requires an integrated approach and coordinated action in a number of sectors which influence undernutrition, such as health, education, agriculture, water, energy access and sanitation, together with the responsible involvement of all stakeholders. The Commission and the Member States must adopt consistent long-term development strategies and make efforts to reduce undernutrition.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. - I supported the EP's motion for an EP resolution on the lack of nutrition and malnutrition of children in developing countries, which name the state and causes of poor nutrition in children in the world, but also seeks solutions to improve the situation. Even today, in the 21st century, we must say that almost a billion people are still suffering from hunger and at least 225 million children in the world under the age of five suffer from acute and chronic undernutrition, slowed body growth as a result of chronic under-nutrition of children and mothers, with an estimated 2.6 million of them dying every year in developing countries. The biggest problem with children's lack of nutrition is the problem of food availability and adequacy, which means that food must be safe and meet nutritional needs. Therefore, in order to improve the nutrition of children, but also of mothers, the development and emergency programmes of individual policies and states must be coordinated with each other.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. — Almost one billion people in the world still suffer from hunger and at least 225 million children under the age of 5 suffer from acute and chronic malnutrition. Maternal malnutrition is estimated to result in 2.6 million children dying annually in developing countries. Research shows that malnutrition is the leading cause of death among children. Malnutrition has a negative impact on people's health and productivity. As a result, social and economic development in developing countries is also deteriorating. International organisations confirm that there is enough food production in the world for all of humanity and that child malnutrition is linked to an uneven distribution of food. Access and the right to a quality and balanced diet is crucial for the child's development. For this reason, consistent and long-term strategies need to be adopted that will reduce malnutrition. In order to make food crisis prevention programmes more effective, they need to be more closely linked to the development and strategy of the countries. The latter should focus on sustainable agriculture and locally processed food. This topic is very pressing and problematic. It is necessary to draw the attention of the Member States, the Commission and the Council on the situation and to mobilise as many institutions as possible in order to continue to play an even more active role in this area. For the reasons set out above, I supported this resolution.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — I supported this resolution on child malnutrition in developing countries, which aims to combat the world's hunger scandal. Despite the achievements of the Millennium Goals in the world, we still have almost a billion people starving. Of these, 225 million are children under the age of 5 who are chronically malnourished. Technological advances have allowed there to be food for all, among other things, but despite this, children continue to starve to death and remain malnourished.  As a Christian Democrat, I will emphasize that the issue of child malnutrition shows that the dignity of human life must be protected from the very beginning. That is why I am very pleased that my amendment to this resolution has been adopted, and now paragraph 3 of the resolution clearly states that the first 1 000 days of a child's life, including the gestation period, are the most important for meeting nutritional needs.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. "I think we must be aware that even though we live in 2014, the number of close to 1 billion people suffering from hunger is really alarming. Furthermore, of these, at least 225 million children under the age of 5 suffer from chronic malnutrition, thereby slowing the development of children. According to the report, the reasons for this devastating result are many. The main causes are human decisions that could have been avoided, unequal allocation of funds, mismanagement and unfortunately the problem we face today, namely discrimination against women and lack of education, especially for mothers.  We must actively work to contain this problem and thoroughly address issues such as storedness, especially in children.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. - I am fully aware of the importance of the lack of nutrition of children in developing countries and also of the need to act on this. The text of the proposal also correctly identifies the origins of under-nutrition in children, even in inefficient governments that restrict people's freedom. However, I do not agree with some of the proposals for solutions offered by the text of the proposal. These include, for example, the requirement to increase the EU budget for development aid, the abolition of the reduction in agriculture in the European Development Fund and the welcome of the European Commission's plan to invest EUR 3.5 billion to improve nutrition in the poorest countries between 2014 and 2020. As we have seen many times before, the development assistance of the European Union (and Western countries in general) is not only inefficient, but often leads to the exact opposite of the intended one. Poor countries do not need an endless continuation of foreign financial assistance. What poor countries really need are effective institutions that will allow these countries to create wealth and be able to be independent.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — We agree that the problem of malnutrition is very important and that solving it could also help to tackle other problems, such as illegal immigration, but it is impossible for us to support the financing of third countries when Greece is in the vise of the Memorandum, when it has been treated hostilely by many other Member States and when there are hundreds of thousands of children in our country who are malnourished but the EU does not care about it.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Before the age of five, girls are three times more likely than boys to be malnourished. Deprived of good food conditions at the expense of boys, and therefore more vulnerable to growth problems, girls are more likely to die when they are still very young. Cultural barriers, including discriminatory practices and attitudes that favour boys over girls, need to be identified and addressed.  Moreover, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, if women farmers had access to the same means of production as their male counterparts in the world, they could increase their agricultural yields by 20-30% and increase total agricultural production by 2.5 to 4%. In other words, advances that would prevent 100 million, or even 150 million people, from suffering from hunger!  Tackling gender inequalities from an early age, ending the unfavourable treatment of girls, improving the prospects of women farmers, here are the concrete ways to combat child malnutrition in developing countries!

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. - I support the initiation of this overt question about the malnutrition of children in developing countries for a myriad of reasons. One of them is recognizing the need to constantly create programs to combat malnutrition, since they are the same, among other things, a very profitable investment because malnutrition leads to conflict, poverty and social insecurity. Also, I agree with the notion that the absence of timely and effective action is the most common cause of malnutrition.  I find it particularly useful to support Scaling Up Nutrition, an innovative movement in which countries collaborate with partners through two specific approaches – specific dietary interventions and specific dietary approaches. I find it extremely useful to communicate with the Commission – 'Improving maternal and child nutrition through external assistance: the EU's strategic framework' whereas it promotes a multi-sectoral approach that aligns policies in the fields of rural development, sustainable agriculture, public health, water supply, sanitation, social protection and education; but at the same time I fully support the question Ms. McAvan raises about her effectiveness, i.e. better coordination of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution, although in my view it falls short of the ambition of the objectives and the direction of policies that the EU has with regard to third countries. Hunger kills people, and millions of children suffer and die from malnutrition in Third World countries, but not only there: in the Spanish state, to give an example, there are more than 20% of infants living below the poverty line, and the percentage of Spanish citizens who are at risk of falling into poverty and social exclusion rises to 60%.  This catastrophic situation is due to the neoliberal orientation of European policies towards third countries, which take precedence over the interests of multinationals, opening the door to the expolio of the natural resources, lands and agriculture of those countries.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
