text: in writing. — An estimated 2 billion people globally, or one out of three people in developing countries, are suffering from chronic deficiency of essential vitamins and minerals (micronutrients), a condition known as ‘hidden hunger’, which drastically increases their susceptibility to birth defects, infection and compromised development. Almost 20 million children are suffering from severe acute malnutrition in both emergency and non-emergency contexts. I voted to support this resolution as it calls for the EU to increase the support provided by its development aid programmes for sustainable smallholder, peasant and medium-scale agriculture production which will directly address this concerning reality.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — With more than 225 million children under the age of five suffering from acute undernourishment and 2.6 million of them dying from acute undernourishment each year, undernourishment is by far the leading cause of infant mortality. Yet many international conventions commit states to combat this phenomenon, including the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).  Once is not customary: beyond the unanimously shared findings and paternalistic recommendations to developing countries, this resolution analyses the causes of child undernourishment: unequal distribution of resources, impacts of climate change on agricultural production, economic crises, discrimination against women and children, etc. It considers them to be avoidable and recognizes the responsibility of industrialized countries in this regard; it also denounces the reduction of funding for agriculture under the 10th European Development Fund.  This resolution therefore calls for an increase in the EU budget of EUR 3.5 billion for the period 2014-2020. I vote for it, but without illusions.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - According to the report, more than 165 million children under the age of five are malnourished or rife and about 52 million children suffer from severe malnutrition. The same report also says that the physical and cognitive damage caused by an undernutrition during the first 1000 days of the child's life is irreversible and can no longer be treated. Malnutrition affects the overall potential of society, reduces economic productivity and potential income of nations. Malnutrition is a direct consequence of our economic system that fails to put science and technology at the service of the human being, leaving both at the mercy of large companies and financial capital. The result is a glaring and growing inequality with hunger gaining increasing parts of our territory. The solution to this problem is not to reinforce humanitarian or charitable actions. It involves overcoming capitalism with its replacement by socialist society.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – Child malnutrition and under-nutrition continues to be of great concern. Therefore, I will continue to support the measures taken by this House and this Union in the efforts to eliminate child malnutrition. It is evident that there is not a ‘one solution fits all scenarios’ in which to implement, thus we must remain open and diligent in our approach. One important facet that can make a tremendous amount of difference is that of nutrition for unborn children while the mother is providing for both. The crucial point for child nutrition is the first 1 000 days which is when the nutritional needs of the child may vary but good nutrition during this time is vital. In addition child nutrition can be linked to the education, or lack thereof, of the mother and also needs to be addressed in future policy. While the Commission has in fact earmarked EUR 3.5 billion between 2014 and 2020 for improving nutrition in some of the world’s poorest countries, I would encourage the Commission to scale up its commitments as regards nutrition-specific interventions in order to meet its objective of reducing by 7 million the number of stunted children under the age of five by 2025.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — On Thursday, 27.11.2014, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on the problem of malnutrition and malnutrition among children in developing countries. According to the Committee on Development (DEVE), the problem of malnutrition is serious and undermines the productivity and human resources potential of the country. Lack of proper nutrition in the first 1000 days of life is the cause of physical and mental impairment. This global problem affects more than 165 million children under the age of five and requires decisive action. The resolution recommends multisectoral actions involving the coordination of rural development policy, increased support for small-scale farmers, medium-scale farms, the establishment of a law guaranteeing access to food and proper nutrition, and the development of rescue, prevention and prevention programmes for food crises. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, and a healthy person is the basis for building a properly functioning society.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Every year diseases and malnutrition kill almost 10 million children under the age of 5, especially in the first weeks of life. In half of the cases, the effects of the disease are made lethal by a state of debilitation due to malnutrition or vitamin deficiencies. In the industrialised countries, almost no child dies for such reasons any more; It is therefore not wrong to say that the spectre of poverty is almost always behind the death of a child. In 2000, world leaders strengthened their commitment to child health to reduce the mortality rate of children under five by two-thirds, but unfortunately this was not enough. The European Union must do more to ensure that the governments of developing countries create an environment conducive to better child nutrition by strengthening policies and coordination between national plans and strategies.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — No one is at odds that child malnutrition and malnutrition is a serious global problem, affecting mainly peripheral countries and countries with armed conflicts. It is necessary to urgently and effectively resolve it, but to do so we need to get to the root of its problems. It is at this point, the causes and solutions, which we are at odds with the majority of Members of the European Parliament. We believe that the main causes of this humanitarian disaster focus on the favouring of the exporting agro-industrial model, on the large agri-food industry, on the consequent qualitative impoverishment of the global agricultural sector, on disinvestment in agriculture and on the policies of agricultural abandonment and settlement of family farming and small and medium-sized farms, market fundamentalism, privatisation and liberalisation policies and free trade. Child hunger and malnutrition are the most vivid consequence of an unjust, exploitative and oppressive system and, therefore, historically condemned.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Ladies and gentlemen! Thank you all for being there. I would like to thank the services here in the Chamber and, above all, the interpreters. I wish you all a good way home! I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned. (The sitting was closed at 1.30 p.m.)
